question: Where a firm holds accounts on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits, what must the firm do to ensure those accounts can be immediately identified, and what further capability and timeframe must it meet to provide separately identified details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts to the PRA or FSCS upon request?
gold_answer: A firm must implement an account-marking approach that enables immediate identification of accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) held on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits, so that such accounts can be promptly distinguished when needed [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. In addition, the firm must be able to make available the details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts, with those categories separately identified, to the PRA or the FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and the statement, and it must do so within twelve hours from the point of a request by the PRA or the FSCS [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. Taken together, the obligations require both (i) operational marking that supports immediate identification of the relevant beneficiary-held accounts and (ii) a supporting data-extraction and delivery capability that can produce the required account details, separated by eligibility status, in the specified format and within the stated response window when the PRA or FSCS requests it.
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: For compliance purposes, how should an Authorised Person identify and evidence the applicable Bank of England and PRA approach to interpreting EU Guidelines and Recommendations after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, including the relevant publication date and where the authoritative Statement of Policy can be accessed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should treat the relevant interpretive framework as the joint Bank of England and PRA Statement of Policy (SoP) titled “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations: Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU,” which establishes that the approach is set jointly by the Bank of England and the PRA and is framed specifically for the post-withdrawal context [#SRC:146eb61baedf4f91]. To evidence that the correct and current SoP is being relied upon, the firm should record the publication date shown for this item—November 2022—and retain the access path to the authoritative source location provided for the SoP (the Bank of England webpage link) as part of its compliance documentation and internal referencing [#TGT:b4af3a3d0be5028e]. In practice, this means compliance files should clearly tie the interpretive position back to the joint Bank of England and PRA SoP and include the date marker “November 2022” alongside the URL reference, so that reviewers can confirm both the provenance (joint Bank of England and PRA) and the specific version being applied.
source_text: the joint Bank and PRA Statement of Policy (SoP) ‘Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations: Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU’. 13
target_text: 13. November 2022: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/paper/2019/interpretation-of-eu-guidelines-and-recommendations-boe-and-pra-approach-sop .

question: For variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate drawing up accounts under the Accounts Directives framework, International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, how must the yield be determined when the undertaking’s accounting period is longer or shorter than a year, and what profit-or-loss figure must be used in the yield ratio?
gold_answer: Where the yield is being determined for variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate that draw up accounts in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives, or in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, the yield on an asset is defined as a ratio to the value of the asset [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d]. In that context, if the undertaking’s accounting period is not exactly one year (i.e., it is longer or shorter than a year) and the relevant rule applies, the undertaking must annualise the amount of profits or losses for that accounting period. The annualised profit-or-loss figure is then the figure that must be used when calculating the yield under the ratio-based definition, rather than the unadjusted profits or losses for the non‑annual period [#SRC:f994473a44562eb1]. This ensures the numerator used in the yield ratio reflects a one‑year equivalent amount whenever the accounting period length differs from a year, while still applying the yield definition that ties the calculation to the asset’s value [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d].
source_text: Where 11.6 applies, and a undertaking’s accounting period is longer or shorter than a year, the amount of profits or losses for that period must be annualised, and the annualised figure must be used to calculate the yield.

question: When determining the scope of this supervisory statement, which categories of PRA-authorised firms are covered and which are expressly excluded, and how should a firm reconcile the exclusion of insurance and reinsurance firms with the existence of separate model-management requirements and PRA expectations for Solvency II firms?
gold_answer: Taken together, the passages draw a clear boundary around who the supervisory statement is intended to apply to and what is excluded. The SOURCE limits relevance to PRA authorised banks, building societies, and PRA-designated investment firms, and it explicitly excludes credit unions; it also indicates there is no current proposal to extend the principles to insurance and reinsurance firms [#SRC:ab9cc249aa20e799]. The TARGET aligns with that exclusion by stating that insurance and reinsurance firms are currently not in scope, but it adds an important clarification for firms subject to Solvency II: model management requirements for those firms are addressed elsewhere, namely in Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35 (Title I, Chapter VI), and PRA expectations are set out in SS17/16 on Solvency II internal models [#TGT:ef8741f5cf48e3bc]. Practically, this means a credit union should treat the supervisory statement as out of scope, while an insurance or reinsurance firm should not look to this statement for model-management obligations and should instead follow the Solvency II-specific regulatory requirements and the referenced PRA expectations. Conversely, the in-scope PRA authorised banks, building societies, and PRA-designated investment firms should treat the supervisory statement as relevant to them.
source_text: This SS is relevant to PRA authorised banks, building societies and PRA-designated investment firms only. Credit unions are not in scope and there is currently no proposal to extend the principles to insurance and reinsurance firms 1 .
target_text: 1. Insurance and reinsurance firms are currently not in scope. Requirements on model management for firms subject to Solvency II are set out in Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2015/35 Title I, Chapter VI, and PRA expectations are set out in SS17/16: ‘Solvency II: internal models – assessment, model change and the role of non-executive directors’: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-internal-models-assessment-model-change-and-the-role-of-non-executive-directors-ss .

question: If a firm trades products like cash equities or cash bonds that can create settlement risk but do not attract counterparty credit risk, when can the PRA push back on a zero capital requirement and make the firm hold extra capital?
gold_answer: The products in scope include those (for example, cash equities and cash bonds) that can lead to settlement risk even though they do not attract counterparty credit risk, so the settlement-risk issue can arise without a corresponding counterparty credit risk charge [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9]. For settlement risk arising from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model, the PRA may challenge whether it is appropriate for the firm to apply a zero capital requirement if the firm does not adequately manage that settlement risk [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320]. The passage indicates what “adequately manage” can involve, such as pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, and appropriate reporting. Where those kinds of controls are not sufficient for the settlement risk created by the relevant products, the PRA can require the firm to hold additional capital under Pillar 2, rather than allowing the firm to rely on a zero capital requirement for that risk.
source_text: Where firms do not adequately manage settlement risk arising from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model 13 (eg through pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, appropriate reporting), the PRA may challenge the appropriateness of a zero capital requirement for such risk and require firms to hold additional capital under Pillar 2.
target_text: 13. This would include products (eg cash equities and cash bonds) that can result in settlement risk that does not attract counterparty credit risk.

question: When applying the procedure for the relevant subsidiaries, how must a firm incorporate the Bank’s views on whether the resolution group’s capabilities would achieve resolvability outcomes broadly comparable to those in the Bank of England’s approach to assessing resolvability, and what is the applicable publication date for the referenced update?
gold_answer: In applying the procedure “for the relevant subsidiaries,” the firm must explicitly take into account the Bank’s views on a specific comparative question: whether “the capabilities of the resolution group would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable” to the outcomes described in the Statement of Policy titled “The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability” [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a]. The cross-referenced material that updates the Bank of England’s approach is identified by a dated entry, which provides the timing context the firm should use when aligning its assessment to the Bank’s approach: “July 2019” [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e]. Read together, the source establishes the procedural requirement to incorporate the Bank’s views in evaluating the resolution group’s capabilities against the SoP’s resolvability outcomes, while the target supplies the concrete date associated with the update to that approach. Accordingly, the firm’s documentation and internal analysis for the relevant subsidiaries should reflect both (a) the Bank-view-informed comparability assessment and (b) the fact that the referenced update is dated July 2019, as the linked update is the identified point-in-time reference for the approach being applied [#SRC:2d629999d9d3cb6a] [#TGT:84ab4a624228cd6e].
source_text: (i) for the relevant subsidiaries, taking into account the Bank’s views as to whether the capabilities of the resolution group would deliver resolvability outcomes that are broadly comparable to those set out in the Statement of Policy (SoP) ‘The Bank of England’s Approach to Assessing Resolvability’; 19
target_text: 19. July 2019: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/paper/2020/updates-to-the-boes-approach-to-assessing-resolvability .

question: When preparing a group recovery plan, how must firms that are parent entities of an international group demonstrate coverage of entities in other jurisdictions, and how must they document and explain dependencies between recovery options, including where options are mutually exclusive, in light of dependencies between group entities?
gold_answer: Firms that are parent entities of an international group must be able to show, within their group recovery plan, how they have covered the different entities located in other jurisdictions, rather than treating the plan as applying only to the parent or a single location [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. In doing so, the PRA expects firms to understand and reflect the dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, because these linkages affect how recovery actions can be executed across the group [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. Consistently, firms must detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive, so that the plan makes clear which actions can be pursued together and which cannot be combined [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6]. Taken together, this means the group recovery plan should connect entity coverage across jurisdictions with a clear mapping of option-to-option and entity-to-entity dependencies, enabling the PRA to assess whether proposed recovery actions are coherent across the international group and whether any constraints or incompatibilities have been explicitly identified [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: If a firm uses a simpler (standard) way to calculate the FS because it lacks data at the start, does it still have to model a term structure for the addition to the FS, and what does it need to show if it wants to use one uniform allowance instead?
gold_answer: Even if, at the point of initial investment, a firm cannot build a robust methodology for the addition to the FS because of data scarcity, it may propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS and include safeguards to reduce risks to the quality of matching [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894]. That flexibility does not remove the general expectation that firms should model a term structure for the addition to the FS [#TGT:479d238324e3667c]. A firm may use a uniform allowance instead of a term structure only if it can demonstrate two things: first, that a uniform allowance would not materially affect how adequate the allowance is for the risks arising from cash flow uncertainty; and second, that it would not materially affect the assessment of asset and liability cash flow matching quality or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests [#TGT:479d238324e3667c]. The PRA’s acknowledgement that it does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology in many cases should be read alongside this obligation and exception framework, so the firm must either model the term structure or support a uniform allowance with the required demonstration [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894].
source_text: The PRA understands that, at the point of initial investment, in many cases it may not be possible to develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS, for example due to data scarcity. Firms may therefore propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, together with any safeguards that could mitigate the risks to the quality of matching. The PRA does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as set out in paragraph 5.21 above.
target_text: Firms should model a term structure for the addition to the FS unless it can be demonstrated that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for the risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests.

question: In the context of pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but there is evidence of predictability, how should a firm define the event-driven cash flow variability risk that underpins its proposal to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks, and what modelling benchmark does the PRA associate with that definition when credible data supports more sophisticated modelling?
gold_answer: For pooled asset exposures whose underlying assets are primarily exposed to economic risks, a firm may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks only where it can evidence sufficient predictability in the exposure, and it should align its proposal with the PRA’s framing of event-driven cash flow variability risk as a type of risk that is better captured by fatter-tailed distributions rather than thin-tailed assumptions [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]. In defining the risk for this purpose, the firm should treat the relevant event component as variability in cash flows driven by events, and recognise that the PRA expects this variability to be assessed in a way consistent with heavier tails. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA indicates a benchmark for adequacy: holding a provision equal to one quarter of the difference in MA benefit between median and worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution, and would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c], supporting the firm’s standard-approach proposal [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855].
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: The PRA considers that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be best represented by fatter-tailed distributions. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA considers that a provision of one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution and that this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks.

question: When preparing the Statement for a merger, what must it include about any bonus to be paid to members, and how must the Merger Resolutions address member approval of that bonus depending on whether the total gross cost is within or exceeds the prescribed limit?
gold_answer: The Statement must set out whether a bonus is to be paid to members as consideration for the merger and, if so, it must specify that bonus so members can understand what is being proposed and voted on [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]. Separately, the payment of any such bonus requires members’ approval through the Merger Resolutions, and the placement of that approval within the resolutions depends on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (calculated without adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval need only appear in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed; however, if the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. Read together, the Statement’s required specification of the bonus supports the members’ approval process that must be reflected in the relevant Merger Resolutions [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].
source_text: Paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act requires the Statement to specify the bonus, if any, to be paid to members in consideration of the merger. The PRA’s views on what may, or may not, be regarded as bonus are given in paragraphs 3.41 to 3.42 , and the statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: When preparing an application for assessment and decision by the PRA, how must a firm determine whether to include the information referenced in the specified paragraphs, and how does that interact with the firm’s obligation to add any further information it considers necessary even if not expressly listed elsewhere?
gold_answer: A firm must take a two-step approach when compiling its application for the PRA’s assessment and decision. First, it should identify the information that is described in the referenced set of paragraphs and include that material to the extent it is relevant to the application, rather than treating it as universally applicable in every case [#SRC:1120defe09640987]. Second, beyond that baseline, the firm should ensure the application also contains any other information it considers necessary for the PRA to assess and decide on the application, even where that additional information is not explicitly mentioned in the surrounding list of required items [#TGT:ec76fc94f0d3a021]. Read together, this means relevance is the filter for whether the paragraph-referenced information is included, but the firm cannot rely on the paragraph list as exhaustive: it must actively consider whether further information is needed for the PRA’s assessment and include it accordingly. This combined obligation requires the firm to exercise judgment both in scoping the paragraph-referenced content and in identifying gaps that could affect the PRA’s decision-making.
source_text: iii. to the extent relevant, the information described in paragraphs 2.8 , 2.9 , 2.10 , 2.12 , and 2.13 above.
target_text: In addition to the above, a firm should ensure (in line with paragraph 2.6 above) that the application includes any other information (not explicitly mentioned in paragraphs 2.7 to 2.9 above) that it considers necessary for the assessment and decision by the PRA. Where a firm is seeking to include any guaranteed elements of with-profits annuities in its MA portfolio(s), the PRA would expect the application to include confirmation that the firm has satisfied itself that any implications for its with-profits business (including points around fairness, investment strategy and wider management) have been considered and, if necessary, discussed with the FCA.

question: Who does this Chapter apply to, and if an insurer is covered, what does it have to put in place to run an effective system of governance and manage risk?
gold_answer: This Chapter is limited in scope: it only applies to a large non-directive insurer and a Swiss general insurer [#TGT:5d1441b4dce1a2f4]. If an insurer falls into one of those categories, it must establish an effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems as described in the source passage [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. That means the insurer must set a risk appetite or tolerance for risk, and it must have a process to identify, measure, and monitor risk so that risks are understood and tracked over time [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. It also must have appropriate systems to convey information to management or the board, ensuring that the people responsible for oversight receive the information needed to govern the business and respond to risk exposures [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. In short, the target text defines which insurers are covered, and the source text defines what those covered insurers must implement to meet the governance and risk-management expectation.
source_text: Conditions Governing Business Chapters 2 and 3 , supplemented by Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance Chapters 2 , 3 and 7 require an insurer to establish an effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems. An insurer is required to have a risk appetite or tolerance for risk, a process to identify, measure, and monitor risk and appropriate systems to convey information to management or the board.
target_text: This Chapter only applies to a large non-directive insurer and a Swiss general insurer .

question: When a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation, how must it be prepared to evidence to the PRA, on request, that its arrangements, processes and mechanisms prevent the use of underlying exposures that include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: A firm that acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation and is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook must be prepared to demonstrate to the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms to comply with the relevant requirements in that framework [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. In practical terms, that demonstration should include showing that the firm’s governance and controls are designed to avoid prohibited structures in the securitisation’s asset pool, including ensuring that the underlying exposures used in the securitisation do not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. The expectation is not merely that the firm intends to comply, but that it can evidence, on request, that it has put in place adequate mechanisms to support compliance across its securitisation activities, consistent with its role(s) in the transaction [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. Accordingly, the firm should be able to explain how its processes identify and exclude securitisation positions from the underlying exposures and how those processes are embedded within its overall compliance arrangements [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].
source_text: The PRA expects firms which act as originators, original lenders, and/or sponsors in a securitisation that are subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook to be able to demonstrate to the PRA, on request, that they have in place adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms in order to comply with Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The underlying exposures used in a securitisation shall not include securitisation positions .

question: If a firm realises that a required actuary position will soon be empty (or is already empty), what does it have to do when it cannot meet the needed requirements using people in the firm or its group?
gold_answer: When the firm becomes aware that a vacancy of an actuary that is required will arise or has arisen, that awareness is the point at which the firm needs to act to address the gap created by the vacancy [#SRC:0702ff457fb0e143]. The firm must then consider whether it has the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with the relevant business conditions. If it does not have that capability, the firm must appoint an external actuary [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab]. Put together, the rule on becoming aware of the vacancy sets the “when” for taking action, and the capability test sets the “how” for meeting the requirement: if the firm cannot cover the required actuary function internally or through its group, it must fill the vacancy by appointing an external actuary. This ensures that, once the firm knows a required actuary role is becoming vacant or has become vacant, it takes the required step of making an external appointment where internal or group capability is not sufficient [#SRC:0702ff457fb0e143] [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab].
source_text: (1) when it becomes aware that a vacancy of an actuary required under 2.1 or 2.2 will arise or has arisen:
target_text: A firm must appoint an external actuary if it does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6 .

question: Where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives for a new or growing bank, how can the PRA both accelerate the shift to stress-testing-based calibration and, if needed, depart from the stated PRA buffer calculation approach to avoid disproportionate capital outcomes?
gold_answer: Under the PRA’s procedure for new banks, the initial PRA buffer-setting approach is intended to support banks in their early years and is time-limited; ordinarily, the bank moves to a PRA buffer calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks, once the relevant conditions no longer apply [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. The same procedure also contemplates an earlier introduction of that established-bank calibration where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives, allowing the PRA to bring forward the point at which stress-testing assessments become the basis for calibration [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. Complementing this, the PRA has permission, when exercising supervisory judgement, to diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks in exceptional circumstances, including where the stated approach would fail to avoid a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]. This permission explicitly includes situations where heightened risks to the PRA’s objectives justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks, meaning the PRA can both accelerate the transition and, where exceptional circumstances warrant, adjust the calculation approach to achieve the intended proportionality outcome [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a].
source_text: The PRA’s approach for setting the PRA buffer is designed to support new banks in their early years of operation, and as such is time-limited. Once either of the conditions set out above (paragraph 4.8 ) no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer will be calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks. However, as stated in paragraph 4.12 , such an approach could be introduced earlier where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives.
target_text: When exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA may, in exceptional circumstances, diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, for instance where the stated approach does not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. Such divergence could also include instances where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives which justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks.

question: What must a TWD firm put in place so it can project TWD scenario impacts on capital and liquidity, and what does it need to include in its risk and trade data to make those projections and sensitivity checks work?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should have the methodologies, models, and frameworks needed to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, and to make projections over the period from the reference date through the wind-down period [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e]. Those tools need the right inputs: the firm’s information set should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate financial impact projections and to run sensitivity analysis that tests how results change under different assumptions [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. The data should also include information that lets the firm segment its trading portfolios in multiple ways, so projections can be produced consistently with different portfolio groupings that may be used in execution (including alternative packaging of trades for novation) [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. In effect, the firm must connect its forecasting frameworks to a complete and flexible dataset, so that the projected capital and liquidity impacts can be recalculated and explained when the portfolio is re-segmented for different wind-down actions.
source_text: This should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis in paragraphs 4.25 - 4.51 , including information to support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways (for example, alternative packaging of trades for novation).

question: What does a firm need to do to manage interest rate change risk in its non-trading activities, and how does that connect to what institutions must disclose about the effects on economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: A firm must implement systems that identify, evaluate and manage the risk from potential changes in interest rates that affect the firm’s non-trading activities, including where those changes impact one or both relevant effects for those activities [#TGT:70fc9e8a73e07e79]. Separately, institutions must disclose both quantitative and qualitative information about the risks from potential interest rate changes as they affect both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#SRC:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. Taken together, the firm’s systems should be designed and operated so they generate the information needed for those disclosures: they should enable the firm to spot and assess interest rate risk in non-trading activities and to manage it, while also producing outputs that can be reported as numbers and narrative. The disclosures must cover both economic value of equity and net interest income for the non-trading book, so the systems should support analysis and reporting across both of those impact measures.

question: In the context of an RFTS application, how should the term “applicant” be defined, and what procedural timetable must the court set for that applicant at a Directions hearing regarding public notification and the handling of written submissions from potentially adversely affected persons?
gold_answer: For an RFTS application, the “applicant” is defined as the transferor, the transferee, or both, where that party (or those parties) submits the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]. In procedural terms, a Directions hearing is the point at which the court sets out a timetable specifically for that applicant to carry out two linked steps: first, to notify the public of the RFTS application, and second, to receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. Read together, the definition identifies which entity is responsible for complying with the court-directed timetable, and the Directions hearing procedure clarifies the scope of what the timetable must cover—public notification and the receipt of written submissions from those claiming adverse impact. This means the applicant (as transferor/transferee/both) must be prepared to follow the court’s sequencing and timing for these communications and submissions as part of progressing the application to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e].
source_text: (v) A Directions hearing will take place where the court sets out a timetable for the applicant 4 to notify the public of the RFTS application and receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme.
target_text: 4. The applicant is usually the transferor, transferee (or both) submitting the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer

question: If a Guideline or Recommendation is missing from the appendices, do firms and FMIs still need to follow it, and which EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations count for this SoP given the end-of-transition-period cut-off and the exclusion of later EIOPA updates?
gold_answer: Yes. The appendices are not complete, so firms and FMIs should not assume that anything not listed can be ignored; they should continue, where relevant, to comply with Guidelines and Recommendations even if they are not included (including those made by predecessor committees to the ESAs), unless the material has been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. However, when determining what is relevant for the purposes of this SoP, the EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations that matter are those that were in place as at the end of the transition period, and links to those materials are provided [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. Any changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and any new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for this SoP [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. In using the linked materials, firms and FMIs should also recognise that the Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of those materials [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980].
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of these materials.

question: In plain terms, what is the PRA buffer meant to do in a severe stress scenario, and which named buffers are included in the combined buffer that sits alongside it?
gold_answer: The PRA buffer is an amount of capital that firms should hold in addition to their total capital requirement (TCR) and in addition to the combined buffer, and it is also referred to as Pillar 2B [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224]. Its role is to absorb losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, and it is designed so that it does not duplicate what is already covered by the combined buffers [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224]. To understand what the PRA buffer is avoiding duplicating, the combined buffer must be treated as the set of buffers that includes the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs), and—only for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies—the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer) [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]. Taken together, these definitions explain that the PRA buffer is a separate capital layer above TCR and the combined buffer, while the combined buffer itself is made up of those specific named components [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7].
source_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.
target_text: 33. The combined buffer comprises the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs) and (for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies) the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer).

question: If you are reporting for a group with more than one firm using an internal model, what do Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies have to send to the PRA each year, and what is the AoC.01 template meant to capture?
gold_answer: If the reporting relates to a group that includes more than one firm using an internal model, Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies must send the PRA an annual submission using template AoC.01 that sets out the required analysis of change, and it must contain quantitative information plus a supporting qualitative analysis, following the template’s instructions [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556]. The PRA facilitates meeting this requirement by providing an analysis of change template named AoC.01 for firms to complete, and the template is intended to collect key information about the movement in SCR so it can be reported consistently [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]. Put together, the obligation and the procedure mean you should use the PRA’s AoC.01 format (rather than creating your own structure), complete it with the key SCR movement information and the accompanying narrative analysis expected by the instructions, and then submit that completed AoC.01 to the PRA on an annual basis as part of the group reporting process [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291].
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies reporting information on a group which includes more than one firm using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When a firm has to keep its list of key functions up to date, what exactly has to be on that list, based on the idea that key functions are the functions the firm itself treats as key?
gold_answer: The firm’s duty is not just to have an identification of key functions, but to keep that identification up to date over time. To know what must be included in that identification, you look to what counts as a key function in the paired definition: it is tied to the functions that the firm considers to be a key function. That means the identification the firm maintains must include each function that the firm itself has decided is a key function, and it must stay aligned with the firm’s current view. Practically, the firm should ensure its identification is complete relative to its own determinations—if the firm considers multiple functions to be key, the identification should cover all of them, not only the most obvious ones. And because the obligation is ongoing, the firm must revise the identification whenever its internal assessment changes (for example, when it starts considering an additional function to be key, or stops considering one to be key), so the identification remains current. This is the combined effect of the “must keep … up-to-date” requirement [#SRC:3f1b83e0485737e2] and the definition that focuses on each function the firm considers key [#TGT:0254821a38c334e7].
source_text: A firm must keep its identification of key functions pursuant to 4.1 up-to-date.
target_text: (1) each of the functions that the firm considers to be a key function ; and

question: In a TWD scenario, what must TWD firms project through the wind-down period to demonstrate how expected exit and operational costs and RBLs affect capital resources and capital requirements, including any required forecasts related to trading book-related capital deductions and RWAs across relevant risk types?
gold_answer: TWD firms must be able to produce forward-looking projections from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period that cover, at a minimum, expected exit costs, operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs, so that the wind-down plan is supported by quantified estimates over time [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. In addition, the projections must explicitly show capital resources impacts through the wind-down period in the TWD scenario by incorporating how the expected exit and operational costs and the RBLs affect capital resources, rather than treating these items as standalone estimates [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]. The required analysis also extends to forecasting the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and projecting how implementing the actions, arrangements and measures set out in the TWD option will affect capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]. Together, these requirements mean the firm’s cost and loss projections must be integrated into a coherent capital resources and capital requirements forecast across the full wind-down timeline [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f].
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 26. This should include projections of capital resources impacts through the wind-down period in the TWD scenario, incorporating the impact of expected exit, operational costs and RBLs defined above on capital resources, as well as a forecast of the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and projections of the impact of the implementation of the actions, arrangements and measures set out as part of the TWD option on capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks.

question: How must a firm align its at-least-annual review of the additional assessments with its obligation to establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures covering risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that its governance framework connects two parallel obligations: first, it must conduct an at-least-annual review of the additional assessments, and second, it must have written policies and adequate procedures in place for core control functions. Practically, the firm should embed the annual review cycle for the additional assessments into its documented policies and procedures so that the review is not ad hoc but is executed through established processes that sit within risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing arrangements. This means the firm’s written documentation should describe how the additional assessments are identified, scheduled for review at least annually, performed, and evidenced, and how the outcomes are handled through the firm’s control environment. The annual review obligation applies to the additional assessments themselves [#SRC:1dd4e886ea27eeba], while the requirement to establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures sets the structural baseline through which that review should be operationalized and controlled [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72].
source_text: (1) In accordance with 2.4 , a firm must at least annually review the additional assessments referred to in 3.6B .
target_text: (1) establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures in relation to at least risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing ;

question: When determining the amount of long-term insurance liabilities, what must the determination process require in terms of (i) compliance with the specified valuation requirements and minimum factors to be taken into account, and (ii) the actuarial basis, policyholder expectations, and prudence standards that must be applied (including the treatment of liabilities already due before the valuation date)?
gold_answer: The amount of the long-term insurance liabilities must be determined through a process that satisfies both sets of obligations. First, the determination must be carried out in compliance with the applicable requirements referenced for that purpose and must, at a minimum, take into account the factors that are required to be considered as part of that compliance framework [#SRC:d189ad275bd8059b]. Second, for the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities—excluding liabilities that have already fallen due for payment before the valuation date—the determination must be made using generally accepted actuarial principles, must give due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders, and must make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62]. Read together, this means the determination is not merely a mechanical calculation: it must be anchored in the specified compliance regime and minimum factor-consideration requirement, while also meeting actuarial and prudential standards that explicitly incorporate policyholder expectations and adverse-deviation margins, with a clear carve-out for liabilities already due before the valuation date.
source_text: Without prejudice to the generality of 6.1 , the amount of the long-term insurance liabilities must be determined in compliance with 7 to 16 and must take into account at least the following factors:
target_text: In accordance with 6.2 to 6.4 , the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (other than liabilities which have fallen due for payment before the valuation date ) must be made in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles and have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders and make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation.

question: When designing and operating its risk-management system, what must the firm do to ensure it covers risks included (and not fully included) in the SCR calculation, and how must the firm’s calibration approach ensure that all quantifiable risks—at least those enumerated—are taken into account?
gold_answer: The firm must ensure its risk-management system is effective and well integrated into its organisational structure and decision-making processes, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, and it must cover both the risks to be included in the SCR calculation and the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]. Alongside this system-level coverage obligation, the firm must ensure that the relevant calibration is set so that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]. Together, these requirements mean the firm cannot treat SCR risk coverage as limited to a narrow set of modeled items: the risk-management system must be broad enough to capture SCR-included risks and any residual or excluded risks, while the calibration requirement ensures that, for quantifiable exposures, the firm’s approach explicitly incorporates the minimum specified risk categories and does not leave out other quantifiable risks.
source_text: (2) That risk-management system must: (a) be effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions ; (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and (c) cover at least the following areas: (i) underwriting and reserving as set out in 3.1A(1) ; (ii) asset-liability management as set out in 3.1A(2) ; (iii) investment risk management, in particular derivatives , quasi-derivatives and similar commitments, as set out in 3.1A(3) ; (iv) liquidity risk and concentration risk management: as set out in 3.1A(4) and 3.1A(5) ; (v) operational risk management as set out in 3.1A(6) ; and (vi) reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques as set out in 3.1A(7) .
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: If an institution hits the 5% level, when does it have to start disclosing, and what extra annual disclosures must a large institution make when its non-performing loans and advances ratio is at least 5%?
gold_answer: An institution has to start disclosure based on the SOURCE’s threshold timing rules, and a large institution that meets the TARGET’s 5% non-performing loans and advances ratio must also make additional annual disclosures using specified templates. Under the SOURCE, institutions commence disclosure where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters before the disclosure reference date; and for the first disclosure reference date, they must disclose the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if they meet the threshold on that reference date [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]. Separately, the TARGET requires large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances (subject to the definition of non-performing) equal to or higher than 5% to make the disclosure required in specified points of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with the listed templates (including UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and specified columns of UK CQ4 and UK CQ5) and the related annex instructions, on an annual basis [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37].
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: What is the Transfer Summary, and when can a society send it to members instead of the Transfer Statement, given that the PRA approves the Transfer Statement that must be sent to members?
gold_answer: The Transfer Summary is defined as the summary of the Transfer Statement that may be sent instead of the Transfer Statement, and it is linked to the notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. Specifically, it may (in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act) be sent in or with the notice of that meeting to every member who is entitled to receive the notice [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f]. The source context explains that the PRA’s role includes approving the Transfer Statement, which must be sent to the members, and that the chapter also covers the PRA’s role in the confirmation procedure and its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]. Putting these together, the society’s ability to send the Transfer Summary is a permitted alternative to sending the full Transfer Statement in the specific meeting-notice setting, while the PRA’s approval role remains tied to the Transfer Statement that is otherwise required to be sent to members during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] and the defined scope of the Transfer Summary [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f].
source_text: The chapter also describes the role of the PRA in approving the Transfer Statement which must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure, together with its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process. The Transfer Summary, 44 which a society may send to its members instead of the Transfer Statement, is also discussed.
target_text: 44. The summary of the Transfer Statement which may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent, instead of the Transfer Statement, in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered, to every member entitled to receive that notice.

question: When a firm uses transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) to restructure an asset for inclusion in the MA portfolio, what must the firm do to assess—before relying on the restructuring—whether the underlying unrestructured asset will remain appropriate over time and whether the resulting restructured asset can continue to satisfy the MA eligibility conditions?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the decision to restructure an asset for inclusion in the MA portfolio as dependent on both (i) the continuing appropriateness of the underlying unrestructured asset over the life of the arrangement and under changing operating conditions, and (ii) the ability of the restructured asset created through intra-group transactions (including loans or derivatives) to satisfy the MA eligibility conditions on an ongoing basis. In practice, this means the firm should first assess whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain an appropriate match over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and as conditions change, rather than assuming the restructuring will remain suitable by design [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]. The firm must also have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when judging whether MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied, and be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed on the restructuring arrangements to ensure continuing satisfaction of those conditions [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]. Further, the firm should not apply such arrangements (or arrangements with the same substantive effect) to assets that, in unrestructured form, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad].
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: The extent to which transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can be used to restructure assets in order to include them in the MA portfolio depends on whether the restructured assets thereby created can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects firms to have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when they consider whether the MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied. The PRA would not expect firms to apply arrangements as set out in paragraph 2.55 above, or arrangements that in substance have that effect, to assets that, in unrestructured form, would in any event not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP. The PRA notes that some assets by their very nature may have characteristics that make it infeasible to restructure them as MA eligible assets, and expects firms to be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed upon restructuring arrangements to ensure the continuing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions.

question: When valuing a variable interest investment other than equity shares or land, the yield must be set as the annual rate that equates the asset’s value to the present value of future interest and any capital repayments. If the investment is instead a collective investment scheme that is given a value as an asset in accordance with Friendly Society – Asset Valuation 13, may the yield be determined using a weighted-average approach, and how does that permitted method relate to the required annual-rate approach for variable interest investments?
gold_answer: For a variable interest investment other than equity shares or land, the yield must be established as a single annual rate of interest that, when applied to discount the future interest payments (before tax) and any applicable capital repayments, makes the combined present values equal to the asset’s value; this is the required yield-setting approach for that category of asset [#SRC:3989898d64597ea0]. By contrast, where the investment is in a collective investment scheme that is given a value as an asset in accordance with Friendly Society – Asset Valuation 13, the yield may be determined using a weighted average of the yields on each of the underlying investments held by the scheme, with those underlying yields being determined under the same Chapter framework [#TGT:87c658d3a683d6a8]. Read together, the obligation fixes the yield methodology for direct variable interest investments (a single discount rate that reconciles present values to the asset value), while the permission provides an alternative, scheme-level aggregation method for collective investment schemes, allowing the overall yield to be derived from the component yields rather than requiring a single-rate present-value calculation at the scheme level.
source_text: Subject to 11.12 , for variable interest investments other than equity shares or land, the yield on an asset must, subject to 11.13 , be that annual rate of interest which, if used to calculate the present value of future payments of interest (before deduction of tax), and the present value of repayments of capital, where applicable, would result in the sum of these amounts being equal to the value of the asset, on the assumption that:
target_text: For investments in collective investment schemes given a value as an asset in accordance with Friendly Society – Asset Valuation 13 , the yield may be determined as the weighted average of the yields (as determined by this Chapter) on each of the investments held by the collective investment scheme .

question: In scenario testing of a recovery plan, how should the selection of a subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses be used to evidence that the plan remains suitable across different types of stress and that key plan elements interact effectively?
gold_answer: Scenario testing should be used to connect two complementary objectives: (1) selecting the subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses, and (2) demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable across a range of different types of stress while showing how plan elements interact under those stresses. Practically, the scenario design should require the recovery plan to identify, for each specific stress, which options are realistically expected to be selected (i.e., a subset rather than an exhaustive list), and then use those selections as the basis for testing the plan’s operation in that stress. The testing should explicitly examine how the chosen options work alongside other elements of the plan—such as indicators and governance—to show whether the plan functions coherently when pressures vary in type and severity. This approach ensures the scenario exercise is not merely theoretical, but instead focuses on likely decision pathways and their operational implications, while still supporting the broader demonstration that the recovery plan can be used in multiple stress conditions and that its components interact as intended [#SRC:db5203b384a28349] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450].
source_text: the selection of the subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses (covered under ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below).
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.

question: If an institution is a small CRR firm and is covered by the disclosure rules, what does it have to disclose about pay, and which staff does it have to focus on?
gold_answer: If an institution is in scope of the disclosure framework and it is a small CRR firm, the source text indicates that a specific disclosure requirement applies for that type of institution, and that this requirement is the one connected to the remuneration disclosure framework it references [#SRC:47c62d3f801c6d13]. In that situation, the institution must make disclosures about its remuneration policy and practices, but the target text makes clear that the disclosures are not for all employees; they are for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. Putting the two together: the source tells you when the special disclosure treatment is relevant (only for institutions subject to the framework that are small CRR firms, and only for the remuneration-related information set), and the target tells you what the institution must actually disclose (information about remuneration policy and practices) and who the disclosure must cover (staff categories that materially affect the institution’s risk profile).

question: If a merger includes a bonus for members, what does the Statement have to say about it, and when does the bonus approval have to be put into the Merger Resolutions for just one society versus every participating society?
gold_answer: Where a merger proposal involves paying a bonus to members as consideration for the merger, the Statement must spell out that bonus (if any) so the proposal clearly identifies what is to be paid [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]. In addition, members must approve bonus payments through the Merger Resolutions, and the rules on which societies’ resolutions must contain that approval depend on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), measured without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. Together, this means the Statement’s required bonus specification aligns with, and supports, the member-approval mechanics that must be embedded in the Merger Resolutions [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].
source_text: Paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act requires the Statement to specify the bonus, if any, to be paid to members in consideration of the merger. The PRA’s views on what may, or may not, be regarded as bonus are given in paragraphs 3.41 to 3.42 , and the statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If a firm is following the PRA’s expectations on how firms mark eligible deposits and accounts, what must the firm do when marking eligible deposits so they can be recognised right away?
gold_answer: The source explains that the chapter is about the PRA’s expectations for how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts, so it sets the context for what firms are expected to do in this area [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d]. Within that context, the concrete requirement is that a firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that makes them immediately identifiable—meaning the marking approach must allow someone to recognise an eligible deposit without delay when needed [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Putting both together, the chapter tells you the topic and who it applies to (firms and their marking of eligible deposits and accounts) [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d], and the rule tells you the minimum result the firm’s marking must achieve (immediate identification of eligible deposits) [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. So, a firm should design and operate its marking process for eligible deposits (and related accounts) so that the marking is effective for instant recognition, consistent with the PRA’s expectations described in the chapter [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d] and the immediate-identification requirement [#TGT:60b306349873ce31].
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts and is intended to be read together with Chapters 11 and 13 of the Depositor Protection Part .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: When a firm is unable to evidence that its operational arrangements support recovery and resolution, what minimum description must it be able to provide about the effect on critical services if recovery options are executed or if the Bank exercises its stabilisation powers, and how should the stabilisation powers be understood for this purpose?
gold_answer: Where a firm cannot demonstrate that its operational arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution, the PRA expects the firm to make changes so that they do facilitate that outcome, with supervisory judgement applied in assessing adequacy [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. As a minimum expectation, the firm must be able to describe what would happen to its critical services in two scenarios: (i) if its recovery options were executed, and (ii) if the Bank were to apply one or more of its stabilisation powers [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. For the second scenario, the stabilisation powers should be understood as the Bank’s stabilisation powers as set out in s.1(4) of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d]. In practical terms, the firm’s description should connect its operational arrangements to the continuity or disruption of critical services under those recovery and stabilisation scenarios, so the PRA can judge whether changes are needed to ensure the arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd] while referencing the correct legal basis for the Bank’s stabilisation powers [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d].
source_text: If a firm cannot demonstrate how its operational arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution, the PRA expects the firm to make changes to achieve this outcome. Supervisory judgement will be required to assess this but, as a minimum, the PRA expects firms to be able to describe what would happen to critical services if recovery options were executed or if the Bank were to apply one or more of its stabilisation powers 13 .
