question: Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, at what level must the group solvency calculation be performed, and how does the scope rule requiring certain provisions to apply with any necessary changes affect the application of those requirements at that level, including where the relevant holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar?
gold_answer: Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, the group’s solvency calculation must be carried out at the level of that insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, and it must be done by applying the specified set of requirements referenced for that calculation [#TGT:bfadda41c802247a]. In parallel, the scope provision establishes that, when its stated trigger condition is met, a defined package of provisions (including External Audit requirements) applies “with any necessary changes” at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, and it expressly contemplates application at that level even where the holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, as well as in relation to third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, subject to an “unless” carve-out [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Read together, the obligation fixes the calculation level at the holding company, while the scope rule clarifies that the relevant supporting provisions are adapted to operate at that same level, within the stated territorial and entity-type boundaries and any applicable exception.
source_text: When 2.1(3) applies, 4 to 14 , 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking unless:
target_text: (1) Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company , the calculation of the solvency of the group must be carried out at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company applying 7.1(2) to 12 .

question: When responding to a request from the PRA or any other relevant competent authority for information needed to supervise compliance of outsourced activities, how must a third country branch meet that obligation where the branch and the service provider are members of the same group and the branch may assess the degree of control or influence it has over the service provider’s actions?
gold_answer: A third country branch must be able to provide, on request, all information necessary for the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise whether the performance of outsourced activities complies with the requirements of the regulatory system [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]. Where the third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch is permitted, for the relevant purposes, to take into account the extent to which it controls the service provider or has the ability to influence the service provider’s actions [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47]. In practice, this means the branch should not treat group membership as reducing the information it must be able to make available; rather, it may use its control or influence assessment to inform how it ensures the requested information can be obtained and provided. The branch should therefore be prepared to explain, consistently with its control/influence position, how it can access and deliver the information needed for supervisory review of outsourced activities, including where the service provider’s actions are shaped by the branch’s control or influence within the group structure.
source_text: If a third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch may, for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11 , take into account the extent to which the branch controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.
target_text: A third country branch should make available on request to the PRA and any other relevant competent authority, all information necessary to enable the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise the compliance of the performance of the outsourced activities with the requirements of the regulatory system.

question: For a composite firm, what must be done to ensure the activities relating to its general insurance business are managed separately from those relating to its long-term insurance business, and how does this obligation translate in practice for managing agents that manage syndicates carrying on these different types of insurance business (including where a single syndicate carries on both)?
gold_answer: A composite firm must ensure that the activities relating to its general insurance business are managed separately from the activities relating to its long-term insurance business, and it must organise its management arrangements to achieve that separation in the way required by the obligation [#TGT:fc6847c8e99d5a6a]. In practical terms, this separation requirement means that managing agents must separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business, reflecting the expectation that the two lines of business are not managed as a single combined set of activities [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. Where a single syndicate carries on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business under the referenced exceptions, the same underlying requirement to maintain separate management still applies, but the application of the Composites requirements to managing agents in that scenario is intended to be informed by the referenced guidance (paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites) to help determine how the separation should be implemented in practice [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8].
source_text: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business. In practical terms, this requires that managing agents separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business. However, where a single syndicate carries on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business pursuant to the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2 , paragraphs 3.1 – 3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to assist in determining how the requirements of the Composites Part will apply to managing agents.

question: If Institutions have to make leverage ratio disclosures under the CRR, what information must they include about how the leverage ratio is calculated and how they manage the risk of excessive leverage?
gold_answer: Institutions must make leverage ratio disclosures that are required under the CRR, and those disclosures must include specific information about both the leverage ratio itself and how the institution manages the risk of excessive leverage. The obligation to make the leverage ratio disclosures required under the CRR establishes that Institutions have to provide leverage ratio disclosures in the first place [#SRC:f531114f03d67d24]. The related requirement then clarifies what those disclosures must cover: Institutions must disclose information regarding their leverage ratio as calculated in accordance with the applicable CRR leverage ratio calculation approach, and they must also disclose information about their management of the risk of excessive leverage [#TGT:01b09661643bb171]. Taken together, this means Institutions should ensure their leverage ratio disclosures are not limited to a headline figure; they must be tied to the CRR calculation basis and must address how the institution manages excessive leverage risk, because that is part of what the disclosure obligation requires.

question: If a firm increases remote trading so that risk is managed from an overseas office into the UK, and some books are fully remote-booked into the UK, what must a UK trading bank or international bank do in the UK to oversee those remote books and control the remote-booked risk, especially for orphan or shared books?
gold_answer: If a firm’s change leads to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK, and especially where there are arrangements with 100% remote booking into the UK, those arrangements should face greater scrutiny and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]. At the same time, any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings must ensure there is substantive UK oversight of the remote books as a risk mitigant, with particular attention where there is no UK based trader covering the book (orphan books) [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. For shared books or desks that mix local and remote traders, the bank must clearly define them in the booking taxonomy and identify the portion of risk remote-booked into the UK so that it is subject to remote booking controls [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. These steps collectively support the higher evidencing standard expected for fully remote-booked arrangements.
source_text: c) Whether the change may lead to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity with the role of remotely managing risk into the UK; where the firm plans an increase in remote trading, the allocation of the number and relative seniority of traders should normally be broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations. Where the size of business undertaken in the second location is negligible, this is unlikely to be sufficient justification to warrant the splitting of a desk. Any existing arrangements where there is 100% remote booking into the UK, irrespective of whether they result from a relocation or not, should be subjected to greater scrutiny, and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled (and see 4.25P ).
target_text: Any UK trading bank or international bank (whether a subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure that there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, and particularly in cases where there is no UK based trader covering the book (often called ‘orphan books’). ‘Shared’ books or desks, where there is a mix of local and remote traders, should be clearly defined in the booking taxonomy and the portion of the risk remote-booked into the UK is expected to be identified and subject to remote booking controls.

question: Given that the reiterated valuation requirement is stated to be non-derogable, is a firm prohibited from departing from the prescribed initial-recognition valuation of financial liabilities and from later remeasuring those liabilities to reflect changes in the firm’s own credit standing?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that the reiterated valuation requirement “cannot be derogated,” meaning a firm is not permitted to depart from that reiterated requirement in practice [#SRC:66ac6b27bb56a949]. Read together with the TARGET, this non-derogable status reinforces two prohibitive constraints on a firm’s treatment of financial liabilities: first, the firm must apply the specified valuation approach at initial recognition for financial liabilities referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards, rather than using an alternative approach; and second, after initial recognition the firm is expressly prohibited from making any subsequent adjustment that takes account of changes in the firm’s own credit standing [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6]. In combination, the passages indicate there is no permissible carve-out or discretionary departure from the initial-recognition valuation requirement, and the prohibition on subsequent own-credit adjustments operates as an additional, specific restriction on later measurement. Accordingly, a firm must not attempt to derogate from the reiterated valuation requirement by either substituting a different initial-recognition method or by indirectly revising the liability’s carrying amount later to reflect its own credit standing.
source_text: [The second sentence of Valuation 10.1 reiterates requirement in Valuation 2.2 , and as such cannot be derogated.]
target_text: A firm must value financial liabilities, as referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards , in accordance with 5 upon initial recognition. A firm must not make any subsequent adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the firm after initial recognition.

question: Where a depositor seeks compensation in respect of a temporary high balance, how does the FSCS’s obligation to pay within three months interact with the FSCS’s discretion to reject the claim if the depositor’s written application or supporting evidence contains a material inaccuracy or omission, and what is the effect if the FSCS considers the issue wholly unintentional?
gold_answer: For compensation in respect of a temporary high balance, the FSCS is under a timing obligation to pay compensation within three months of the compensation date, subject to any applicable exceptions [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f]. However, that payment obligation operates only in relation to a valid claim: if the depositor’s written application or evidence contains any material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS has discretion to reject the claim for compensation [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c]. If the FSCS exercises that discretion and rejects the claim, the obligation to pay within three months does not result in payment because the claim is not accepted. Conversely, even where there is a material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may be prevented from rejecting the claim if it considers the issue to be wholly unintentional; in that case, the claim may proceed and the FSCS must then meet the three-month payment requirement for the temporary high balance (again, unless an exception applies) [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c].
source_text: The FSCS must pay compensation in respect of a temporary high balance within three months of the compensation date , unless one or more of 10.9 to 10.11 applies.
target_text: If the written application or evidence provided by the depositor under 10.3 contains any material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may reject the claim for compensation unless this is considered by the FSCS to be wholly unintentional.

question: When checking permitted asset exposure limits, when does the 5% limit apply to land, and what valuation test must be met for a piece of land (or interests in land) to fit that definition?
gold_answer: To check compliance, you first need to treat the permitted asset exposure limits as the limits that are set out in the referenced range, because that is what defines which exposure limits are “permitted” [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Then, for land, a specific definition sets a 5% limit for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land, including one or more interests in such pieces of land, but only where a particular valuation condition is satisfied [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. The condition is that, in the most recent proper valuation of the relevant pieces of land, an aggregate value is ascribed to those pieces of land that is greater than the aggregate of the value of each piece of land or interest valued separately [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. So the steps are: identify the exposure as land (a “piece of land” or multiple pieces, or interests), confirm you are using the most recent proper valuation, and compare the aggregate valuation against the sum of separate valuations. If the aggregate is higher, the land exposure fits the defined category and the applicable quantitative limit is 5%, applied within the permitted asset exposure limits framework [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].
source_text: The permitted asset exposure limits are those set out in 28.2 to 28.23 .
target_text: 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land) to which in the most recent proper valuation of such pieces of land an aggregate value is ascribed which is greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately.

question: If a firm is trying to work out realistic situations that might force it to carry out a solvent exit, can it reuse and adjust scenarios from the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, and which documents set out those expectations?
gold_answer: Yes. When meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm should take account of plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit, using the illustrative examples referenced in the Chapter as a guide to the kinds of circumstances it should be thinking about [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02]. To help identify and understand those circumstances, the firm may draw on and adapt scenarios that it has developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, meaning it can reuse that scenario work but should tailor it so it informs solvent-exit circumstances rather than being applied unchanged [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02]. The recovery planning expectations being referenced are tied to specific sources: Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and the “(a) Design” component under “(iv) Scenario testing” of SS9/17 [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]. Practically, the firm should treat those materials as the baseline for scenario design, then adapt the scenarios to reflect plausible solvent-exit needs in line with the Chapter’s expectations [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] and the identified recovery-planning sources [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a].
source_text: In meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm should take account of plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit (see Box A for illustrative examples). A firm may draw on and adapt scenarios developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations 19 to inform it of such circumstances.
target_text: 19. Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook; and ‘(a) Design’ under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17.

question: If a firm has assets where the cash-flow timing is not certain but is still within a contractual range, when can it treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and how much MA benefit can that HP cash flow slice create overall?
gold_answer: If a firm holds assets with cash flows whose timing is uncertain but bounded (for example, where redemption or the start of repayments can vary within a contractually bounded period), the firm should consider whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and, if they do, it may include them in the MA portfolio within the limited proportion allowed for such assets [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The TARGET explains what “assets with HP cash flows” means in this SS: they are the assets meeting the relevant criteria that firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. This definition matters because it is the trigger for the portfolio treatment described in the SOURCE (including them as part of the permitted limited proportion) rather than only seeking case-by-case assessment under the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The firm must also apply the portfolio-level cap described in the TARGET: in aggregate, the proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and it may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate added risks [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: For a firm’s capital planning, how should the PRA buffer be defined in relation to the total capital requirement and the combined buffer, and what specific buffer components must be treated as comprising the combined buffer for this purpose?
gold_answer: The PRA buffer should be defined as an additional amount of capital that firms should maintain on top of both their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and it is also referred to as Pillar 2B [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224]. Its functional purpose is to absorb losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while being set in a way that avoids duplicating coverage already provided by the combined buffers [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224]. To apply that “no duplication” concept correctly, the combined buffer must be understood as comprising the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs), and—specifically for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies—the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer) [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]. Read together, these definitions mean a firm should distinguish the PRA buffer from the combined buffer’s enumerated elements and treat the PRA buffer as a separate layer of capital above TCR and the combined buffer within the PRA’s capital framework [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7].
source_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.
target_text: 33. The combined buffer comprises the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs) and (for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies) the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer).

question: For purposes of applying the permitted asset exposure limits, how should an Authorised Person determine whether a land holding falls within the defined 5% land exposure category, particularly where a proper valuation assigns an aggregate value to a piece of land or multiple pieces of land (or interests in them) that exceeds the sum of separate valuations?
gold_answer: The permitted asset exposure limits are defined by reference to the limits that are set out elsewhere, and an Authorised Person should treat those limits as the governing framework for what is permitted in relation to asset exposure [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Within that framework, a specific land-related exposure category is defined as 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (including one or more interests in such pieces of land) where, in the most recent proper valuation, an aggregate value is ascribed to the relevant pieces of land that is greater than the aggregate of the value of each piece of land or interest valued separately [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. Practically, this means the compliance assessment must (i) identify whether the asset exposure is to a “piece of land” (or multiple pieces, or interests), (ii) confirm that the valuation used is the most recent proper valuation, and (iii) test whether the valuation methodology produces an aggregate value that exceeds the sum of separate valuations. If those definitional conditions are met, the relevant quantitative limit to apply for that land exposure category is 5%, and it must be applied as part of the permitted asset exposure limits framework [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].
source_text: The permitted asset exposure limits are those set out in 28.2 to 28.23 .
target_text: 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land) to which in the most recent proper valuation of such pieces of land an aggregate value is ascribed which is greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately.

question: If the business is general insurance business that is health insurance based on actuarial principles, what rule applies in each text, what percentage is swapped in, and what has to be true before that swap is allowed?
gold_answer: Both texts limit their scope to the same situation: general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles. In the SOURCE, that situation means the referenced requirement applies, but it must be applied with a different percentage than would otherwise be used: 8.66% is used instead of 26%. This adjusted application is not automatic; it only applies if the conditions listed as 7.5 (1) to (5) are satisfied [#SRC:19c9e8d0b9a70534]. In the TARGET, the same type of business instead brings 7.4 into scope, and it also requires a percentage substitution: 6% is used instead of 18%. As in the SOURCE, the substitution is conditional, but the TARGET frames the prerequisite as satisfaction of the “following conditions,” meaning the swap is only available once those stated conditions are met [#TGT:c34927b3fbe2f827]. So, the business type is the trigger in both, while the applicable provision, the substituted percentage, and the referenced condition set differ.
source_text: In the case of general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, 8.5 applies with the substitution of 8.66% for 26% if the conditions in 7.5 (1) to (5) are satisfied.

question: If a firm outsources a material outsourced function, what must it do to tell the service provider about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers, and how does that fit with the firm’s and the PRA’s ability to inspect and audit the service provider for that outsourced work?
gold_answer: For a material outsourced function, the firm must manage both contractual/relationship oversight and regulatory awareness. On the oversight side, the arrangement is framed by the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function, meaning the firm and the PRA can examine and audit the provider in connection with that outsourced activity [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa]. Separately, and regardless of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights described later in the chapter, the Bank and PRA have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, and some of these powers may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of these powers and requirements (as set out in the referenced tables, which are not exhaustive). Importantly, even if a firm fails to inform the service provider, that failure does not change whether the statutory powers apply. In practice, the firm should therefore ensure the provider is informed while also maintaining the inspection and audit rights connected to the outsourced function.
source_text: the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function (see Chapter 8 );
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: When setting a rate of interest for the relevant purpose, what is prohibited in terms of exceeding the adjusted overall yield on assets, and how does that prohibition interact with the separate cap on the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business before any tax adjustment?
gold_answer: A firm must not set the rate of interest used for the relevant purpose at a level that exceeds the adjusted overall yield on assets, where that adjusted overall yield is calculated as a weighted average of reduced yields on the individual assets (with those reduced yields arrived at under the specified methodology) [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb]. In parallel, for the same purpose, the firm must not attribute to any asset in the long-term insurance business an assumed yield (before any adjustment for taxation effects) that exceeds a capped figure derived from the yield on that asset calculated under the referenced yield-calculation provisions, reduced by 2.5% of that calculated yield [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8]. Read together, these prohibitions require compliance at two levels: (i) the overall interest rate outcome cannot be higher than the portfolio-level adjusted overall yield constraint, and (ii) the assumed yield input for each relevant asset (pre-tax adjustment) cannot be higher than the asset-level yield measure after applying the specified 2.5% reduction. Both constraints must be satisfied when determining the rate and the underlying assumed yields.
source_text: (1) In no case must a rate of interest determined for the purposes of 11.1 exceed the adjusted overall yield on assets calculated as the weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets arrived at under 11.2 .
target_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.

question: If an insurance business transfer scheme has more than one transferor or transferee, and the PRA chooses to treat it as one scheme with one fee, what amount must be paid and when does it have to be paid before applying to the PRA to appoint an independent expert?
gold_answer: When an insurance business transfer scheme involves more than one transferor or transferee, the PRA can choose to treat the whole arrangement as a single scheme for fee purposes, so that only one fee applies to the scheme overall [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1]. In that situation, the transferor seeking regulatory consent must pay a regulatory transaction fee of £25,000 [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. The timing is specific: the fee is due on or before the date of any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert, so payment must be made no later than that application date [#TGT:c75df87775893198]. If there is more than one transferor involved, they do not split the obligation in a way that limits responsibility to a single party; instead, the transferors are jointly and severally liable for the fee, meaning each transferor remains responsible for ensuring the single £25,000 fee is paid on time even though the PRA is applying only one fee to the scheme [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1].
source_text: For the purposes of 4.8 an insurance business transfer scheme involving more than one transferor or transferee may, at the PRA’s discretion, be treated as a single scheme to which only one fee will be applied. Where there is more than one transferor they will be jointly and severally liable for the fee.
target_text: The transferor seeking regulatory consent for an insurance business transfer scheme under Part VII of FSMA pays a regulatory transaction fee of £25,000, the due date for payment being on or before the date of any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert.

question: If a firm wants to use an intra-group loan or derivative to restructure an asset so it can go into the MA portfolio, what must the firm check about the original (unrestructured) asset over time, and what must it show about the restructured asset meeting MA eligibility conditions?
gold_answer: The firm must do two linked checks. First, it must consider whether the original, unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and remains suitable as operating conditions change [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]. This “first” step matters because the PRA expects firms to look at whether the underlying asset will stay appropriate, not just whether the restructuring can be put in place. Second, the firm must assess whether the restructured asset created through transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions, and it must have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when making that assessment [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]. The firm should not use such arrangements (or arrangements that in substance have the same effect) for assets that would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP, in unrestructured form [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]. Finally, the firm is expected to be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to ensure the MA eligibility conditions continue to be satisfied [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad].
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: The extent to which transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can be used to restructure assets in order to include them in the MA portfolio depends on whether the restructured assets thereby created can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects firms to have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when they consider whether the MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied. The PRA would not expect firms to apply arrangements as set out in paragraph 2.55 above, or arrangements that in substance have that effect, to assets that, in unrestructured form, would in any event not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP. The PRA notes that some assets by their very nature may have characteristics that make it infeasible to restructure them as MA eligible assets, and expects firms to be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed upon restructuring arrangements to ensure the continuing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions.

question: If a credit union undertakes additional activities or has more than 15,000 members, what does the PRA expect it to do to monitor its relevant business using ratios, and how should it use the Table 1 percentage figures?
gold_answer: For a credit union that undertakes additional activities or has more than 15,000 members, the PRA expects it to monitor its relevant business using the ratios described in the supervisory material, but with ratio values calibrated so they are specifically aligned to the credit union’s own business model [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466]. The credit union should also have measures to help define its tolerance for triggers and ratios that support resilience, and the PRA expects boards to decide what matters most and best reflects the risks in their organisation, rather than treating the table as a one-size-fits-all solution [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466]. The Table 1 percentage figures are described by the PRA as an example only of prudent practice for credit unions in this category, and (for all calculations except loans to assets) the indicative percentages are those set out in Table 1, which can be used as a reference point when setting the credit union’s own calibrated values [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150]. Finally, the credit union should be able to provide details of the ratios it chose and evidence explaining why it chose them if the PRA asks [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466].
source_text: A credit union that is undertaking ‘additional activities’ 1 (see Table 1) or that has more than 15,000 members, and is therefore subject to the requirement in Rule 10.3(3) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, is expected to monitor its relevant business by using the ratios in paragraph 4.3 below, calibrated with values that are specifically aligned to its individual business model. Credit unions should have measures that help them define their tolerance for triggers and ratios that underpin their resilience. The ratios in table 1 below are indicative; the PRA expects boards to assess what is most important and reflects the risks in their organisation. The PRA expects the values selected by the credit union to provide an accurate and reliable business tool, by which its board may routinely and accurately monitor the credit union’s performance against its strategic plan and its regulatory obligations. The PRA also expects the credit union to be able to provide details of its chosen ratios, and evidence of the rationale underlying them, on request.
target_text: By way of example only, the PRA considers that prudent practice suggests that the indicative ratio percentages for credit unions that undertake additional activities or have more than 15,000 members for all calculations save loans to assets are those outlined in Table 1 .

question: If a managing agent manages syndicates, what must it do to keep general insurance business and long-term insurance business separate, and what is it prohibited from allowing within a single syndicate unless an exception applies?
gold_answer: The source states that Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and clarifies that, in practical terms, managing agents should separately manage syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. The target reinforces the separation outcome by prohibiting a managing agent from permitting both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate managed by it, unless an exception applies [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6]. Put together, the normal expectation is that the managing agent structures its syndicate portfolio so each syndicate is dedicated to one class of business and is managed accordingly, rather than combining both classes in one syndicate. The source also anticipates that there may be limited cases where a single syndicate carries on both classes under referenced exceptions, and notes that paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to help determine how the Composites Part requirements apply to managing agents in those circumstances [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8], which corresponds to the target’s “except where” qualification [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6].
source_text: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business. In practical terms, this requires that managing agents separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business. question: If this Part applies to a group, does it cover every undertaking in the relevant group, or can an undertaking be left out when the PRA gives a waiver or when the group supervisor decides not to include it in group supervision?
gold_answer: If this Part applies at the level of a group, the default scope is broad: the group is treated as consisting of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated limitations and conditions that qualify that group-level application [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. But the target text makes clear that an undertaking can be excluded from the group supervision that applies on that group basis in specific situations: either the PRA has granted a waiver, or a supervisory authority which is the group supervisor has decided—following Solvency II EEA implementing measures implementing Article 214 of the Solvency II Directive—not to include that undertaking in the group supervision [#TGT:835e743b1b5b8d84]. Putting both together, you should assume all undertakings in the relevant group are in scope when applying this Part at group level, and then confirm whether any undertaking is removed from that scope because a waiver or a group supervisor decision has been made to exclude it from group supervision. This approach reconciles the general “all undertakings” group definition with the explicit exclusion mechanism described for group supervision.

question: When you are documenting the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, how do you link the Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19 mention in the source to the Bank of England entry that includes a date, and what date should you record?
gold_answer: You should link the two references by matching the Supervisory Statement identifier and topic, then use the target entry to capture the date for your records. The source names the document as Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19 and describes its purpose as the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, which tells you exactly which Supervisory Statement your documentation should point to [#SRC:4cab36a7d094e1aa]. The target repeats the same Supervisory Statement 2/19 title and frames it as a Bank of England publication entry, but crucially it adds the specific timing detail “December 2020,” which is the date you should record in your compliance inventory or policy cross-reference [#TGT:6be01175d4277214]. Using both together ensures your documentation is consistent: SS 2/19 is the referenced interpretive statement, and December 2020 is the dated publication entry you can use for version control and evidence of the relevant publication listing.

question: For a group assessing coverage of its minimum consolidated group SCR, what must the participating undertaking do in the group solvency calculation regarding its related undertakings, given that the own-funds qualification test is conducted under specified principles applied with necessary changes?
gold_answer: Where a group is determining whether those eligible own funds qualify to cover the minimum consolidated group SCR, the assessment must be carried out under the applicable principles referenced for that purpose, applied with any necessary changes, and Undertakings In Difficulty 3 must also be applied with any necessary changes [#SRC:62d005c6aa11116b]. In parallel, and as a mandatory feature of the solvency computation that underpins this determination, the calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc]. Accordingly, the participating undertaking cannot ignore or treat as fully consolidated amounts that should be reflected proportionally: the group solvency calculation must be structured to incorporate the proportional share in related undertakings, and that proportionality-adjusted solvency outcome is then used in the process of determining whether the eligible own funds qualify for covering the minimum consolidated group SCR. This links the scope of the own-funds qualification exercise to a specific required method element in the group solvency calculation.
source_text: (3) For the purposes of determining whether those eligible own funds qualify to cover the minimum consolidated group SCR of a group , the principles in 8 to 10 apply with any necessary changes. Undertakings In Difficulty 3 also applies with any necessary changes.
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: When a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or activities to a service provider that is a member of the same group, what must the firm do to ensure the written outsourcing agreement remains aligned with the firm’s obligations while also reflecting the firm’s level of control or influence over the service provider?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the firm must do two things in parallel. First, it must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement governing the outsourcing are consistent with the firm’s obligations under the applicable requirements referenced in the source obligation, so the contract does not dilute, contradict, or omit what the firm is required to do [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]. Second, because the outsourcing is to a service provider within the same group and involves critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm must take into account the extent to which it controls the service provider or can influence its actions, and use that assessment to shape how it structures and manages the outsourcing arrangement [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5]. Practically, this means the firm should align contractual responsibilities, governance, and oversight mechanisms with both (i) its own regulatory obligations and (ii) the reality of intra-group control or influence, so that the agreement and the firm’s management of the arrangement remain coherent and enforceable across both sets of requirements.
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: Where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group , the firm must, when outsourcing any critical or important operational functions or activities, take into account the extent to which the firm controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.

question: If a credit union is making more complex investments and is expected to follow the Chapter 11 expectations (paragraphs 11.1–11.6), does a loan it provides on subordinated terms count as an investment for this Chapter, and how does that affect whether those expectations apply to it?
gold_answer: Where a credit union invests in more complex investments, it is expected to adhere to the investment expectations set out in Chapter 11, covering paragraphs 11.1–11.6 [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4]. But for the purposes of this Chapter, the definition draws a clear boundary around what is and is not an “investment.” Specifically, the term rule is that “a loan is not an investment” if it is “provided by a credit union on subordinated terms” [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. Putting these together, the credit union should classify a subordinated loan it provides as not being an investment for this Chapter, because it meets the definition’s condition (it is a loan, provided by a credit union, on subordinated terms) [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. Since the Chapter 11 expectations are tied to the credit union investing in more complex investments, this classification means the subordinated loan is not treated as part of the Chapter’s “investment” population for applying those investment expectations, even though the credit union is still expected to follow Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1–11.6) in relation to its more complex investments generally [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4].
source_text: Credit unions that invest in more complex investments under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook are expected to adhere to the investment expectations set out in Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1-11.6 ).
target_text: For the purposes of this Chapter, a loan is not an investment if it is provided by a credit union on subordinated terms.

question: Under the PRA’s expectations about marking eligible deposits and accounts, what is the required outcome of a firm’s marking method for eligible deposits?
gold_answer: The source sets the scope by stating that the chapter covers the PRA’s expectations of how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts, so the relevant area is specifically the firm’s approach to marking in relation to eligible deposits (and associated accounts) [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d]. The target then states the required outcome for that marking: a firm must mark eligible deposits so that they can be identified immediately [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Read together, this means the firm’s marking method must not only exist, but must work in practice to enable instant recognition of which deposits are eligible [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. The chapter’s framing indicates that the PRA is setting expectations for firms’ marking practices in this area [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d], and the obligation defines the minimum standard those practices must meet—immediate identification of eligible deposits [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Therefore, within the chapter’s scope, the firm’s marking approach should be implemented so that eligible deposits can be spotted right away.
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts and is intended to be read together with Chapters 11 and 13 of the Depositor Protection Part .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: You must not break an insurance contract’s obligations into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, unless it is an eligible element. So when can a with-profits annuity contract component go into an MA portfolio, and what must the firm do to show it is not splitting the contract in a prohibited way?
gold_answer: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, the contract’s obligations must not be split into different parts, except where the split relates to an eligible element [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. A component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio only if it is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, can be organised and managed separately, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. To support that this is a permitted eligible-element treatment rather than prohibited splitting, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the only liabilities included in the MA portfolio are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. The PRA also expects the firm to set out a clear policy on the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere, so that any future bonus treatment does not blur the boundary of what is included as the eligible element [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: Following a transfer event, how must a firm sequence its TMTP method calculations so that the updated ‘C 0 ’ continues to represent the non-dynamic portion of TMTP post-transfer and is then used to calculate ‘C r ’, and how does this interact with the firm’s obligation to act within two months of the effective date of the transfer event?
gold_answer: After a transfer event, the PRA’s procedural expectation is that the update required by Transitional Measure on Technical Provisions 6 results in ‘C 0 ’ continuing to represent the portion of non-dynamic business attributable to the total TMTP post transfer, subject to any relevant adjustment, and that firms then use this updated ‘C 0 ’ to calculate ‘C r ’ in the TMTP method [#SRC:17bee439d0303dc4]. Where the firm is the transferee or reinsurer, the PRA expects it to use an amount equivalent to the ‘C 0 ’ attributable to the transferred business as calculated by the transferor or cedant, and to adjust that amount to reflect any revised split of business between the dynamic and non-dynamic portions, including by proportionally adjusting the non-dynamic portion of “transferred TMTP” to the revised split of BEL [#SRC:17bee439d0303dc4]. These calculation and adjustment steps must be planned and executed in a way that supports the firm meeting its obligation to take the required action(s) within two months of the effective date of any transfer event [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9].
source_text: The PRA expects that the update required by Transitional Measure on Technical Provisions 6 should result in ‘C 0 ’ continuing to represent the portion of non-dynamic business attributable to the total TMTP post transfer subject to any adjustment referred to in 3.7E . Firms should use their updated ‘C 0 ’ to calculate ‘C r ‘ in the TMTP method. The PRA expects the transferee or reinsurer to use an amount equivalent to the amount of ‘C 0 ’ attributable to the transferred business as calculated by the transferor or cedant. As with ‘Z B ’, such amount should be adjusted to reflect any revised split of business between the dynamic and non-dynamic portions. A firm can do this by adjusting the non-dynamic portion of ‘transferred TMTP’ proportionally to the revised split of BEL.

question: Based on The PRA’s approach to banking supervision and its high-level expectations, can a firm use an AMA together with the BIA or TSA, and what does it need from the PRA first?
gold_answer: Yes, a firm can use an AMA together with either the BIA or the TSA, but it can only do this if it first obtains permission from the PRA. The key point is that combining these approaches is not something a firm may do by default; it is allowed only when the PRA has granted permission. When considering whether and how to proceed, the firm should also take account of the high-level expectations outlined in The PRA’s approach to banking supervision, because those expectations provide the supervisory context for how the PRA expects firms to behave and engage when operating under PRA oversight. Put simply, the firm’s ability to use an AMA in combination with the BIA or TSA depends on securing PRA permission [#TGT:3fa782fa2cb4f833], and the firm should align its actions and engagement with the high-level expectations set out in The PRA’s approach to banking supervision [#SRC:dcae29fa2115b476].
source_text: Article 314(3) and the high-level expectations outlined in The PRA’s approach to banking supervision. 1
target_text: A firm may use an AMA in combination with either the BIA or TSA provided it obtains permission from the PRA.

question: Can the auditor avoid judging whether an approval or waiver is valid, and just use what the competent authority has already decided as the basis for the audit opinion (including any transitional-measures figures from the previous regime)?
gold_answer: Yes. Both passages allow the auditor to treat supervisory decisions as fixed inputs rather than matters the auditor must validate. The SOURCE states that, when forming the required audit opinion, auditors are not required to assess whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA and are not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff]. The TARGET repeats that the auditor is not expected to express an opinion on the validity of approvals, waivers, or supervisory determinations, and then explains what the auditor should do instead: approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations provided by the competent authority should be considered as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]. It also adds that, for transitional measures on technical provisions, Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital calculated under the previous regime should be treated as part of that same framework [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]. So the auditor audits within that framework, without opining on the determinations’ validity.
source_text: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, auditors are not required to assess whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA. As noted in paragraph 3.4 , auditors are not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination.
target_text: The auditor is not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination. Instead approvals, waivers and supervisory determinations provided by the competent authority should be considered as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given. For the purposes of transitional measures on technical provisions, Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities and capital calculated in accordance with the previous regime, should be treated as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given.

question: If a firm is seeking to include guaranteed elements of with-profits annuities in its MA portfolio(s), what must it include in the application regarding consideration of implications and engagement with the FCA, and how should it treat the information referenced in the specified paragraphs when deciding what to submit to the PRA?
gold_answer: Where a firm is seeking to include any guaranteed elements of with-profits annuities in its MA portfolio(s), the application must include confirmation that the firm has satisfied itself that implications for its with-profits business have been considered, including matters such as fairness, investment strategy, and wider management, and that these implications have been discussed with the FCA if necessary [#TGT:ec76fc94f0d3a021]. In parallel, the firm should also assess the information described in the referenced paragraphs and include it to the extent it is relevant to the application being submitted [#SRC:1120defe09640987]. The combined effect is that the firm must not only provide the specific confirmation expected by the PRA for this scenario, but also ensure that any paragraph-referenced information that bears on the application is included, while still adding any other information it considers necessary for the PRA’s assessment and decision. This ensures the submission is both responsive to the scenario-specific expectation and appropriately complete for regulatory review.
source_text: iii. to the extent relevant, the information described in paragraphs 2.8 , 2.9 , 2.10 , 2.12 , and 2.13 above.
target_text: In addition to the above, a firm should ensure (in line with paragraph 2.6 above) that the application includes any other information (not explicitly mentioned in paragraphs 2.7 to 2.9 above) that it considers necessary for the assessment and decision by the PRA. Where a firm is seeking to include any guaranteed elements of with-profits annuities in its MA portfolio(s), the PRA would expect the application to include confirmation that the firm has satisfied itself that any implications for its with-profits business (including points around fairness, investment strategy and wider management) have been considered and, if necessary, discussed with the FCA.

question: What does a third country CRR firm have to do to allocate all third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities, and who must those responsibilities be given to?
gold_answer: A third country CRR firm must take responsibility for making sure the allocation process covers all third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities, so the firm’s approach must address the complete set of prescribed responsibilities rather than only some of them [#SRC:09fb22f0b9fd2ac5]. In practical terms, the firm must then allocate each of the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities to one or more persons, meaning every individual prescribed responsibility needs an identified assignee (or multiple assignees) [#TGT:f7c5508f92091364]. Using both requirements together, the firm’s obligation is twofold: (1) ensure there is responsibility for the allocation of all prescribed responsibilities, and (2) ensure the end result is that each prescribed responsibility is actually allocated to one or more persons [#SRC:09fb22f0b9fd2ac5] [#TGT:f7c5508f92091364]. This combination implies the firm should be able to show that allocation decisions have been made across the full set and that each prescribed responsibility has been assigned to at least one person, consistent with the “one or more persons” allocation structure [#TGT:f7c5508f92091364].

question: What must a credit union do in its accounts for bad debts, and what does the PRA expect all directors to do regularly to make sure the credit union is doing it accurately?
gold_answer: A credit union has to include specific provisions in its accounts for bad debts, and those provisions must be at least the minimum amounts required [#TGT:65c1218eacbe9c7e]. Alongside that accounting obligation, the PRA expects that all directors do not simply rely on management assurances, but instead regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union is accurately complying with the relevant provisioning requirements [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f]. Read together, this means the credit union must actually record the required minimum bad-debt provisions in its accounts, and directors must repeatedly check and confirm that the credit union’s provisioning is being done correctly and matches the required standard. The directors’ regular “satisfy themselves” expectation is therefore tied to the concrete accounting outcome: ensuring that specific bad-debt provisions are made and are not below the minimum amounts that must be provided for in the accounts.
source_text: The PRA expects that all directors regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union accurately complies with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook.
