question: If you are checking limits on debts, how do you apply the 5% limit for the aggregate of debts of the relevant descriptions alongside the 1% limit for unsecured debts due or to become due from one counterparty (excluding debt securities terms and regulated institution debts, and excluding an individual, body corporate or group)?
gold_answer: You need to apply two separate percentage limits that address different scopes, and both can matter for the same set of exposures. One limit is 5% and it applies to “the aggregate of debts of the descriptions” identified in the source text, meaning you total up the debts that fall within those described categories (linked to 28.5, 28.6 and 28.7) and ensure the aggregate stays within 5% [#SRC:49457b0134191ba3]. The other limit is 1% and it applies to “all unsecured debts” that are due or to become due from any one counterparty, but only after excluding unsecured debts that arise under the terms of debt securities and excluding debts from a regulated institution; it also only applies where the counterparty is “other than an individual, body corporate or group” [#TGT:cd6a8143565de2fd]. So, for a qualifying counterparty, you must keep that counterparty’s unsecured-debt exposure within 1%, while also ensuring that the relevant described debts, in aggregate, do not exceed 5%.
source_text: 5% for the aggregate of debts of the descriptions in 28.5 , 28.6 and 28.7 .
target_text: 1% for all unsecured debts (other than debts arising under the terms of debt securities or debts from a regulated institution ) due or to become due from any one counterparty other than an individual, body corporate or group.

question: If you are using the older Appendix for Solvency II public disclosure narrative sections and templates, how do you decide which parts of your SFCR are the main SFCR elements and which parts count as other information under ISA (UK) 720?
gold_answer: If you are working from the past version of the Appendix on Solvency II public disclosure narrative sections and templates (including the associated PRA expectations that applied before 31/12/2024), you should first use that Appendix to build the content and layout of your public disclosure. Then, you should use the SFCR table that lists the elements of the SFCR and shows which are treated as relevant elements versus other information under ISA (UK) 720 (Revised June 2016). The practical approach is to take each disclosure item you draft in the Appendix’s narrative sections and templates and cross-check it against the SFCR element list, so you can classify it correctly as either part of the relevant elements of the SFCR or as other information. This is important because the Appendix is the source for the disclosure structure and expectations [#SRC:e6c4adf56f744a98], while the table is the source for the SFCR categorisation needed for ISA (UK) 720 treatment [#TGT:dd6ec992205916f7].
source_text: Past version of Appendix: Solvency II public disclosure – narrative sections and templates and associated PRA expectations before 31/12/2024
target_text: The table below lists the elements of the SFCR and highlights which are considered to be part of the ‘relevant elements of the SFCR’ and which should be treated as ‘other information’ in accordance with ISA (UK) 720 (Revised June 2016).

question: When performing the class A tariff base calculation, how must a firm determine the covered-deposit basis from the SCV file while also ensuring the calculation is supported by the same information content and quality that would be required for its single customer views as at the valuation date, including the treatment of accounts holding funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled or that are safeguarded funds and any exclusion of confirmed non-covered deposits?
gold_answer: A firm must calculate the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base) using covered deposits drawn from its SCV file, and it must do so using information that is of the same extent and standard as would be required if the firm were preparing its single customer view in line with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. In practice, this means the firm’s tariff base computation should be traceable to the data elements it would have to include in its single customer views, and those data must meet the required completeness and quality benchmark at the relevant valuation date [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. When identifying the deposit amounts to include, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account holding funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, as required under the rules, because those balances form part of the covered-deposit basis used for the calculation [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1]. However, the firm may exclude funds it has confirmed are not covered deposits, ensuring exclusions are limited to confirmed non-covered amounts [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1].
source_text: Depositor Protection 43 sets out the PRA’s rule for calculating the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base). Depositor Protection 43.2 requires firms to do this calculation on the basis of covered deposits from the SCV file. Depositor Protection 43.1 requires firms to include the total balance of deposits in any account which holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, under the rules. Any funds which the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits may be excluded.
target_text: The class A tariff base calculation must be made on the basis of the information that the firm would have to include in its single customer views . The information must be of the extent and standard required if the firm was preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base.

question: When making an application for an insurance business transfer scheme, what must the firm(s) do to (i) send notice to the required recipients unless the court directs otherwise, and (ii) ensure that the scheme report, the notice, and an accompanying statement are available to anyone who requests them, including via an appropriate internet method?
gold_answer: The firm(s) must ensure that notice of the application is sent, unless the court directs otherwise, to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme [#TGT:c99af11004d99259]. In parallel, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them, and the internet may be used to provide access where it is suitable for the person making the request [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]. The statement included with the notice would normally set out the terms of the scheme and contain a summary of the scheme report, drafted so recipients can understand in broad terms how the scheme is likely to affect them; it should be clear and concise, with sufficient detail, and should not be lengthy or hard to understand [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]. The notice and related communications should also explain how and when affected parties can make representations for the court to consider [#TGT:c99af11004d99259].
source_text: It would normally be appropriate to include with the notice referred to in 2.49 above a statement setting out the terms of the scheme and containing a summary of the scheme report. Ideally every recipient should understand in broad terms from the summary how the scheme is likely to affect them. This objective will be most nearly achieved if the summary is clear and concise while containing sufficient detail for the purpose. A lengthy summary or one that was hard to understand would not be appropriate. The Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them. The internet can be used for this purpose if it is suitable for the person making the request.
target_text: Under the Business Transfers Regulations, unless the court directs otherwise, notice of the application must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) any of whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme. It may also be appropriate to give notice to others affected, for example, to anyone with an interest in the policies being transferred who has notified the transferor of their interest. This notice, along with other communications and advertising by or and on behalf of the firm(s), should provide details of how and when any representations by affected parties should be made in order to be considered by the court.

question: When deciding what would generally be expected to be written down, what does the law treat as an excluded liability for amounts secured on property, and how does the PRA expect liabilities secured by floating charges to be handled in the creditor hierarchy?
gold_answer: To decide what would generally be expected to be written down, you need to combine the legal definition of excluded liabilities for secured amounts with the PRA’s stated approach to write-down plans. Legally, an amount secured on property is treated as an excluded liability, but there is an important exception: if the security is a charge that, as created, was a floating charge, that secured amount is not treated as excluded on that basis (Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA) [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc]. The PRA then explains how this plays out in practice: it recognises that liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities and may therefore be written down, and it links this to avoiding an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors who often have floating charges but are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority) [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]. As a result, where floating-charge liabilities are not subordinated in that way, the PRA says they would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, following the creditor hierarchy [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96].
source_text: The PRA anticipates that write-down plans will broadly respect the creditor hierarchy in order to ‘lead to a better outcome for the insurer’s policyholders and other creditors (taken as a whole) than not making the order.’ 7 The PRA also recognises that while liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities, 8 and may therefore be written-down, this is intended to ‘avoid creating an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors, who are often granted a floating charge but contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority)’. 9 Accordingly, liabilities secured by floating charges which are not subordinated in this way would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in accordance with the creditor hierarchy.
target_text: 8. Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA treats ‘an amount secured on property of any kind, other than an amount secured by a charge which, as created, was a floating charge’ as an excluded liability (the term ‘floating charge’ is then defined in section 377B(2) of FSMA).

question: When checking the PRA’s expectation for branches about keeping FSCS-covered retail and small company instant access deposits under a set level, what exactly counts as an “instant access account” and what must customers be able to do?
gold_answer: When applying the PRA’s expectation for branches about the amount of FSCS-covered retail and small company instant access deposit balances that branches should have under the stated threshold, you must identify which balances are actually in “instant access” accounts, because only those balances fall within the described category of “FSCS covered instant access deposits” relevant to the branch expectation [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad]. An “instant access account” is defined by the customer’s ability to withdraw: it means an account from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, and they must be able to do so without giving notice and without paying penalties [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3]. So, for your branch-level assessment, treat an account as instant access only if the customer can take money out at any time with no conditions, no notice period, and no penalty. If an account requires notice or charges a penalty for withdrawal, it does not meet the definition and should not be counted as instant access when evaluating the PRA’s expectation for branches on FSCS-covered balances [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3].
source_text: (a) FSCS covered instant access deposits: the PRA expects branches to have under £130 million of retail and small company 55 instant access 56 account balances covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS);
target_text: 56. An instant access account means accounts from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, without providing notice or paying penalties.

question: When identity verification has not been completed under the relevant anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, how should insolvency practitioners align their required consideration of their objectives and responsibilities with the ability for the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate identity verification to determine eligibility for FSCS protection?
gold_answer: Where identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA’s view is that the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court is permitted to facilitate the identity verification specifically for the purpose of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection [#SRC:eb355065b8865baf]. In parallel, insolvency practitioners are expected to consider matters in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:02363a43a51fdf7b]. Read together, this means the insolvency practitioner’s decision-making should not treat facilitation of identity verification as a standalone discretionary step; rather, it should be approached as an action that may be used to support the eligibility determination where the pre-compensation-date verification gap exists, while ensuring the practitioner’s overall approach remains consistent with their statutory objectives and responsibilities. The practical linkage is that the permitted facilitation addresses the missing verification needed to assess FSCS eligibility, and the required consideration frames how and why the practitioner proceeds in that context, given their role and responsibilities.
source_text: In the event that identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements referred to in Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA considers that Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) would allow the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate the identity verification for the purposes of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection. 2
target_text: 2. Insolvency practitioners should consider in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009.

question: If an institution is a large subsidiary under a UK parent (or under a parent undertaking in a third country), what information must it publish about pay policies for staff who can materially affect the institution’s risk, and does it have to publish it at entity level or sub-group level?
gold_answer: If the institution falls within the category of large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country, it must make the required disclosures using the basis specified for that situation: the information must be disclosed either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. Separately, institutions have a specific obligation to disclose information about their remuneration policy and practices for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. Putting these together, the institution must publish remuneration policy and practices information focused on the staff who materially influence risk, and it must do so in the correct form for a large subsidiary—either at the single-entity level or for the relevant sub-group. The key is that both the content (remuneration policy and practices for material risk-impact staff) and the presentation basis (individual or sub-consolidated) must be satisfied.
source_text: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country shall disclose the information specified in Articles 437 , 438 , 440 , 442 , 450 , 451 , 451a and 453 on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis.
target_text: Institutions shall disclose the following information regarding their remuneration policy and practices for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on risk profile of the institutions:

question: If an institution stopped calculating exposure values for its derivative positions, when can it start again using the Section 5 method, and what checks does it need to meet at the same time?
gold_answer: If an institution has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under the applicable approaches, it may restart only if it can demonstrate to the competent authority that the relevant conditions for resuming have been met continuously for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. If the institution wants to restart specifically with the Section 5 method, it must also satisfy the permission conditions tied to that method: it may calculate the exposure value in accordance with Section 5 only subject to a stated restriction and only where the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is no more than both required thresholds, based on an assessment performed monthly using data as of the last day of the month [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d]. In practice, that means the institution needs both the one-year uninterrupted compliance record that it can evidence to the competent authority and ongoing monthly confirmation that its derivative business remains within the threshold limits for Section 5.
source_text: Where an institution has ceased to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, it shall only be permitted to resume calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions as set out in Section 4 or 5 where it demonstrates to the competent authority that all the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) or (2) have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year.

question: Where a basic own funds item includes terms permitting earlier repayment or redemption, how should the undertaking interpret the minimum capital reference used for eligibility purposes, given that the relevant minimum capital concept is defined to cover both the issuer’s minimum and a group-related minimum depending on the calculation method used?
gold_answer: The undertaking can include terms in a basic own funds item that permit repayment or redemption earlier than the otherwise applicable period, but only where the specified conditions for that permission are met [#TGT:ced6b1767ce7d407]. In assessing how that permission interacts with minimum capital references used in the own-funds framework, the undertaking should apply the defined meaning of “MCR” that governs the relevant own-funds provisions: “MCR” is not limited to a single standalone minimum, but instead means both (i) the MCR of the undertaking that issued the own funds item and (ii) an additional minimum that depends on the group solvency calculation approach—either the minimum for the group SCR where method 1 is used, or the minimum determined under the relevant rule where a combination of method 1 and method 2 is used [#SRC:631aeb48b3b31120]. Accordingly, when structuring or evaluating an early repayment/redemption feature, the undertaking should ensure any MCR-based triggers, tests, or references are read as encompassing both components of the defined MCR, while separately confirming that the conditions for the early repayment/redemption permission are satisfied [#TGT:ced6b1767ce7d407].
source_text: (2) the term ‘ MCR ’ in Own Funds 3B.1 – 3B.13 , 3E.1 – 3E.5 and 3G.1 – 3G.5 shall mean both the MCR of the undertaking that has issued the own funds item and one of the following minimums: (a) where method 1 is used, the minimum for the group SCR as calculated in accordance with 11.3 (2), or (b) where a combination of method 1 and method 2 is used, the minimum determined in accordance with 10.7 .

question: For a credit union over the asset threshold, what must it be ready to explain to the PRA about how it runs its at-least-annual liquidity stress tests, especially the assumptions behind stressed outflows and retail book run-off, so the tests reflect severe but plausible (and combined) scenarios and the credit union’s RAS?
gold_answer: Where a credit union has more than £50 million in total assets, the PRA expects it to run periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually, and the testing must consider the impact of stressed outflows to support holding sufficient liquid funds [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0]. In practice, the credit union should be ready to explain how its test design meets the PRA’s expectation that stress tests consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios, including combined scenarios, so that the stressed outflow impacts are not based on an unrealistically narrow set of conditions [#SRC:505c78059496b268]. The credit union may rely on its own analysis to meet this expectation, but it should be able to show that the analysis is grounded in a clearly articulated RAS defining the duration and type of stress or stresses the credit union aims to survive, which frames what the tests are trying to demonstrate [#SRC:505c78059496b268]. It should also anticipate PRA engagement on the method used and assumptions made, including its assessment of likely run-off of different elements of the retail book, and be able to connect those assumptions directly to the stressed outflows considered in the periodic tests [#SRC:505c78059496b268].
source_text: The liquidity stress testing expectation referred to in paragraph 12.1 could be met by the credit union’s own analysis, which is based on a clearly articulated RAS (see paragraph 10.1 ) defining the duration and type of stress or stresses that the credit union aims to survive. The PRA expects the stress tests to consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios (including combined scenarios). Credit unions should expect the PRA to engage with them on the method used and assumptions made, eg their assessment of the likely run-off of different elements of the retail book.
target_text: In order to ensure a credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds under Credit Unions 9.4 , the PRA expects credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing whereby the impact of stressed outflows is considered.

question: Where an individual (or trustee acting for a trust) has temporary high balances attributable to more than one qualifying life event, what must be the approach to applying the maximum compensation sum payable, including whether the cap can apply separately by event and how the personal-injury/incapacity no-limit carve-out interacts with that approach?
gold_answer: The rule sets a maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance of £1,400,000, while also providing that no limit applies to compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity, and this operates subject to the stated qualification in the rule [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. The PRA’s view is that the temporary high balance protection limit is applied to each depositor on a per event per authorised entity basis and is intended to apply to natural persons only [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. Accordingly, where an individual (or a trustee making a claim on behalf of a trust as a whole in the circumstances described) has eligible deposits in excess of £85,000 as a result of more than one of the relevant life events, a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both events and the protection limit applies separately to each event [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. This means the £1,400,000 maximum is applied in a way that respects separate event-based claims, while the personal-injury/incapacity carve-out removes any cap for the portion of a temporary high balance that arises from such a payment [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. Trust treatment remains anchored to the underlying beneficiary being an individual, with trustees able to claim in the specified trust scenarios [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef].
source_text: The PRA considers that the THB protection limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 applies to each depositor on a ‘per event per authorised entity’ basis and is intended to apply to natural persons only (ie individuals) and not all eligible depositors (eg not companies). Where the depositor is a trust, the PRA considers that it is the underlying beneficiary that is required to be an individual. This includes a beneficiary who is absolutely entitled to the deposit (under a bare trust). Trustees of a trust where individual beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest may make a THB claim on behalf of the trust as a whole. This includes where the trust involves the exercise of discretion (under a discretionary trust). If an individual or a trustee has eligible deposits in excess of £85,000 as a result of more than one of the life events set out in Depositor Protection 10.2 , a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both of those events and the limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 would apply separately to each event. For example, if an individual had a deposit of £750,000 from an inheritance and a deposit of £750,000 from a house sale, then they would be able to claim up to £750,000 in each case.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: What does “keep complying where relevant” mean for firms and FMIs when the SoP links only to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations that existed at the end of the transition period, and says later ESMA changes are not relevant?
gold_answer: It means firms and FMIs need to apply two scope filters at the same time. One filter is about the appendices: the lists are not exhaustive, and even if certain Guidelines and Recommendations are missing—like those made by predecessor committees to the ESAs—firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. The other filter is about the SoP’s ESMA references: the SoP provides links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place at the end of the transition period, and it states that ESMA-issued changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and new Guidelines and Recommendations after that date are not relevant for SoP purposes [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024]. The Bank and PRA also acknowledge ESMA as the source of the linked materials. In practice, firms and FMIs should not assume the SoP links replace the broader “where relevant” compliance expectation for non-listed, non-revoked/non-superseded guidance [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024].
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials.

question: Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the listed requirements are applied at the level of the group with any necessary changes, how must a firm implement its obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system, and what does that imply for identifying and reporting risks on both an individual and aggregated basis across the group?
gold_answer: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the scope provision requires that the specified requirements apply “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that context, a firm’s obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system must be carried out in a way that functions at group level, not only for the firm viewed in isolation [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Practically, this means the firm’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures must be capable of identifying, measuring, monitoring, managing, and reporting risks on a continuous basis in a manner that captures both (i) risks at an individual level and (ii) risks at an aggregated level, including the interdependencies among those risks, across the group as relevant [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. The “necessary changes” concept in the scope provision supports adapting the application of the listed requirements so the risk-management system’s design and reporting lines operate effectively at group level while still meeting the continuous, multi-level risk coverage required of a firm [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: When setting downturn parameters for UK mortgage portfolios, how must a firm align its downturn PPGD estimates with its downturn LGD rating-system assumptions on property value declines, including the minimum house price deflation floor and the reference point for peak-to-downturn reductions?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its downturn PPGD estimates appropriately reflect economic downturn conditions and are consistent with a fall in property values driven by house price deflation, applying a minimum deflation assumption that is not lower than 25% from the previous peak price and not lower than 5% from the current price [#SRC:12e0a6fed4bfdc7e]. In parallel, when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios, the PRA expects the firm’s rating systems to assume an average reduction in property sales prices of 40% from the peak price prior to the market downturn as an appropriate reference point, and to treat that reduction as capturing both market value decline and a distressed forced sale discount [#TGT:5bb0579cf870e51b]. The firm should therefore calibrate its downturn PPGD and downturn LGD assumptions so they are mutually consistent: the PPGD downturn property-value fall must at least meet the PRA’s deflation floors, while the LGD framework should be anchored to the PRA’s 40% peak-to-downturn sales-price reduction reference point and incorporate the forced-sale component described by the PRA. This alignment is required to ensure the downturn property-value assumptions used across estimation and rating systems are coherent and appropriately conservative.
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure that PPGD estimates appropriately reflect economic downturn conditions. The PRA expects (as in paragraphs 13.8 and 13.9 above) downturn PPGD estimates to be consistent with a fall in the value of property due to house price deflation not lower than 25% from the previous peak price, and not lower than 5% from the current price.
target_text: The PRA believes that an average reduction in property sales prices of 40% from their peak price, prior to the market downturn, forms an appropriate reference point when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios and expects a firm’s rating systems to assume a reduction consistent with this. This reduction captures both a fall in the value of the property due to market value decline as well as a distressed forced sale discount. The PRA expects the assumption for the fall in the value of the property due to house price deflation not to be lower than 25%.

question: If one model includes more than one UK firm, what does it mean to set the model maintenance fee using aggregated figures, and how do you decide which firm usually pays it based on the idea that periodic fees in a fee year are a sum of applicable parts?
gold_answer: When a model includes more than one UK firm, the model maintenance fee is not worked out firm-by-firm; it must be determined by reference to aggregated figures for all UK firms that fall within the scope of that model [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. This ties into the way periodic fees payable by firms in any fee year are described as a sum of the relevant components (so far as they apply to the firm): the firm that pays the largest periodic fee (i.e., the largest summed periodic-fee amount for that fee year, based on what applies to it) will usually be the firm that pays the model maintenance fee for the model [#TGT:be7e091f57b18a8f] [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. If that “largest periodic fee” approach is not used, the PRA can instead direct that the model maintenance fee is payable by such firms and in such proportions as it specifies, which still depends on identifying each firm’s periodic fee as a summed amount [#TGT:be7e091f57b18a8f] [#SRC:062242588b894af5]. Where the model scope includes one or more CRD credit institutions and one or more designated investment firms, the aggregation is facilitated by rounding each relevant designated investment firm’s total assets for fees purposes to the nearest £1 million, converting each £1 million to £0.4 million in modified eligible liabilities, and then adding modified eligible liabilities across all UK firms in scope [#SRC:062242588b894af5].
source_text: (8) For models incorporating more than one UK firm , the model maintenance fee shall be determined by reference to aggregated figures for all UK firms included within the scope of that model, and shall usually be payable by the firm which pays the largest periodic fee under 3.3 (3) or otherwise by such firms and in such proportions as the PRA directs. To facilitate the aggregation calculation where a model incorporates one or more CRD credit institutions and one or more designated investment firms within its scope, for each designated investment firm which is also a UK firm , total assets for fees purposes shall be rounded to the nearest £1million, and each £1million of total assets for fees purposes shall be deemed equivalent to £0.4million in modified eligible liabilities . Total modified eligible liabilities shall then be added together for all UK firms within scope of the model.
target_text: Periodic fees payable by firms in any fee year will be the sum of the following (so far as applicable to them):

question: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation, how must the firm’s internal audit function provide assurance that the firm’s involvement is compliant, including confirming that the securitisation’s underlying exposures must not include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction that is subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation is compliant with the applicable requirements referenced for that framework [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b]. As part of providing that assurance, the internal audit function should explicitly test and evidence that the securitisation structure and asset pool respects the prohibition on the composition of underlying exposures—specifically, that the underlying exposures used in the securitisation do not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. In practice, this means the internal audit function’s assurance work should cover both (i) the firm’s role-based involvement in the transaction (as originator, original lender, and/or sponsor) and (ii) the transaction’s compliance with the prohibition on including securitisation positions within the underlying exposures, so that the firm can demonstrate that its involvement is compliant with the relevant requirements as expected by the PRA [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] and that the prohibited exposure composition is avoided [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].
source_text: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation is compliant with the requirements in Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The underlying exposures used in a securitisation shall not include securitisation positions .

question: When documenting capital requirements for long-term insurance business, what must be shown to demonstrate that NMCR (linear,l) is being used consistently with its defined meaning and with the requirement that the notional linear minimum capital requirement be set equal to specified components?
gold_answer: To evidence compliance, the documentation should first make clear that NMCR (linear,l) is being used as the defined notation that denotes the notional linear minimum capital requirement for long-term insurance business, i.e., the prescribed requirement for that business category [#SRC:8b1e37626a8c2741]. It should then demonstrate that the firm has applied the mandatory structural condition for that requirement: the notional linear minimum capital requirement for long-term insurance business must be equal to the specified items set out in the applicable provision, rather than being derived by an alternative method or presented as a non-binding benchmark [#TGT:ff037072dc98b21b]. In practice, this means the firm should (i) label the requirement as NMCR (linear,l) to align with the defined term, and (ii) present an equality statement showing NMCR (linear,l) (as the notional linear minimum capital requirement) equals the “following” components referenced in the obligation. This ties the defined denotation to the required equality form, ensuring consistent terminology and calculation structure.

question: For compliance mapping purposes, how should a firm align the supervisory statement titled on enhancing banks’ and insurers’ approaches to managing the financial risks from climate change with the Prudential Regulation publication entry that provides the April 2019 date and web location, and what identifying markers must be retained to ensure both references point to the same item?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the supervisory statement entry and the Prudential Regulation publication entry as two cross-references to the same supervisory statement on enhancing banks’ and insurers’ approaches to managing the financial risks from climate change, and it should preserve the shared identifying elements that appear across both records. From the supervisory statement record, the firm should retain the identifier “SS3/19” and the associated title text, as well as the trailing reference number “17,” to anchor the internal control mapping to the correct item [#SRC:b56e255afd8a5779]. From the publication record, the firm should retain the explicit publication date “April 2019” and the full Bank of England Prudential Regulation URL that resolves to the same titled item, again linked to the reference number “17,” to support traceability to the external source [#TGT:b96b25cb718f3754]. Using both together, the firm can evidence that its climate financial risk management reference is consistently identified by SS3/19, tied to item 17, and externally verifiable via the April 2019 publication page.
source_text: SS3/19 ‘Enhancing banks’ and insurers’ approaches to managing the financial risks from climate change’; 17
target_text: 17. April 2019: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2019/enhancing-banks-and-insurers-approaches-to-managing-the-financial-risks-from-climate-change-ss .

question: When a firm maintains the required up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, what signatures must be obtained on that record and on any updated version, and who must provide them?
gold_answer: A firm must maintain an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, meaning the firm is responsible for ensuring the record remains current for every key function holder [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. In addition to keeping that record current, the firm must ensure that the record and each updated version is signed by two parties: (1) the relevant key function holder, and (2) an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Practically, this means that whenever the firm creates the record for a key function holder or updates it to reflect changes, the firm must obtain fresh signatures from both the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm on the updated version, not only on the initial record. The obligation therefore combines ongoing maintenance (keeping the record up to date for each key function holder) with a formal sign-off requirement that applies to the record itself and every subsequent updated version, ensuring both the individual and the firm acknowledge the current statement of responsibilities [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: How must TWD firms ensure they have the methodologies, models, and frameworks to forecast the impact of a TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, while also being able to model the gap between expected exit value and accounting book value for positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the TWD scenario actions?
gold_answer: TWD firms should maintain methodologies, models, and frameworks that enable them to forecast how a TWD scenario affects capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity over the wind-down period, based on projections from the reference date of the TWD option through wind-down [#SRC:eecba58e91b8b36e]. In parallel, those same modelling capabilities should extend to quantifying valuation impacts for positions subject to wind-down execution, specifically by modelling the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and the accounting book value for positions to be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the scenario’s actions, arrangements, and measures [#TGT:e278c7223b5808a7]. The gap analysis should be grounded in the fact that TWD scenario assumptions can differ from accounting fair value assumptions, including assumptions about how other market participants react in stressed circumstances (potentially distorting the market) and a greater perceived likelihood that certain pricing factors crystallise in the TWD scenario compared with business-as-usual sale conditions [#TGT:e278c7223b5808a7]. Together, these capabilities support forecasting both resource impacts and execution-related valuation differences across the wind-down timeline [#SRC:eecba58e91b8b36e] [#TGT:e278c7223b5808a7].
source_text: TWD firms should have the methodologies, models, and frameworks needed to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity. question: When a firm includes the TWD option in its recovery plan, what is the applicable boundary for SS9/17 expectations, and how should the firm understand the relationship between those expectations and other PRA policies while still meeting the requirement to maintain a range of executable recovery options?
gold_answer: A firm’s starting point is whether it is subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules; if it is, it is required to have a recovery plan containing a range of executable options [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8]. Within that scope, the boundary for applying SS9/17 expectations to a specific option is addressed for TWD: because the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]. Accordingly, a firm that includes TWD in its recovery plan should treat TWD as falling within the same expectations that SS9/17 sets out for recovery planning, including expectations relating to governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks, amongst other areas [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8]. The firm should also frame its approach by reference to how SS9/17 expectations interact with other relevant PRA policies and the SS, as that interaction is set out in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down SoP [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]. This ensures the firm both maintains the required range of executable options and applies the correct expectation set to TWD.
source_text: All firms subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules are required to have a recovery plan containing a range of executable options. SS9/17 sets out expectations for recovery planning relating to governance, information and reporting requirements, fire drills and playbooks, amongst other areas. 7
target_text: 7. As the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply. The interaction between the expectations in SS9/17, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS is set out in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down SoP.

question: When a firm wants to use the standard approach for the FS addition for event risks on a pooled asset exposure (because the underlying assets are mainly economic risk and the exposure is predictable), what does the PRA mean by event-driven cash flow variability risk, and what percentile-style benchmark does the PRA link to that risk when better data allows more advanced modelling?
gold_answer: If a pooled asset exposure’s underlying assets are exposed to economic risks, and the firm has enough evidence that the exposure is predictable, the firm may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855]. In doing so, the firm should define the relevant event risk in the way the PRA characterises it: event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be appropriately represented using fatter-tailed distributions, meaning the firm should not assume that event impacts on cash flows are narrowly distributed around the average [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA links this definition to a practical benchmark for provision: a provision equal to one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is described as broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution, and this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]. This benchmark can therefore be used to support and explain the firm’s proposal under the standard approach permission [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855].
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: The PRA considers that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be best represented by fatter-tailed distributions. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA considers that a provision of one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution and that this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks.

question: Where a firm lacks the capability within the firm or the firm’s group and therefore must appoint an external actuary, what steps must the firm take before making that appointment to ensure the actuary is suitable for the firm’s business and regulatory obligations?
gold_answer: If a firm does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6, it must appoint an external actuary [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab]. Before the firm makes that appointment, it must take reasonable steps to ensure the actuary has the required skill and experience to perform the actuary’s functions under the regulatory system, and that this competence is commensurate with the nature, scale and complexity of the firm’s business [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71]. In practice, this means the firm’s obligation is twofold: (1) determine that an external actuary is required because internal or group capability is insufficient, and (2) conduct a suitability assessment before appointment that is tailored to the firm’s specific profile and the regulatory requirements and standards to which the firm is subject. The pre-appointment steps should therefore be designed to evidence that the selected external actuary can meet the relevant regulatory-system functions and standards for the firm’s particular business complexity, rather than relying solely on general credentials.
source_text: Before a firm appoints an actuary under 2.1 or 2.2 , it must take reasonable steps to ensure that the actuary has the required skill and experience to perform his functions under the regulatory system commensurate with the nature, scale and complexity of the firm’s business and the requirements and standards under the regulatory system to which it is subject.
target_text: A firm must appoint an external actuary if it does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6 .

question: For a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission, what must auditors take into account about the size of the matching adjustment the firm claims when forming the audit opinion on the SFCR, and how does the permission boundary affect that assessment?
gold_answer: Where the Chapter applies—i.e., for a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131]—auditors, in providing the audit opinion required in relation to the SFCR, are expected (to the extent material to their opinion) to consider the scale of the MA claimed by the firm [#SRC:a3f87c93e8c6ab03]. This expectation is linked to the fact that the MA’s impact on technical provisions falls within the relevant elements that are within the required scope of audit. In assessing the scale, auditors should recognise that the MA calculation depends in part on the application of MA calculation requirements, and that the apparent scale could be affected if the assets and liabilities used to calculate the MA were not within scope of an MA permission. Accordingly, for a firm within the Chapter’s scope, the auditor’s consideration of scale is not limited to arithmetic; it also includes whether the MA claimed could be influenced by using assets and liabilities that fall outside what the firm’s MA permission covers, because that could change the scale of MA presented and therefore be material to the SFCR audit opinion.
source_text: However, to provide the audit opinion required in relation to the SFCR, to the extent it is material to their opinion, auditors are expected to consider the scale of the MA claimed by the firm. This reflects the fact that the impact of the MA on technical provisions falls within the relevant elements that are within the required scope of audit as set out by Rule 2.2 in the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook. The MA calculation depends in part on the application of the MA calculation requirements (set out including in regulations 5 and 6 of the IRPR regulations and Chapters 4 , 6 and 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part ). However, the scale of the MA could also be affected if the assets and liabilities used to calculate the MA were not within scope of an MA permission.
target_text: This Chapter applies to a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission .

question: What does the PRA’s overall check of whether the home state supervisor is equivalent apply to, and what parts of the PRA’s work are outside that scope because they relate to advice to HM Treasury?
gold_answer: The PRA’s overall check of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent applies to the PRA’s own purposes of authorisation and supervision, and it is based on the outcomes achieved [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. In carrying out that assessment, the PRA looks at whether the home state supervisor’s regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives, and it assesses the relevant factors in their totality [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. As part of the PRA’s process, it places considerable weight on the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor, and it also takes into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, as well as the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. Outside that scope, the PRA may separately provide advice to HM Treasury, where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes; that advisory activity is distinct from the PRA’s equivalence assessment for PRA authorisation and supervision [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581].
source_text: The PRA will make an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, and whether its regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. 9 The PRA assesses these factors in their totality, but will place considerable weight on assessing the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor. The PRA will take into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and it will consider the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK.
target_text: 9. The PRA’s assessment of equivalence is based on the outcomes achieved and is for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, which is separate from advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes. The PRA may give advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541).

question: If an Authorised Person wants to make an application, where does the SoP tell them to look for the application steps, and which June 2024 document should they use for internal model matching adjustment modelling?
gold_answer: The SoP says that, for information about making an application, the Authorised Person should look at the Authorisations page of the PRA’s website, and it also explains that the SoP should be read alongside a set of related materials, including supervisory statements on Solvency II topics [#SRC:6f1cefbb88e9a396]. One of those related materials is the supervisory statement on internal models and the modelling of the matching adjustment (SS8/18), so an applicant should ensure they are using the correct referenced publication when preparing their application materials [#SRC:6f1cefbb88e9a396]. The cross-referenced entry specifies exactly which document to use: the TERM ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’, June 2024, and it provides the web link where that June 2024 version is available on the Bank of England site [#TGT:ad88d1cd8dfc3d97]. Taken together, this means the application “how-to” comes from the PRA Authorisations page, while the technical expectations for internal model matching adjustment modelling are supported by the June 2024 ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’ document.
source_text: This SoP should be read in conjunction with the IRPR regulations, the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, the Investments Part of the PRA Rulebook, the relevant rules in the rest of the Solvency II Sector of the PRA Rulebook, supervisory statement (SS) 7/18 – Solvency II: Matching adjustment 1 , SS1/20 – Solvency II: Prudent Person Principle 2 , SS8/18 – Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment 3 , SS3/17 – Solvency II: Illiquid unrated assets 4 and the PRA’s insurance approach document. 5 For information about making an application, see the Authorisations page of the PRA’s website.
target_text: 3. ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’, June 2024: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2018/solvency-2-internal-models-modelling-of-the-matching-adjustment-ss .

question: If a firm is going to issue CET1 or AT1, or change the terms of CET1 or AT1, when must it tell the PRA, and how is that different from the timing for Tier 2 under the PRA Rulebook’s pre-issuance vs post-notification approach?
gold_answer: For CET1 and AT1, a firm must notify the PRA ahead of time when it intends to issue the instrument or when it intends to amend or vary its terms, as long as the instrument will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds. The timing is at least one month before the intended date of the issuance or the intended date of the amendment or variation, and this applies whether the instrument is counted at solo, sub-consolidated, or group consolidated level (or any combination) [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]. This matches the PRA Rulebook description that CET1 and AT1 issuances require pre-issuance notification [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268]. Tier 2 is handled differently: instead of a one-month pre-notice, the firm must notify the PRA immediately after it issues a Tier 2 capital instrument, and immediately after it amends or varies the terms of a Tier 2 capital instrument, where it will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]. That immediate-after approach corresponds to the Rulebook’s post-notification requirement for Tier 2 issuances [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268].
source_text: Firms are generally required 6 to notify the PRA at least one month before the intended date of issuance or amendment or variation to the terms of each CET1 or AT1 capital instrument, and immediately after issuing or amending or varying the terms of each Tier 2 capital instrument, that will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds, either at solo, sub-consolidated or group consolidated level or any combination of these.
target_text: 6. Rules 7A to 7D of Definition of Capital Part of the PRA Rulebook require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances, and post-notification for Tier 2 issuances.

question: When assessing whether a local entity’s risk can be treated as already addressed, how should the analysis distinguish between mitigation achieved through the risk based capital framework or other means and mitigation achieved at the group level through group risk management processes or internal control mechanisms?
gold_answer: In evaluating whether a local entity’s risk can be treated as already addressed, the analysis should explicitly map the mitigation to one of two pathways and document which applies. First, determine whether the relevant risks are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, as this indicates the risk is addressed within the capital-based approach or an alternative mitigation method recognized in the same context [#SRC:d59b0f174c2241e4]. Second, assess whether the risk of the local entity is mitigated at the group level through risk management processes or internal control mechanisms established at the group level, which frames mitigation as arising from group-level governance and controls rather than solely from capital treatment [#TGT:7a8270fc93e6d439]. Where both appear to apply, the assessment should explain how the group-level processes or controls interact with, complement, or substitute for the capital framework or other means, so that the conclusion that the risk is “already mitigated” is traceable to the specific mechanism relied upon and avoids double-counting the same mitigation effect.
source_text: (i) are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework 20 or by other means; 21 or (ii) net off in consolidation (for example, intragroup risks and offsetting positions); and
target_text: 21. For example, the risk of a local entity might be mitigated at the group level through risk management processes or internal control mechanisms established at the group level.

question: How do you work out the limit using the society’s reserves after taking off fixed assets (including the pro rata split), and then decide which societies’ Merger Resolutions must include members’ approval for the bonus payments if the bonus cost is over that limit?
gold_answer: You start by calculating the relevant limit using the definition that ties it to a sum based on the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets, with the fixed assets apportioned pro rata for the relevant context, and then applying the definition’s instruction to use whichever resulting amount is the less; the source also notes that the Regulations should be consulted for full calculation detail [#SRC:fa83aff840ed1f2b]. Next, you compare that limit to the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), which is assessed without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery, because that is the cost measure used to test whether the limit is exceeded [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. This comparison drives the approval-routing step: if the cost is within the prescribed limit, members’ approval only needs to be included in the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are being distributed; but if the cost exceeds the limit, the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].
source_text: (c) a sum equal to the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets (apportioned pro rata in respect of paragraph 3.107(b) above), whichever is the less. The Regulations should be consulted for the full detail of the calculations.
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If Institutions are publishing the required disclosures using the Templates UK KM1 and the Annex II instructions, do they also have to publish the extra disclosure in the same place and on the same schedule as the other disclosures?
gold_answer: Yes. Institutions must make the specified disclosures using the Templates UK KM1 of Annex I and follow the relevant instructions in Annex II, and they must also ensure that the extra disclosure is not treated as a standalone publication. The extra disclosure has to be provided in addition to the other templates and must appear in the same location and with the same frequency as the other required disclosures. In practice, Institutions should place the extra disclosure wherever they place the rest of the required disclosure set (so it is accessible in the same location) and release it whenever they release those other disclosures (so it follows the same frequency). This ensures consistency for readers and avoids a mismatch where the main disclosures are available in one place or at one time while the extra disclosure is elsewhere or later. The obligation to use the UK KM1 templates and Annex II instructions for the required disclosures [#TGT:5873c14fcb8a77d7] therefore needs to be implemented together with the procedural requirement to publish the extra disclosure in the same location and with the same frequency as the other disclosures [#SRC:120f21cd6ec7a55c].
source_text: (c) For the disclosure required in Article 451(2)(e) , in addition to the templates referred to in (a), in the same location and with the same frequency as the disclosures required by Article 2(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall make the disclosures required in Article 447 (a) to (g) and point (b) of Article 438 of the CRR in accordance with the Templates UK KM1 of Annex I and the relevant instructions set out in Annex II .

question: If societies are not publicly quoted, what code should they take into account when setting up and checking their corporate governance arrangements, and what does “the Combined Code” mean in terms of who developed it and which accounting periods it covers?
gold_answer: Even though societies are not publicly quoted, they are expected to take a recognised governance framework into account when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements; in practice, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or, where appropriate, the Combined Code [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]. To apply that “as appropriate” choice, you need the definition of the Combined Code: it is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council, and it applies to accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010 [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]. Putting both points together, a society deciding whether to use the Combined Code should check whether the relevant accounting period begins before the stated date and understand that the code being referenced is the one produced through the Financial Reporting Council’s Corporate Governance Committee. If those definition conditions are not met, the society would instead look to having regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code when setting up and reassessing its governance arrangements.
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: When applying the rule that sets the boundary for whether a deposit qualifies as an eligible deposit, what reasonable steps must a firm take to establish a local authority’s annual budget, and how must the firm treat the local authority if it cannot determine eligibility after taking those steps?
gold_answer: In determining whether a deposit falls within the scope of the rule that decides if it is an eligible deposit, a firm must apply the PRA’s expectation that it takes reasonable steps to ascertain a local authority’s annual budget, because that information is relevant to whether the local authority is eligible for the purposes of the eligibility determination [#TGT:02fb0fbf6939a082]. The firm may rely on a reasonable estimate of the annual budget provided by the local authority, including an estimate based on the previous year’s budget, as an acceptable means of meeting this expectation where direct confirmation is not available [#SRC:6c7186a4053377c4]. However, if after taking reasonable steps the firm is unable to determine whether the local authority is eligible, the firm must treat the local authority as a public authority for the purposes of applying the eligibility framework to the deposit [#SRC:6c7186a4053377c4]. This approach ensures the firm’s eligibility assessment is grounded in a documented attempt to obtain budget information while still providing a clear classification outcome when eligibility cannot be confirmed, so the deposit can be assessed consistently under the rule’s eligibility provisions [#TGT:02fb0fbf6939a082].
source_text: Regarding Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(j) , it is acceptable for firms to rely upon a reasonable estimate provided by the local authority of its annual budget, which could for example be based on the previous year’s budget. The PRA expects a firm to take reasonable steps to ascertain a local authority’s budget, but where a firm has been unable to determine if a local authority is eligible, it should be treated as a public authority.

question: If a depositor has both aggregate eligible deposits and a temporary high balance, what maximum compensation sums must be used for each, and when is there no maximum limit for the temporary high balance?
gold_answer: You must apply the maximum compensation sum based on the type of balance being compensated, because the passages set different caps and different exceptions. For the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor, the maximum compensation sum payable is £120,000, but the rule also allows that additional compensation may be payable in certain specified cases [#SRC:336f75f8cdcde56e]. For a temporary high balance, the maximum compensation sum payable is £1,400,000, and that cap is stated to operate subject to a further condition referenced in the temporary-high-balance provision [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. However, the temporary-high-balance rule also creates an important exception that removes any numerical ceiling: no limit applies to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance if the temporary high balance arises from a payment connected with personal injury or incapacity [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. In practice, this means you cannot assume a single universal cap; you must classify the claim as aggregate eligible deposits versus temporary high balance, then apply the relevant cap and any stated exception, including the uncapped personal-injury-or-incapacity category.
source_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: When a BRRD undertaking is considering entering into a group financial support agreement, is it prohibited from doing so unless the agreement ensures the financial support is provided on terms (including consideration) in accordance with the referenced requirements, and how does that terms requirement operate as part of the conditions that must be satisfied?
gold_answer: A BRRD undertaking is prohibited from entering into a group financial support agreement unless the applicable conditions are satisfied [#TGT:7bf72e89d4d4b9ff]. One of the relevant conditions to be met concerns how any financial support under the arrangement is structured: the financial support must be provided on terms, including consideration, and those terms must be in accordance with the referenced requirements [#SRC:2648535839d54757]. Read together, the prohibition means the BRRD undertaking cannot proceed with entering the agreement unless it can demonstrate that the contemplated support is not open-ended or informal, but instead is set out on defined terms that address consideration and align with the specified framework referenced in the source. In practical compliance terms, the BRRD undertaking should treat the “terms (including consideration) in accordance with” requirement as a gating element within the broader set of conditions: if the agreement does not clearly specify the terms on which support will be provided, including the consideration, and does not align those terms with the referenced requirements, the undertaking remains within the “must not enter into” prohibition.
