question: If a firm wants to put its liquidity contingency plan and recovery plan into one document, what does it need to do to make sure it still meets the PRA Rulebook requirements for the liquidity contingency plan, and when can it keep two documents instead?
gold_answer: A firm can combine its liquidity contingency plan (also called a contingency funding plan) and its recovery plan into a single integrated document, because firms are strongly encouraged to do so to create a coherent process for being alerted to and addressing liquidity stress and to support a coherent risk management framework [#SRC:d6da2dce246d82de]. However, even when integrated, the firm must ensure that the liquidity contingency plan element of the combined document continues to satisfy the PRA Rulebook requirements that apply specifically to the liquidity contingency plan, which are set out in Rule 12 of the Internal Liquidity Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook [#TGT:856519b5145b9260]. If the firm needs to keep the liquidity contingency plan and recovery plan as separate documents (for example, because local regulators require separate documents), the PRA recognises that this may be necessary but expects it to be the exception; in that case, the firm should keep the documents consistent with each other while ensuring the liquidity contingency plan document still meets the Rule 12 requirements [#SRC:d6da2dce246d82de] [#TGT:856519b5145b9260].
source_text: Firms are strongly encouraged to combine their liquidity contingency plan 16 (also known as a contingency funding plan) and their recovery plan into one integrated document. This would ensure that the firm has a coherent process for being alerted to and addressing a liquidity stress and helps to ensure a coherent risk management framework. The PRA recognises that there may be some instances when it is necessary to maintain separate documents (eg due to requirements of local regulators), but expects this to be the exception and that any separate documents should be consistent with each other.
target_text: 16. Rule 12 of the Internal Liquidity Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook sets out the requirements a firm needs to meet in relation to its liquidity contingency plan.

question: If a firm updates the statement of responsibilities record for a key function holder to keep it current, what must the firm do to ensure the updated record is properly executed, and which persons must sign?
gold_answer: The firm’s obligation has two linked components: it must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, and it must ensure that the record is properly signed when created and whenever it is updated [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Specifically, the record and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Accordingly, when the firm updates the record to keep it current, it is not sufficient merely to revise the content; the firm must also obtain signatures on the updated version from both required signatories. This ensures that the key function holder confirms the updated statement of responsibilities and that an appropriate representative of the firm also attests to the updated record. The requirement applies to each updated version, so the firm should treat every update as requiring renewed execution by the key function holder and the firm’s appropriate representative, aligning the ongoing “up-to-date” maintenance duty with a continuing sign-off control [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: A firm must keep the statement of responsibilities record for each key function holder up to date. When the firm creates or updates that record, who must sign it?
gold_answer: The firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, so the firm needs to maintain a current record for every key function holder [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Alongside that ongoing maintenance duty, the record must be formally signed: the record itself and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. This means that whenever the firm first prepares the record, it must obtain both signatures, and whenever the firm updates the record to keep it current, it must again ensure the updated version is signed by both the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm. The combined effect is that the firm is responsible not only for keeping the content current for each key function holder, but also for ensuring that every version that is current has the required sign-off from the individual key function holder and the firm’s representative [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: If a firm uses and tweaks its existing management information and recovery-planning indicator frameworks instead of building a new indicator set, what does it still need to do to meet its monitoring duties for a solvent exit?
gold_answer: A firm may meet the relevant expectations by drawing on and adapting its existing management information framework and the indicator framework it developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, and it does not necessarily have to create and monitor a brand-new set of indicators to do so [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32]. Even when using that approach, the firm still has a monitoring duty for the indicators it relies on: it should monitor the projected levels and the actual levels of those indicators, and it should also monitor their trend so it can see how they are moving over time [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. The point of this monitoring is not just record-keeping; the indicators, together with other relevant information, should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. So, if the firm reuses existing reporting and recovery-planning metrics, it should ensure they are tracked in a way that provides projections, actual outcomes, and trend information that can be used quickly for solvent-exit decisions [#TGT:30201d932e512926], while taking advantage of the flexibility to adapt existing frameworks [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32].
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should monitor the projected and actual levels of these indicators, as well as their trend. These indicators, alongside other relevant information, 23 should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit.

question: If the rules are meant to apply (with needed adjustments) at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that is not based in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, what do the relevant insurance group undertakings or any UK holding company have to report to the group supervisor about risk concentrations, and how often?
gold_answer: Where the scope condition is satisfied so that the specified set of requirements, including External Audit provisions, apply with any necessary changes at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, the related reporting duty must still be met in the way that fits that level of application [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. In practical terms, the relevant insurance group undertakings or any UK holding company must provide the group supervisor with reports of any significant risk concentration at the level of the group [#TGT:58ef7092c29ce99f]. This is not a one-off requirement: the reports must be made on a regular basis and at least annually, so there is a minimum annual reporting requirement plus an expectation of ongoing periodic reporting as part of regular supervision [#TGT:58ef7092c29ce99f]. The “with any necessary changes” scope wording means the reporting process should be adapted as needed to work at the specified holding company or third-country undertaking level, while still ensuring the group supervisor receives group-level information on significant risk concentrations [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8] [#TGT:58ef7092c29ce99f].
source_text: When 2.1(3) applies, 4 to 14 , 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking unless:
target_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the relevant insurance group undertakings or any UK holding company must report on a regular basis and at least annually to the group supervisor any significant risk concentration at the level of the group .

question: If an institution is a client and wants to use the allowed method to work out own funds requirements for its trade exposures to its clearing member for CCP-related transactions, can it still use that method when it is a lower-level client in a multi-level client structure, only if the conditions are met at every level?
gold_answer: Yes. An institution that is a client is permitted to calculate the own funds requirements for its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member using the allowed approach, but only if all required conditions for that approach are met [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1]. Separately, when the institution is part of a multi-level client structure—specifically, when it is a lower-level client accessing the services of a CCP through a higher-level client—it may apply the relevant treatment only where the conditions tied to that treatment are satisfied at every level of the structure [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b]. Putting these together, the institution can use the permitted calculation approach in a multi-level setup only if it can confirm compliance not just at its own level, but across the entire chain of clients involved in accessing the CCP. If the conditions fail at any tier, the institution cannot apply the treatment in that multi-level structure, even though it is a client and is otherwise eligible to use the calculation approach [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b].

question: What must happen before the Merger Notification Statement can be sent to members, and what must be included in the written application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement (including the board declaration and documents)?
gold_answer: The Merger Notification Statement cannot be sent to members until it has been approved by the PRA, and once approved it must be sent within the specified time limit; in general, the application for that approval should follow the stated procedure and the final draft should be submitted with the relevant supporting documents, adjusted to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc]. Separately, for a Schedule 16 Statement, the firm must apply to the PRA for approval in writing, and the application should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should be aware of; that declaration should also indicate whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals and confirm that the information about them is correct, and the application should be accompanied by the listed documents [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]. In practice, both regimes require a pre‑circulation approval step with a structured submission package to the PRA, including supporting documentation and a clear statement of completeness for members’ purposes.
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Schedule 16 Statements must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports. An application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board, that the Statement is complete and includes all material information of which, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware. question: If the firm says turning tenant ratings into a non-rent payment probability is straightforward, what should it do to reflect that PD usually is not a direct measure of non-payment, and how should it handle differences between observed default rates and PD when economic conditions change in the mid-corporate space?
gold_answer: The firm can treat the conversion of tenant ratings into a non-rent payment probability as an intuitive step, but it should not assume that the PD it produces is the same thing as the probability of non-payment. The text explains that, even where tenants are rated by the firm, PD will not usually be a direct read-across to non-payment because of issues such as model philosophy, so the firm should build in and explain the reasons for that disconnect when it performs the transformation [#SRC:091fac39c7e6e49b] and [#TGT:43ecedb5d0451d08]. It should also treat the relationship between observed default rate and PD as a key area to address, since many firms struggle to define what level of divergence is expected under different economic conditions in the mid-corporate space. That implies the firm should set out how it expects observed default rates and PD to differ across economic conditions, rather than relying on a simple one-to-one mapping from ratings to non-payment outcomes [#TGT:43ecedb5d0451d08].
source_text: (b) the transformation of ratings into non-rent payment probability is intuitive; 12
target_text: 12. Even where tenants are rated by the firm the PD will not usually represent a direct read across to probability of non-payment due to, for example, model philosophy issues. Addressing this is likely to be a key area since many firms struggle with defining what divergence is expected between observed default rate and PD in different economic conditions in the mid-corporate space.

question: What must Institutions do to make sure they disclose all required information in one place electronically, and at the same time explain their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk (including the risks covered by the Title)?
gold_answer: Institutions must publish the complete set of required disclosures electronically and keep them together in a single medium or location, rather than spreading them across different documents or channels. That single place must either be a standalone document that gives users a readily accessible source of prudential information, or a distinctive section that is included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports and is easily identifiable to users. Within that same single, electronic disclosure location, Institutions must also provide their risk management objectives and policies, and they must do so separately for each category of risk, including the risks referred to in the applicable Title. Put together, the requirements mean the disclosure package must be both easy to find (one electronic location) and easy to navigate (clearly organized by risk category), so that users can identify where the prudential disclosures sit and can locate the objectives and policies relevant to each risk category without confusion [#SRC:8422ed9edcda5caa] and while still covering each separate category of risk required by the Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].

question: After a firm has worked out the amount from the earlier step, what must it do to adjust it for the length of the financial year and then work out the required 18% figure?
gold_answer: The firm must do two required calculations using the amount it has already arrived at under the earlier step. To adjust for the length of the financial year, it must multiply that amount by twelve and then divide the result by the number of months in the financial year, so the figure is scaled to a twelve‑month basis even if the financial year is shorter or longer [#TGT:4c8a5122c2f0aa8c]. After that adjustment, the firm must calculate 18% of the amount arrived at, meaning it must take the relevant “amount arrived at” and determine the value equal to 18% of it as the required output [#SRC:042f154e50bf3b5b]. In practice, this means the firm starts with the previously determined amount, applies the twelve‑month/months‑in‑year adjustment, and then applies the 18% calculation to produce the final required figure.
source_text: A firm must calculate 18% of the amount arrived at under 7.3 .
target_text: A firm must multiply the amount arrived at under 7.2 by twelve and divide by the number of months in the financial year .

question: If the PRA issues a statement to explain its general approach in the Insurance Approach document, what should you expect it to say about the public consultation and any wording changes, and how does that connect to why the PRA is publishing the statement?
gold_answer: If the PRA publishes a statement to expand on its general approach as set out in its Insurance Approach document, you should expect it to link the publication to its aim of clearly and consistently explaining its views in the area, and to connect that clarity to advancing its statutory objectives of ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and contributing to protection for policyholders [#TGT:6513a735d431f5ba]. You should also expect a clear account of process: the statement was subject to public consultation and reflects feedback received by the PRA [#SRC:f7de2cea26e343cf]. Where consultees suggested changes to wording, the PRA indicates it accepted those suggestions when they would improve clarity, but it also makes clear that these edits do not change the policy itself [#SRC:f7de2cea26e343cf]. In other words, the consultation is presented as a way to refine how the PRA communicates its views, while the reason for publishing remains to explain its approach consistently in support of its objectives, not to introduce a new policy direction [#TGT:6513a735d431f5ba] [#SRC:f7de2cea26e343cf].
source_text: The statement was subject to public consultation, 1 and reflects feedback received by the PRA. Some comments suggested altering wording and these suggestions have been accepted where clarity would be improved. There is no change in policy.
target_text: The PRA is publishing this statement to expand on its general approach as set out in its Insurance Approach document. 2 By clearly and consistently explaining its views in this area, the PRA seeks to advance its statutory objectives of ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates, and contributing to securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders.

question: Institutions must put required prudential disclosures online in one place. If the Institution is a G-SII, when can it put the information required under Article 441 somewhere else, and what still has to be true about the main disclosure document or section?
gold_answer: Institutions are required to disclose all information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location, and that single location must take a defined form: either a standalone document that is readily accessible for users of prudential information, or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports that contains the required disclosures and is easily identifiable to those users [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]. For a G-SII, there is a limited permission that departs from that single-location approach: by way of derogation, where the G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1, it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document used for the single-medium framework [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76]. This means the “somewhere else” option is not automatic; it depends on the G-SII relying on the derogation, and it applies only to the Article 441 information. The main single medium or location requirement, and the need for a readily accessible standalone document or clearly identifiable section, still frames how the overall disclosures are presented.
source_text: By way of derogation from Article 434(1) , where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1 , it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.

question: If you need the Bank’s indicative thresholds for setting preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements, what documents or webpages should you use, and where on the Bank of England site is the right link?
gold_answer: Use the SOURCE to identify what content you need and the TARGET to find where to access it. The SOURCE explains that the detail on the Bank’s indicative thresholds used to set preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements is in the Bank’s approach to resolution, and it separately notes that thresholds for reporting under the Resolvability Assessment Framework are in the PRA RAF SS 4/19 document on resolution assessment and public disclosure by firms [#SRC:5423b3916f47b476]. The TARGET then tells you how to reach the Bank’s approach to resolution online: it points to the Bank of England’s resolution page and indicates that you should use the link to the “framework for resolution” located under “Why we need a resolution regime” [#TGT:001a06cd5d5a94ac]. Putting both together, you would go to the Bank of England resolution webpage to access the framework material that supports the Bank’s approach to resolution for the indicative thresholds, and you would consult the PRA RAF SS 4/19 for RAF reporting thresholds.
source_text: Detail on the Bank’s indicative thresholds to set preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements can be found in the Bank’s approach to resolution. 91 In addition, thresholds for reporting under the Resolvability Assessment Framework can be found in the PRA RAF SS 4/19 ’Resolution assessment and public disclosure by firms’. 92
target_text: 91. Available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/financial-stability/resolution (link to ‘framework for resolution’ under ‘Why we need a resolution regime).

question: When this Part is applied on a group basis, how should the scope of the group be determined across all undertakings within the relevant group, and how is that scope affected if the PRA grants a waiver or if a supervisory authority acting as the group supervisor decides not to include an undertaking in group supervision?
gold_answer: When this Part applies at the level of a group, the starting point for scope is that the group is defined to consist of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated qualifications and conditions attached to that group-level application [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. However, that baseline “all undertakings” composition is not absolute: the scope can be narrowed where the PRA has granted a waiver, or where a supervisory authority which is the group supervisor has decided—using the Solvency II EEA implementing measures implementing Article 214 of the Solvency II Directive—not to include a particular undertaking in the group supervision that is being applied on that group basis [#TGT:835e743b1b5b8d84]. Read together, the provisions mean you should first identify the relevant group and the undertakings within it for purposes of applying this Part at group level, and then check whether any undertaking is carved out from inclusion in group supervision due to either a PRA waiver or a group supervisor decision under the referenced Solvency II implementing framework, in which case that undertaking is not included for the group supervision in question.

question: What do banks have to keep ready for the PRA or FSCS, how quickly must they provide it when asked, and what kinds of deposits must firms include in the exclusions file because they are not in the single customer view?
gold_answer: Banks must maintain a single customer view (SCV) and an exclusions file to support orderly resolution, and they are required to provide this information to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740]. At the same time, firms must make sure the exclusions file they are required to provide includes data on deposits that are not in the SCV; the guidance gives examples such as deposits held in client accounts and deposits held through deposit aggregators [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6]. Putting both requirements together, the deliverable is not just a file produced quickly, but one that is complete in the sense that it separates SCV-covered deposit data from deposits that sit outside the SCV and therefore need to be recorded in the exclusions file. This ensures that, when the PRA or FSCS requests the SCV and exclusions file, the bank can meet the 24-hour deadline while also providing an exclusions file that contains the expected non-SCV deposit categories, including client account deposits and aggregator-held deposits [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6].
source_text: In order to support orderly resolution, banks must maintain a single customer view and exclusions file, 67 and are required to provide this to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request. 68 Banks’ systems must automatically identify the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and identify any portion of an eligible deposit that is over the specified coverage level. 69
target_text: 67. The exclusions file that firms are required to provide should include data on deposits which are not in the SCV including for example deposits held in client accounts and deposit aggregators.

question: During the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, what must a UK domestic firm do to stay appropriately informed about the controller or proposed controller, and what immediate action must it take if it becomes aware (or has information reasonably suggesting) that the person submitting the notice has provided information that was or may have false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed materially?
gold_answer: A UK domestic firm must actively monitor and investigate, on a reasonable-steps basis, the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that are relevant to the notification, so that it keeps itself informed throughout the relevant period [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979]. That ongoing duty to remain informed is not passive: it is intended to ensure the firm can identify developments in the controller/proposed controller’s circumstances that bear on the notification and the information provided to the PRA. If, during the period between submission of a section 178 notice and the change in control, the firm becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided information to the PRA that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular, the firm must notify the PRA immediately [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]. Read together, the reasonable-steps monitoring obligation supports timely detection, and the immediate notification obligation governs the required escalation once such concerns arise.
source_text: During the period referred to in 3.6 , a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or the proposed controller to which the notification related.
target_text: (1) A UK domestic firm must notify the PRA immediately if, in the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control , the firm becomes aware, or has information which reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information which was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular.

question: If a firm is checking whether an outsourcing or third party arrangement is “material outsourcing” (and therefore covers what other rules call “critical or important outsourcing”), what does the PRA expect the firm to do when judging materiality, and does using ICT like cloud automatically make it material?
gold_answer: A firm should understand that the PRA uses “material outsourcing” for clarity and to avoid confusion with other overlapping regulatory terms, and that the PRA considers a “material outsourcing” arrangement to encompass a “critical or important outsourcing” arrangement under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]. In practice, that means the firm should approach the identification of material outsourcing using criteria that are substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying critical or important outsourcing under the EBA Outsourcing GL, while recognising there are some justified exceptions (including those referencing the PRA’s operational resilience requirements) [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]. When the firm assesses whether a particular outsourcing or third party arrangement is material (especially where it is not otherwise covered by the earlier referenced paragraphs), the PRA expects the firm to consider all applicable criteria in the table, looking at each criterion on its own and also how the criteria work together [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1]. The firm should also avoid treating ICT involvement (such as cloud) as an automatic trigger for materiality; ICT presence alone does not make an arrangement material [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1].
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms to have regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5 below, both individually and in conjunction, when assessing the materiality of an outsourcing or third party arrangement not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9 . Although in practice many material outsourcing and third party arrangements involve ICT products or services (eg cloud), the presence of a given ICT product or service does not, in itself, automatically render an outsourcing arrangement material.

question: If you are working out the add-on for a hedging set, what is the supervisory factor coefficient you must use for hedging set j, and how is that coefficient supposed to be determined?
gold_answer: For add-on calculations, the supervisory factor coefficient is a defined coefficient that must be used as part of calculating the add-on for a hedging set. The target definition makes clear that the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient “ε” is specified for the purpose of calculating the add-on of a hedging set, meaning it is an input that must be applied when performing that add-on calculation [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2]. The source definition then explains how to identify the coefficient for a particular hedging set: for hedging set j, the coefficient is written as εj and it is the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient of hedging set j, with the further requirement that it is determined in accordance with the referenced determination provision [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c]. Putting these together, when you calculate the add-on for hedging set j you should use εj (not a generic or ad hoc factor), and you must ensure the value you apply is the one determined under the applicable determination rule, because the coefficient is defined by both its role in the add-on calculation and its prescribed method of determination.
