question: If a firm (or an underwriting member of the Society of Lloyd’s, or someone who used to be one) is planning to apply to transfer insurance business or accept a transfer, does the PRA have to talk to the FCA before making some decisions, and who else is covered by the same Chapter 2 process?
gold_answer: Yes. In the context of insurance business transfers, the PRA explains that it sets out its expectations but will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions about a transfer, and it will try to avoid accidentally creating incompatible requirements [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. This matters for the scope of Chapter 2, because Chapter 2 is aimed at any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, when they are proposing to make an application to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme or to accept such a transfer [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. So, if you fall into that group and are planning a transfer or acceptance, you should expect that some PRA decision steps will involve prior FCA consultation as part of the overall regulatory handling of the transfer [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. Chapter 2 also covers the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report, meaning that the independent expert’s work is part of the same in-scope process in which the PRA’s coordination with the FCA is a stated feature [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f].
source_text: While this statement sets out the PRA’s expectations in relation to insurance business transfers, the PRA will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions in respect of a transfer and will seek to avoid introducing, inadvertently, incompatible requirements. 1 The FCA has also set out its own approach to and expectations in respect of insurance business transfers in SUP 18 of the FCA Handbook and FCA Final Guidance (FG) 18/4: The FCA’s approach to the review of Part VII insurance business transfers. 2
target_text: Chapter 2 is aimed at any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, proposing to make an application to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme under section 107 of the FSMA or to accept such a transfer. Chapter 2 is also aimed at the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report under section 109 of FSMA.

question: If the rules apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV and you have to treat “key function holder” as meaning “PRA senior management function holder,” who has to sign the record and each update, and does anyone else at the firm also need to sign?
gold_answer: When the requirements apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV, they apply as though any mention of a “key function holder” is instead a reference to a “PRA senior management function holder” [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c]. The signing requirement for the record (and every updated version of it) is that it must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Putting those two points together for a UK ISPV firm, the person who must sign in the “key function holder” capacity is the PRA senior management function holder (because that is how the reference is to be read), and there must also be a second signature from an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. This applies not only to the initial record but also to each updated version, so whenever the record is updated the same two signatures are required, with the UK ISPV role-substitution applied to identify the correct individual signer [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c].
source_text: The requirements in 5.4 and 5.6 apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV as if any reference to a key function holder were a reference to a PRA senior management function holder .
target_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .

question: For annual reports and accounts within the Chapter’s application dates, may an auditor treat the reporting obligation concerning the audited annual report and accounts of the firm’s ultimate parent undertaking as inapplicable where the auditor is not also the auditor of that ultimate parent undertaking?
gold_answer: The Chapter’s requirements apply in relation to annual reports and accounts by reference to the accounting reference date: it applies for accounting reference dates on or after 1 November 2016, but the specific provisions that include the relevant reporting framework apply only for accounting reference dates on or after 31 December 2018 [#SRC:857a0e15a398cd88]. Within that applicable population of annual reports and accounts, the auditor’s position on reporting about the audited annual report and accounts of the firm’s ultimate parent undertaking is qualified by an express exception: an auditor is not required to report in relation to those audited annual report and accounts if the auditor is not also the auditor of the ultimate parent undertaking [#TGT:f18969dc0a4b1513]. Accordingly, even where the Chapter (and, where relevant, the later-applying provisions) would otherwise govern the annual reports and accounts based on the accounting reference date, the auditor may rely on this condition to conclude that no reporting is required in respect of the ultimate parent undertaking’s audited annual report and accounts when the auditor does not hold that ultimate parent undertaking audit role [#SRC:857a0e15a398cd88] [#TGT:f18969dc0a4b1513].
source_text: This Chapter applies in relation to annual reports and accounts with an accounting reference date on or after 1 November 2016 but 8.3 (2) and (3) and 8.3A apply only in relation to annual reports and accounts with an accounting reference date on or after 31 December 2018.
target_text: But an auditor is not required to report in relation to the audited annual report and accounts of the firm’s ultimate parent undertaking if the auditor is not also the auditor of the ultimate parent undertaking .

question: If the Bank of England tells a firm it is (or is likely to be) above regulatory capital requirements for external or internal MREL, what MREL information does the firm need to give the PRA, and when might the PRA ask the firm to update it during the Phase 1 and Phase 2 process?
gold_answer: If the Bank of England has notified a firm that it is, or is likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements, the PRA expects the firm to provide information on MREL resources, including projected resources and the characteristics of individual instruments [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef]. This requirement is linked to the PRA’s phased information process. The PRA reviews Phase 1 submissions and, working with the Bank of England, decides a preferred resolution strategy for the firm; that decision then drives what information the PRA will request in Phase 2 [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9]. The PRA uses supervisory judgement to decide how much detail is needed in Phase 2 and tries to align requests with other supervisory work (such as business model, liquidity, or operational risk reviews) to reduce duplication. Because firms differ in structure, the PRA may require information beyond what is otherwise outlined. After Phase 2 information is provided, the PRA will notify firms when updates are required, and it may ask for refreshed data as the firm moves closer to resolution, so firms should be ready to update the MREL information when asked [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9].
source_text: The PRA will review Phase 1 submissions and, in conjunction with the Bank of England, will determine a preferred resolution strategy for the firm. This will define the information that should be requested in Phase 2 . Supervisory judgement will inform the breadth and depth of the information firms will be requested to provide in Phase 2 and, where possible, this will be integrated with other scheduled supervisory initiatives (eg business model analysis reviews, liquidity reviews, operational risk reviews) in order to avoid duplication of effort. The PRA expects firms that are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources as specified in Chapter 2 section A4 of this statement. Given the diversity of legal, financial and operational structures across firms, firms may be required to provide information beyond that which is outlined in this supervisory statement. The PRA will notify firms where updates are required to Phase 2 information. As firms move closer to resolution the PRA may ask for data to be updated.
target_text: The PRA expects firms that have been notified by the Bank of England that they are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources, projected resources, and individual instrument characteristics.

question: If a firm is working out surplus funds and deciding whether something counts as Tier 1 own funds, what does it need to do with the PRA Rulebook Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts, and when must it treat certain basic own funds items as having the right characteristics and classify them as Tier 1?
gold_answer: The firm needs to do two connected things. First, it should use the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook as the key reference when it calculates surplus funds and when it considers whether it meets the criteria for classifying an item as Tier 1 own funds; this includes looking to the parts that list own funds items and describe the features that determine Tier 1 classification [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e]. Second, for the basic own funds items covered by the TARGET, the firm must follow the rule that these items are treated as substantially having the relevant characteristics once the stated features are taken into account, and it must classify them as Tier 1 own funds when those items display all of the required features [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]. In practice, the “have regard” step sets the firm’s overall method for calculation and assessment, while the deeming-and-classification step creates a mandatory outcome for the specified basic own funds items when the full feature set is present.
source_text: Firms should have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and considering whether they meet the criteria for classification as Tier 1 own funds. In particular, Own Funds 3A sets out a list of own funds items and Own Funds 3B the features determining classification as Tier 1 own funds.
target_text: The following basic own funds items shall be deemed to substantially possess the characteristics set out in 3.5 , taking into consideration the features set out in 3.6 , and a firm must classify them as Tier 1 own funds , where the following items display all of the features set out in 3B :

question: If a firm needs to appoint an external auditor to carry out the required functions, what must the firm do before it appoints the auditor, and how does that fit with the requirement to appoint the external auditor in accordance with the auditor provisions?
gold_answer: The firm has to meet both requirements as part of one compliant appointment process. On the one hand, it must appoint an external auditor in accordance with the specified auditor provisions, and the appointment must be to perform the relevant functions referred to in that obligation [#SRC:6499d8de81f4da18]. On the other hand, the firm cannot wait until after appointment to check suitability: before it appoints an auditor, it must take reasonable steps to ensure that the auditor satisfies the required conditions that apply to the appointment decision [#TGT:08caa7c2d29f1956]. In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify the external auditor it proposes to appoint, (ii) carry out and record the “reasonable steps” checks required before appointment, and then (iii) complete the appointment in the manner required by the auditor provisions, so the external auditor is engaged to perform the relevant functions [#SRC:6499d8de81f4da18] [#TGT:08caa7c2d29f1956]. If the firm skips the pre-appointment reasonable-steps work, it would not be meeting the condition that applies specifically “before” the appointment, even if it otherwise appoints an external auditor for the functions.
source_text: (1) appoint an external auditor in accordance with Auditors 2 , 3 and 4 to perform the functions in 2 ; and
target_text: Before a firm appoints an auditor, it must take reasonable steps to ensure that the auditor:

question: When a firm is a member of a group whose parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is treated as an overseas jurisdiction for insurance group supervision, how does that affect whether the firm must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems comply with the Operational Resilience obligations, and are any group provisions disapplied in that scenario?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group that falls within the group categories that trigger the requirement, the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (noting the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3)) [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19]. However, the scope text also creates a conditional disapplication: where the firm is a member of a group covered by the specified group coverage condition, certain provisions (22.2, 22.3 and 22.4) do not apply if the third country in which the group’s parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated for insurance group supervision and the stated condition about the IRPR regulations applies [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]. Read together, the firm should treat the overseas-jurisdiction/third-country condition as narrowing which group-related provisions apply, while still meeting the group-level operational resilience compliance duty where the target obligation applies to the firm’s group category [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] and the source condition does not remove that duty [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8].
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , with the exception of Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3) , the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations set out in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 .

question: If a new DGS member has to work out its class A tariff base, how should it do the calculation, and when does it use a projected valuation of the business instead of something else?
gold_answer: A new DGS member is required to calculate its class A tariff base, so it must take an active step to determine that figure rather than leaving it unspecified [#SRC:f441f3fa763671cd]. The way the calculation is to be done is set by the procedural rule that, as the default position, A’s class A tariff base is calculated—when the calculation is needed—using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates [#TGT:7eeca38c43f8e855]. So, the member should start by checking whether the tariff base needs to be calculated in the particular situation (“where necessary”). If it does, the member should then base the tariff base on a projected valuation of the relevant business. The only time the member should not follow that projected-valuation approach is when the stated exception applies (“unless otherwise provided”), in which case the member would follow whatever alternative is provided for that exception. This ties the member’s obligation to calculate the tariff base to the specific method used to compute it.
source_text: A new DGS member must calculate its class A tariff base in accordance with 41.6 .
target_text: (1) Unless otherwise provided in (2), A’s class A tariff base is calculated, where necessary, using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates

question: If a firm changes its assumptions after a stress to update its forward-looking view of the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions, what must it do about increasing the fundamental spread, and which version of the spread should be increased?
gold_answer: If a firm has applied a stress and then changes assumptions to reflect an updated forward-looking view of the fundamental spread (FS), it must incorporate those assumption changes into the FS used for calculating technical provisions (TPs), including any changes to additions that had been made to the FS for TP purposes [#SRC:a7a361377b5193d9]. Separately, the firm is required to increase the fundamental spread that it has calculated under the applicable calculation steps, and it must do so in line with the specified increase requirement [#TGT:c7843cb82c6d586c]. Putting these together, the firm should not increase an earlier FS that ignores the post-stress assumption updates; instead, it should first update the FS to reflect the forward-looking view after the stress (and adjust any FS additions as needed for TP calculation) [#SRC:a7a361377b5193d9], and then apply the required increase to that updated calculated FS [#TGT:c7843cb82c6d586c]. This aligns the required increase with the same FS basis that is being used to calculate TPs.
source_text: (ii) assumption changes to reflect an updated forward-looking view of the FS following the stress, including any changes to additions made to the FS (as per Matching Adjustment 4.16 for assets with HP cash flows, or as per Matching Adjustment 4.17 for other reasons) for the purpose of calculating the TPs; and
target_text: A firm must increase the fundamental spread calculated under 4.10 to 4.15 in accordance with 8.2 .

question: May a firm treat a with-profits annuity contract as notionally split into parts so that only a component is included in an MA portfolio, and if so what conditions and supporting analysis does the PRA expect to ensure the included component is genuinely separable and not reliant on future premiums or investment performance?
gold_answer: A firm may include only a component of a with-profits annuity contract in an MA portfolio, but only where that component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in line with the IRPR requirements, and otherwise meets MA eligibility conditions [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]. This permission should not be treated as allowing a purely notional “split” of a contract into parts: the PRA does not view approaches that notionally split a contract into parts as compatible with Matching Adjustment 2. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e]. The PRA’s concern is that such notional treatments would undermine the insurer’s ability to manage its MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, which is a regulatory expectation referenced in both passages [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]. Accordingly, where a firm seeks to include a component, the PRA expects a detailed assessment demonstrating that only contractually guaranteed elements are included and that they are not dependent on future premiums (including structures where premiums may be paid as an initial sum followed by instalments) or future investment performance, and that the firm sets out a clear policy on the treatment of future attaching bonuses [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7].
source_text: Some contracts of insurance include an option for the premium to be paid as an initial sum followed by a series of further (smaller) instalments. Except in the limited cases set out in paragraphs 3.5A , 3.5B and 3.5C above, the PRA does not view any approach that notionally splits a contract into parts as being compatible with Matching Adjustment 2.3 . The PRA’s view is that such a treatment would also undermine the ability of the insurer to manage its MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, as required by regulation 4(6)(b) of the IRPR regulations.
target_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.

question: If a firm has several relevant agreements in place, when do the Chapter’s conditions kick in—only when the firm sells securities to a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm?
gold_answer: Yes, but only when you combine both scope statements. The SOURCE sets the scene by saying that where a firm has entered into a number of the relevant agreements, that fact is used for applying the later provisions it points to [#SRC:3cdb1069d838eb01]. The TARGET then explains what makes the Chapter’s conditions apply in the first place: the conditions are specified to apply if the firm sells securities to a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm [#TGT:cf080f440c4d0b75]. So, for a firm with multiple relevant agreements, you do not apply the Chapter’s conditions just because the agreements exist; you apply them when there is a sale of securities by the firm and the buyer is one of the two named types of entity. In practice, the firm should confirm (1) it is operating under multiple relevant agreements and (2) the transaction is a sale of securities to one of the specified counterparties; if both are true, the Chapter’s conditions apply in that scenario.
source_text: Where a firm has entered into a number of agreements described in 8.1 , for the purposes of 8.3 and 8.4 :
target_text: The conditions specified in this Chapter are that, if the firm sells securities to a CRD credit institution or a MiFID investment firm :

question: When, at the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, how must the firm reflect the resulting deemed acquisition or disposal of assets in the value ascribed to assets of each description?
gold_answer: Where the firm meets the definition that it must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option—specifically, at the relevant date it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised—the firm must treat the option as creating a deemed acquisition or disposal for valuation purposes [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157]. Once that definitional trigger is met, the firm has a corresponding obligation to adjust the values it has ascribed to assets: the value ascribed in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to the option [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]. In practice, this means the firm must (i) identify the relevant asset description affected by the option, (ii) determine the value of the assets of that description that are treated as deemed acquired or disposed of under the option, and (iii) apply that value as an increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description. The adjustment is required because the deemed transaction changes the firm’s position in those assets once the option is treated as effectively exercisable.
source_text: For the purposes of 20.1 , the firm must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option if, at the relevant date , it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised and the option is one which:
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .

question: This supervisory statement says it matters to banks, building societies and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) designated investment firms and explains the PRA’s expectations and Pillar 2 reporting clarity. How does the note that it was updated in 2016 and 2017, with details in an annex, affect how you should use it?
gold_answer: You should use the supervisory statement as guidance aimed at banks, building societies and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) designated investment firms, because it is presented as being of interest to those firms and as setting out the PRA’s expectations while giving further clarity on Pillar 2 reporting [#SRC:0438216f78dc5eb1]. At the same time, you should factor in that the statement has been revised before: it was previously updated in 2016 and 2017, and you are directed to the annex for the details of those updates [#TGT:266a62be9029c8b7]. Putting these together, the practical effect is that you should read the current expectations and reporting clarifications with an awareness that the document has a change history, and you should consult the annex to understand what was updated in those earlier versions. That helps ensure you are relying on the statement as it currently stands, while also understanding the context of prior updates that may explain how the expectations and Pillar 2 reporting clarity have been refined over time.
source_text: This supervisory statement is of interest to banks, building societies and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) designated investment firms. It sets out the PRA’s expectations of firms and provides further clarity on Pillar 2 reporting. 1
target_text: 1. This supervisory statement was previously updated in 2016 and 2017. See the annex for details.

question: For credit unions within the PRA’s expected scope for concentration limits based on asset size or holding certain investments, when may those limits be treated as inapplicable because the funds are only being held temporarily pending an investment decision, and how should that boundary be understood alongside the stated scope and exceptions?
gold_answer: Taken together, the two passages indicate that the PRA’s expectation to adhere to concentration limits applies to a defined set of credit unions—those with more than £10 million in total assets and any credit unions that hold investments falling under the specified Rules—subject to stated exceptions for certain investments. Within that overall scope, the PRA also indicates a specific circumstance in which the relevant limits are not intended to bite: where funds are held only temporarily in an account before an investment decision is made. In practice, this means a credit union that would otherwise be expected to follow the concentration limits because it meets the asset threshold or holds the relevant types of investments should treat the limits as not applying to the interim holding of cash-like balances that are merely parked pending a decision, rather than representing an investment position. This temporary-holding carve-out sits alongside (and does not replace) the broader scope statement and the separate exception for listed investments, so the credit union should distinguish between pre-decision temporary funds and actual investments to which the concentration limits are expected to apply. [#SRC:960de0d328d37ad1] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce]
source_text: The PRA considers that the limits in paragraph 11.1 would not apply to funds held temporarily in an account before an investment decision is made.
target_text: The PRA expects credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets, and any credit unions that hold investments that come under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, to adhere to the following concentration limits (in addition to the limits required by Rule 6.4A of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, 9 and with the exception of the investments listed in paragraph 11.2 ):

question: When a TWD firm plans for a wind-down, what does it need to project from the reference date through the wind-down period, and how must those projections be tied to capital resources and capital requirements (including trading book deductions and RWAs)?
gold_answer: A TWD firm needs to be able to project, from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, its expected exit costs, operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs, so the wind-down is supported by quantified estimates over time [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. Those projections must then be pulled together into a capital-focused view for the TWD scenario: the firm should include projections of capital resources impacts through the wind-down period that incorporate how the expected exit and operational costs and the RBLs affect capital resources, rather than leaving them as separate figures [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]. The firm should also forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and project how implementing the actions, arrangements and measures in the TWD option affects capital requirements in the TWD scenario [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]. This includes projecting RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks, ensuring the firm can explain how its wind-down steps and cost profile translate into capital requirements over the whole wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f].
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 26. This should include projections of capital resources impacts through the wind-down period in the TWD scenario, incorporating the impact of expected exit, operational costs and RBLs defined above on capital resources, as well as a forecast of the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and projections of the impact of the implementation of the actions, arrangements and measures set out as part of the TWD option on capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks.

question: If an assigned asset is not using the published tables for government and central bank assets, and it has a credit rating (or comparable internal assessment) that maps to credit quality steps 1–5, what must the firm do so the fundamental spread reflects rating-notch differences, and when does the “where possible and appropriate” limitation apply?
gold_answer: The firm must build rating-notch sensitivity into its treatment of the assigned asset in two connected ways. First, for assigned assets that do not use the published fundamental spread tables for assets issued by governments and central banks, the firm is required to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic fundamental spread, but only where this is possible and appropriate [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1]. Second, where the assigned asset has a credit rating or a comparable-standard internal credit assessment that maps to credit quality steps 1 to 5, a firm with a matching adjustment permission must make an adjustment to the fundamental spread that is derived from the credit quality step attributed to that asset so that it reflects the corresponding rating notch [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3]. The “where possible and appropriate” qualifier applies to the requirement to reflect notch differences in the basic fundamental spread for the relevant set of assigned assets, while the target obligation specifies that the firm must make a notch-reflecting adjustment for assets within steps 1–5 that meet the rating/assessment condition.
source_text: Firms are required to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic FS (where possible and appropriate) for all assigned assets that do not use published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. Matching Adjustment 6.1 requires the PD to be adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch. Firms are also required to reflect such differences in the basic FS, which can be done by either:
target_text: Where an assigned asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard (within the meaning of 7.1(1) ) mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), a firm with a matching adjustment permission must make an adjustment to the fundamental spread derived from the credit quality step attributed to that asset in order to reflect the corresponding rating notch , in accordance with 6.3 and 6.4 .

question: If a firm wants to restructure an asset using a wholly owned SPV, what must it check first about whether the asset would still be suitable if left unrestructured over time, and what must it do to show the restructure is acceptable and properly reflected across the firm and the group?
gold_answer: A firm should begin by considering whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that is consistent with how long the restructuring arrangement would last and with the possibility that operating conditions might change [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]. That initial check matters because the PRA expects these restructuring arrangements to be used only where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, such as pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]. If the firm still proposes to restructure, doing so through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group (an SPV) may be acceptable, but only if the proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]. The firm must also ensure the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring can create [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33].
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: For a firm that is a member of a group, when must it ensure that group-level strategies, processes and systems enable it to assess whether important group business services can stay within impact tolerance during a severe but plausible operational disruption, and in what circumstances does the group’s status mean that certain related provisions do not apply?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that, at the level of the group of which it is a member, the group’s strategies, processes and systems enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at group level could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9]. This obligation is framed to apply where the firm is a member of a group covered by the specified group-coverage conditions, including where the group is covered by the condition referenced in the scope provision [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9]. Separately, where a firm is a member of a group covered by that same group-coverage condition, certain provisions do not apply if additional criteria about the group’s parent undertaking are met: specifically, if the third country in which the group’s parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under the relevant regulation for insurance group supervision, and the referenced paragraph of that regulation applies [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]. In practice, the firm should treat the group-coverage status as the trigger for both the group-level assessment capability requirement and the potential disapplication of the specified provisions, subject to the third-country designation and applicability conditions [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8].
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at the level of the group could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.

question: A firm has policies that relate to certain listed areas and are set out in more detail elsewhere. What must the firm do to make sure its risk-management system uses those policies to continuously identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks (including linked risks) at both individual and overall levels?
gold_answer: A firm must connect its risk-management system to its policies that relate to the specified listed areas, which are described as being set out in further detail in the referenced materials [#SRC:01041daf6bcf6af2]. The firm’s obligation is not just to have policies, but to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system made up of strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that can work on a continuous basis [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. To satisfy both, the firm should use those policies to define what areas the system must cover, and then ensure the system’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures actually deliver continuous identification, measurement, monitoring, management, and reporting of the risks the firm is or could be exposed to. This must be done at the level of individual risks and also in aggregate, and it must take into account how risks depend on or affect each other (their interdependencies) [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].
source_text: (1) policies relating to the areas listed in (i) to (vi) in 3.1(2)(c) as set out in further detail in 3.1A and Chapter 2A ; and
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: In the older Annex 1 information sheet (Chapter 16) used before 01/12/2025, what are the key messages a customer should see about FSCS protection for deposits and the follow-on exclusions list?
gold_answer: In the past version of Annex 1 – Information Sheet (Chapter 16) used before 01/12/2025, the customer should see a short set of connected messages that explain both the benefit and the limits of deposit protection, and how to verify it in practice [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a]. The information sheet should say that the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (‘FSCS’) protects deposits made by most individuals and businesses, so customers understand that FSCS protection generally applies to deposits and covers many depositors [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. It should then tell the customer how to confirm whether their own deposits with [name of firm] are eligible, by explaining that the account statement will provide that confirmation [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. Finally, it should make clear that FSCS protection has exclusions and that the details of certain exclusions are provided in the exclusions list after the information sheet, so customers know where to find the exceptions [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. These points should be presented as part of the older Annex 1 information sheet context referenced above [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a].
source_text: Past version of Annex 1 – Information Sheet (Chapter 16) before 01/12/2025
target_text: The Financial Services Compensation Scheme (‘FSCS’) protects deposits made by most individuals and businesses. Your account statement will confirm whether your deposits with [name of firm] are eligible for FSCS protection. Details of certain exclusions from the FSCS’s protection are set out in the exclusions list after this information sheet.

question: When applying the PRA’s supervisory statement on algorithmic trading, how should a firm treat the cross-reference to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565, and what does that Regulation cover in terms of organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s supervisory statement as setting out the PRA’s expectations for the firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, while also using it in conjunction with the referenced EU instrument where relevant. Specifically, the supervisory statement indicates it is intended to be read alongside Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 (where applicable), meaning the firm should align its approach to algorithmic trading governance and risk management with the organisational requirements and operating conditions framework addressed by that Regulation, rather than viewing the supervisory statement in isolation [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2]. The referenced Regulation is described as supplementing Directive 2014/65/EU as regards organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, and it also addresses defined terms for the purposes of that Directive [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]. Taken together, the supervisory statement provides the PRA’s supervisory expectations for algorithmic trading risk management and governance, and the Regulation provides the broader EU-level organisational and operating conditions context for investment firms that the firm should consider when the cross-reference is applicable [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3].
source_text: This supervisory statement (SS) sets out the PRA’s expectations of a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading and should be read alongside: Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 on organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms 1 (if applicable); the General Organisational Requirements Part and Risk Control Part of the PRA Rulebook; European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) Guidelines on systems and controls in automated trading environment trading platforms; 2 Joint ESMA and European Banking Authority (EBA) Guidelines on the assessment of suitability of members of the management body and key function holders; 3 and EBA Guidelines on internal governance. 4
target_text: 1. Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 of 25 April 2016 supplementing Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms and defined terms for the purposes of that Directive.

question: If you group policies, what must you do so the best estimate work is clear and a qualified expert can check it, while also showing that the grouping of policies is appropriate?
gold_answer: If policies are grouped, you must ensure two things are met together: the grouping itself is appropriate, and the best estimate calculation remains transparent and reviewable by a qualified expert. The grouping decision should therefore be treated as part of the calculation design, not separate from it. You should set up the best estimate so that a qualified expert can follow how the calculation method works under the chosen grouping and can also see how the results come out of that method. This requires presenting the method and results in a way that makes the impact of the grouping understandable and traceable, so an expert reviewer can assess whether the approach is sound and whether the outputs are consistent with the method used. In other words, the grouping must be justified as appropriate [#SRC:454105ea3e8bfc14], and the best estimate must be calculated transparently with a method and results that are capable of review by a qualified expert [#TGT:d7e9f9c8806d968f].
source_text: (b) the appropriateness of any grouping of policies in accordance with Technical Provisions - Further Requirements 19 ;
target_text: The best estimate is to be calculated in a transparent manner and in such a way as to ensure that the calculation method and the results that derive from it are capable of review by a qualified expert.

question: If a firm holds assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, what must it do to find all the cash flow timing/amount uncertainties and make sure the extra risks from cash flow variability are properly covered in the FS, and what does the PRA expect the firm to write down?
gold_answer: If a firm includes assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, it must recognise that these assets are likely to add extra risk and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required to provision for those additional risks [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. The firm must also identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for those uncertainties, so that the FS outcome reflects the full set of relevant uncertainties rather than only a subset [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. Alongside this, the firm should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, using the guidance referenced in the source passage to support that assessment [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. The PRA expects the firm to document the details of the sources of uncertainty it has identified and to document how it has allowed for them, providing a clear record that the FS increases and other FS additions are grounded in the firm’s identified variability and uncertainty drivers [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121].
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: Assets with HP cash flows are likely to introduce additional risks into firms’ MA portfolios and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required (in accordance with Matching Adjustment 4.16 ) to provision for these additional risks. As required by Chapter 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part , firms must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for these. The PRA expects firms to document details of these sources of uncertainty and how they have allowed for them.

question: If, on the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume it will be exercised, what must the firm do to the values it has assigned to each type of asset to reflect the assets it is treated as having bought or sold under that option?
gold_answer: If the firm is, at the relevant date, a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised, the rules treat the firm as having acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to that option [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157]. When that deemed acquisition or disposal applies, the firm must not leave its asset values unchanged. Instead, for assets of each description, the value the firm has ascribed must be increased or decreased by the value of the assets of that same description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under the option [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]. So the firm must first decide whether the option meets the “deemed” test (party to the option at the relevant date, and prudent to assume exercise). Then it must identify which asset description the option relates to and calculate the value of the assets that are treated as deemed acquired or disposed of. Finally, it must apply that amount as an upward or downward adjustment to the ascribed value for that asset description, ensuring the valuation reflects the option-driven deemed change in the firm’s asset position.
source_text: For the purposes of 20.1 , the firm must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option if, at the relevant date , it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised and the option is one which:
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .

question: Where a firm is determining whether an outsourcing or third party arrangement is a material outsourcing arrangement (including one that would be treated as critical or important under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules), what must the firm do in applying the PRA’s materiality assessment criteria, and how should the firm treat the mere presence of ICT products or services in that assessment?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s term “material outsourcing” as intentionally broader and clearer terminology that, for all intents and purposes, includes arrangements that would be regarded as “critical or important outsourcing” under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules, with the identification criteria being substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL subject to justified exceptions (including references to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements) [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]. When the firm is assessing whether an outsourcing or third party arrangement is material (in particular, where it is not otherwise covered by the specified earlier paragraphs), the PRA expects the firm to have regard to all applicable criteria in the relevant table, considering those criteria both individually and together, rather than relying on a single factor [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1]. In applying that criteria-based assessment, the firm should not assume that an arrangement is automatically material simply because it involves an ICT product or service (for example, cloud); ICT presence may be common in practice but is not determinative on its own [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1].
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms to have regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5 below, both individually and in conjunction, when assessing the materiality of an outsourcing or third party arrangement not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9 . Although in practice many material outsourcing and third party arrangements involve ICT products or services (eg cloud), the presence of a given ICT product or service does not, in itself, automatically render an outsourcing arrangement material.

question: How must a managing agent structure its management of syndicates to ensure general insurance business and long-term insurance business are kept separately managed, given the prohibition on allowing both classes to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages (subject to limited exceptions)?
gold_answer: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and explains that, in practice, this means managing agents must separately manage syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. This obligation aligns with the prohibition that a managing agent must not permit both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate managed by it, except where an exception applies [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6]. Accordingly, the default compliance approach is to avoid any single syndicate carrying on both classes and instead allocate each class to different syndicates under separate management arrangements. Where a single syndicate does carry on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business pursuant to the exceptions referenced in the Composites material, the source notes that paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to assist in determining how the requirements of the Composites Part apply to managing agents in that scenario [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8], consistent with the target’s “except where” carve-out [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6].
source_text: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business. In practical terms, this requires that managing agents separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business. However, where a single syndicate carries on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business pursuant to the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2 , paragraphs 3.1 – 3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to assist in determining how the requirements of the Composites Part will apply to managing agents.

question: If the FSCS cannot recover some amounts from DGS members because of the levy process, must the FSCS still stay within the yearly levy cap, and when (if ever) can it charge more?
gold_answer: Yes. Even if there are amounts that the FSCS has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of the relevant levy outcomes described in the source, the FSCS is still constrained by the rule that sets a maximum annual amount of DGS compensation costs it can levy on DGS members [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380]. Specifically, the FSCS must not set the maximum amount of DGS compensation costs for which it can levy DGS members per calendar year above 0.5% of total covered deposits (excluding temporary high balances) of all DGS members [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860]. The unrecovered-amounts situation explains that some sums may remain unpaid or uncollected from DGS members, but it does not itself authorize the FSCS to exceed the cap [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380]. The only stated way the FSCS can levy more than the cap is if there are exceptional circumstances and the FSCS has the prior consent of the PRA; without that consent (and without exceptional circumstances), charging above the cap is prohibited [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860].
source_text: (2) amounts that the FSCS has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of 33.3 or 33.4 ; or
target_text: The maximum amount of DGS compensation costs for which the FSCS can levy DGS members per calendar year must not exceed 0.5% of total covered deposits (excluding temporary high balances ) of all DGS members . The FSCS may in exceptional circumstances and with the prior consent of the PRA impose higher levies.

question: When a credit union undertakes more complex investments and is expected to follow the investment expectations in Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1–11.6), how should it classify a subordinated loan it provides for the purposes of this Chapter, and what does that classification imply for whether the Chapter 11 investment expectations apply to that instrument?
gold_answer: A credit union that invests in more complex investments is expected to adhere to the investment expectations set out in Chapter 11, specifically paragraphs 11.1–11.6 [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4]. For the purposes of this Chapter, however, the definition of what counts as an “investment” excludes certain instruments: the term criterion is that “a loan is not an investment” where it is “provided by a credit union on subordinated terms” [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. Read together, this means the credit union must first determine whether the instrument in question is a loan it provides on subordinated terms; if so, it is treated as not being an investment for the purposes of this Chapter (i.e., it falls outside the Chapter’s investment classification) [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]. The expectation to adhere to Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1–11.6) is framed as applying when the credit union “invest[s] in more complex investments,” so the subordinated loan, being defined as not an investment for this Chapter, is not captured by that investment classification trigger even though the credit union remains within the broader context of Chapter 11 expectations for its more complex investments [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4].
source_text: Credit unions that invest in more complex investments under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook are expected to adhere to the investment expectations set out in Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1-11.6 ).
target_text: For the purposes of this Chapter, a loan is not an investment if it is provided by a credit union on subordinated terms.

question: When calculating the value ascribed to assets of each description, how must the firm adjust that value to reflect assets it is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under both an option and a futures contract?
gold_answer: In valuing assets of each description, the firm must not leave the ascribed value static where deemed transactions arise from derivatives. Instead, it must adjust the value ascribed to the relevant asset description by making a corresponding increase or decrease that reflects the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of. This adjustment obligation applies where the deemed acquisition or disposal arises pursuant to an option, requiring the firm to incorporate the value impact of the option-driven deemed position into the ascribed value for that asset description [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124]. The same adjustment mechanism also applies where the deemed acquisition or disposal arises pursuant to a futures contract, again requiring the firm to increase or decrease the ascribed value by the value of the assets of that description implicated by the futures-driven deemed position [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d]. Read together, the requirements ensure consistent treatment across both instruments: for each asset description, the firm must translate deemed acquisitions/disposals under options and futures contracts into an increase or decrease to the ascribed value, aligned to the value of the affected assets.
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract.

question: When testing governance arrangements for recovery planning, what must a firm do to ensure that the board and the relevant business areas can rapidly use the recovery plan to make strategic decisions in a stress, including through assembling the right people at short notice?
gold_answer: A firm should design and test its governance arrangements so that, in a stress, the recovery plan can be used immediately by the board and the specific business areas that would need to act, and so that the board can quickly navigate and understand the plan in order to take key decisions [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d]. In practice, this means that governance testing should include a realistic exercise of convening the right people at short notice and checking whether those participants can actually use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions, rather than merely confirming that the document exists or is complete [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc]. The test should therefore focus on usability: whether the plan’s structure supports rapid orientation by the board, and whether the relevant business areas can locate and apply the information they need to execute their roles. By linking the governance test to the plan’s navigability and decision-support function, the firm can evidence that the recovery plan is structured for real-time use by decision-makers and implementers, consistent with the PRA’s expectation.
source_text: testing the governance arrangements. This might include assembling the right people at short notice and understanding whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions. This would test the usefulness of the ‘playbook’ (see ‘ (vii) Playbooks and structure of recovery plans ’ below);
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: For the period covered by the past version addressing disclosure of the leverage ratio before 31/03/2025, what must Institutions do to meet the required leverage ratio disclosure obligation, and how should they treat the fact that the applicable context is a past version tied to that pre‑31/03/2025 timeframe?
gold_answer: Institutions must make leverage ratio disclosures in line with the specified disclosure requirement, and they must do so within the context that the relevant disclosure framework is explicitly framed as a past version addressing disclosure of the leverage ratio before 31/03/2025. The SOURCE establishes that the applicable context is a “Past version” focused on “Disclosure of the Leverage Ratio before 31/03/2025,” which signals that the obligation is being applied with reference to that earlier, time-bounded version rather than a later iteration [#SRC:0560c5d9ce5b155f]. The TARGET then sets the operative duty: “Institutions shall make the disclosures on the leverage ratio” and indicates that these disclosures are the ones required under the referenced CRR disclosure requirement, to be made “as follows,” i.e., according to the prescribed approach that follows in the rule text [#TGT:f531114f03d67d24]. Read together, Institutions should ensure they are producing the leverage ratio disclosures that are required, while aligning their compliance assessment and documentation to the pre‑31/03/2025 past-version context indicated in the SOURCE.
source_text: Past version of Article 7 Disclosure of the Leverage Ratio before 31/03/2025
target_text: Institutions shall make the disclosures on the leverage ratio , required in Article 451 of the CRR as follows:

question: When doing Identification of Key Functions, what exactly does the firm need to list, based on what the firm itself thinks is a key function?
gold_answer: When the firm carries out Identification of Key Functions, it needs to produce an identification that covers the full set of functions that meet its own definition of “key.” The SOURCE makes clear that the relevant compliance activity is specifically the Identification of Key Functions exercise [#SRC:4b63d605a75385d7]. The TARGET then clarifies what the firm must capture as the outcome of that exercise: it must identify each of the functions that the firm considers to be a key function [#TGT:0254821a38c334e7]. Put simply, the firm should not treat this as a partial or sample list; it should ensure that every function the firm regards as key is included. The emphasis is on the firm’s own assessment (“considers to be”), so the firm must apply its internal judgment consistently and make sure the identification reflects that judgment across all relevant functions. This ties the topic (Identification of Key Functions) to a concrete deliverable (a complete list of the functions the firm itself treats as key) as required by the paired texts.
source_text: (1) 4 (Identification of Key Functions); and
target_text: (1) each of the functions that the firm considers to be a key function ; and

question: When the PRA’s expectations apply to how firms disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme, what must a firm do if it leaves the scheme or is kicked out, and by when must depositors be told?
gold_answer: The source explains the scope and context for disclosure by stating that the chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme, and that it is intended to be read together with the rules in the Depositor Protection Part of the PRA Rulebook (Chapters 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23) [#SRC:e2e3d0af57f2615a]. Against that disclosure framework, the target imposes a clear obligation tied to a specific event: a firm must inform depositors within one month if it withdraws from or is excluded from the deposit guarantee scheme [#TGT:b611159cf94e0b70]. Putting the two together, the PRA’s expectations describe how firms should approach disclosures about the scheme generally, while the target identifies a particular disclosure that becomes mandatory when the firm’s participation status changes (withdrawal or exclusion) and fixes the deadline as “within one month” [#SRC:e2e3d0af57f2615a] [#TGT:b611159cf94e0b70]. In practice, the firm should treat this one-month notification as a required depositor communication within the broader scheme-disclosure expectations and related rule context.
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme and is intended to be read together with the rules contained in Chapters 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 22 and 23 of the Depositor Protection Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: A firm must inform depositors within one month if it withdraws from or is excluded from the deposit guarantee scheme .

question: If an institution has to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions within six months after something happens, can it still use one exposure value for all transactions under a contractual netting agreement, and what must it do if the netting conditions are not met?
gold_answer: An institution has an obligation to stop calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions using the specified approach within six months after a triggering event occurs [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Separately, institutions are allowed to calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement, but only if all the required conditions for that treatment are satisfied [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. If those conditions are not satisfied, the institution must not combine the transactions and instead must calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each transaction as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Putting these together: the netting rule tells the institution when it may use one combined exposure value versus when it must use separate exposure values per transaction, while the other rule imposes a deadline to cease the specified exposure‑value calculation method for derivative positions after a trigger [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c].
source_text: An institution shall cease to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, within six months of one of the following occurring:
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If Firms use historical data to set internal model parameters, what must they do to avoid missing quantifiable risks, and what does the rule require about the quality of the data used in the internal model?
gold_answer: Firms must not assume that parameterising the internal model using only historical data will automatically reflect all quantifiable risks. Because the concept of ENID also applies to the data used to set the parameters, Firms need to consider whether their approach captures risks beyond what is directly visible in past observations and whether it reflects the full range of possible future events [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645]. Where Firms intend to rely on an unadjusted distribution based on historical data, they must be able to show that it captures that full range, for example by using stress and scenario testing to demonstrate that future-event variability is adequately represented [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645]. Alongside this, the rule requires that the data used for the internal model is accurate, complete and appropriate, so Firms must ensure the dataset is correct, not missing material elements, and suitable for the modelling purpose rather than merely available or convenient [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0]. Together, these requirements mean Firms should pair strong data-quality checks with evidence that their parameterisation approach is not narrowly backward-looking.
source_text: The concept of ENID also applies to the data used to set the parameters for the internal model, in line with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11.4 . Firms should not assume that parameterising the internal model using only historical data will take into account all quantifiable risks, unless an unadjusted distribution has been shown to capture the full range of possible future events, for example by way of stress and scenario testing.
target_text: (1) Data used for the internal model must be accurate, complete and appropriate.

question: For operational shared services, what contract documentation must firms provide to support continuity of key services in resolution and to ensure contractual terms do not permit termination in resolution, and how does this align with the contract documentation expectations referenced in the source outline?
gold_answer: Firms must provide contract documentation that covers the arrangements underpinning operational shared services so that key services can be maintained in resolution and contractual terms do not allow termination solely because the firm has entered resolution. In practice, this means supplying documentation for relevant service agreements and for relationships with market counterparties, because these are the contract types explicitly identified as necessary to evidence continuity and non-termination protections. The source outline frames this requirement within the broader contract documentation workstream (alongside loss absorbing capacity, intra-group exposures, and operational shared services), indicating that contract documentation is a distinct deliverable area that must be addressed when considering shared services dependencies [#SRC:20d1801fb38ba071]. The target further specifies the purpose and expected content: providing the documentation enables the authorities to assess whether key services can be maintained in resolution and whether contracts prevent termination in resolution, based on the service agreements and market counterparty contracts supplied by firms [#TGT:a7d44660114f92da].
source_text: A1.1 Loss absorbing capacity: equity and liability structures A1.2 Intra-group exposures A1.3 Contract documentation A1.4 Operational shared services

question: For purposes of a TWD scenario, how must a TWD firm determine what constitutes an exit cost for positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated, and how should that defined exit cost be incorporated into the firm’s ability to project exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period?
gold_answer: A TWD firm’s obligation to be able to project its exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period requires it to apply the defined meaning of “exit cost” when identifying and quantifying those projected amounts [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. Under the definition, an exit cost is not simply any expense of winding down; it is specifically the gap between (i) the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and (ii) the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that, under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario, are to be novated, terminated or liquidated [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. Accordingly, when projecting exit costs over the wind-down period, the firm should (a) identify the relevant positions subject to novation, termination, or liquidation under its TWD actions and measures, (b) estimate the expected exit value for those positions under the TWD scenario, and (c) compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to calculate the gap that constitutes the exit cost. This defined gap then forms the basis of the firm’s exit cost projections across the relevant timeframe [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 24. An exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and accounting book value for positions to be novated, terminated or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario.

question: In documenting the calculation workflow, what linkage must be shown between the defined meaning of the multiplier as a formula-based multiplication factor and the mandatory calculation steps that apply for the stated purpose?

The procedural text then imposes a mandatory requirement that, for the relevant purpose, the multiplier “shall be calculated as follows,” which means the firm must follow the prescribed calculation steps rather than an informal or approximate method [#TGT:bd4335a117dddc31]. question: What is this statement trying to do, and where should you look to see the Prudential Regulation Authority’s wider approach to insurance supervision that the statement builds on?
gold_answer: The statement’s purpose is to add detail to the PRA’s general approach that is already set out in its Approach Document, and it is intended to help ensure the PRA meets its statutory objectives. Those objectives are ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders [#SRC:b4560df99bbb6972]. To see the wider supervisory approach that the statement is expanding, you should consult the Prudential Regulation Authority’s approach to insurance supervision, which the PRA makes available through its published material at the referenced Bank of England webpage [#TGT:6ecb47c731ad66dc]. Using both together matters: the published approach provides the overall framework for how the PRA supervises insurance, and the statement provides further explanation that is meant to support the PRA’s ability to achieve its safety-and-soundness and policyholder-protection aims. In practice, you should read the statement in the context of the broader approach described in the PRA’s published supervision materials, rather than treating it as separate from that framework.
source_text: This statement expands on the PRA’s general approach as set out in its Approach Document, 2 and is designed to help ensure the PRA meets its statutory objectives of ensuring safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders.
