question: When determining the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, what must be done to ensure the best estimate calculation remains transparent and can be reviewed by a qualified expert, and how should the grouping decision be reflected in the calculation approach and outputs?
gold_answer: When assessing the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, the best estimate must still be calculated transparently and in a way that enables a qualified expert to review both the calculation method and the resulting outputs. This means the grouping approach cannot be treated as a purely administrative step; it must be integrated into the best estimate methodology so that an expert reviewer can understand how the grouping was selected, how it affects the calculation method, and how it influences the results. In practice, the calculation should be structured and documented so that the link between the grouping of policies and the best estimate is clear, including how the grouping is applied within the method and how the results “derive from it” under that grouping. The overall objective is that the grouping is demonstrably appropriate while the best estimate remains capable of independent expert review, with transparency over both method and outcomes as required [#TGT:d7e9f9c8806d968f] and with explicit consideration of the appropriateness of any grouping of policies [#SRC:454105ea3e8bfc14].
source_text: (b) the appropriateness of any grouping of policies in accordance with Technical Provisions - Further Requirements 19 ;
target_text: The best estimate is to be calculated in a transparent manner and in such a way as to ensure that the calculation method and the results that derive from it are capable of review by a qualified expert.

question: If a firm is preparing a submission and needs the MREL-related taxonomy or later updates, where should it look, and what is the exact Bank of England webpage it is being sent to?
gold_answer: When a firm is preparing a submission and needs the MREL-related taxonomy, plus any additional materials and updates, it should be referred to the Bank’s website as the place to obtain those resources [#SRC:1e283699ee1a4205]. The related reference then tells you exactly where on the Bank of England site those materials are available: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/regulatory-reporting/regulatory-reporting-banking-sector [#TGT:80a7be360fe010b6]. Using both pieces together, the instruction is not just “go to the Bank’s website,” but “go to this specific regulatory reporting banking sector page” to access the taxonomy and any updated supporting materials. This matters for submission purposes because it points firms to a single maintained location for the MREL-related taxonomy and for any later updates, rather than treating the taxonomy as static or contained only within the submission process documentation [#SRC:1e283699ee1a4205], and it provides the precise web address that implements that referral [#TGT:80a7be360fe010b6].
source_text: For submission purposes, firms are referred to the Bank’s website for the MREL-related taxonomy and any additional materials and updates. 10
target_text: 10. Available at www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/regulatory-reporting/regulatory-reporting-banking-sector .

question: When an institution is using the methods in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, under what conditions may it use the Section 4 method to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions, specifically in relation to how the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is determined and assessed over time?
gold_answer: For an institution that is within the scope of institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the relevant measure for determining the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is the size as calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2), as applicable [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1]. Against that scoped sizing approach, the institution is permitted to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method set out in Section 4 only if it meets the stated preconditions: it must be subject to the restriction referenced for this permission, and it must satisfy the requirement that the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is equal to or less than both thresholds specified for the permission [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]. In addition, the threshold condition is not a one-off test: it must be determined on the basis of an assessment carried out on a monthly basis using data as of the last day of the month, meaning the institution’s eligibility to use the Section 4 method depends on ongoing monthly assessment of that size measure [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2].

question: What does the Head of Overseas Branch need to do so the PRA gets the information it expects, and how does the PRA’s annual meeting with the CEO or the CRO for systemic wholesale branches help the PRA see the financial and operational risks of international banks?
gold_answer: The Head of Overseas Branch is expected to make sure the PRA receives the information the PRA expects for all branches, so the supervisor can get the access it needs to understand what is happening in the branch and how it fits within the wider authorised entity. This directly links to the PRA’s broader expectations for access to information that gives it appropriate visibility of the financial and operational risks of international banks [#TGT:5538cf7dcc92ba9b]. For systemic wholesale branches, the PRA builds this into its supervisory programme by expecting to meet at least annually, as part of existing annual meetings, with the CEO or the CRO (or both) of the authorised entity that the branch is part of. The purpose of that meeting is to discuss the PRA’s expectations on information sharing for the firm, which helps the PRA confirm that the right information is being provided and that information-sharing arrangements are working as the PRA expects [#SRC:34b9ba610e4d38a6].
source_text: The PRA will look to the Head of Overseas Branch (SMF19) to ensure it receives the requisite information it expects for all branches. For systemic wholesale branches, as part of its supervisory programme, the PRA will expect to meet at least annually as part of existing annual meetings with the CEO or the CRO, or both, of the authorised entity of which the branch is part, to discuss the PRA’s expectations on information sharing, as outlined in Box 1 , for the firm.
target_text: The PRA’s expectations for access to information to ensure appropriate visibility of the financial and operational risks of international banks

question: If Institutions have to publish the information covered by Titles II and III, what do they need to do so that the written explanation and any extra supporting information around the numbers is clear enough for users to understand the numbers, and where should that explanation appear in relation to the templates?
gold_answer: Institutions must publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in line with the applicable disclosure provisions, while recognising that this duty is subject to the stated exceptions. [#TGT:8764079e3800c628] When those public disclosures include quantitative disclosures, any qualitative narrative and any other necessary supplementary information that accompanies the quantitative disclosures must be written so it is adequately clear and comprehensive. The purpose of this requirement is to enable users of information to understand the quantitative disclosures, so the narrative and supplementary information must directly support comprehension of the figures rather than merely restating them. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] Institutions must also place that qualitative narrative and supplementary information next to the templates that the narrative describes, so users can read the explanation alongside the relevant quantitative templates. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] In practice, this means the public disclosure package should combine the required published information with adjacent, user-focused narrative that is sufficiently complete to make the quantitative disclosures understandable, consistent with the overall public disclosure obligation. [#TGT:8764079e3800c628]
source_text: The qualitative narrative and any other necessary supplementary information accompanying quantitative disclosures in accordance with Article 431 of the CRR shall be adequately clear and comprehensive, enabling users of information to understand the quantitative disclosures and shall be placed next to the templates, which they describe.
target_text: Institutions shall publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in accordance with the provisions laid down in this Title, subject to the exceptions referred to in Article 432 .

question: If a rule says certain responsibilities are “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities,” but another provision says those prescribed responsibilities do not apply, what does that mean for a third country CRR firm? Please define what counts as a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” and then explain the effect of the non-application statement.
gold_answer: A “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” is defined by reference to the responsibilities listed in the relevant rule: subject to a stated condition, each responsibility set out in that rule is treated as a third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105]. However, the scope provision then states that the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities do not apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. Putting these together, the responsibilities can still be identified and labelled under the definition (because they are “responsibilities set out in this rule” and therefore fall within the defined category when the definition’s condition is satisfied) [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105], but the separate scope statement removes any requirement for the third country CRR firm to comply with them because they are expressly stated not to apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. In other words, the definition tells you what the category would include, while the scope statement tells you that, for the third country CRR firm, that category is switched off for applicability purposes.

question: If Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiaries of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, where must the group solvency calculation be done, and do the rules that apply “with any necessary changes” also apply at that holding company level even if it is not based in the UK or Gibraltar?
gold_answer: If Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company, the solvency of the group must be calculated at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company, using the set of requirements identified for that calculation [#TGT:bfadda41c802247a]. The separate scope provision then explains how other related requirements are meant to operate at that same level: when its stated condition is met, it applies a specified range of provisions (including External Audit provisions) “with any necessary changes” at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. It also makes clear that this adapted, holding-company-level application is contemplated even where the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, and it also references third country insurance undertaking and third country reinsurance undertaking, while indicating there is an exception introduced by an “unless” clause [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Together, these passages mean the calculation is anchored at the holding company level, and the surrounding requirements are intended to be applied at that level in an adjusted way, within the stated scope limits.
source_text: When 2.1(3) applies, 4 to 14 , 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking unless:
target_text: (1) Where Solvency II undertakings in a group are subsidiary undertakings of an insurance holding company or a mixed financial holding company , the calculation of the solvency of the group must be carried out at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company applying 7.1(2) to 12 .

question: If you need to check whether the PRA has formally put certain EU Guidelines into effect after the implementation period, what should you note about the PRA’s position and what date should you tie it to?
gold_answer: You should note that, according to the Statement of Policy (SoP) on the “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations: Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU,” the PRA has not formally implemented the relevant Guidelines that came into force after the implementation period [#SRC:64fc82fb669b5a5f]. You should also tie that note to the SoP reference date provided in the related citation information, which is December 2020, and keep the associated link as evidence of which SoP is being relied upon [#TGT:66acc6070f5817e8]. Using both points together makes your compliance record clearer: it shows (1) the PRA’s stated approach to Guidelines that became effective after the implementation period, and (2) the specific dated SoP reference you used when reaching that conclusion. This helps ensure your internal analysis is consistent and traceable to the cited SoP reference date.

question: If a credit union must make sure a member’s total non-deferred shares do not go over the allowed maximum, does it have to count an increase in the percentage of non-deferred shares held by that member when checking the limits, and what conditions apply?
gold_answer: The credit union’s compliance check must combine the TARGET obligation with the SOURCE counting rule. Under the TARGET, Subject to 2.3 and 2.4, a credit union must ensure that a member does not have non-deferred shares in the credit union which in aggregate exceed the greater of the applicable limit. When assessing that requirement against the limits in 2.2, the SOURCE provides a specific treatment for a particular type of change: “the increase in the percentage of the non-deferred shares held by that member is disregarded for the purposes of the limits in 2.2.” Practically, this means that if the member’s position involves an increase in the percentage of non-deferred shares held by that member, the credit union should not count that percentage increase when applying the limits in 2.2 as part of determining whether the member’s aggregate non-deferred shares exceed the greater-of cap described in the TARGET. The credit union must still perform the aggregation and ensure the member does not exceed the maximum, but it must do so while disregarding that percentage increase for the stated purpose and within the “Subject to 2.3 and 2.4” conditions. [#SRC:409fe036e0477549] [#TGT:20f46de0cd0e38dc]

question: For a CRR firm doing its self-assessment, what does it need to take into account from the CRR consolidation entity’s work, and what must the CRR consolidation entity assess about each group member’s ability to stay within impact tolerance if there is a severe but plausible disruption?
gold_answer: A CRR firm’s self-assessment must look beyond the firm itself and identify any additional risks to its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances that come from elsewhere in its group. Because it is a CRR firm, that self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken about important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance [#SRC:525172756112897c]. Separately, the CRR consolidation entity must carry out a specific assessment: for each important group business service, it must assess whether each member of its consolidation group that provides that service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service if there were a severe but plausible disruption to its operations [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]. In practice, the CRR firm should use the CRR consolidation entity’s group-level assessment to inform its own view of group-driven risks and the likelihood of remaining within impact tolerances during disruption.
source_text: identify any additional risks to their ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances arising from elsewhere in their group. In the case of a CRR firm, the self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken to comply with the requirements under Rules 8.6 , 8.7 and 8.8 , regarding important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance.
target_text: A CRR consolidation entity must assess whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group providing each important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that important group business service in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.

question: If you need to cite the EBA document about the minimum qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, what is the document called and where can someone find it online?
gold_answer: You should cite the document by its name as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” which makes clear that it covers both qualitative and quantitative indicators and that it is focused on recovery plan indicators and a minimum list [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. To help someone actually locate the official text, you should also include the online location where it is available by pointing to the EBA webpage indicated as the access source, i.e., the “Available at” link to the EBA site hosting the guidelines [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Using both elements together in your citation or internal reference note ensures that readers understand exactly which EBA guidelines you mean and have a direct route to retrieve the authoritative version from the EBA’s own publication page. This is especially useful when sharing recovery planning materials internally or with reviewers, because it links the named guidelines to the official online source.
source_text: the EBA ‘Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators’; 3
target_text: 3. Available at: https://www.eba.europa.eu/activities/single-rulebook/regulatory-activities/recovery-resolution-and-dgs/guidelines-recovery .

question: If a firm is treated as having bought or sold assets because of an option, what must it do to the value it has assigned to those assets, and how does that affect how the firm must work out its exposure to that type of asset?
gold_answer: The firm must first assign a value to assets of each description using the valuation method required by the Part. That means the value must be determined in accordance with the rules in the Part, or—if there is no specific valuation provision for that kind of asset—it must be the amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer of the asset [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]. After that initial value is set, the firm must adjust it for option-driven deemed transactions: the value ascribed for assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124]. The adjusted value is not just informational; it is then used to determine exposure. Specifically, the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets as required for exposure determination under the Part [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]. So, deemed option acquisitions/disposals change the asset value, and that changed value is what drives the exposure figure.
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: A firm must recognise and value deferred taxes for all assets and liabilities recognised for solvency or tax purposes. When doing that, how can the firm rely on IFRS consistency to show IFRS use would not be disproportionately costly, while still meeting the other valuation requirements that continue to apply?
gold_answer: The firm’s starting point is that it must recognise and value deferred taxes for all assets and liabilities that are recognised for solvency or tax purposes, and this includes technical provisions, so the work must cover the full set of relevant balance sheet items rather than a limited subset [#TGT:d84bdc975f6ad72f]. In meeting that obligation, the firm can frame its valuation approach by noting that the relevant provisions are consistent with IFRS and, on that basis, using IFRS would not impose disproportionate costs; this supports the firm’s decision to use IFRS methods or measurements when valuing deferred tax impacts connected to those provisions [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610]. However, the firm must also treat the IFRS-consistency point as operating alongside, not instead of, other valuation requirements that are stated to continue to apply. Practically, that means the firm should document both (i) how IFRS is used without disproportionate cost and (ii) how the deferred tax recognition and valuation remains compliant with the continuing valuation provisions, while still satisfying the requirement to recognise and value deferred taxes across all in-scope assets and liabilities [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610] and [#TGT:d84bdc975f6ad72f].
source_text: Deferred tax — Provisions are consistent with IFRS as regards Valuation 11.1 so using IFRS would not impose disproportionate costs. Valuation 11.2 and 11.3 still apply.
target_text: A firm must recognise and value deferred taxes in relation to all assets and liabilities, including technical provisions , that are recognised for solvency or tax purposes in accordance with 5 .

question: If a firm uses an internal model to calculate its solo-level SCR, which supervisory statement should it also look at, and how does the definition describe that statement (name, topic, and date)?
gold_answer: If a firm calculates its solo-level SCR using an internal model, the SOURCE indicates that firms should also refer to a specific supervisory statement: PRA Supervisory Statement SS6/15 [#SRC:271703a0633133c4]. The TARGET then defines exactly what that TERM refers to, so the firm can identify the right document: “PRA Supervisory Statement SS6/15”, titled ‘Solvency II: the internal model treatment of participations’, published in November 2024 [#TGT:466b960f164be1d8]. Using both passages together matters because the SOURCE provides the condition that makes the reference relevant (the internal model being used for solo-level SCR) and the action expected (also refer to the supervisory statement), while the TARGET supplies the defining details that remove ambiguity about which SS6/15 is meant (its full title and publication date). The TARGET also includes the web address (www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2015/solvency2-the-internal-model-treatment-of-participations-ss), which supports locating the defined supervisory statement the SOURCE points firms to [#TGT:466b960f164be1d8].
source_text: In relation to paragraph 1.40 of Guideline 9, firms should also refer to supervisory statement SS6/15 13 where the firm calculates its solo-level SCR using an internal model.
target_text: 13. PRA Supervisory Statement SS6/15, ‘Solvency II: the internal model treatment of participations’, November 2024; www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2015/solvency2-the-internal-model-treatment-of-participations-ss .

question: For Solvency II reinsurance counterparty credit risk, how should a firm align the Supervisory statement (SS) 20/16 title reference in its internal compliance inventory with the Bank of England publication record, including the timing and identifier shown alongside the entry?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the internal compliance inventory reference to “Supervisory statement (SS) 20/16 – Solvency II: Reinsurance – Counterparty credit risk” as the same supervisory statement that appears in the Bank of England publication record as “Supervisory Statement 20/16 – Solvency II: reinsurance counterparty credit risk.” The alignment should be done by matching (i) the supervisory statement identifier “20/16,” (ii) the subject matter “Solvency II” and “reinsurance” with the focus on “counterparty credit risk,” and (iii) the publication timing shown in the Bank of England record as “November 2016.” This cross-reference supports consistent naming and traceability between the internal title form used in the supervisory statement listing [#SRC:f16c93e20a3101b0] and the external publication entry that includes the date and the Bank of England hosting context [#TGT:caedbf39cb57b65a]. Where the internal record includes the “5c” marker, the firm should ensure that the corresponding Bank of England entry is the “5c” item that carries the “November 2016” date and the same supervisory statement identifier and topic, so the inventory points to the correct publication instance.

target_text: 5c. November 2016: Supervisory Statement 20/16 – Solvency II: reinsurance counterparty credit risk | Bank of England: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-reinsurance-counterparty-credit-risk-ss

question: If you are looking at land interests, how do you tell whether the case is a reversionary interest or remainder outside the referenced category versus a case where the latest proper valuation gives a higher combined value than separate values, and what percentage is used for that combined-valuation case?
gold_answer: You need to match the facts to the correct description because the two passages set out different conditions and percentages. The SOURCE addresses “a reversionary interest or a remainder” and specifies 1% where that interest is “not falling within” the referenced category [#SRC:f5557a061603e239]. The TARGET, by contrast, applies to “a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land)” and turns on what “the most recent proper valuation” does: if that valuation ascribes an “aggregate value” to the combined pieces or interests and that combined figure is “greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately,” then the percentage is 5% [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. So, when the trigger is the valuation outcome described in the TARGET—combined valuation higher than the sum of separate valuations—you use 5%. Separately, if the situation is the reversionary/remainder case described in the SOURCE and it is outside the referenced category, the SOURCE indicates 1% [#SRC:f5557a061603e239] and [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].
source_text: 1% for a reversionary interest or a remainder not falling within 28.2 .
target_text: 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land) to which in the most recent proper valuation of such pieces of land an aggregate value is ascribed which is greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately.

question: When setting internal expectations for liquidity, what must the credit union do to ensure the maintained quantity and quality of liquid assets over time does not fall below the minimum level tied to total relevant liabilities?
gold_answer: The credit union must establish and operate an approach to liquidity that addresses both the quantity and the quality of liquid assets it maintains over time, explicitly taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements that apply to it [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. This obligation requires the credit union to look beyond a one-off calculation and instead ensure that its liquid asset holdings remain appropriate and sustainable as conditions change, while still meeting the minimum quantitative requirement. The minimum quantitative requirement is clear: a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. Therefore, internal expectations and monitoring should be calibrated so that, at all times, the maintained stock of liquid assets is not only of sufficient quality and managed over time, but also remains at or above the 10% of total relevant liabilities threshold. In effect, the credit union’s ongoing maintenance of liquid assets (quantity and quality) must be designed so that the minimum percentage requirement is continuously satisfied as part of the overall liquidity position [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce] and not treated as a separate or occasional compliance check [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf].
source_text: the quantity and quality of liquid assets to be maintained by the credit union over time, taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements in Rule 9.2 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook; and
target_text: A credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities .

question: What must a critical third party do to make sure its strategies, controls, processes and systems both support compliance with this Part and are sized appropriately for the nature, scale and complexity of its activities?
gold_answer: A critical third party must put in place strategies, controls, processes and systems that are sound, effective and comprehensive, and that enable it to comply with this Part [#TGT:760ea87c0f5b6ba5]. It must also ensure that the strategies, processes and systems it uses are proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of the critical third party’s activities [#SRC:7e35f6571b52787e]. Taken together, this means the critical third party cannot treat compliance arrangements as either a generic checklist or a one-size-fits-all program. Instead, it must build a complete and effective set of arrangements that can actually support compliance, while tailoring how detailed, extensive, and resource-intensive those arrangements are to what the critical third party does, how large those activities are, and how complex they are. The proportionality requirement shapes the level of sophistication and breadth expected, but it does not remove the need for the overall framework to be sound, effective, and comprehensive for the purpose of complying with this Part.
source_text: The strategies, processes and systems required by 4.1 must be proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of the critical third party’s activities.
target_text: A critical third party must have in place sound, effective and comprehensive strategies, controls, processes and systems that enable it to comply with this Part.

question: When the firm determines its exposure to assets of each description by adjusting the ascribed value, how must it treat assets of that description that the firm has transferred by way of initial margin—specifically, must the ascribed value be increased to reflect those transferred assets before the exposure amount is calculated?
gold_answer: In determining the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description, the firm must start from a value ascribed to those assets and then determine exposure by adjusting that value under the applicable valuation approach described in the rules [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]. Where, for a given description of assets, the firm has transferred assets of that same description by way of initial margin, the value ascribed for that description must be increased by an amount that represents the value of the transferred initial margin assets [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433]. Read together, this means the firm cannot calculate exposure using only the on-hand assets’ ascribed value; it must incorporate an uplift that captures the value of any same-description assets already transferred as initial margin, so that the adjusted value used for exposure determination reflects both the assets held and the value impact of those transferred assets. This increase applies at the level of each asset description and is tied to the value of the assets transferred by the firm as initial margin, ensuring the exposure calculation is based on an appropriately adjusted ascribed value across each description.
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 20 in respect of assets of each description must be increased by an amount representing the value of any assets of that description which have been transferred by the firm by way of initial margin .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: If a composite firm runs both general insurance business and long-term insurance business, what must it do to keep the management of those activities separate, and what does that mean for managing agents that manage syndicates for each type of business (including when one syndicate does both)?
gold_answer: A composite firm must manage the activities relating to its general insurance business separately from the activities relating to its long-term insurance business, meaning it must set up its management so the two sets of activities are kept distinct as required [#TGT:fc6847c8e99d5a6a]. The practical implication described for the market is that managing agents are expected to separately manage syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business, rather than managing them together as one combined operation [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. If a single syndicate carries on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business under the referenced exceptions, the separation requirement does not disappear; instead, the referenced material is intended to help managing agents determine how the Composites requirements apply in that mixed-syndicate situation, so they can still implement separate management in a way that aligns with the overall obligation [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] and the requirement to separately manage the relevant activities [#TGT:fc6847c8e99d5a6a].
source_text: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business. In practical terms, this requires that managing agents separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business. question: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer and has to work out its maximum distributable amount, how should it pick the right percentage for the product calculation, and what does each combined-buffer quartile mean for how much of the profits it can pay out?
gold_answer: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it will face restrictions on distributions and will be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA) [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The MDA is not a general limit the firm can set itself; it must be calculated as the product of (i) a fixed percentage and (ii) a defined profits base [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The percentage must be chosen from 60%, 40%, 20% or 0%, and the correct choice depends on which quartile of the firm’s combined buffer position it is in [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The quartiles also define what share of the relevant profits can be distributed: in the first quartile (where the firm meets between 75% and 100% of its combined buffer), 60% of such profits can be distributed; in the second quartile, 40%; in the third, 20%; and in the fourth, 0% [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d]. The profits base used in the product is the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits, net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from the items referenced in the MDA calculation requirement [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b].
source_text: Firms may use their combined buffer as required in times of stress, but should not use it in the normal course of business or propose to enter it as part of their base business plan. As set out in the PRA’s capital buffers rules, firms that do not meet their combined buffer shall face restrictions on their distributions, and be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA). The MDA must be calculated as the product of 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% (depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in) 3 and the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in Capital Buffers 4.3(5)), net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from:
target_text: 3. Where firms are in the first quartile of their combined buffer (when they meet between 75% and 100% of it), 60% of such profits can be distributed. In the second quartile, 40% can be distributed; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%.

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one important risk driver, and one of those drivers is linked to climatic conditions, what must institutions do to map the transaction to the right risk category or categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must map the transaction in a way that captures both the climatic-conditions rule and the rule for transactions with multiple material risk drivers. If the primary risk driver is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]. Also, because the transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions shall map it to more than one risk category when the drivers belong to different risk categories, mapping it once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If, instead, all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, institutions only need to map the transaction once to that single category, using the most material driver as the basis [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Putting these together: the presence of a climatic conditions variable as the primary driver (or as the most material driver within a risk category used for mapping) requires commodity mapping, and the multi-driver framework then determines whether additional mappings are required to other risk categories as well [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad].
source_text: (b) where the primary risk driver of a transaction, or the most material risk driver in a given risk category for transactions referred to in paragraph 3 , is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When a firm outsources a material outsourced function, what must the firm do to ensure the service provider is aware of the Bank and PRA’s statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, and how does this obligation relate to the firm’s and the PRA’s rights to inspect and audit the service provider in connection with that outsourced function?
gold_answer: Where a firm has outsourced a material outsourced function, the firm must address two connected aspects of oversight. First, the firm must recognise that there are rights for firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function, which frames the practical ability to review and test the provider’s performance and controls in that outsourced arrangement [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa]. Second, independent of those access, audit, and information expectations, the Bank and PRA also have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers that may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms, and the PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of those powers and requirements (as described in the referenced tables, which are not exhaustive) [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]. The firm’s obligation is therefore to communicate these statutory powers and requirements to the service provider as part of managing the outsourced relationship, while understanding that the applicability of those powers does not depend on whether the firm has provided that notice. This complements, rather than replaces, the inspection and audit rights tied to the outsourced function.
source_text: the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function (see Chapter 8 );
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: When determining the applicable percentage for land-related interests, how should a firm distinguish between a reversionary interest or remainder that is outside the referenced category and a case where the most recent proper valuation assigns an aggregate value to multiple pieces of land (or interests in them) that exceeds the sum of separate valuations, and what percentage applies in the latter case?
gold_answer: The firm must first identify which factual trigger applies to the interest being assessed, because the passages describe two different situations with different percentage outcomes. One situation concerns “a reversionary interest or a remainder” that is “not falling within” the referenced category; that condition is expressly tied to a 1% figure in the SOURCE [#SRC:f5557a061603e239]. A separate situation concerns “a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land)” where, in “the most recent proper valuation,” an “aggregate value” is ascribed to the combined pieces or interests and that aggregate is “greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately”; in that valuation-driven circumstance, the applicable percentage is 5% [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. Accordingly, if the firm is dealing with the valuation scenario described in the TARGET—i.e., the combined valuation exceeds the sum of separate valuations—it should apply 5%, while recognizing that the SOURCE separately specifies 1% for the reversionary/remainder scenario outside the referenced category [#SRC:f5557a061603e239] and [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].
source_text: 1% for a reversionary interest or a remainder not falling within 28.2 .
target_text: 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land) to which in the most recent proper valuation of such pieces of land an aggregate value is ascribed which is greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately.

question: For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but there is sufficient evidence of predictability, may firms propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks, and if so how should that proposal align with the PRA’s expectation that the standard approach for economic cash flow variability assumes a yield-to-worst cash-flow pattern and only permits alternative methods on a case-by-case basis where the issuer is assumed to act economically rationally?
gold_answer: Yes. The PRA indicates that, for pooled asset exposures whose underlying assets are exposed to economic risks and where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose applying the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855]. In developing that proposal, firms should also align with the PRA’s expectations for assets exposed to economic cash flow variability risks: the standard approach is expected to assume a cash-flow pattern that delivers the investor’s minimum yield (yield to worst) [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]. If the pooled asset’s features or contractual terms make that standard assumption less appropriate, the PRA indicates an alternative method could be considered case-by-case, but only if it retains the assumption that the issuer will act in an economically rational manner [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]. Accordingly, a firm’s proposal should explain (i) why the pooled exposure meets the predictability condition supporting use of the standard approach for the event-risk FS addition, and (ii) how the economic-risk component is treated consistently with the yield-to-worst expectation or, where justified, an alternative method that preserves the issuer rationality assumption [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e].
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: Where assets are exposed to economic cash flow variability risks, the PRA expects that a standard approach would assume a pattern of cash flows where the yield for the investor is at a minimum (ie ‘yield to worst’). Where the features or contractual terms of an asset make an alternative method more appropriate, this could be considered on a case-by-case basis, provided that the method retains the assumption that the issuer will act in economically rational manner. The FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for the risk of reinvestment and rebalancing costs as set out in paragraph 5.20 above.

question: If the society has agreed the final draft Transfer Statement and the PRA is minded to approve it, what does the society need to send to the PRA, and does it also need a directors’ assurance about the register of members and systems?
gold_answer: When the society has settled on the final draft of a Transfer Statement that the PRA is minded to approve, the society should send the PRA two authenticated copies of that final draft Transfer Statement, together with the accompanying documents required for that submission [#TGT:aa1358fe2fd02ead]. One of the required accompanying items is an assurance from the directors of the society about the society’s register of members and its systems [#SRC:dedc202a7e1e59e1]. Taken together, this means the society’s submission should be assembled as a complete pack: it includes the two authenticated copies of the final draft Transfer Statement and, alongside them, the directors’ assurance that speaks specifically to the register of members and the systems used by the society. The society should therefore plan to have the directors’ assurance ready at the same time as the final draft Transfer Statement is finalised for submission, so that the PRA receives both the core document and the directors’ confirmation as part of the same submission bundle.

question: If you must identify measures to reduce the risks and include documentation changes to better match the preferred resolution strategy, what counts as standardised documentation versus non-standardised documentation, and how should that definition shape what you change?
gold_answer: You must identify the measures required to alleviate the risks, and that identification must include any changes required to documentation—covering both standardised and non-standardised documentation—to better align with the preferred resolution strategy [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5]. To do that correctly, you need to use the definition that standardised documentation refers to ISDA agreements, while non-standardised documentation refers to bilateral or bespoke agreements [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad]. This definition shapes the scope of your documentation work: you should treat ISDA agreements as the standardised set that may need changes, and separately review any bilateral or bespoke agreements as the non-standardised set that may also require changes. Your measures should therefore not be limited to one type of agreement; they must address documentation changes across both categories where needed, because the obligation is to identify measures that alleviate the risks and include documentation changes that improve alignment with the preferred resolution strategy. In short, the definition tells you exactly which agreements fall into each bucket, and the obligation requires you to consider and specify changes for each bucket as part of the risk-alleviation measures [#SRC:d897e37fd43356a5] [#TGT:e7dc92806ee8dbad].
source_text: identify the measures required to alleviate these risks, including changes required to documentation (standardised 5 and non-standardised) to better align with the preferred resolution strategy;
target_text: 5. Standardised documentation refers to ISDA agreements. Non-standardised documentation refers to bilateral or bespoke agreements.

question: If the default method is a prospective calculation for each contract’s long-term insurance liability, can you ever use a retrospective calculation for a specific contract or benefit, and what limits apply?
gold_answer: Yes, but only within strict limits. The default obligation is that the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation, which means prospective calculation is the required starting point for contract-level liability determination [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. A retrospective calculation is allowed only to determine the liabilities in two defined circumstances [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. One is where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit; in that case, the retrospective approach is permitted because the prospective method is not applicable for that specific category [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. The other is where you can demonstrate that the liabilities produced by the retrospective calculation would be no lower than the amount that would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; this condition prevents using retrospective methods to reduce liabilities below what a prudent prospective approach would require [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. These permissions operate as exceptions to, not replacements for, the general prospective requirement for each contract [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb].
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: How must the firm’s governing body make sure it stays confident that the firm’s systems meet the requirement to clearly mark beneficiary accounts (including client and trust accounts) so they can be identified immediately when they contain or may contain eligible deposits?
gold_answer: The firm needs a clear governance procedure explaining how the firm’s governing body will ensure it remains satisfied that the firm’s systems comply with the applicable requirements over time [#SRC:d11985b37b3a54b1]. That ongoing assurance must cover the concrete obligation placed on the firm’s systems and processes: the firm must mark accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries—specifically including client accounts and trust accounts—where those accounts contain or may contain eligible deposits, and the marking must be done in a way that allows those accounts to be identified immediately [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. So, the governing body’s procedure should be designed to check that the marking is actually applied to all relevant accounts, that it captures both “contain” and “may contain” situations, and that the result is immediate identifiability. The procedure should also set out how the governing body will keep monitoring this (not just at one point in time) so it can continue to be satisfied that the systems are operating as required and that the account-marking outcome remains in place.
source_text: (d) how the firm’s governing body will ensure that they remain satisfied that its systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 ;
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: If a firm has permission to use a partial or full internal model and is using an internal model, what does it have to send to the PRA every quarter about model changes, and what details must be included?
gold_answer: A firm with permission to use a partial or full internal model that is using an internal model must send the PRA a quarterly report about model changes that meets two linked requirements. First, it must provide a quarterly summary of both minor and major model changes to the PRA, reflecting the reporting expectation connected to the PRA Rulebook reporting provisions and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd]. Second, it must make that quarterly submission using the PRA’s quarterly template QMC.01, which is specifically designed to capture model-change reporting and requires the firm to specify information on model changes and provide supporting qualitative information, following the relevant QMC.01 instructions [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]. In practice, this means the firm should not only list or describe changes, but also ensure the quarterly summary is structured through QMC.01 and includes the qualitative support the template calls for, so the PRA receives a consistent quarterly view of both minor and major changes.
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: If an outsourcing arrangement is material, what does the PRA expect firms to do so that business continuity and exit strategies are actually ready to use?
gold_answer: The SOURCE identifies the topic that needs to be addressed—business continuity and exit strategies [#SRC:cbf91fe709000f41]. The TARGET then explains what the PRA expects firms to do for each material outsourcing arrangement: they should develop something that covers that topic, keep it up to date, and test it [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1]. So, when a firm decides an outsourcing arrangement is material, it should ensure there is a continuity-and-exit plan (or equivalent) specifically for that arrangement, not just a general statement. The firm should also maintain it over time, meaning it should be reviewed and updated as the outsourcing arrangement, the service, or the firm’s needs change. Finally, the firm should test it so it can show the continuity and exit approach works in practice, rather than assuming it would work. The key link is: material outsourcing is the trigger, and continuity/exit is the content that must be developed, maintained, and tested.
source_text: business continuity and exit strategies ( Chapter 10 ).
target_text: For each material outsourcing arrangement, the PRA expects firms to develop, maintain, and test a:

question: If an institution pays into (or delivers assets to) the default fund of a QCCP, what does it have to do to calculate its own funds requirement for that pre-funded contribution, and how do you work out the exposure value of the contribution if the QCCP has already used part of it to cover losses after a clearing member default?
gold_answer: Where an institution has a pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP, it is required to calculate the own funds requirement for that contribution using the applicable approach for those pre-funded contributions [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]. To apply that approach, the institution needs the exposure value of its pre-funded contribution, which is defined as the amount the institution paid in or, if it delivered assets instead of cash, the market value of the assets it delivered [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af]. That exposure value is not always the full paid-in amount or full market value, because the definition requires a reduction in a specific situation: if the QCCP has already used some of the institution’s contribution to absorb losses, and those losses occurred following the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members, then the exposure value must be reduced by the amount already used. As a result, the institution’s own funds requirement calculation should be based on the remaining (net) exposure value after that reduction, rather than on the original gross contribution.
source_text: (a) it shall calculate the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP in accordance with the approach set out in Article 308 ;
target_text: The exposure value for an institution's pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP (DFi) shall be the amount paid in or the market value of the assets delivered by that institution reduced by any amount of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb its losses following the default of one or more of its clearing members .

question: When ensuring that best estimates are calculated net of intra-group transactions for the participating Solvency II undertaking and each related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, what documentation and data directory may the participating Solvency II undertaking limit itself to, and how must that limitation align with the required intra-group reinsurance adjustments?
gold_answer: For these purposes, the participating Solvency II undertaking is required to ensure that the best estimates of the participating Solvency II undertaking and of each related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking and third country reinsurance undertaking are net of any intra-group transactions, and that, in relation to intra-group reinsurance contracts, the specified adjustments are made [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd]. In meeting that obligation, the participating Solvency II undertaking is permitted to restrict the documentation and the directory of data (otherwise referred to in Conditions Governing Business 11C) so that it covers only the data used in calculating the adjustments of the best estimate that are relevant for these purposes [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366]. Practically, this means the undertaking may narrow the evidence set and data inventory to what is necessary to support the calculation of the best estimate adjustments that implement the netting of intra-group transactions and the adjustments required for intra-group reinsurance contracts, rather than maintaining a broader documentation and data directory beyond what is used for those adjustment calculations [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366].
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1D , the participating Solvency II undertaking may restrict the documentation and the directory of data referred to in Conditions Governing Business 11C to the data used in the calculation of the adjustments of the best estimate referred to in 11.1E .
