question: When deciding what a “prescribed responsibility” is, how do you apply the source definition that points to the prescribed responsibilities in 4.1 (1)–(3) together with the target definition that says responsibilities set out in this rule are prescribed responsibilities?
gold_answer: To identify a “prescribed responsibility,” you need to use both definitions together. The source definition limits what you are looking for to “each of the prescribed responsibilities in 4.1 (1) – (3),” so the scope is tied to that specific referenced set and its section label “4.1 (1) – (3)” [#SRC:f190ef490669d7e0]. The target definition then tells you how to treat responsibilities that appear in the rule: “Each of the responsibilities set out in this rule is a prescribed responsibility,” meaning the act of being set out in the rule is enough to make it a prescribed responsibility [#TGT:a05fb83553247826]. Putting these together, you should (1) look at the responsibilities that are set out in the rule (the target’s criterion, captured by the term “responsibilities set out in this rule”), and then (2) confirm that the responsibility is within the set referenced by the source cross-reference to 4.1 (1)–(3). If both conditions are satisfied, it should be treated as a prescribed responsibility.
source_text: (1) each of the prescribed responsibilities in 4.1 (1) – (3);
target_text: Each of the responsibilities set out in this rule is a prescribed responsibility :

question: Where a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names must communicate information in a way that best brings it to depositors’ attention, can the firm satisfy that obligation by placing the required disclosures prominently on the front page of its website or mobile application, or via a pop-up box on login, and on what basis?
gold_answer: For a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names, the firm must communicate the relevant information in a way that best brings it to depositors’ attention [#TGT:ff1653a69f0caf02]. In applying that obligation, the PRA indicates that the firm is permitted to rely on certain prominent digital placements as meeting the “best brings” standard, provided the content is the information required to be disclosed under the relevant depositor protection disclosure requirements. Specifically, if the required information is displayed prominently on the front page of the firm’s website or mobile application, or is presented in a pop-up box upon logging on to the website or mobile application, the PRA expects that the requirement to communicate in a way that best brings the information to depositors’ attention will have been satisfied [#SRC:06cb6758ebf841c4]. Accordingly, the obligation in the multi-brand/trading-name context can be met through these website/app presentation methods, so long as the firm is in fact displaying the required depositor protection information and doing so prominently in the specified locations or at login.
source_text: If information required to be disclosed under Depositor Protection 23.7 and 23.8 is displayed prominently on the front page of the firm’s website or mobile application or a pop-up box upon logging on to the website or mobile application, the PRA expects that the requirement to communicate in a way that best brings the information to depositors’ attention will have been satisfied.
target_text: A firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names must, in a way that best brings the information to depositors' attention:

question: If a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking appoints an external auditor, what does the external auditor have to say in the report about the information and where it came from, and is that duty subject to any condition?
gold_answer: If a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking appoints an external auditor, the external auditor is required to make a specific statement in the report about the status and basis of the information being reported. The external auditor must state that the information has been properly compiled in line with the relevant PRA rules and UK law relating to the undertaking, and that the compilation was done using information provided by undertakings in the group and the relevant insurance group undertaking [#SRC:eca198ee0fd1c158]. However, the target text makes clear that the external auditor’s required actions apply in the context of an appointment by a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking and are expressly conditional, because the obligation is framed as “Subject to 4.2” and applies to an external auditor appointed pursuant to the referenced appointment basis [#TGT:911a28130622e256]. Taken together, the target sets the scope and conditionality for when the external auditor’s duties apply, and the source defines the exact substance that must be stated in the report about compilation and the information sources.
source_text: the external auditor shall state in the report under 4.1 (2) that the information has been properly compiled in accordance with the relevant PRA rules and UK law relating to that undertaking from information provided by undertakings in the group and the relevant insurance group undertaking .
target_text: Subject to 4.2 , an external auditor appointed by a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking pursuant to 3 must:

question: If a firm’s residential mortgage rating system includes a built-in calculation that changes the PD for exposures with the same characteristics, what does the PRA say the firm must treat that as, and what cyclicality cap must the firm assume when it is filling in missing grade-level default-rate history while uplifting to a long-run average?
gold_answer: The PRA’s definition means that a built-in calculation mechanism in a rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics should be treated as a recalibration, and the PRA expects recalibrations of rating systems applying the relevant cyclicality assumptions to be rare and to indicate failures of the rating system’s assumptions rather than being part of the system’s intended design [#SRC:5f859b5bac10db27]. Separately, to mitigate under-calibration risk when firms calibrate residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, the PRA expects firms to assume that cyclicality is no more than 30% in years where grade-level internal observed default rates are not available; this is the maximum cyclicality the PRA expects firms to assume when imputing missing historical default rates [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. In setting long-run average default rates for each rating grade, the PRA also expects firms to assume that at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate reflects changes in default rates within grades (rather than grade migration) [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The PRA notes it may adjust this expectation if it judges the risk of under-calibration has changed [#TGT:8705f442785054e1].
source_text: The PRA expects recalibrations of rating systems applying the cyclicality assumptions set out in paragraph 12.4 to be rare and to be symptomatic of failures of the rating system’s assumptions rather than part of rating system design. For these purposes any calculation mechanism embedded in a rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics should be treated as a recalibration. The PRA expects that any recalibration of such a rating system would include:
target_text: In the PRA’s experience, firms often have difficulty in practice in understanding the cyclicality of their residential mortgage rating systems. To mitigate the risk of under-calibration of these rating systems due to inaccurate estimation of their cyclicality, the PRA expects that when firms calibrate their residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, they should do so on the assumption that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in those years where grade level internal observed default rates are not available. This cyclicality cap is the PRA’s expectation of what firms should assume is the maximum level of cyclicality when imputing missing historical default rates. If 30% of the change in portfolio default rates comes from grade migration the remaining 70% would come from change in default rates within grades. Therefore when calibrating the long-run average default rates to assign to each rating grade the PRA expects firms to assume that at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate reflects grade level changes in default rate. This level reflects the PRA’s current view of an appropriately conservative assumption for rating system cyclicality in light of recent experience. This expectation may be adjusted by the PRA if it judges that there has been a change in the risk of under-calibration.

question: When updating the insurer’s liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, what governance and prudential risk management elements must an insurer have in place to ensure the update is aligned with its required system of governance and information flows to management or the board?
gold_answer: When an insurer updates its liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, it should do so within the framework of the effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems it is required to establish [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. Practically, the update should be anchored to the insurer’s risk appetite or tolerance for risk, and supported by a defined process to identify, measure, and monitor risk so that liquidity-related risks are assessed consistently and the strategy and policies remain coherent with the insurer’s overall risk approach [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. The insurer must also ensure it has appropriate systems to convey relevant information arising from the liquidity strategy and policy update to management or the board, so that decision-makers receive the necessary inputs and oversight can be exercised effectively [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. In this context, the liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies are specifically described as being used for update purposes, reinforcing that the insurer should treat liquidity strategy and policy maintenance as an ongoing governance activity rather than a one-off exercise [#SRC:8cda5a0f7fa9c1dd].
source_text: used to update the insurer’s liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies (elaborated on in Chapter 2 );
target_text: Conditions Governing Business Chapters 2 and 3 , supplemented by Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance Chapters 2 , 3 and 7 require an insurer to establish an effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems. An insurer is required to have a risk appetite or tolerance for risk, a process to identify, measure, and monitor risk and appropriate systems to convey information to management or the board.

question: For Insurance - Fitness and Propriety, what must a firm do to make sure its best estimate and the assumptions behind it are checked against what actually happens in practice?
gold_answer: Under the Insurance - Fitness and Propriety context, a firm must translate the expectation of being fit and proper into practical controls over how it produces and maintains its best estimate. The firm is required to have processes and procedures in place that make sure the best estimate and the assumptions used to calculate it are regularly compared with real-world experience. In practice, this means the firm cannot rely only on initial modelling choices; it must set up an ongoing, repeatable way to compare the estimate and its key assumptions to experience data, so it can identify when experience supports the assumptions and when it suggests the assumptions (and therefore the best estimate) may need review. The requirement is on the firm to have these processes and procedures established, and the comparison must be done regularly rather than only when problems arise. Read together, the source’s Insurance - Fitness and Propriety framing and the target’s explicit “must” obligation connect suitability expectations to disciplined monitoring of estimation assumptions against experience [#SRC:1fe3558db5a4bfed] [#TGT:656d998a79e6eb2c].
source_text: (c) Insurance - Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; and
target_text: A firm must have processes and procedures in place to ensure that the best estimate and the assumptions underlying the calculation of the best estimate are regularly compared against experience.

question: When a firm sets the interest rates used to discount future payments for its long-term insurance business, what is prohibited in terms of assuming an asset yield that would cause those discount rates to exceed a prudent assessment of yields on existing assets, given the specific cap that applies to the assumed yield on an attributed asset before tax adjustments?
gold_answer: A firm is prohibited from using discount rates for present value calculations that are higher than rates supported by a prudent assessment of the yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business (and, where appropriate, expected yields on future investments) [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221]. In applying that prudence constraint, the firm must also ensure that any assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business, before any tax-effect adjustment, does not exceed the asset’s calculated yield (as determined under the referenced yield-calculation approach) after applying a reduction equal to 2.5% of that yield [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8]. Read together, these prohibitions mean the firm cannot justify a higher discount rate by selecting an assumed asset yield that breaches the pre-tax cap, nor can it set discount rates above what a prudent assessment of attributed-asset yields (and appropriate expected future-investment yields) would support. The assumed-yield limitation operates as a hard ceiling on the yield input for an attributed asset, while the discount-rate limitation constrains the overall interest-rate basis used in present value calculations to remain no greater than prudently assessed yields.
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.
target_text: The rates of interest to be used in calculating the present value of future payments by or to a firm must be no greater than the rates of interest determined from a prudent assessment of the yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business and, to the extent appropriate, the yields which it is expected will be obtained on sums to be invested in the future.

question: If an institution wants to recognise the effect of internal hedges against interest rate risks, what must it do when the internal hedge is a trading book credit derivative used to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure?
gold_answer: Even where an institution is seeking recognition of the effect of hedges against interest rate risks and uses internal hedges that meet the applicable requirements [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d], it must follow the special rule for an internal hedge that uses a credit derivative booked in the trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]. In that situation, the institution shall ensure the non-trading book exposure is not treated as hedged for calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless it also buys matching protection from an eligible third party protection provider. That third-party protection must be a corresponding credit derivative that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. If the institution buys that third-party protection and recognises it as a hedge for capital requirements, it shall also ensure that neither the internal hedge nor the external hedge is included in the trading book for the purpose of calculating capital requirements. This means internal hedge recognition does not, by itself, allow capital relief for the non-trading book exposure.
source_text: (iv) the recognition of the effect of hedges against those interest rate risks, including internal hedges that meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3) ;
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraphs 1 and 2 , when an institution hedges a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure using a credit derivative booked in its trading book using an internal hedge, institutions shall ensure that the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure shall not be deemed to be hedged for the purposes of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless the institution purchases from an eligible third party protection provider a corresponding credit derivative meeting the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Without prejudice to point (h) of Article 299(2), where such third party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge of a non-trading book exposure for the purposes of calculating capital requirements, institutions shall ensure that neither the internal nor external credit derivative hedge shall be included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements.

question: If a smaller firm (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm) is setting its remuneration policy, what must it do to use proportionality properly (without dropping the requirements) and still make sure the policy fits its internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks in its business?
gold_answer: A smaller firm (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm) must treat proportionality as a way to scale how it applies the remuneration requirements, not as a way to avoid them. The PRA still expects smaller firms to comply appropriately with the Chapter 3A framework when setting remuneration policies, and proportionality does not mean the firm can disapply those requirements [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed]. Instead, the firm should use appropriate judgement so that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff are applied proportionately and modified where required to reflect the size and nature of its business, while keeping the requirements in place [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed]. Alongside that, the firm must ensure the remuneration policy is designed to take account of the firm’s internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c]. Putting both together, the firm should tailor the detailed arrangements to its circumstances and risk profile, but it must still build and maintain a policy that is aligned to how the firm is organised and the risks it faces.
source_text: The PRA will still expect smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) to comply appropriately with Chapter 3A when setting their remuneration policies. The application of proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 does not equate to smaller firms being able to disapply the Chapter 3A requirements. These firms should be exercising appropriate judgement to ensure that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff contained in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 are applied proportionality and modified where required to reflect the size and nature of their businesses.
target_text: A firm must ensure that the remuneration policy is designed in such a way as to take into account the internal organisation of the firm , and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business.

question: If a firm uses external credit rating assessments to calculate technical provisions and the SCR, what must it do in risk management to check those ratings are appropriate and avoid relying on them automatically, and what must be included in its risk management policy to support that?
gold_answer: If a firm uses external credit rating assessments in the calculation of technical provisions and the SCR, it must actively assess whether those external ratings are appropriate as part of its risk management, with the specific aim of avoiding overreliance on external credit assessment institutions. To achieve that, the firm must use additional assessments wherever practicably possible so that it does not become automatically dependent on external assessments. Alongside this practical requirement, the firm must also reflect the approach in its governance documentation: for the purpose of assessing the appropriateness of the external credit rating assessments it uses for technical provisions and the SCR, the firm must include the relevant elements in its policy on risk management, including the use of additional assessments for that appropriateness check. Taken together, the firm is required both to perform the appropriateness assessment (using additional assessments where practicable to avoid automatic dependence) and to ensure its risk management policy contains what is needed to support and govern that assessment process. [#SRC:53e44a3e4a1680e9] [#TGT:e8306a907d006bc2]
source_text: For the purpose of assessing the appropriateness of external credit rating assessments used in the calculation of technical provisions and the SCR by way of additional assessments referred to in 3.6 , a firm must include in its policy on risk management the following:
target_text: In order to avoid overreliance on external credit assessment institutions when it uses external credit rating assessments in the calculation of technical provisions and the SCR , a firm must assess the appropriateness of those external credit rating assessments as part of its risk management by using additional assessments wherever practicably possible in order to avoid any automatic dependence on external assessments.

question: When a credit union provides loans to corporate members, how should the credit union determine who qualifies as a corporate member for this purpose, and what risk awareness does the PRA expect the credit union to apply when making such loans?
gold_answer: Where a credit union provides loans to corporate members, it should first ensure it is applying the correct meaning of “corporate members” by using the statutory definition referenced in the Credit Union Act 1979 (Great Britain) or the Credit Unions (Northern Ireland) Order 1985, as indicated in the definitional cross-reference [#TGT:9a06bf48f1b5c869]. Once the credit union has identified that the borrower falls within that defined category, the PRA’s expectation is that the credit union should be mindful of the additional risks involved in providing corporate loans [#SRC:721423c1d136c2e3]. This includes, in particular, recognising that lending to corporate members can introduce business model risks and may involve difficulty predicting future cash flow, which can affect the credit union’s ability to assess repayment capacity and manage exposures [#SRC:721423c1d136c2e3]. In practice, the definitional step matters because the PRA’s stated risk expectation is triggered specifically in relation to loans provided to corporate members, so misclassification could lead to the credit union failing to apply the heightened risk awareness the PRA expects for that lending activity [#TGT:9a06bf48f1b5c869] [#SRC:721423c1d136c2e3].
source_text: The PRA expects credit unions that provide loans to corporate members 13 should be mindful of the additional risks involved in providing corporate loans, for example business model risks, or difficulty predicting future cash flow.
target_text: 13. See section 5A of the Credit Union Act 1979 (Great Britain) or Section 14A of the Credit Unions (Northern Ireland) Order 1985 for the definition of corporate members.

question: When must institutions begin making the additional annual disclosures tied to a 5% non-performing loans and advances ratio, and what threshold-testing conditions govern the start of disclosure and the first reference date templates?
gold_answer: Institutions must commence disclosure once the 5% threshold condition is met under the commencement test in the SOURCE, and, where applicable, they must also satisfy the TARGET’s requirement for large institutions to provide specified additional annual disclosures when their ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances to total gross carrying amount of loans and advances is equal to or higher than 5%. Under the SOURCE, institutions start disclosure where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the disclosure reference date, and for the first disclosure reference date they must disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that reference date [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]. In parallel, the TARGET imposes an annual disclosure obligation on large institutions meeting the 5% ratio test, requiring the disclosures required in specified points of Article 442 of the CRR to be made also in accordance with the listed templates and related annex instructions [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37]. Read together, commencement timing and first-reference-date template inclusion follow the SOURCE’s threshold mechanics, while the content and annual cadence for large institutions meeting the ratio test follow the TARGET.
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: When an issuer changes an asset’s cash flows through an upgrade, how must a firm design and apply its own criteria for assessing “sufficient compensation” so that it can justify continued inclusion of the asset in the MA portfolio and determine whether only part of the asset’s cash flows should be recognised up to the level of contractual compensation payable?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its own criteria for assessing “sufficient compensation” are built to handle foreseeable events such as an asset being upgraded, and then apply those criteria to decide whether the asset needs to be removed from the MA portfolio. The PRA’s expectation is that, in an upgrade event, the firm would not necessarily need to remove the asset if its criteria explicitly provide for such events and are effective in assessing whether compensation remains sufficient, including by reference to the MA liabilities being matched and the firm’s ability to purchase a replacement asset of at least as good quality to maintain matching if the issuer changes cash flows [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3]. The firm must also be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace the cash flows as it uses in its broader assessment of replacement capability. In practice, where the criteria support it, the firm may recognise only part of the asset’s cash flows, limited to the level of contractual compensation payable, while taking into account the considerations applicable to partial recognition [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3] and ensuring compensation remains sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match relevant MA eligible liabilities [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to consider how their own criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ cater for foreseeable events such as an asset being upgraded. The PRA considers that in such upgrade events, a firm would not necessarily need to remove the asset from the MA portfolio, if its own criteria provide for this (and to the extent that those criteria were effective in assessing whether compensation would be sufficient, taking into account paragraph 2.37 above). For example, where sufficiency of compensation criteria follow the approach described in paragraph 2.41 above, the firm might continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows up to the level of the compensation payable, ie so that the asset’s compensation would remain sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match relevant MA eligible liabilities.
target_text: The PRA’s view is that it may be possible for firms’ criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ to be devised by reference to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows, together with the ability to purchase an asset of at least as good quality as the original to replace these cash flows in the event they are changed by the issuer, ie to ensure that this matching continues. The PRA expects a firm to be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in its assessment in paragraph 2.39 above. This may, in practice, mean that the firm would recognise part of the asset’s cash flows up to the level of contractual compensation payable, subject to the considerations relating to partial recognition set out in paragraphs 2.15 to 2.16A above.

question: When calculating the percentage that must be used to express the amount determined under the later step, how must a firm treat the amount determined under the earlier step in light of the required deduction for sums recoverable under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period?
gold_answer: A firm must first adjust the amount determined under the earlier step by deducting, from that amount, the total sum recoverable in respect of it under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period, because that deduction is required to be taken from the earlier-step amount itself [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]. Once that earlier-step amount has been reduced by the required reinsurance recoverables deduction, the firm must then use that resulting figure as the denominator when it expresses the amount determined under the later step as a percentage of the amount determined under the earlier step [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23]. In other words, the percentage expression obligation depends on the earlier-step amount, and the target requirement specifies that this earlier-step amount is not used gross but must be net of the total sum recoverable under relevant reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]. The firm therefore must ensure the percentage is calculated by comparing the later-step amount to the earlier-step amount after applying the mandated deduction, rather than to an undeducted earlier-step amount [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23].
source_text: A firm must express the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2).
target_text: From the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), a firm must deduct the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period.

question: Who exactly is Chapter 2 meant for in an insurance business transfer, and what does the PRA say it will do with the FCA before it makes some transfer decisions?
gold_answer: Chapter 2 is meant for any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, if they are proposing to apply to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme or to accept such a transfer [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. It is also aimed at the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report, so the independent expert is explicitly within the Chapter 2 audience as well [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. Alongside that scope, the PRA states that, while it sets out its expectations for insurance business transfers, it will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions in respect of a transfer and will seek to avoid inadvertently introducing incompatible requirements [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. Put together, this means that when an in-scope party is going through the Chapter 2 transfer process, they should anticipate that some PRA decision points will be preceded by PRA consultation with the FCA, reflecting the PRA’s intent to coordinate and reduce the risk of conflicting regulatory requirements [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a].
source_text: While this statement sets out the PRA’s expectations in relation to insurance business transfers, the PRA will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions in respect of a transfer and will seek to avoid introducing, inadvertently, incompatible requirements. 1 The FCA has also set out its own approach to and expectations in respect of insurance business transfers in SUP 18 of the FCA Handbook and FCA Final Guidance (FG) 18/4: The FCA’s approach to the review of Part VII insurance business transfers. 2
target_text: Chapter 2 is aimed at any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, proposing to make an application to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme under section 107 of the FSMA or to accept such a transfer. Chapter 2 is also aimed at the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report under section 109 of FSMA.

question: How should a firm reconcile the prohibition against holding an expenses provision below the prudent amount needed to cover likely net contract-fulfilment costs under a 12‑month new-business cessation scenario with the requirement that the provision reflect the firm’s last‑12‑months actual expenses and prudent assumptions about inflation in prices and earnings affecting future expenses?
gold_answer: The firm must treat the expenses provision as subject to a minimum prudential threshold: it must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (net of taxation effects) that would likely be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease transacting new business twelve months after the valuation date [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f]. To support and shape those prudent assumptions, the firm must base the provision on evidence from its actual expenses in the twelve months before the valuation date and must explicitly consider how inflation will affect future expenses, using prudent assumptions about future increases in prices and earnings [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc]. Practically, the firm should start from the observed recent expense experience, adjust it for expected inflation impacts on future expenses under prudent price and earnings growth assumptions, and then test whether the resulting provision is at least sufficient to cover the likely net fulfilment costs under the specified cessation-of-new-business scenario, ensuring it does not fall below that required amount.
source_text: In accordance with 13.2 , a firm’s provision for expenses, whether implicit or explicit, must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of the effect of taxation) that would be likely to be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date .
target_text: The provision mentioned in 13.1 must have regard to the firm's actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and the effects of inflation on future expenses on prudent assumptions as to the future rates of increase in prices and earnings.

question: Where must an Applicant look to obtain the pro forma public notice of application and the pro forma letters of application, and what does the referenced appendix contain and how are its materials accessed?
gold_answer: The pro forma public notice of application and the pro forma letters of application are provided by reference to Appendix 2, which is the location where those pro forma materials are set out [#SRC:b1049e5f12f3de1c]. In the cross-referenced requirement, the same appendix is described as consisting only of one or more forms, and it directs the reader to obtain those forms via a specified address rather than implying additional narrative content within the appendix itself [#TGT:a46060c909d8df17]. Read together, this means an Applicant seeking the pro forma notice and pro forma application letters should treat Appendix 2 as a forms-only repository and should use the address indicated in the appendix to locate and retrieve the relevant forms. Accordingly, compliance practice should focus on ensuring the Applicant uses the correct Appendix 2 forms for both the public notice of application and the letters of application, and that the Applicant follows the appendix’s access direction (through the stated address) to obtain the current versions of those forms, since the appendix is characterized as containing forms only [#SRC:b1049e5f12f3de1c] and as being accessed through the provided address [#TGT:a46060c909d8df17].
source_text: A pro forma public notice of application, and pro forma letters of application are set out in Appendix 2 .
target_text: This appendix consists only of one or more forms. Forms are to be found through the following address:

question: For a firm that is within scope as being in its first fee year, what must it do to determine and pay periodic fees, and what valuation basis and time horizon must it use for that calculation?
gold_answer: Where the scope condition is met—i.e., the firm is treated as being in its first fee year—the firm is required to pay periodic fees using a specific calculation basis tied to its early-stage business activity. In particular, the obligation applies to a firm in its first fee year [#SRC:90259c5cdf2b7c1b], and it must pay periodic fees that are calculated based on the firm’s projected valuation. The projected valuation is not open-ended: it must relate to the first twelve months of the firm’s new business, meaning the firm must form a projection covering that initial twelve‑month period and use that projection as the basis for the periodic fee calculation and payment. This links the applicability boundary (first fee year) with the required method (projected valuation over the first twelve months of new business) so that, when the firm is in its first fee year, it cannot default to another valuation basis or a different time horizon for periodic fees. These requirements are set out as the applicable scope [#SRC:90259c5cdf2b7c1b] and the corresponding payment obligation [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666].
source_text: (a) 3.7 for firms in their first fee year ;
target_text: A firm in its first fee year pays periodic fees based on its projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business as follows:

question: Where a firm undertakes restructuring, pairing or grouping of assets within the scope of assets involving restructuring, pairing or grouping as referred to in the asset restructuring section, what must the firm do with its supervisor, and what additional planning is expected when the purpose is to obtain a portfolio of MA eligible assets and secure compliance with the MA eligibility conditions?
gold_answer: Where a firm’s activity falls within the scope of assets involving restructuring, pairing or grouping as referred to in the asset restructuring section [#SRC:9dc01e47b05ba20c], and the firm is doing so as part of risk transformation transactions to obtain a portfolio of MA eligible assets, the PRA expects specific supervisory engagement and planning steps. The PRA recognises that firms may use transactions such as securitisation or hedging arrangements specifically to secure compliance with the MA eligibility conditions, and it links that recognition to an expectation that the firm should discuss its plans with its supervisor at the earliest opportunity [#TGT:793e976574893053]. In addition, when engaging in such restructuring, pairing or grouping, the firm should also be considering contingency options in case it is not possible to transform the asset cash flows in a way that meets the eligibility criteria [#TGT:793e976574893053]. Taken together, the scope framing of the relevant asset activity [#SRC:9dc01e47b05ba20c] and the PRA’s stated expectations [#TGT:793e976574893053] mean the firm should treat early supervisory discussion and contingency planning as integral to the restructuring approach.
source_text: assets involving restructuring, pairing or grouping as referred to in the asset restructuring section in Chapter 2 of this SS (paragraphs 2.52 to 2.61A ); and/or
target_text: The PRA recognises firms may undertake certain risk transformation transactions in order to obtain a portfolio of MA eligible assets. In particular, firms may be entering into securitisation transactions or putting in place hedging arrangements, specifically to secure compliance with the MA eligibility conditions. A firm that engages in such restructuring, pairing or grouping of assets should discuss its plans with its supervisor at the earliest opportunity and should also be considering contingency options in case it is not possible to transform the asset cash flows in a way that meets the eligibility criteria.

question: If a firm does not yet have a preceding financial year, what minimum guarantee fund amount applies for long-term insurance business, instead of using the table based on the firm’s highest annual contribution income?
gold_answer: Normally, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is worked out by using a table: you identify the firm’s highest annual contribution income for that business in any preceding financial year, find the matching income band in column 1, and then take the corresponding amount from column 2 [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993]. But that method only works if the firm has a preceding financial year to look back to. If the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, the definition provides a direct fallback amount rather than requiring any table lookup or income comparison. In that situation, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000 [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]. So, for a newer firm without a preceding financial year, you apply the fixed £90,000 figure; once the firm has a preceding financial year, the table-based approach tied to the highest annual contribution income becomes the relevant way to determine the amount.
source_text: Subject to 6.2 , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is the amount in column 2 of the following table, which corresponds to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in respect of that business in any preceding financial year , as shown in column 1 of the table:
target_text: If a firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000.

question: When calculating the group solvency of the group, how must the participating Solvency II undertaking treat certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking where those own funds cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking, and how does the definition of items assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR for a related undertaking affect that treatment?
gold_answer: In calculating the group solvency of the group, the participating Solvency II undertaking must exclude from the calculation any certain own funds that are eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking but cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which the solvency of a group is calculated [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. The only permitted inclusion is a limited one: those own funds may be included solely to the extent that they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking, and no further [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. The definition in the paired text reinforces how “cannot effectively be made available” is operationalised by specifying that particular items of a related undertaking are to be assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR, and it applies across related undertakings that are a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697]. Where an item falls within that assumed-not-available category, it triggers the prohibition on including it for group coverage purposes, subject only to the limited eligibility-for-the-related-undertaking carve-out [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] and the definitional scope of related undertakings [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697].
source_text: Subject to 9.4A and 9.4B , where certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking (other than those referred to in 9.2 and 9.3 ) cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which the solvency of a group is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the calculation of the group solvency of the group unless they are, and only in so far as they are, eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking .

question: If a firm says it has transferred enough risk on a Standardised Approach exposure portfolio, what does it have to do under the PRA’s approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios, including how it should look at tranche thickness and what it must compare the detachment point to?
gold_answer: Where a firm is seeking to justify that commensurate risk has been transferred for a portfolio of Standardised Approach (SA) exposures, it must follow the PRA’s approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios by doing two connected things. First, the PRA expects the firm to take a prudent view of the thickness of the tranches that are actually used to transfer risk—meaning tranches sold to third parties and/or tranches on which protection is purchased—because those tranche features are part of how the firm is demonstrating CRT [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. Second, when making the CRT justification, the PRA expects the firm to compare the detachment point (D) of the tranches sold or protected against the portfolio’s K SA, which is calculated using the risk-weighted exposure amount of the underlying exposures as if they had not been securitised, multiplied by 8% and divided by the value of the underlying exposures [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. Together, these steps reflect and implement the PRA’s stated approach to assessing commensurate risk transfer for SA portfolios [#SRC:621804de98de0e6a].
source_text: (8) ‘ Assessment of commensurate risk transfer (CRT) for portfolios of Standardised Approach (SA) exposures ’ – the PRA’s approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios.
target_text: The PRA expects firms to consider the thickness of tranches sold to third parties or tranches on which protection is purchased, for portfolios of SA exposures, in a prudent manner. When justifying that commensurate risk has been transferred, the PRA expects firms to compare the detachment point (D) of tranches sold, or on which protection is purchased, against the K SA (RWEA in respect of the underlying exposures as if they had not been securitised multiplied by 8% and divided by the value of the underlying exposures) of the portfolio.

question: When a ring-fenced body enters into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, how must it ensure the transaction terms meet the arm’s length requirement, and to what extent may the firm rely on compliance with existing regulatory requirements and OCIR record-keeping to evidence and document the relevant intragroup dependencies and arrangements for PRA review?
gold_answer: A ring-fenced body must ensure that any transaction it enters into with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate is conducted only on arm’s length terms, so the pricing and other terms should be set and supported as if agreed between independent parties [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c]. In meeting this obligation, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations for intragroup outsourcing arrangements, including where those arrangements are subject to requirements in Operational Continuity and the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook; such compliance may also mean those banks meet certain expectations relevant to intragroup outsourcing, including expectations connected to business continuity and exit planning [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, provided the relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. Together, these materials can help a firm demonstrate that intragroup arrangements and dependencies are understood and documented while the ring-fenced body still adheres to the arm’s length transaction requirement [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c].
source_text: Where relevant, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations in respect of their intragroup outsourcing arrangements. For instance, for some banks, intragroup outsourcing arrangements may be subject to the requirements in Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook. Compliance with these requirements may also mean those banks meet certain expectations in this SS in respect of intragroup outsourcing arrangements (for instance, in respect of business continuity and exit plans (see Chapter 10 )). The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document their intragroup dependencies, as long as relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request. 23
target_text: A ring-fenced body must enter into a transaction with a member of its group which is not a ring-fenced affiliate only on arm’s length terms.

question: In calibrating a new bank’s PRA buffer, when may the PRA move from the time-limited approach to using the bank’s stress testing assessments in line with established banks, and under what exceptional circumstances is the PRA permitted to diverge from the stated calculation approach to justify an earlier transition?
gold_answer: The PRA’s baseline procedure is that its approach to setting the PRA buffer for new banks is designed to support them in their early years and is therefore time-limited; once the relevant conditions no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer is calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, consistent with the approach for established banks [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. In addition, the PRA can introduce that established-bank calibration earlier where it identifies heightened risks to its objectives, effectively accelerating the transition point that would otherwise occur only after the time-limited conditions fall away [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. Separately, when exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA is permitted, in exceptional circumstances, to diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, including where the stated approach would not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]. That permitted divergence also expressly encompasses cases where heightened risks to the PRA’s objectives justify an earlier transition to a PRA buffer in line with established banks, aligning the permission to depart from the stated method with the earlier-transition trigger described in the procedure [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a].
source_text: The PRA’s approach for setting the PRA buffer is designed to support new banks in their early years of operation, and as such is time-limited. Once either of the conditions set out above (paragraph 4.8 ) no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer will be calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks. However, as stated in paragraph 4.12 , such an approach could be introduced earlier where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives.
target_text: When exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA may, in exceptional circumstances, diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, for instance where the stated approach does not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. Such divergence could also include instances where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives which justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks.

question: For a firm carrying on long-term insurance business, how must the minimum guarantee fund be determined when the usual table-based calculation tied to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in a preceding financial year cannot be applied because the firm lacks a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The definition operates in two linked steps that must be read together. Ordinarily, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is determined by selecting the amount shown in column 2 of the relevant table, matched to the firm’s highest annual contribution income for that business in any preceding financial year (with the income band identified in column 1) [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993]. However, that table-based approach depends on the existence of a preceding financial year from which the firm’s highest annual contribution income can be identified. Where the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, the definition provides a specific substitute amount: the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000 [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]. In practice, this means a newly established firm (or one without a completed preceding financial year) does not attempt to infer or approximate a “highest annual contribution income” for table selection; instead, it applies the fixed £90,000 minimum guarantee fund until it has a preceding financial year that enables the standard table correspondence to be used.

target_text: If a firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000.

question: For firms covered by the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations (including ‘UK trading banks’), who should be made responsible for overseeing booking arrangements, where must that responsibility be recorded, and when might someone in the parent or group entities need SMF7 approval?
gold_answer: For firms within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations—including PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that meet the ‘UK trading bank’ description (UK-headquartered or part of a UK-based group, with investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas)—the expectations apply as described, with the text also indicating that the PRA distinguishes between expectations that apply to international banks alone and those that apply to international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. Where applicable, the PRA expects the firm to allocate responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record this appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. In addition, if individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, the firm should consider whether it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), recognising that firms have sought SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. We make clear in the relevant sections where the expectations apply to international banks alone, and where they apply to international banks and UK trading banks. See paragraph 4.24B for a summary of the terminology used to describe the scope of application for the booking expectations.

question: When determining the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (excluding liabilities already due before the valuation date), how must the firm ensure the determination both reflects generally accepted actuarial principles and also considers the characteristics and duration of the assets backing those liabilities, including prudence for potential future asset value changes?
gold_answer: The firm must make the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (other than liabilities that have fallen due for payment before the valuation date) using generally accepted actuarial principles, with due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders, and it must make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62]. In parallel, the determination must take into account the nature and term of the assets representing those liabilities and the value placed upon those assets, and it must include prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of the assets [#SRC:77cfb62c67129fc6]. Read together, this requires an integrated valuation approach: actuarial methodology and policyholder-expectation considerations must be applied in a way that is consistent with the asset profile supporting the liabilities, and the prudence embedded in the assumptions and margins must also address the risk that asset values may change in the future. The outcome should therefore reflect both liability-side prudence (including margins for adverse deviation) and asset-side prudence (including provision for potential future asset value movements).

target_text: In accordance with 6.2 to 6.4 , the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (other than liabilities which have fallen due for payment before the valuation date ) must be made in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles and have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders and make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation.

question: If you are updating a governance pack that lists SS5/16, SS21/15, the EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance, and SS28/15, what date should you show for SS28/15 and what Bank of England page should you use to pull the document?
gold_answer: If your governance pack groups SS28/15 (strengthening individual accountability in banking) together with SS5/16 on corporate governance and board responsibilities, SS21/15 on internal governance, and the EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance (EBA Governance Guidelines), you should keep SS28/15 aligned with that same governance reference set [#SRC:2c626199be43f728]. For the specific dating and sourcing details to include for SS28/15, the date shown should be December 2020, and the document should be pulled from the Bank of England’s prudential regulation publication page at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2015/strengthening-individual-accountability-in-banking-ss [#TGT:add0c244e780cb55]. This approach ensures your pack is internally consistent: it reflects that SS28/15 is the accountability-focused item within a broader governance list, and it uses the Bank of England page and December 2020 date as the concrete reference point for the SS28/15 source you are relying on.

question: If a firm is using transitional arrangements and the PRA is assessing its capital position until the end of 2023, what does IFRS 9 mean in this context, including when it was issued and when it became effective?
gold_answer: In this context, IFRS 9 is the accounting standard that sets the rules for accounting for financial instruments and replaces the earlier rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39 [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]. The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary, and it will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for IFRS 9 until the end of 2023 where firms are using these arrangements [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7]. The definition details that IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and, following endorsement for use in the EU, is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018 [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]. Putting these together, when the PRA assesses a firm’s capital position under the IFRS 9 transitional arrangements through end-2023, the relevant accounting baseline is the IFRS 9 framework (issued July 2014; effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018; replacing IAS 39) that governs financial instruments accounting [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary based on other factors. These include, but are not limited to: the firm’s leverage ratio; Tier 1 and total capital ratios; risks associated with double leverage; and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not captured fully as part of the stress test. Until the end of 2023, the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9, 53 where firms are using these arrangements.
target_text: 53. IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and sets out new rules for accounting for financial instruments, replacing the rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39. Following endorsement for use in the EU, IFRS 9 is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. The PRA’s communications to firms on IFRS 9 are available on the Bank’s website at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/letter/2017/transition-disclosures-for-ifrs9-financial-instruments .

question: For a firm that is not a small CRR firm, a credit union or a third country CRR firm, how should it determine which responsibilities it must allocate to one or more persons who perform, given that the term “prescribed responsibility” is defined by reference to responsibilities set out in the relevant rule?
gold_answer: A firm that falls within scope (i.e., it is a firm other than a small CRR firm, a credit union or a third country CRR firm) must allocate each of the prescribed responsibilities to one or more persons who perform, and it must do so for the set of responsibilities identified as prescribed responsibilities for this purpose [#SRC:936b595d900da181]. To determine what counts as a “prescribed responsibility” that must be allocated, the firm should apply the definition that treats every responsibility set out in the relevant rule as a prescribed responsibility [#TGT:a05fb83553247826]. Read together, the obligation establishes the allocation requirement and the definition establishes the universe of items that are subject to that requirement: the firm must ensure that none of the responsibilities that are “set out in this rule” are left unallocated, because each such responsibility is, by definition, a prescribed responsibility. Accordingly, compliance requires (i) confirming the firm is not within the excluded categories, and then (ii) allocating all responsibilities that the rule itself sets out, to one or more persons who perform, without omitting any responsibility that the definition captures. [#SRC:936b595d900da181] [#TGT:a05fb83553247826]

question: When a firm undertakes a solvent exit—i.e., ceasing its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent—what actions should it plan to take regarding deposits and liabilities, and how must a building society address the additional consequence that transferring and/or repaying all deposits affects its ability to meet the principal purpose test and may require dissolution steps?
gold_answer: A solvent exit is defined as the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent, and the firm is expected to structure that process around the orderly transfer and/or repayment of all deposits [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. In its solvent exit planning, the firm should build in sufficient time and resources to support meeting liabilities when they fall due and to complete the transfer and/or repayment of deposits, recognising that the solvent exit ultimately ends after deposit-taking activity is removed from the firm’s Part 4A permission or the permission is cancelled [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a]. The target obligation clarifies that this process does not necessarily lead to liquidation and is circumstance-dependent, so planning should not assume liquidation as the default outcome [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]. However, if the firm is a building society, transferring and/or repaying all deposits has a specific regulatory consequence: it will mean the building society ceases to meet the principal purpose test, so it should also take into account the steps necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986 [#TGT:401295982d2ab654].
source_text: A solvent exit means the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent. 2 The firm should transfer 3 or repay (or both) all deposits as part of its solvent exit. 4 In the firm’s solvent exit planning, it should build in sufficient time and resources to support the firm in meeting liabilities when they fall due and in transferring and/or repaying all deposits. At a point after this, a solvent exit will end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission, or with the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (hereinafter referred to as the removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). 5
target_text: 4. A solvent exit does not necessarily result in the liquidation of the firm, as it depends on the circumstances. If the firm is a building society, the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits will mean it ceases to meet the principal purpose test. Therefore, a building society should also take into account steps which are necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986.

question: If a derivative transaction seems to have more than one important risk driver, what must institutions do to map it to risk categories, and how does that fit with the rule that mapping is based on the primary risk driver as the only material risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions have to align the mapping approach across both texts. The TARGET requires institutions to do the mapping based on the primary risk driver of the derivative transaction, and it also states that the primary risk driver is the only material risk driver of that transaction [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]. The SOURCE addresses the situation where a transaction has more than one material risk driver and sets the mapping outcome: institutions must map the transaction to more than one risk category, except where all material risk drivers are in the same risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; where the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each such category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Taken together, institutions must ensure their mapping is driven by the relevant risk driver basis (primary/most material) while applying the SOURCE’s rules on whether mapping occurs once or across multiple risk categories.
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.
target_text: Institutions shall conduct the mapping referred to in paragraph 1 on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction. The primary risk driver shall be the only material risk driver of a derivative transaction.

question: What does a third country branch need to do to regularly check whether its systems and internal controls are working well and fix problems it finds, and how does this depend on the firm employing staff with the right skills and expertise for the responsibilities they are given?
gold_answer: A third country branch should have a routine approach to monitoring and regularly evaluating whether its systems, internal control mechanisms and governance arrangements are adequate and effective, and it should take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies it identifies through that process [#SRC:ccbb370053078096]. For that routine checking and fixing to be effective, the firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise needed to carry out the responsibilities allocated to them, considering the nature, scale and complexity of the business and the nature and range of financial services and activities it undertakes [#TGT:e5e58d967893ceaf]. Put together, the branch’s regular evaluation work should be assigned to people who are capable of performing it, and the people responsible for follow-up actions should be capable of designing and carrying out the measures needed to address deficiencies. The staffing requirement supports the branch’s ability to run the monitoring cycle properly and to ensure that identified weaknesses are addressed in a timely and competent way.
source_text: A third country branch should monitor and, on a regular basis, evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements established in accordance with the Internal Governance of Third Country Branches 5.1 and section 5 of this supervisory statement and take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies.
target_text: A firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise necessary for the discharge of the responsibilities allocated to them, taking into account the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of financial services and activities undertaken in the course of that business.

question: If a firm triggers an SPF for restructuring by engaging, or preparing to engage, in the restructuring activity, does it have to include third‑party fees and disbursements that are billed to the PRA for help with the PRA’s related regulatory work?
gold_answer: Yes. Once an SPF for restructuring becomes payable because a firm engages, or prepares to engage, in activity that involves it undertaking or making arrangements with a view to the specified outcomes, the payable amount must be calculated in a way that also captures certain external costs incurred by the PRA. The procedure says to add any fees and disbursements that a third party provider invoices to the PRA, but only where those charges are for services performed for the PRA and are connected to assisting the PRA in carrying out the relevant regulatory work. In other words, the trigger for payment is the firm’s engagement (or preparation to engage) in the restructuring activity [#TGT:28f11ba870345a3b], and the calculation step requires including third‑party invoiced fees and disbursements to the PRA that relate to supporting the PRA’s performance of that regulatory work [#SRC:f9e22b9441fa0c58].

question: When an institution has made a pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP, how must it calculate the own funds requirement using the approach that applies to those contributions, and how is the exposure value of that pre-funded contribution defined for this purpose, including any reduction where the QCCP has already applied part of the contribution to absorb losses after a clearing member default?
gold_answer: An institution that has made pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP must calculate the own funds requirement for those contributions by applying the specified approach for such calculations [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]. To do that consistently, the institution must first determine the exposure value of its pre-funded contribution to the QCCP default fund (DFi) using the definition that sets the measurement basis for that contribution [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af]. Under that definition, the exposure value is anchored to what the institution has actually provided to the default fund—either the amount paid in or, where assets are delivered, the market value of those assets. The definition also requires a specific adjustment that directly affects the exposure used in the calculation: the exposure value must be reduced by any amount of the institution’s contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb losses, but only where those losses arise following the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members. In practice, the institution’s own funds requirement calculation should therefore be based on this net exposure value, reflecting both the initial contribution and any qualifying loss-absorption usage by the QCCP.
source_text: (a) it shall calculate the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP in accordance with the approach set out in Article 308 ;
target_text: The exposure value for an institution's pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP (DFi) shall be the amount paid in or the market value of the assets delivered by that institution reduced by any amount of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb its losses following the default of one or more of its clearing members .

question: Can an institution use the Section 4 method to work out the exposure value of its derivative positions if it is using the methods in Sections 4 to 5, and what does it have to do to show its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is small enough?
gold_answer: Yes, but only if the institution meets the permission’s conditions and uses the right sizing basis. Where the institution is in the category of institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is the size calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2), as applicable [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1]. The institution may then calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method set out in Section 4 only subject to the restriction referenced for that permission and provided that this size measure is equal to or less than both thresholds required for eligibility [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]. It also has to keep checking this: the thresholds must be tested based on an assessment carried out monthly, using data as of the last day of each month, so the institution must monitor and evidence compliance on that recurring monthly basis rather than relying on a single point-in-time calculation [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2].
source_text: (m) for institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the size of their on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business as calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2) , as applicable.
