question: If a TWD firm needs to update the TWD option within weeks, how should it decide what counts as a “material component,” and what must it set up so it can consistently refresh assumptions, modelling/methodology, and scenario factors when changes could affect decisions?
gold_answer: A TWD firm must be able to refresh the material components of the TWD option within weeks through a “full plan refresh,” which includes updating the assumptions and approximations that inform the TWD option, updating the modelling or methodology used for information provision and decision-making, and updating the factors that make up the TWD scenario [#SRC:76a8dbf9e47fc1dd]. To decide what is in scope for that refresh, material components are those where the impact of a change could influence decision-making, and TWD firms must define what they mean by “material component” and set thresholds for what level of change is treated as material [#TGT:8d564dede4742c2a]. In practice, the firm’s definitions and thresholds provide the consistent trigger points for identifying decision-relevant changes and ensuring they are captured in the full plan refresh within the required weeks-long timeframe, rather than being handled ad hoc or inconsistently across different assumptions, methods, or scenario drivers.
source_text: Refresh capabilities: these capabilities enable a firm to refresh the information supporting the development and execution of the TWD option in a timely manner. Firms should be able to refresh data on their balance sheet (including data on trading book positions at the individual contract, collateral and asset levels), their quantification of wind-down costs, and capital and liquidity projections, within a matter of days (the ‘data refresh’). Firms should be able to refresh the material components of the TWD option, including changes to assumptions and approximations that inform the TWD option, changes to the modelling or methodology firms use as part of their information provision and decision-making capabilities, and changes to the factors that make up the TWD scenario within weeks (the ‘full plan refresh’). 10
target_text: 10. Material components are those whereby the impact of a change could influence decision-making. TWD firms should define material component and change thresholds.

question: Can a firm put only part of a with-profits annuity contract into an MA portfolio if the contract could be treated as split into parts (for example because premiums may be paid up front and then in instalments), and what does the PRA expect the firm to show?
gold_answer: A firm can include only a component of a with-profits annuity contract in an MA portfolio, but only where that component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, can be organised and managed separately in accordance with the IRPR requirements, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]. However, the PRA does not accept an approach that merely notionally splits a contract into parts as compatible with Matching Adjustment 2. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e]. This matters in practice for contracts that have features such as an option for the premium to be paid as an initial sum followed by smaller instalments, because a firm might be tempted to treat different payment-related elements as separate “parts” without a legally established guaranteed component [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e]. To rely on the component approach, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment showing that the only elements included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance, and to set out a clear policy on where future attaching bonuses will sit (in the MA portfolio or elsewhere) [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]. The firm should also be able to demonstrate that the MA portfolio can be managed separately from the rest of the business, consistent with the PRA’s stated concern about notional splitting [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7].
source_text: Some contracts of insurance include an option for the premium to be paid as an initial sum followed by a series of further (smaller) instalments. Except in the limited cases set out in paragraphs 3.5A , 3.5B and 3.5C above, the PRA does not view any approach that notionally splits a contract into parts as being compatible with Matching Adjustment 2.3 . The PRA’s view is that such a treatment would also undermine the ability of the insurer to manage its MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, as required by regulation 4(6)(b) of the IRPR regulations.
target_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.

question: If the firm intends to include an item issued under a debt securities programme within basic own funds eligible for the group SCR, and the undertaking is establishing or amending that programme, what must the firm ensure regarding (i) the basic own funds character of instruments issued under the programme and (ii) the impact of any post-notification legal or interpretive changes on information previously notified to the PRA?
gold_answer: In the scenario where an undertaking proposes to establish or amend a debt securities programme for the issue of an item the firm intends to include within the basic own funds forming the own funds eligible for the group SCR, the firm must treat the programme as a controlled framework for producing instruments with the intended capital classification [#TGT:d43cd8def623245e]. First, the firm must ensure that the programme’s terms themselves require that any instrument issued pursuant to the programme constitutes basic own funds; the obligation attaches at the programme level and applies to every issuance under it [#SRC:a0002fe3a6bea784]. Second, the firm must ensure the programme complies with requirements and that the information previously notified to the PRA in relation to the programme remains unaffected by any changes in law or regulation, or by changes in the interpretation or application of either, that have come into effect since the last notification [#SRC:a0002fe3a6bea784]. Practically, this means the firm must both embed basic own funds status into the programme documentation and perform a forward-looking check for legal or interpretive developments that could undermine the continued accuracy of what was previously notified, before proceeding with establishment or amendment for group SCR-related inclusion [#TGT:d43cd8def623245e].

target_text: If an undertaking proposes to establish or amend a debt securities programme for the issue of an item which the firm intends to include within the basic own funds forming the own funds eligible for the group SCR , the firm must:

question: If a transferor society and a transferee society want to pay bonuses to help equalise the reserves going into the combined society, what approvals must members give in the Merger Resolutions, and when does the prescribed limit mean every participating society’s Merger Resolutions must include that approval?
gold_answer: A bonus may be paid to members of a transferor society where it has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society, to help equalise the reserves both bring to the combined society; and if it is also desired to pay a bonus to members of the transferee society, the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio, but only if it is prudent to do so [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]. Even where such payments are permitted on that basis, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. The prescribed limit then determines how widely that approval must be included: if the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) is within the prescribed limit, approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8], regardless of whether the bonus is being used to equalise reserves between the transferor society and the transferee society [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6].
source_text: A bonus may, for example, be paid to the members of a transferor society with a higher capital ratio than the transferee society so as to equalise the reserves which both bring to the combined society. If it is thought desirable also to pay a bonus to the members of the transferee society, then the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the capital ratio of the transferee society, but only if it is prudent to do so. The statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If Institutions put the required disclosures inside their financial statements or financial reports, what must be true about that section, and how should the risk management objectives and policies be laid out across different risk categories?
gold_answer: If Institutions choose to include the required disclosures within their financial statements or financial reports, they must present them as a distinctive section that is included in or appended to those statements or reports and is easily identifiable to users. They must also ensure that this approach still delivers a readily accessible source of prudential information and meets the requirement that all required information is disclosed electronically in a single medium or location. In that same identifiable section, Institutions must disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, and they must include the risks referred to in the applicable Title. This means the section should not be a general narrative scattered throughout the report; it needs to be clearly set apart and organized so users can find the risk management objectives and policies by risk category while still accessing the full set of required disclosures in one electronic place [#SRC:8422ed9edcda5caa] and ensuring coverage of each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in the Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].
source_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.
target_text: Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in this Title. These disclosures shall include:

question: Who counts as a person indebted to a society on a land-secured loan, and how does that connect to when a society or subsidiary undertaking may use derivative investments to reduce how much it (or a connected undertaking) is affected by changes in a borrower’s creditworthiness?
gold_answer: A person fits the definition if they are indebted to a society in respect of a loan that is fully secured on land, or, where the Rules so provide, substantially secured on land [#TGT:7856ac9ac9cb1882]. That matters because the permission on derivative investments is framed around limiting exposure to specified changes, including changes in the creditworthiness of any borrower(s) [#SRC:bf19a4f593cb137a]. So, if the society is considering derivatives to manage the risk that a borrower’s ability to repay deteriorates, it should first confirm the borrower is indebted to the society under a qualifying land-secured loan as described in the definition. If that condition is met, the permission supports using derivative investments to limit the extent to which the society, its subsidiary undertaking, or a connected undertaking will be affected by that borrower creditworthiness change. The same permission also covers limiting impacts from interest rates, exchange rates, and certain price indices, but the borrower-creditworthiness link is the key connection to the defined land-secured indebtedness category.
source_text: (b) those which allow a society or subsidiary undertaking to use derivative investments in order to limit the extent to which it, or a connected undertaking, will be affected by changes in interest rates, exchange rates, any index of retail prices, any index of residential property prices, any index of the prices of securities, or the creditworthiness of any borrower(s). 2
target_text: 2. A person who is indebted to a society in respect of a loan fully, or where the Rules so provide, substantially secured on land.

question: When allocating responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm), what must a firm do in terms of establishing and maintaining policies and procedures to ensure compliance by the firm and its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents), and to counter financial crime risk?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that the governance arrangements assigning responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm) are supported by adequate, operating controls. Specifically, the firm must establish, implement and maintain policies and procedures that are sufficient to ensure compliance by the firm and by its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents) with the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system, and that also counter the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304]. In practice, this means the firm’s compliance framework should be designed so that the compliance function can operate independently and be effectively overseen, with clear accountability for monitoring its performance and for supervising any FCA-approved individual performing compliance oversight on the firm’s behalf [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789]. The policies and procedures should therefore be adequate not only in design but also in implementation and ongoing maintenance, so they remain effective as the firm’s activities and risks evolve.
source_text: (16) responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function, including the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm , in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K) ;
target_text: A firm must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents ) with its obligations under the regulatory system and for countering the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime .

question: If the directors of a society are planning a merger, what do they need to check with their external auditors before applying for approval, and what does the PRA mean by the “relevant requirements of the Rules” that could later be treated as not met?
gold_answer: When a society is contemplating a merger, the directors need to satisfy themselves, in consultation with their external auditors, that the society’s systems can deliver the merger-related information that is expected, because the PRA will require an assurance on that capability when the society applies for approval of the Schedule 16 Statement [#SRC:4238cf753ff75039]. To understand what procedural compliance areas this assurance should support, the PRA defines the “relevant requirements of the Rules” as those Rules that set out the procedure to be followed, particularly around membership, special meetings, notice of meetings, procedure at meetings, members’ entitlement to vote on resolutions, appointment of proxies, and joint shareholders and borrowers [#TGT:7927c5a64f38a519]. This definition matters because, at the confirmation stage, the PRA has to consider whether a relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled; directors should therefore ensure their systems and processes can generate information and evidence that supports compliance with those procedural topics and enables the required assurance to be provided at the approval-application stage [#SRC:4238cf753ff75039] and assessed against the PRA’s stated scope [#TGT:7927c5a64f38a519].
source_text: It will be necessary for the directors of a society contemplating a merger to satisfy themselves, in consultation with their external auditors, that the society’s systems are capable of delivering the information described above. The PRA will require an assurance on this point when the society applies for approval of the Schedule 16 Statement (see paragraph 3.98(e) ). One of the criteria which the PRA has to consider at the confirmation stage is whether some relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled (see paragraphs 3.172 to 3.177 ).
target_text: The PRA considers that the relevant requirements of the Rules are those which prescribe the procedure to be followed that is, in particular, the Rules concerning membership, special meetings, notice of meetings, procedure at meetings, entitlement of members to vote on resolutions, appointment of proxies and joint shareholders and borrowers.

question: When setting parameters for an internal model, what must Firms do to ensure they do not rely solely on historical data in a way that fails to reflect all quantifiable risks, and how does this interact with the requirement for the data used in the internal model to meet specified quality standards?
gold_answer: Firms must treat parameter-setting data as subject to the same expectation that it captures relevant non-hedgeable risks and does not omit quantifiable risks simply because it is drawn from history. In practice, Firms should not proceed on the assumption that using only historical data to parameterise the internal model will reflect the full range of quantifiable risks; instead, they must consider whether the distribution used is capable of capturing the full range of possible future events, including by demonstrating this through stress and scenario testing where relevant [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645]. At the same time, the data used for the internal model must meet the baseline quality requirement that it is accurate, complete and appropriate, which means Firms must ensure the dataset is not only technically correct and sufficiently comprehensive, but also suitable for the purpose of capturing the risks the model is intended to quantify [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0]. Read together, these obligations require Firms to combine data-quality controls with a forward-looking assessment of whether historical parameterisation is adequate, and to evidence any decision to use an unadjusted historical distribution as capturing future-event variability.
source_text: The concept of ENID also applies to the data used to set the parameters for the internal model, in line with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11.4 . Firms should not assume that parameterising the internal model using only historical data will take into account all quantifiable risks, unless an unadjusted distribution has been shown to capture the full range of possible future events, for example by way of stress and scenario testing.
target_text: (1) Data used for the internal model must be accurate, complete and appropriate.

question: What does the credit union have to do to keep the right amount and type of liquid assets over time, and how does that relate to the minimum liquid assets it must hold compared with its total relevant liabilities?
gold_answer: The credit union has to manage liquidity as an ongoing requirement by maintaining, over time, both the quantity and the quality of the liquid assets it holds, and it must do this while taking account of the minimum liquidity requirement that applies [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. This means the credit union should not only look at how much liquidity it has today, but also ensure that the liquid assets it relies on remain suitable (quality) and are maintained over time as part of its continuing liquidity position. Alongside that broader maintenance obligation, there is a specific minimum quantitative threshold: a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. Put together, the credit union’s ongoing plan for how much liquidity to hold and what form it should take must be set up so that the liquid asset position stays at or above that 10% minimum, while also meeting the expectation that the assets maintained are of appropriate quality and are managed continuously over time [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce] in line with the minimum requirement [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf].
source_text: the quantity and quality of liquid assets to be maintained by the credit union over time, taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements in Rule 9.2 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook; and
target_text: A credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities .

question: For general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, how is the scope of the applicable requirement determined across the two regimes—specifically, which underlying provision is triggered in each, what percentage substitution must be applied, and what condition set must be satisfied for the substitution to operate?
gold_answer: Where the business is general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, each regime brings a different underlying provision into scope and modifies it by substituting a different percentage, but only once the relevant conditions are met. Under the SOURCE, the applicable framework is the one that would otherwise apply under the referenced provision, but it is applied on a modified basis: the percentage used is substituted to 8.66% in place of 26%, and this modified application is contingent on satisfying the conditions identified as those in 7.5 (1) to (5) [#SRC:19c9e8d0b9a70534]. Under the TARGET, the same type of business instead triggers application of 7.4, again with a substitution mechanism: 6% is substituted for 18%, and this operates only if the “following conditions” are satisfied as specified in that text [#TGT:c34927b3fbe2f827]. Read together, the scope boundary is the same business type, but the operative provision, the substituted percentage, and the way the condition set is referenced differ between the two passages.

question: If a related Solvency II undertaking that is included in the group solvency calculation has already put an own funds item into a tier, what tier must the group use, and when can the group still put the same item into Tier 1 even if the undertaking used Tier 2?
gold_answer: As a general rule, when a related Solvency II undertaking that is included in the calculation of the group solvency has classified an own funds item into one of the three tiers using the tiering criteria, the group must classify that own funds item in the same tier at group level, as long as the additional requirements for that treatment are met [#TGT:669a47dbe318f67a]. But the rules also allow a limited exception so that the undertaking’s tier choice does not automatically block a different group result. Specifically, if the related Solvency II undertaking has included an own funds item in Tier 2 even though the item would qualify for inclusion in Tier 1, that Tier 2 classification does not prohibit the group from classifying the same item in Tier 1 at group level, provided the relevant group-level limits are complied with [#SRC:d7efe71fb905e0c9]. In practice, this means the group should first check whether it can meet the conditions for mirroring the undertaking’s tier, and then assess whether the item meets the conditions for the permitted Tier 1 classification at group level despite the undertaking’s Tier 2 treatment.
source_text: Notwithstanding 8A.1 , where a related Solvency II undertaking has included in Tier 2 own funds an own funds item which would qualify for inclusion in Tier 1 own funds in accordance with Own Funds 3E.1(11) , that classification shall not prohibit the classification of the same own funds item in Tier 1 own funds at group level, provided that the limits set out in Own Funds 4A.3 are complied with at group level.

question: If the Merger Document includes the Schedule 16 Statement, what does the board have to say about any material financial changes since the period covered by the financial information, and what should it do if it cannot put a number on the impact?
gold_answer: When the Merger Document is being provided and it includes the Schedule 16 Statement (along with the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments), the board must deal with the fact that the financial information will cover a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Specifically, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim, so members have a clear, direct statement rather than assumptions [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. If there has been a change but the effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members at least know it has been identified and that it matters to their consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. This obligation sits within the broader requirement to provide the Merger Document including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1].
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: What does the PRA say its statement is adding to its insurance supervision approach, and what is the named document it points to as the baseline for that approach?
gold_answer: The PRA explains that its statement is meant to add detail to its existing insurance supervision approach by expanding on the PRA’s general approach and then setting out the PRA’s expectations of firms in a clear and consistent way for the specific areas covered by the statement [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064]. In other words, the statement is not presented as a standalone approach; it is positioned as building on an already-published framework for how the PRA supervises insurance. The baseline document the PRA points to for that general approach is explicitly identified as “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s approach to insurance supervision, June 2014,” with a link to the publication [#TGT:ca54d7921f57df42]. The PRA also explains why it is providing this additional clarity: it seeks to advance its statutory objectives by supporting the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and contributing to an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064]. Finally, the PRA notes that it has considered matters it is required to have regard to and considers the statement compatible with the Regulatory Principles and relevant provisions of the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006 [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064].
source_text: This statement expands on the PRA’s general approach as set out in its insurance approach document. 1 By clearly and consistently explaining its expectations of firms in relation to the particular areas addressed, the PRA seeks to advance its statutory objectives of ensuring the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates, and contributing to securing an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders. The PRA has considered matters to which it is required to have regard, and it considers that this statement is compatible with the Regulatory Principles and relevant provisions of the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006.
target_text: 1. The Prudential Regulation Authority’s approach to insurance supervision, June 2014; https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/prudential-regulation/approach/insurance-approach-2014.pdf

question: Within the PRA’s expectations for how firms disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme, what must a firm do if it withdraws from or is excluded from the deposit guarantee scheme, and how does the intended cross-reading with the Depositor Protection Part rules affect the scope of that disclosure duty?
gold_answer: The chapter defines the disclosure context by setting out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme, and it is expressly intended to be read together with the rules in the Depositor Protection Part of the PRA Rulebook (Chapters 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23) [#SRC:e2e3d0af57f2615a]. Within that scoped disclosure framework, a firm has a specific, time-bound obligation: if it withdraws from or is excluded from the deposit guarantee scheme, it must inform depositors within one month [#TGT:b611159cf94e0b70]. Read together, the source establishes that the PRA’s expectations govern the manner and content of firms’ disclosures about the scheme, while the target supplies a concrete trigger event (withdrawal or exclusion) and a mandatory deadline (“must inform depositors within one month”) for communicating that change to depositors [#SRC:e2e3d0af57f2615a] [#TGT:b611159cf94e0b70]. Accordingly, the firm should treat the one-month depositor notification as part of its broader scheme-related disclosure approach under the PRA’s expectations and the associated Depositor Protection Part rules.
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will disclose information about the relevant deposit guarantee scheme and is intended to be read together with the rules contained in Chapters 16 , 17 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 22 and 23 of the Depositor Protection Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: A firm must inform depositors within one month if it withdraws from or is excluded from the deposit guarantee scheme .

question: What do Institutions have to do to set up hedging sets the right way, and how do they have to group them by risk category for a netting set and place each transaction into the right hedging set?
gold_answer: Institutions have two linked duties that must be satisfied at the same time. One duty is about the standard they must follow when creating hedging sets: all hedging sets must be established in accordance with the specified requirements, so the establishment process must follow that referenced approach rather than being done ad hoc [#SRC:aad180c11178b9e8]. The other duty is about how those hedging sets must be organized and used in practice: Institutions shall establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and shall assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a]. Put simply, Institutions must (1) create hedging sets in the required manner, and (2) do so in a structured way for each netting set by setting up hedging sets per risk category, then (3) ensure every transaction is allocated into the appropriate hedging set. Together, these requirements ensure both compliant setup and consistent transaction-to-hedging-set assignment.
source_text: (e) all hedging sets shall be established in accordance with Article 277a(1) ;

question: When applying the expectation to treat an outsourcing or third party arrangement as material where a defect or failure could materially impair the firm, how must a firm interpret the scope of “material outsourcing” given the PRA’s clarification that it is used for clarity and is intended to cover arrangements that would otherwise be treated as “critical or important outsourcing” under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the materiality expectation to outsourcing and third party arrangements by using the PRA’s clarified meaning of “material outsourcing” as the operative scope for assessment. The PRA explains that it uses “material outsourcing” for clarity and to avoid confusion with other overlapping regulatory terms, and that, for all intents and purposes, a “material outsourcing” arrangement encompasses a “critical or important outsourcing” arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]. Therefore, when the firm follows the expectation to generally consider an arrangement as material where a defect or failure in performance could materially impair the firm, it should not treat “material” as a narrower category than “critical or important”; rather, it should treat the categories as effectively covered within the PRA’s “material outsourcing” framing [#TGT:52624254f79512d2]. In doing so, the firm should also align its identification approach to the criteria that are substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria (where applicable), recognising that the PRA notes there are a few justified exceptions, including references to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b].
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
