question: If a firm has just received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, what must it send to the PRA within three months, and what must its deposit-marking method allow staff or systems to do for eligible deposits?
gold_answer: A firm that has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits must meet both a reporting requirement and an operational requirement that the report should address. Within three months of receiving the permission, the firm must provide the PRA with a report describing its systems for complying with the applicable requirements, so the PRA can understand how the firm intends to meet those obligations in practice [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558]. At the same time, the firm must ensure that eligible deposits are marked in a way that allows those deposits to be identified immediately, which means the marking must be set up so eligible deposits can be recognised straight away when needed [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. In practical terms, the systems described in the report should therefore explain how the firm will implement and maintain the marking of eligible deposits so that immediate identification is possible, and how that marking capability forms part of the firm’s overall compliance systems that are being reported to the PRA within the three-month deadline [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558] [#TGT:60b306349873ce31].
source_text: A firm must provide the PRA with a report on its systems to comply with 11.1 and 11.2 within three months of receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: If a firm becomes aware that an actuary position will be vacant soon or is already vacant, what does it have to do so the With-Profits Actuary function is still covered for all its with-profits business classes?
gold_answer: If a firm becomes aware that an actuary role that is required will become vacant or is already vacant, it must respond to that situation by ensuring there is an effective appointment in place so the With-Profits Actuary function continues without a gap. The key procedural trigger is the firm’s awareness of the vacancy (whether future or current), which indicates the firm needs to take action because a required actuary role is not, or soon will not be, filled [#SRC:0702ff457fb0e143]. At the same time, the firm’s underlying duty is clear: a firm carrying on with-profits insurance business must appoint one or more actuaries to perform the With-Profits Actuary function for all classes of its with-profits insurance business [#TGT:869d49551453c204]. Putting these together, once the firm knows a vacancy will arise or has arisen, it should make or adjust its appointment(s) so that one or more actuaries are appointed and the With-Profits Actuary function remains performed across every class of its with-profits insurance business, despite the vacancy event [#SRC:0702ff457fb0e143] [#TGT:869d49551453c204].
source_text: (1) when it becomes aware that a vacancy of an actuary required under 2.1 or 2.2 will arise or has arisen:
target_text: A firm carrying on with-profits insurance business must appoint one or more actuaries to perform the With-Profits Actuary function in respect of all classes of its with-profits insurance business .

question: What does a firm need to do to make sure its non-executive directors can think and decide independently and challenge executives, and how should it use the Joint ESMA and EBA suitability guidelines and the PRA Rulebook’s General Organisational Requirements when setting this up?
gold_answer: A firm should apply good governance principles to all PRA-regulated subsidiaries by ensuring the board has enough independence to challenge the business, and by meeting its obligation to ensure all directors—especially non-executive directors—act with independence of mind and make their own sound, objective, independent decisions when carrying out their functions [#SRC:a498a9c92e081d73]. The firm should also ensure non-executive directors can hold management to account for what has been delegated to management and can challenge executives effectively and promptly, rather than only providing passive oversight [#SRC:a498a9c92e081d73]. If a smaller and less complex subsidiary does not plan to have an independent non-executive chair, the firm should still be able to explain how its governance arrangements provide independent oversight of executives through other means [#SRC:a498a9c92e081d73]. In designing and evidencing these arrangements, the firm should take account of relevant external references on suitability and organisation, including the Joint ESMA and EBA Guidelines on assessing suitability of members of the management body and the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook [#TGT:f9459c2cbbae00e1].
source_text: The principles of good governance should apply to all PRA-regulated subsidiaries, including the principle that boards should have sufficient independence, to help ensure they can provide effective challenge to the business. Where a smaller and less complex subsidiary proposes not to have an independent non-executive chair, the firm should still be able to explain how its governance arrangements will otherwise satisfy the need for independent oversight of the executives. Moreover, all firms have an obligation to ensure that all their directors, in particular non-executives, act with sufficient independence of mind and ‘make their own sound, objective and independent decisions and judgments when performing their functions and responsibilities’. 28 The non-executive directors on the board should hold management to account against the matters delegated, and be able to challenge the executive effectively and promptly. Firms should have regard to the expectations on board responsibilities outlined in SS5/16 ‘Corporate governance: Board responsibilities’. 29
target_text: 28. Joint European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and EBA Guidelines on the assessment of the suitability of members of the management body, paragraph 80. https://eba.europa.eu/regulation-and-policy/internal-governance/joint-esma-and-eba-guidelines-on-the-assessment-of-the-suitability-of-members-of-the-management-body . See also the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook

question: When an institution acts as a clearing member for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, what must it do to determine the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP, and how must the resulting sum of own funds requirements for exposures to a QCCP arising from trade exposures and default fund contributions be constrained?
gold_answer: Where an institution acts as a clearing member, either for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it is required to calculate the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP in accordance with the prescribed approach for that calculation [#TGT:90f89b9de841e0ff]. In addition, for the purposes of the relevant calculation context, the institution must apply a limiting constraint to the aggregate outcome for certain QCCP-related components: specifically, the sum of the institution’s own funds requirements for its exposures to a QCCP that are due to trade exposures and default fund contributions is not permitted to exceed a cap. That cap is defined by reference to a counterfactual calculation—namely, the sum of own funds requirements that would be applied to those same exposures if the CCP were treated as a non-qualifying CCP [#SRC:61d9b5a70f557f6d]. Taken together, the institution must both perform the required clearing-member calculation for CCP exposures and ensure that, for the specified QCCP exposure categories, the aggregate own funds requirement is bounded by the non-qualifying CCP benchmark cap.
source_text: For the purposes of paragraph 1 , the sum of an institution's own funds requirements for its exposures to a QCCP due to trade exposures and default fund contributions shall be subject to a cap equal to the sum of own funds requirements that would be applied to those same exposures if the CCP were a non-qualifying CCP.

question: In implementing the derogation that requires institutions to establish separate individual hedging sets in each risk category, what is the compliance significance of the defined index that denotes all interest risk rate hedging sets for the netting set, and how should institutions ensure consistency between the required hedging-set establishment and the index’s scope?
gold_answer: The compliance significance is that the required establishment of separate individual hedging sets in each risk category must be reflected in, and be traceable through, the defined index that denotes the full population of interest risk rate hedging sets for the netting set. The obligation requires institutions to establish separate individual hedging sets in each risk category for the specified transactions [#TGT:a3cc17fc347e6b59]. Separately, the definition provides that “j” is the index that denotes all the interest risk rate hedging sets established for the netting set in accordance with the referenced establishment provisions [#SRC:73f861950b2825dc]. Read together, institutions should ensure that the hedging sets they establish under the derogation are not only created as separate individual sets by risk category, but also fall within the universe of hedging sets that “j” is intended to denote for that netting set. This supports consistent identification and referencing: “j” should map to the complete set of established interest risk rate hedging sets, including those created to satisfy the separate-set requirement.

question: For societies that are not publicly quoted, what is the required governance standard they must take into account when establishing and reviewing corporate governance arrangements, and how should the relevant version of the Combined Code be identified by reference to its defined scope and timing?
gold_answer: Societies that are not publicly quoted are expected, when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements, to take into account an appropriate governance code; specifically, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or, where appropriate, the Combined Code [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]. Determining when the Combined Code is the appropriate reference point requires using the definition of that term: it is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council, and it is tied to accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010 [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]. Read together, this means a society’s obligation to consider a governance code is not limited by its unquoted status, but the selection between the UK Corporate Governance Code and the Combined Code should be made by applying the defined temporal scope of the Combined Code (i.e., whether the relevant accounting period begins before the stated date) and recognising its provenance (the Financial Reporting Council’s Corporate Governance Committee). This supports consistent governance benchmarking when arrangements are created and periodically reassessed.
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: When forecasting the impact of a TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, what must TWD firms ensure about the completeness and usability of the risk and trade data used to produce financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, including the ability to segment trading portfolios for different wind-down actions?
gold_answer: TWD firms must ensure that their forecasting capability is supported by both robust analytical capability and sufficiently complete underlying inputs. Specifically, they should have the methodologies, models, and frameworks needed to forecast how the TWD scenario affects capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity across the period from the reference date through wind-down [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e]. To make those forecasts credible and operable, the supporting dataset should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, and it should also contain information that enables segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways to support execution choices during wind-down (such as different ways of packaging trades for novation) [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. In practice, this means the data must be comprehensive enough to feed the models and frameworks and flexible enough to be re-aggregated or re-cut to reflect alternative portfolio management actions, so that projected impacts on capital and liquidity remain consistent with the portfolio segmentation used in the wind-down approach.
source_text: This should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis in paragraphs 4.25 - 4.51 , including information to support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways (for example, alternative packaging of trades for novation).

question: When the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy to MREL set by the Bank (for both interim and end-state MREL), what do the Threshold Conditions mean and why do they matter?
gold_answer: Here, the Threshold Conditions mean the PRA’s statutory minimum requirements that firms must meet so they are permitted to carry on the regulated activities they undertake, and they are intended to promote safety and soundness as a crucial part of how the PRA’s regulatory regime operates [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff]. The scope for using that meaning is that the PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy together with the Threshold Conditions policy in respect of MREL that is set by the Bank, and it will do so for both interim MREL requirements and end-state MREL requirements [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. Putting these together, when MREL is set by the Bank, the PRA’s application of the MREL buffer policy is linked to its application of the Threshold Conditions policy, and the relevant Threshold Conditions are those minimum statutory requirements that determine whether a firm can continue to conduct its regulated activities, with the stated objective of supporting safety and soundness [#TGT:fae17596a3a12aff], across both the interim and end-state stages of MREL requirements [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe].
source_text: The PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy ( Chapter 2 ) and Threshold Conditions policy ( Chapter 3 ) in respect of MREL set by the Bank with respect to both interim and end-state MREL requirements.
target_text: The PRA’s statutory Threshold Conditions, which set out the minimum requirements that firms must meet in order to be permitted to carry on the regulated activities in which they engage, are designed to promote safety and soundness and are crucial to the operation of the PRA’s regulatory regime.

question: When a firm uses external credit rating assessments in calculating technical provisions and the SCR and relies on additional assessments to test their appropriateness, what must the firm do to ensure those additional assessments are governed by its risk management policy and are reviewed on an annual cycle?
gold_answer: Where a firm assesses the appropriateness of external credit rating assessments used in the calculation of technical provisions and the SCR by using additional assessments, it must embed the relevant requirements within its policy on risk management and also operate an ongoing review cadence for those additional assessments. Specifically, the firm must include in its risk management policy the elements required for using additional assessments to support the appropriateness assessment of external credit rating assessments for technical provisions and the SCR [#TGT:53e44a3e4a1680e9]. In addition to setting this governance and documentation framework, the firm must at least annually review the additional assessments it uses for that purpose, ensuring the review is performed in accordance with the referenced framework and applies to the additional assessments in scope [#SRC:1dd4e886ea27eeba]. Taken together, the obligations mean the firm cannot treat additional assessments as ad hoc: they must be formally addressed in the risk management policy and then revisited at least once each year to maintain their continued suitability for assessing the appropriateness of the external credit rating assessments used in those calculations.
source_text: (1) In accordance with 2.4 , a firm must at least annually review the additional assessments referred to in 3.6B .

question: When the PRA’s external audit rules apply to an undertaking’s SFCR, does the external audit scope extend to assessing the scale of the matching adjustment, and does that scope include quantifying the financial-position impact of changing the matching adjustment to zero because of its effect on Life Technical Provisions?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the PRA’s external audit rules apply, the scale of the matching adjustment—described as the extent to which the MA impacts on technical provisions—falls within the scope of audit because the MA’s impact is treated as part of the “relevant elements” on which external auditors of the SFCR are required to form a view [#SRC:428012445d83f28d]. Consistently, the scope includes quantification work that captures the impact of the MA on the undertaking’s financial position, including the specific example of quantifying the effect of a change to zero of the MA, which is specified as a relevant element of the SFCR [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf]. In addition, the MA’s direct effect on Life Technical Provisions brings it within the scope of the External Audit rule, reinforcing that audit coverage is not limited to narrative disclosure but extends to the measured impact of the MA where it affects technical provisions and the undertaking’s financial position [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf].
source_text: The scale of the matching adjustment (ie the extent to which the MA impacts on technical provisions) is within scope of audit where the PRA’s external audit rules apply. 6 This reflects the fact that the impact of the MA falls within the ‘relevant elements’ that external auditors of the SFCR are required to form a view on. 7
target_text: 7. For example, the quantification of the impact of a change to zero of the MA on that undertaking’s financial position is specified as a relevant element of the SFCR (External Audit 2.2(1) and Rules 3.4(1)(a) and (b) in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. In addition, the MA has a direct effect on Life Technical Provisions which are within scope of the External Audit rule.

question: Where the PRA is consulted on the development of the Bank’s SoPs but does not directly supervise against them, what must a firm do to ensure its resolution preparations are sufficiently robust to minimise disruption of critical services, including by developing and executing the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring?
gold_answer: The firm must ensure it is prepared for resolution so that, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]. The SOURCE clarifies that, although the PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC, the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies and the Bank’s approach promotes the PRA’s safety and soundness objective [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. Accordingly, the firm should implement the Bank’s SoPs as part of its resolution preparedness framework to translate the TARGET requirement into actionable internal capabilities and processes, while recognising the supervisory nuance described in the SOURCE [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. In particular, the SOURCE states that implementing these SoPs will help TWD firms develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring, which supports the firm’s ability to carry out resolution-related actions in a controlled way consistent with orderly resolution and continuity of critical services [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52; #TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0].
source_text: The PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC. However, the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies. The Bank’s approach acts to promote the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8 in the Fundamental Rules Part of the PRA Rulebook. Implementing these Bank’s SoPs will help TWD firms to develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: If a firm thinks an arrangement with a third party is outside the outsourcing rules, how can it check whether it is actually “outsourcing” under the PRA Rulebook, and what still applies if it is a “third party arrangement” instead?
gold_answer: To check whether an arrangement is “outsourcing,” the firm should test it against the PRA Rulebook definition, not just assume it is outside scope. The definition focuses on whether there is an arrangement (in any form) between a firm and a service provider (whether a supervised entity or not) where the service provider performs a process, service, or activity—either directly or through sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise do itself [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. As part of that assessment, the firm should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis, which is a factor in deciding whether the arrangement falls within the outsourcing definition [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. If the arrangement does not meet that definition, it can be treated as a “third party arrangement,” meaning it is outside the scope of existing requirements on outsourcing and some detailed expectations [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2]. Even so, it is still subject to the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations on business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management, including cyber risk [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2].
source_text: Chapter 2 elaborates on the definition of ‘outsourcing’ in the PRA Rulebook. It also notes that there are arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside this definition (‘third party arrangements’) and are consequently outside of the scope of existing requirements on outsourcing and some of the detailed expectations in this SS. However, these third party arrangements are still subject to the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations on business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management (including but not limited to cyber risk).
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: If something says it applies only to the first sentence of a valuation rule, what does a firm have to do when it first recognises financial liabilities under UK-adopted international accounting standards, and what part about later credit-standing changes is not covered by that limited scope?
gold_answer: The scope note makes clear that only the first sentence of the valuation text is in scope, so you should treat the initial-recognition valuation requirement as the applicable obligation and treat the later sentence as outside that limited application. Under the first sentence, a firm must value financial liabilities that are referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards using the specified approach at the point of initial recognition [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6]. The same valuation text then contains a second sentence that deals with what happens after initial recognition, stating that a firm must not make subsequent adjustments to reflect changes in the firm’s own credit standing. However, because the scope statement restricts application to the first sentence only, that later prohibition is not part of what is covered by the scoped application described in the scope note [#SRC:98186a002f1f50ae]. So, the limited scope applies to how the firm values the liability when it is first recognised, and it does not extend to the separate, later instruction about not adjusting for changes in the firm’s own credit standing after that point.
source_text: applies to the first sentence of Valuation 10.1 .
target_text: A firm must value financial liabilities, as referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards , in accordance with 5 upon initial recognition. A firm must not make any subsequent adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the firm after initial recognition.

question: In an amalgamation, when the amalgamating societies submit their application to the PRA, what must they do regarding the number and execution status of the Rules and Memorandum they provide to the PRA and the FCA, and how does that obligation align with the expectation that proposed Memorandum/Rules and any Rule changes have been cleared with the FCA and the PRA during the pre-application discussions for the Schedule 16 Statement?
gold_answer: For an amalgamation, the amalgamating societies must treat the submission to the PRA as a formal step that follows prior regulatory engagement. Before filing, they are advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage, reflecting that the FCA must be satisfied as to the proposed Rules, Memorandum and name of the successor society [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724]. Consistently, the process described for a society’s formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement anticipates many weeks of discussion in which the PRA’s staff review and comment on drafts, and societies should have cleared any proposed Rule changes—or, in an amalgamation, the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society—with both the FCA and the PRA [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535]. When the amalgamating societies then apply to the PRA for confirmation, they must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to both the PRA and the FCA, ensuring the regulators receive executed versions aligned with the drafts previously discussed and cleared [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724].
source_text: In the case of an amalgamation, the FCA is required to be satisfied as regards the proposed Rules, Memorandum and name of the successor society. The amalgamating societies are, therefore, advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage (see paragraph 3.96 ). When they apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, the amalgamating societies must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to the PRA and the FCA (Section 93(2)(d)). If the FCA is satisfied on these matters it will, upon confirmation by the PRA , register the successor society and issue to it a certificate of incorporation specifying the date (the specified date) from which the incorporation takes effect, and will return to it one copy each of the Rules and Memorandum together with a certificate of registration. Copies are placed on the public file of the successor society.
target_text: A society’s formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement is likely to be the culmination of many weeks of discussion with the PRA’s staff who will have reviewed and commented upon a draft or successive drafts of the Statement, having had regard also to drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and the prudential information described in ‘Preliminary matters’ . Societies should also have cleared any proposed Rule changes or, in the case of an amalgamation, the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society, with the FCA and the PRA.

question: For assets with contractually bounded but uncertain timing of cash flows, how should a firm determine whether it may treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and what portfolio-level limit applies to the MA benefit created by that HP cash flow proportion?
gold_answer: Where a firm is considering assets whose cash-flow timing is uncertain but bounded (eg, where redemption or repayment timing can vary within contractual bounds), the firm should assess whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and can be demonstrated not to present a material risk to the quality of matching. In the SS, assets that meet the relevant criteria and for which firms can demonstrate no material risk to matching quality are defined as “assets with HP cash flows” [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. The SOURCE indicates that, if the assets meet the HP cash flow criteria, firms may include them in the MA portfolio as part of a limited proportion permitted for such assets, rather than relying solely on a case-by-case assessment against the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. In applying this permission, the firm must also observe the aggregate portfolio constraint: the proportion of the MA portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: When a firm carries on long-term insurance business, how must it ensure its margin of solvency remains at or above the guarantee fund, given that certain items are prohibited from being counted toward compliance?
gold_answer: A firm must manage its capital position so that its margin of solvency does not fall below the guarantee fund, and it must do so without relying on items that are expressly disallowed for compliance purposes in the long-term insurance context. Specifically, where the firm is conducting long-term insurance business, the unpaid initial fund of a firm and implicit items relating to future profits and zillmerising are not permitted to be taken into account for meeting the relevant compliance requirement [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1]. Accordingly, when assessing whether the margin of solvency is sufficient relative to the guarantee fund, the firm should exclude those prohibited components from the calculation or evidencing of compliance, and ensure that the remaining eligible resources are adequate to keep the margin of solvency above the guarantee fund threshold as required [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9]. In practice, this means the firm must be able to demonstrate that, even after removing any contribution from the unpaid initial fund and the specified implicit items, its margin of solvency still meets or exceeds the guarantee fund level, and it should monitor this on an ongoing basis to prevent any shortfall.
source_text: In the case of long-term insurance business , the unpaid initial fund of a firm and implicit items which relate to future profits and zillmerising may not be taken into account in complying with 4.2 .
target_text: A firm must ensure that its margin of solvency does not fall below the guarantee fund .

question: For which wholesale LGD models must firms apply the specified assessment framework, and what are the scope limits or exclusions (including any sovereign treatment) when using that framework to evaluate conservatism and calibration in low-default portfolios?
gold_answer: Firms should use the stated framework when assessing wholesale LGD models in the specific circumstances referenced in the supervisory statement, meaning its use is conditional on those defined circumstances rather than being a universal requirement for all LGD workstreams [#SRC:0d1c3826fa54a61a]. Within that overall requirement, the framework’s intended scope is to assess the conservatism of firms’ wholesale LGD models where there is a low number of defaults, and it is the framework set out in Appendix C that is being applied for that purpose [#TGT:e7a136c2be9a20b6]. The scope is also expressly bounded by an exclusion: it does not apply to sovereign LGD estimates that are floored at 45%, so firms should not use this framework for those sovereign estimates even if they otherwise relate to LGD [#TGT:e7a136c2be9a20b6]. In terms of supervisory use, the framework is being used to assess the calibration of firms’ material LGD models for low-default portfolios, aligning the procedural expectation to “use” the framework with a defined application to conservatism and calibration in low-default wholesale LGD models [#SRC:0d1c3826fa54a61a] [#TGT:e7a136c2be9a20b6].
source_text: The following framework should be used to assess wholesale LGD models in the circumstances set out in paragraph 13.15 of this supervisory statement:
target_text: We have developed a framework for assessing the conservatism of firms’ wholesale LGD models for which there are a low number of defaults. The framework is set out in Appendix C and does not apply to sovereign LGD estimates which are floored at 45%. We are in the process of using this framework to assess the calibration of firms’ material LGD models for low-default portfolios.

question: What must a firm do to make sure its expenses provision is not set too low for the likely net cost of fulfilling contracts if it stops taking new business 12 months after the valuation date, and how must it use its actual expenses from the last 12 months and prudent inflation assumptions when setting that provision?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its provision for expenses, whether it is implicit or explicit, is not less than the amount required on prudent assumptions to meet the total net cost (after allowing for taxation effects) that would likely be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f]. At the same time, the firm must build that provision by having regard to what it actually spent on expenses in the twelve months before the valuation date and by considering how inflation will affect future expenses, using prudent assumptions about future increases in prices and earnings [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc]. In other words, the firm cannot pick a low number: it must ground the provision in recent real expense experience, adjust for prudent inflation impacts on future expenses, and then confirm the resulting provision is at least enough to cover the likely net costs of fulfilling contracts under the scenario where new business stops after twelve months.
source_text: In accordance with 13.2 , a firm’s provision for expenses, whether implicit or explicit, must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of the effect of taxation) that would be likely to be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date .
target_text: The provision mentioned in 13.1 must have regard to the firm's actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and the effects of inflation on future expenses on prudent assumptions as to the future rates of increase in prices and earnings.

question: If a TWD firm wants to check whether it can produce the data the PRA expects under this SS, how do the PRA’s templates and instructions and Template A help it judge the required breadth and detail, especially for exit costs and liquidity flows?
gold_answer: A TWD firm can use the PRA’s templates and accompanying instructions as the main reference point for what the PRA would expect the firm to be able to produce under the SS, because those materials are described as providing a guide to the breadth and granularity of the required data outputs [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c]. Template A (Appendix 1) helps the firm make that expectation more concrete by showing the kind of data breadth and detail that should be available to demonstrate a specific capability: analysing exit costs and liquidity flows. In doing so, Template A highlights that the firm should be able to segment the balance sheet by method and price of exit, which implies the firm’s data production needs to support those breakdowns so the analysis can be performed in a structured way rather than at a single aggregated level [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8]. So, the firm should compare what it can currently produce against the PRA’s templates/instructions generally, and then use Template A as a focused check that it can produce sufficiently granular, segmented balance-sheet data to support exit-cost and liquidity-flow analysis as expected [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c] [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8].
source_text: Template A (Appendix 1) provides a guide to the breadth and granularity of data that TWD firms should be able to provide to demonstrate an ability to analyse exit costs and liquidity flows through the segmentation of the balance sheet by method and price of exit.
target_text: The following templates and accompanying instructions provide a guide to the breadth and granularity of data that the PRA would expect TWD firms to be able to produce under this SS. They are available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2021/october/trading-activity-wind-down .

question: If a new and growing bank is loss making at first and needs regular capital injections, what does it need to do to make sure it gets new capital early enough to avoid going into capital buffers, and why is this important given that some banks wait until the last minute to secure investment?
gold_answer: A new and growing bank that is loss making initially and relies on regular capital injections is expected to work toward profitability and organic capital generation within a reasonable time after authorisation, and—until it becomes profitable—to have a credible capital plan that ensures new capital is injected in good time so it does not enter capital requirements plus buffers [#SRC:a16e16fe3364010b]. This matters because poor capital management is described as a common issue for new and growing banks, including waiting until the last minute to secure the investment needed to keep operating without entering capital buffers [#TGT:0b17ba9a4e4a6431]. When investment is delayed, a bank can end up entering its capital buffers in the normal course of business, which is not aligned with PRA policy, or it may have to raise extra capital under difficult conditions. That kind of reactive fundraising can also become a major distraction for management. So the credible plan is not just about having access to capital in theory; it is about timing and certainty so capital is available before buffers are threatened.
source_text: New and growing banks are often loss making initially and rely on regular capital injections to maintain their capital adequacy. The PRA understands this is often a feature of new businesses, but it is of course not sustainable over the longer term and creates a vulnerability to capital not being available when needed. Banks should focus on reaching profitability and the ability to achieve organic capital generation within a reasonable time period following authorisation, recognising that the longer they are unprofitable, the more uncertainty there is about whether investor sentiment will remain positive. By around three years post-authorisation, the PRA expects banks to have more clarity over their path to profitability. By five years post-authorisation, banks should either be profitable or have a credible strategy to achieve profitability, with definite capital support to achieve this. If the firm is of a size to require minimum requirement for own funds and eligible liabilities (MREL) at greater than minimum capital requirements within this planning horizon, it needs to factor in those requirements (see paragraph 4.4 ). The PRA, however, recognises that a number of factors, including the nature of the business model, could impact the path to profitability, and will apply flexibility in exceptional circumstances where the path to profitability is credible and there is sufficient financial resources in place in advance to manage the risks around that path. At least until profitability is achieved, the PRA expects firms to have a credible capital plan which will ensure new capital is injected in good time to avoid capital requirements plus buffers being entered. There will be no delay in transitioning to the PRA buffer on a stress test basis (see Chapter 4 ) if there is a delay in achieving profitability.
target_text: Poor capital management is a common theme across new and growing banks, with such banks often leaving it to the last minute before securing the investment needed to continue operating without entering capital buffers. This can result in banks entering their capital buffers in the usual course of business, which is not in line with PRA policy, or the need to seek additional capital investment under challenging circumstances, which can act as a significant distraction for management.

question: If you need to list the provider and the recipient(s) of a service, who should you name when the service is an intra-entity critical service—can it be a business unit, and if so, which one?
gold_answer: You should still identify both sides of the service relationship by naming the provider and the recipient(s) of the service, so it is clear who delivers the service and who receives it [#SRC:9a27881b26b46dfd]. If the service is an intra-entity critical service, the provider and/or recipient does not have to be an external firm or third party; it may instead be an internal business unit. In that intra-entity context, the business unit providing the service can be treated as the provider, and the business unit receiving the service can be treated as the recipient [#TGT:9c6cdb1878bd46fb]. This approach keeps the provider/recipient identification consistent with how the service actually operates inside the entity: you document the internal organisational units on each side of the service flow rather than looking for outside counterparties. The key is that you do not omit either role—your documentation should still clearly specify the provider and the recipient(s), but you may populate those fields with the relevant business unit(s) when the critical service is delivered within the same entity [#SRC:9a27881b26b46dfd] [#TGT:9c6cdb1878bd46fb].
source_text: the provider and recipient(s) of the service; 17
target_text: 17. For intra-entity critical services, this may be the business unit providing or receiving the service.

question: If a firm has dependants with exposure to the same type of assets, how do you work out the dependant exposure and what do you then have to do to the firm’s own exposure amount?
gold_answer: You must treat the dependant exposure as something that is calculated in a structured way, not estimated informally. Specifically, for each dependant, you calculate its exposure by applying the same provisions used for a firm’s exposure calculation, and you do so as if that dependant were a firm to which those provisions apply, even if it is not actually within scope as a firm [#TGT:d0975ff530ed6e30]. After you have those dependant exposure results, you then adjust the firm’s own exposure figure: the amount of the firm’s exposure to the relevant assets (as determined under the same provisions) must be increased by an additional amount that represents the exposure, if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description [#SRC:250709f3ef53e2f6]. So the sequence is: calculate the firm’s exposure under the provisions, calculate each dependant’s exposure using the same method-as-if-a-firm approach, and then add an increment to the firm’s exposure equal to the dependant exposure amount(s), but only where dependant exposure exists.
source_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.
target_text: For the purposes of 23.1 , the exposure of each dependant must be calculated by applying 18 to 22 to that dependant as if it were a firm to which those provisions apply (whether it is or not).

question: When a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is acquiring or disposing of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity and is complying with the relevant directions, how must a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA be completed, and in what circumstances may the Controller’s Form be used for that submission?
gold_answer: For a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager, the PRA’s direction creates a conditional permission to use the Controller’s Form when the investment manager is acquiring or disposing of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity and is complying with the specified directions connected to that activity [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda]. Separately, when a section 178 notice is submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA, the PRA directs that the notice must include the information and be accompanied by the documents that the Controller’s Form (as approved for the relevant application) requires [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]. Read together, this means that where the investment-manager conditions for using the Controller’s Form are met, the submitter may rely on that form as the vehicle for ensuring the notice contains the required information and supporting documents; however, regardless of the vehicle used, the notice must still meet the Controller’s Form content and document requirements applicable to the relevant application. The practical compliance outcome is that the form’s required fields and attachments set the minimum content standard for the notice, and the investment-manager direction clarifies when use of that form is permitted in the listed-shares fund-management context.
source_text: Where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with the acquiring or disposal of listed shares in the course its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5 .
target_text: The PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by such documents as are required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application.

question: What must a firm do to keep its important business services running within impact tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios, and how should boards and senior management use impact tolerances as a standard to decide where to invest and how to plan recovery and response?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure it can deliver its important business services within impact tolerances even in severe but plausible scenarios, and it should use mapping and testing of those services to work out whether and how it can stay within those tolerances [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950]. Impact tolerances also provide a standard that boards and senior management should use to prioritise investment and to make recovery and response arrangements, so the firm’s resilience work and its governance decisions should be tied to the same tolerance levels [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. Practically, mapping and testing should feed into decisions about what to improve and what recovery and response steps are needed to keep services within tolerances when stressed [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950]. If there is an operational disruption, impact tolerances may help guide decisions, but they should be considered alongside other information relevant to managing the incident effectively, so the response reflects both the tolerance standard and the wider incident facts [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5].
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 17 require firms to ensure they are able to deliver their important business services within impact tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios. Mapping and testing the delivery of important business services will equip firms to establish whether and how they can remain within impact tolerances.

question: Where the Bank and PRA provide links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations for SoP purposes, what must firms and FMIs do in relation to other Guidelines and Recommendations (including those from predecessor committees to the ESAs) that are outside the linked list, and what are the limits on relevance for ESMA updates issued after the transition period?
gold_answer: Firms and FMIs should not treat the linked ESMA materials as the full universe of potentially applicable guidance. The appendices’ lists are described as not exhaustive, and the text gives a specific example that Guidelines and Recommendations made by predecessor committees to the ESAs are not included; nevertheless, firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with such materials unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. At the same time, the SoP frames the scope of the ESMA materials it points to: it provides links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period, and it states that changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for SoP purposes [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024]. The Bank and PRA also acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials, reinforcing that the SoP’s linkage is a scoped reference point rather than an exhaustive compliance inventory [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0].
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials.

question: If a firm uses an implicit expenses provision, what checks must it make so the provision is not below the prudent amount needed for likely net fulfilment costs under the stop-new-business-after-12-months scenario, and what information about past expenses and inflation must it take into account?
gold_answer: Even where the expenses provision is implicit, the firm must ensure it is not less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of taxation effects) that would likely be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f]. To determine and justify those prudent assumptions, the firm must have regard to its actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and must consider the effects of inflation on future expenses, using prudent assumptions about future rates of increase in prices and earnings [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc]. So the firm should (1) look back at its real expense levels over the prior year, (2) apply prudent inflation-related adjustments for future expenses based on expected price and earnings increases, and (3) verify that the resulting implicit provision still meets or exceeds the prudent minimum needed for the likely net cost of fulfilling contracts under the specified cessation scenario.
source_text: In accordance with 13.2 , a firm’s provision for expenses, whether implicit or explicit, must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of the effect of taxation) that would be likely to be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date .
target_text: The provision mentioned in 13.1 must have regard to the firm's actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and the effects of inflation on future expenses on prudent assumptions as to the future rates of increase in prices and earnings.

question: If you are working out the interest rate for this purpose, what are you not allowed to do with (a) the overall rate compared with the adjusted overall yield on assets, and (b) the assumed yield you assign to a long-term insurance business asset before tax effects are considered?
gold_answer: You are prohibited from setting the interest rate for this purpose above the adjusted overall yield on assets, which is defined as a weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets (with those reduced yields worked out under the referenced approach) [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb]. At the same time, you are also prohibited—when attributing an assumed yield to an asset in the long-term insurance business, before making any adjustment for the effect of taxation—from using an assumed yield that is higher than the yield on that asset calculated under the specified yield-calculation provisions, after first reducing that calculated yield by 2.5% of itself [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8]. In practice, this means you must respect both a portfolio-level ceiling (the adjusted overall yield limit for the rate of interest) and an asset-level ceiling (the pre-tax assumed yield limit for each attributed asset). If either ceiling would be breached, the rate or the assumed yield inputs must be lowered to comply.
source_text: (1) In no case must a rate of interest determined for the purposes of 11.1 exceed the adjusted overall yield on assets calculated as the weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets arrived at under 11.2 .
target_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.

question: If a firm uses an intragroup service company to provide staff (so it counts as outsourcing) and the outsourced work is critical or important, what written document should the firm put in place, and does outsourcing change who is responsible for meeting the firm’s legal and regulatory duties?
gold_answer: If a firm’s relationship with an intragroup service company involves provision of staff that is regarded as outsourcing, and the outsourced operational functions or activities are critical or important, the firm should put in place a written agreement with the service provider that clearly sets out each party’s rights and obligations [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a]. However, putting that agreement in place does not shift responsibility away from the firm. When a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245]. In practice, this means the written agreement is a key tool for defining what the service provider will do and what the firm will retain, but the firm must still ensure it can meet all applicable obligations despite the outsourcing. The firm should also consider whether having this type of written agreement creates a requirement under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the balance sheet of the authorised firm [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a].
source_text: Firms should also pay particular attention to relationships with intragroup service companies, where provision of staff can be regarded as having been outsourced to the service company for the purposes of Conditions Governing Business 7 . The Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook requires that, where a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or activities, a written agreement should be entered into between the firm and the service provider which clearly defines the respective rights and obligations of each party. 5 Firms should consider whether a written agreement of this nature leads to a requirement under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the balance sheet of the authorised firm.
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: What do Independent experts need to do when they write an opinion on the likely effects of a scheme, and how should they check whether different kinds of policyholders could be affected differently at the policyholder level?
gold_answer: Independent experts need to assess the likely effects of the scheme at both the firm level and the policyholder level, so their opinion covers impacts on the firm as well as impacts on policyholders [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67]. When they focus on the policyholder level, Independent experts should also consider whether the scheme may lead to different prudential impacts for different types of policyholders, rather than assuming the effect is the same for everyone [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. This means the policyholder-level assessment should be framed to identify and address any prudential differences that could arise between policyholder types, including the examples of unit-linked policyholders and with-profit policyholders, if those distinctions are relevant to how the scheme operates [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. By combining the dual-level assessment with this check for differentiated prudential impacts, Independent experts can present an opinion that reflects both the overall position and any meaningful variation within the policyholder population [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67].
source_text: The independent expert’s opinion of the likely effects of the scheme should be assessed at both firm and policyholder level 12 and should:
target_text: 12. Independent experts when forming their assessment of the effects of a scheme at the policyholder level should have regard to whether the scheme may give rise to different prudential impacts for different types of policyholders for example unit-linked policyholders and with-profit policyholders.

question: As part of its annual regulatory reporting, what must a firm submit regarding its assessment of the effect of the volatility adjustment within its asset-liability management, and what additional analysis must it provide if setting the matching adjustment or volatility adjustment to zero would cause non-compliance with the SCR?
gold_answer: A firm must include, within the information it reports annually, the relevant assessment that covers the effect of the volatility adjustment as part of the firm’s asset-liability management framework [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] and must submit that assessment as part of the annual reporting package [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]. In addition, if the firm determines that reducing either the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would lead to non-compliance with the SCR, it must also provide an analysis of the measures it could apply in that scenario [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]. That analysis must address how the firm would re-establish the level of eligible own funds covering the SCR or, alternatively, how it would reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]. Taken together, the annual submission therefore needs to (i) document the firm’s assessment of the effect of the volatility adjustment in the context of asset-liability management [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] and (ii) include a contingency-focused measures analysis where removal of the adjustment(s) would otherwise breach the SCR [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389].
source_text: (c) the assessment of the effect of the VA as a part of the firm’s asset-liability management ( Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3 ).
target_text: A firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information reported annually in accordance with Reporting 2 . Where the reduction of the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR , the firm must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply in such a situation to re-establish the level of the e ligible own funds covering the SCR or to reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR .

question: If an Institution is making the listed credit risk disclosures under the CRR, what does it have to say about its risk management objectives and policies, and what table and instructions does it have to follow?
gold_answer: If the Institution is producing the particular set of disclosures that are identified as being required for credit risk of the CRR, those disclosures are within a defined scope that must be prepared in accordance with the Table UK CRA of Annex XV and the relevant instructions in Annex XVI [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2]. For disclosures in that context, Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, and this includes the risks referred to in this Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. So, when the Institution is addressing the scoped credit risk disclosures, it must include information describing its objectives and policies for managing risk, and it must do so in a way that is broken out by each separate risk category rather than being a single undifferentiated description. At the same time, the Institution must ensure the disclosure is structured and completed in line with the specified table and the related instructions, because those materials govern how the required credit risk disclosures are to be made [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2] while still satisfying the obligation to disclose objectives and policies by risk category [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].
source_text: (a) For the disclosures required in points (a), (b), (d), and (f) of Article 435 (1) regarding credit risk of the CRR , in accordance with the Table UK CRA of Annex XV and the relevant instructions set out in Annex XVI .

question: Where a firm uses an internal model, what must it submit to the PRA each year in relation to the analysis of change, and how does the PRA’s AoC.01 template shape the content and completion of that submission (including the information on movement in SCR and the required quantitative and qualitative elements)?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model must make an annual submission to the PRA using template AoC.01 to provide the required analysis of change. The obligation is to submit AoC.01 each year and ensure it sets out the analysis of change referred to for internal models, comprising both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, and to do so in line with the applicable instructions for that template [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20]. The PRA’s procedure-level material supports how the firm should meet that obligation by providing the AoC.01 template for firms to complete, and by indicating that it is intended to capture key information regarding movement in the SCR, which the firm should populate before submitting to the PRA [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]. Read together, the target establishes the annual duty and the required content categories (quantitative plus qualitative analysis), while the source clarifies that the PRA has issued a specific named template for firms and that completion should focus on key SCR movement information as part of the submission package.
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: What has to be included with the meeting notice for everyone who should get it, and if someone does not get the notice, how should the scrutineers’ report think about whether the meeting is still valid—especially if the problem was a wider system or management decision?
gold_answer: The society must send the Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary in or with the notice, and it must go to every person entitled to receive the notice, so the required document is part of the notice package rather than something optional or separate [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856]. If a person entitled to receive notice does not get it, that non-receipt (or an accidental omission to give notice) does not, by itself, invalidate the meeting proceedings, and the scrutineers’ report may properly take that into account when considering the notice position [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0]. But the protection is limited: “accidental omission” does not include a systemic failure to send notices, such as leaving out new shareholders or borrowers, or missing an entire group/class because of a computer programme fault, and it also does not cover all management errors [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856]. In particular, if management wrongly decided not to send notices to certain persons or groups, that kind of error would not be treated as “accidental” or “non-receipt” for these purposes, so the scrutineers should not rely on the saving principle in the same way [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0].
source_text: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the notice to every person entitled to receive it (paragraphs 2 and 4 of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, ‘accidental omission’ does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new shareholders or borrowers, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management – see also paragraph 4.153 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers’ report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that ‘accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting does not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting’. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that ‘accidental’ and ‘non-receipt’ would not cover all cases of ‘error’ on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: Where a person performs a PRA senior management function, is a firm prohibited from allocating a prescribed responsibility to that person if the person also performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: A person falls within the relevant category if they perform a PRA senior management function (or, in the alternative, an FCA designated senior management function) [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903]. Separately, the prohibition applies to allocation decisions by a firm: the firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4]. Read together, this means that even if an individual is identified by virtue of performing a PRA senior management function, the firm is still barred from allocating a prescribed responsibility to that individual where they also perform an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function. The trigger for the prohibition is the individual’s performance of the FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, and the firm’s act of allocation is the restricted action. The definition-like criterion in the source helps determine whether the person is within the set of senior management function performers, but it does not override the allocation restriction in the target; the firm must ensure its allocation process screens for the FCA other overall responsibility senior management function status before assigning any prescribed responsibility.
source_text: (1) performs a PRA senior management function or, subject to 3.6 (1), an FCA designated senior management function ; and
target_text: (1) A firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function .

question: Where the FSCS has amounts it has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of the levy-related mechanisms, is the FSCS prohibited from setting annual DGS compensation cost levies above the stated percentage cap, and if so what is the only route to impose a higher levy?
gold_answer: If the FSCS has amounts it has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of the relevant levy outcomes, that circumstance does not remove the annual cap on what the FSCS can levy for DGS compensation costs. The FSCS must keep the maximum amount of DGS compensation costs for which it can levy DGS members per calendar year within 0.5% of total covered deposits (excluding temporary high balances) of all DGS members, and it must not exceed that limit as a matter of prohibition [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860]. The existence of unrecovered amounts from DGS members is a separate condition described in the source and does not itself create an automatic exception to the cap [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380]. The only stated route for the FSCS to impose higher levies is where there are exceptional circumstances and the FSCS has obtained the prior consent of the PRA; absent both of those elements, the FSCS remains constrained by the cap even if recovery from DGS members has not been possible [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860] and notwithstanding the unrecovered amounts scenario [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380].
source_text: (2) amounts that the FSCS has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of 33.3 or 33.4 ; or
target_text: The maximum amount of DGS compensation costs for which the FSCS can levy DGS members per calendar year must not exceed 0.5% of total covered deposits (excluding temporary high balances ) of all DGS members . The FSCS may in exceptional circumstances and with the prior consent of the PRA impose higher levies.

question: In classifying an own funds item issued by a related third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, what must the participating undertaking do to satisfy the classification-criteria requirement, and what must the firm do if the item also falls within the category of basic own funds items that are deemed to possess the relevant characteristics and meet all specified features?
gold_answer: The participating undertaking must classify an own funds item issued by a related third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking by using the applicable criteria for classification identified in the own-funds classification framework, and it may do so only where the stated additional requirements are met [#SRC:d91f2be80f93c5ed]. If the same item is also within the set of basic own funds items addressed in the target obligation, the firm must treat that item as substantially possessing the relevant characteristics, making that assessment by taking into consideration the specified features, and then must classify it as Tier 1 own funds provided the item displays all of the features set out in the relevant feature set [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]. The combined effect is that classification is not discretionary: the actor must apply the prescribed classification criteria for the related third-country issuance scenario, and, where the item is one of the specified basic own funds items and meets the full feature test, the classification outcome is mandated as Tier 1. This ensures the classification method (criteria-based, with additional requirements) and the classification result (Tier 1 when the feature conditions are satisfied) are both complied with [#SRC:d91f2be80f93c5ed] [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4].
