question: How must banks maintain and deliver a single customer view and exclusions file to support orderly resolution, and what specific categories of deposits must firms ensure are captured in the exclusions file when responding to a request from the PRA or FSCS?
gold_answer: Banks must maintain both a single customer view (SCV) and an exclusions file to support orderly resolution, and they must be able to provide that SCV and exclusions file to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740]. In parallel, firms must ensure that the exclusions file they are required to provide includes data on deposits that are not in the SCV, with examples including deposits held in client accounts and deposits held via deposit aggregators [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6]. Read together, the operational obligation is not only to keep the SCV and exclusions file current and deliverable on short notice, but also to structure the exclusions file so it clearly identifies deposits excluded from the SCV population, including those specific non-SCV deposit types. This supports the authorities’ ability to use the SCV for covered deposit identification while relying on the exclusions file to understand which deposits are outside the SCV scope and why, within the same rapid response window to the PRA or FSCS request [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] and consistent with the expected content of the exclusions file [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6].
source_text: In order to support orderly resolution, banks must maintain a single customer view and exclusions file, 67 and are required to provide this to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request. 68 Banks’ systems must automatically identify the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and identify any portion of an eligible deposit that is over the specified coverage level. 69
target_text: 67. The exclusions file that firms are required to provide should include data on deposits which are not in the SCV including for example deposits held in client accounts and deposit aggregators.

question: When a firm is considering restructuring an asset via a wholly owned subsidiary special purpose vehicle (SPV), what must the firm do first to assess whether keeping the asset unrestructured would remain appropriate over the expected life of the arrangement as operating conditions change, and how must that assessment be reflected in the firm’s proposals and internal recognition of any resulting risk-profile changes across the firm and the group?
gold_answer: Before proceeding with an SPV-based restructuring, the PRA expects firms to start by assessing whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, taking into account the duration of the restructuring arrangement and the potential for operating conditions to change [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]. That “first step” assessment should inform whether restructuring is justified at all, particularly given the PRA’s expectation that such arrangements are used only where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach (for example, pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows) [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]. If the firm proceeds, restructuring through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group (an SPV) may be acceptable only if the firm’s proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]. The firm must also ensure the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, reflecting the additional complexity and consequential risks introduced [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33].
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the group treat own funds that are only eligible to cover the SCR of the related undertaking, and what quantitative cap applies to the amount of such own funds that may be included so that the group calculation does not rely on amounts beyond the related Solvency II undertaking’s SCR?
gold_answer: In the group solvency calculation, items that fall within the category described in the group-calculation rule must be excluded unless they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking concerned, and then only to the extent of that eligibility [#TGT:d68b868d9faa51ba]. This exclusion/limited-inclusion condition must be applied together with the quantitative constraint on inclusion of own funds: the sum of the own funds included under the relevant inclusion routes must not exceed the SCR of the related Solvency II undertaking [#SRC:d8e1f257c79a1b03]. Read together, the group must (i) start from a presumption of exclusion for the specified items in the group solvency calculation, (ii) allow inclusion only where and to the extent the items are eligible to cover the related undertaking’s SCR, and (iii) ensure that, even where inclusion is permitted, the aggregate amount of own funds included does not go beyond the related undertaking’s SCR. Operationally, this means the group should apply an eligibility screen first and then apply a hard cap at the related undertaking’s SCR to the total own funds it includes via those routes.
source_text: The sum of the own funds included under 9.2 and 9.4 must not exceed the SCR of the related Solvency II undertaking .

question: If a firm is the parent entity of an international group, what must it show in its group recovery plan about entities in other jurisdictions, and how must it explain the links between recovery options (including options that cannot be used together) given dependencies between group entities?
gold_answer: A firm that is a parent entity of an international group must demonstrate in its group recovery plan how it has covered the different entities in other jurisdictions, so the plan clearly addresses the wider group and not just a single entity or location [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. The PRA also expects the firm to understand dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, because these relationships can affect whether and how recovery actions can be carried out across the group [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. Alongside this, the firm must detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive, so it is transparent which options rely on others and which options cannot be pursued at the same time [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6]. In practice, the plan should therefore link the coverage of each relevant group entity (including those in other jurisdictions) with a clear explanation of how recovery options interact, so that the overall recovery approach is internally consistent and any constraints created by group-wide dependencies are explicitly set out [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: If a firm is estimating long-run PDs for a grade or pool, what does it need to do with the length of its data series, and how should it avoid just averaging its own past defaults or updating the estimate every year?
gold_answer: The firm should use a data series of appropriate length so it can produce a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, rather than relying on an arbitrarily short or convenient window [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a]. For PDs that are long-run averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects the firm to estimate expected default rates over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, instead of simply taking the historic average of default rates the firm actually incurred over a period of years [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]. This means the “right” length is the one that helps capture that representative mix, not just the number of years on hand. The PRA also expects that the long-run estimate should be changed when there is reason to believe the current estimate is no longer accurate, but it should not be automatically updated to add each new year of experience, because those additional years may not be representative of the long-run average [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]. So the firm should pick a data series length that supports a representative long-run view and update it only when accuracy is in doubt [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea].
source_text: Principle 3: a firm should use a data series of appropriate length in order to provide a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate referred to in paragraph 10.13 ; and
target_text: In order to estimate PDs that are long-run averages of one year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects firms to estimate expected default rates for the grade/pool over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply taking the historic average of default rates actually incurred by the firm over a period of years. The PRA expects that a long-run estimate would be changed when there is reason to believe that the existing long-run estimate is no longer accurate, but that it would not be automatically updated to incorporate the experience of additional years, as these may not be representative of the long-run average.

question: How must the firm work out how much it is exposed to each type of asset, and when must it add on any exposure of the firm’s dependants, taking into account the stated exceptions?
gold_answer: The firm must start by giving each description of assets a value. That value must be an amount determined under the relevant Part’s rules; if there is no rule for valuing that description, the firm must use the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of the assets [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff]. Next, the firm must determine the amount by which it is exposed to assets of each description by adjusting the asset value in line with the specified adjustment range (19 to 23) [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff]. After the firm has determined its exposure to assets in accordance with the earlier determination steps (18 to 22), it must then increase that exposure by an amount representing the exposure, if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that same description [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6]. However, this increase is not unconditional: it is expressly subject to SECTION 23.2 and 23.3, so the firm must apply those sections as limits or conditions on whether and how the dependant exposure is added to the firm’s own exposure figure [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6].
source_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .
target_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.

question: In the PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business section that covers general governance and related topics like risk management and outsourcing, what does a firm have to put in place, and what is it meant to achieve?
gold_answer: The PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business text signals that the relevant material is the set of General Governance Requirements, alongside related chapters on risk management and outsourcing, which together frame the governance expectations being addressed [#SRC:1b62e98bf7fca2b2]. In that framed context, the rule imposes a direct obligation on “a firm” (the only actor specified) [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. The firm must have an effective system of governance in place, meaning governance arrangements that function effectively rather than existing only on paper [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. The purpose of that system is also defined: it must provide for sound and prudent management of the firm’s business, so the governance framework is expected to support careful, well-managed operation of the business as an outcome [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. Using the source and target together, the source establishes that this obligation sits within the Conditions Governing Business governance requirements landscape, while the target states the specific “must” requirement and the management standard the governance system must deliver [#SRC:1b62e98bf7fca2b2] [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6].
source_text: PRA Rulebook Conditions Governing Business ; 16 Rules 2.2 to 2.6 – General Governance Requirements ; 17 Chapter 3 – Risk Management ; Chapter 7 - Outsourcing ; 18
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place an effective system of governance which provides for sound and prudent management of its business.

question: When meeting the expectations in this Chapter for identifying plausible circumstances that could require a solvent exit, to what extent may a firm rely on and tailor scenario work from the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, and which specific recovery-planning materials define those expectations for this purpose?
gold_answer: In meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm is expected to consider plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit, using illustrative examples as a reference point for what such circumstances might look like [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02]. To inform its identification and assessment of those circumstances, the firm is permitted to draw on and adapt scenarios that were developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, rather than starting from scratch, provided the scenarios are tailored to the solvent-exit context [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02]. The recovery planning expectations that the firm may use for this purpose are anchored in the materials identified as Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and the “(a) Design” element under “(iv) Scenario testing” of SS9/17 [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]. Accordingly, a compliant approach is to use those recovery-planning scenario design sources as inputs, then adapt them to reflect plausible solvent-exit triggers and conditions relevant to the firm’s circumstances, consistent with the Chapter’s expectations [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] and the referenced recovery-planning framework [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a].
source_text: In meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm should take account of plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit (see Box A for illustrative examples). A firm may draw on and adapt scenarios developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations 19 to inform it of such circumstances.
target_text: 19. Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook; and ‘(a) Design’ under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17.

question: If this Part covers Article 109 undertakings and says that mentions of a firm in Chapters 2–4 should be read to include them, what must they do about the capital conservation buffer and how is it calculated?
gold_answer: This Part is stated to apply to Article 109 undertakings, and it also explains that references to a firm in Chapters 2–4 should, where appropriate, be read as including all Article 109 undertakings [#SRC:bb2dd76c55650361]. That scope and interpretation means the duty placed on “a firm” in those chapters is not limited to firms in the narrow sense; it extends to the Article 109 undertakings that fall within this Part. As a result, the covered entity must calculate a capital conservation buffer, and the buffer must be made up of common equity tier 1 capital and set at 2.5% of its total risk exposure amount [#TGT:1fa5af1842dbec2d]. Put simply, the source text tells you who the rule is meant to capture (Article 109 undertakings by reading “firm” to include them), and the target text tells you the required action and the exact measurement basis for the calculation.
source_text: This Part applies to Article 109 undertakings and references to a firm in Chapters 2 - 4 should, as appropriate, be read to include all Article 109 undertakings .
target_text: A firm must calculate a capital conservation buffer of common equity tier 1 capital equal to 2.5% of its total risk exposure amount .

question: In a TWD firm’s wind-down modelling, what does it need to do to reflect how market prices could change the value of trading positions during wind-down, and how will the PRA use the firm’s RBL estimate when comparing it to Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should keep its modelling proportionate by focusing its quantification of wind-down costs (used for capital and liquidity projections) on the TWD scenario and on the actions, arrangements, and measures it would actually use in that scenario, rather than trying to model many different scenarios given the uncertainty in projections [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649]. As part of that focused modelling, the firm should be able to account for how market price movements over the wind-down period could affect the valuations of its trading positions, and it should capture those valuation effects as risk-based losses (RBLs) in its calculation [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649]. The PRA will then compare the firm’s RBL estimate with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to assess how much of the firm’s capital executing the TWD option might absorb [#TGT:31786ae603de3309]. The firm should also understand and reflect in its presentation that the PRA does not treat Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A as a measure of RBLs, but uses it only to provide context for interpreting the firm’s RBL calculation in the PRA’s assessment [#TGT:31786ae603de3309].
source_text: These projections may be subject to significant levels of uncertainty, and it would not be proportionate for TWD firms to build and maintain capabilities to fully model a large number of scenarios. TWD firms should focus the modelling of their quantification of wind-down costs, used to determine their capital and liquidity projections, on the TWD scenario, and the actions, arrangements, and measures that the TWD firm would implement under that scenario. TWD firms should be able to account for the potential impact of market price movements throughout the wind-down period on the valuations of trading positions, known as risk-based losses (RBLs, see paragraphs 4.26 and 4.38 - 4.40 ).
target_text: The PRA will compare TWD firms’ estimates of RBLs with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A in order to assess the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb. It should be understood that the PRA does not regard the sum of Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A capital as an appropriate measure of RBLs, but rather as a metric for the purpose of providing context to understand the results of a firm’s RBL calculation as part of the PRA’s assessment.

question: For firms and FMIs, what is the scope of the expectation to continue complying with Guidelines and Recommendations that are not captured in the non-exhaustive appendices, and how should that be applied given that only EIOPA materials in place at the end of the transition period are relevant for the purposes of this SoP and later EIOPA issuances are excluded?
gold_answer: The appendices are expressly non-exhaustive, so firms and FMIs must not treat inclusion in those lists as the sole determinant of what they should follow; instead, they should continue, where relevant, to comply with Guidelines and Recommendations even where those materials are not listed (including those made by predecessor committees to the ESAs), unless the relevant material has been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. At the same time, for the purposes of this SoP, the relevant EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations are those in place as at the end of the transition period, with links made available, and changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period being not relevant [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980]. Accordingly, firms and FMIs should align their ongoing compliance approach to the non-exhaustive nature of the appendices while applying the SoP’s temporal boundary for EIOPA-issued materials, and should also note that the Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of the linked materials [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980].
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of these materials.

question: When assessing whether a person is fit and proper, what must a firm do before it is permitted to submit a PRA senior management approval application in relation to that person, and how does the firm’s satisfaction requirement operate as a condition to avoid a prohibited application?
gold_answer: A firm must first carry out its fit and proper assessment in a way that results in the firm being satisfied about the person’s fitness and propriety, because the firm’s own satisfaction is the required outcome of the assessment process. The obligation is framed as a decision-making requirement: in deciding whether a person is fit and proper, a firm must be satisfied that the person meets that standard [#SRC:9ee95a9789677f6b]. That obligation then becomes a gating condition for regulatory submissions: the firm is prohibited from making a PRA senior management approval application in relation to a person unless it is satisfied that the person is fit and proper to perform the specific PRA senior management function covered by the application [#TGT:27965488ad9f0cda]. Read together, the firm must ensure its fit and proper decision is completed to the point of satisfaction, and that satisfaction must relate to the relevant PRA senior management function, before any application is made. If the firm cannot reach that satisfaction, it must not proceed with the application, because doing so would breach the prohibition tied to the firm’s satisfaction threshold.
source_text: In deciding whether a person is fit and proper pursuant to 2.1 to 2.5 and, where applicable, section 60A(1) of FSMA , a firm must be satisfied that the person :
target_text: A firm must not make a PRA senior management approval application in relation to a person unless it is satisfied that person is fit and proper to perform the PRA senior management function to which the application relates.

question: When can the PRA start using a bank’s stress testing assessments to set the PRA buffer like it does for established banks, and when is the PRA allowed to make an exception and use a different calculation approach for a new or growing bank?
gold_answer: The PRA’s normal process for new banks is to use a time-limited approach to setting the PRA buffer that is designed to support banks in their early years; once the relevant conditions no longer apply, the PRA buffer is then calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. The same process also allows that stress-testing-based calibration to be introduced earlier if the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives, so the transition can happen before the time-limited period would otherwise end [#SRC:786185f23d84f194]. In addition to that timing flexibility, the PRA is permitted, when exercising supervisory judgement, to diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks in exceptional circumstances [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]. The passage explains that this can be relevant where the stated approach would not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks, and it also confirms that heightened risks to the PRA’s objectives can justify an earlier transition to the established-bank approach [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a].
source_text: The PRA’s approach for setting the PRA buffer is designed to support new banks in their early years of operation, and as such is time-limited. Once either of the conditions set out above (paragraph 4.8 ) no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer will be calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks. However, as stated in paragraph 4.12 , such an approach could be introduced earlier where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives.
target_text: When exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA may, in exceptional circumstances, diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, for instance where the stated approach does not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. Such divergence could also include instances where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives which justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks.

question: If an insurer plans to pay a dividend, what does it need to show about how appropriate the payment is, and does the same kind of check also cover things like returning premiums to mutual members or making a loan to a parent or holding company?
gold_answer: An insurer needs to be able to demonstrate that any planned dividend payment is appropriate when set against both (i) the insurer’s actual and projected business performance and (ii) the insurer’s current and future capital position, and it must do so while taking account of its documented risk appetite, because that is what the PRA expects when assessing potential dividend payments [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469]. The same kind of assessment is not confined to dividends alone: it would also include the assessment made for distributions to any capital providers, which explicitly covers examples such as a return of premiums to the members of a mutual and a loan to a parent or holding company [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]. So, when the insurer considers any of these distribution forms, it should apply the same appropriateness logic—linking the proposed outflow to performance and capital impacts, and checking consistency with the risk appetite it has documented—so the rationale is coherent across different ways value might be transferred to capital providers.
source_text: When assessing potential dividend payments, 10 the PRA expects insurers to be able to demonstrate that any planned dividend payments are appropriate in relation to actual and projected business performance, as well as the current and future capital position of the insurer, taking account of its documented risk appetite.
target_text: 10. This would include here the assessment made for distributions to any capital providers, including for a return of premiums to the members of a mutual, or for a loan to a parent or holding company.

question: What does a firm have to produce to show it is prepared for an orderly solvent exit in BAU, even if solvent exit seems very unlikely, and what extra plan is required if execution later becomes a reasonable prospect?
gold_answer: A firm should build preparation for an orderly solvent exit into its BAU activities and produce a solvent exit analysis to meet the PRA’s expectations for that preparation stage [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. The preparation expectation is intended to apply broadly and is not limited to firms that think a solvent exit is imminent; it applies even where the prospect of solvent exit seems unlikely or distant to the firm, so the firm should still complete the analysis as part of its BAU preparation [#TGT:ce7365f82f898e3e]. Separately, the materials distinguish preparation from execution: if and when execution of a solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the firm should produce a solvent exit execution plan, aligning with the PRA’s expectations for execution planning and for how the firm manages and monitors the execution of a solvent exit [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. In practice, this means the firm maintains an up-to-date preparation analysis in BAU, and then adds the execution plan when the execution condition is met.
source_text: This SS sets expectations for both the preparations for and execution of a solvent exit. Chapter 2 sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should prepare for an orderly solvent exit as part of its BAU activities. A firm should produce a ‘solvent exit analysis’ to meet the expectations in this Chapter. Chapter 3 sets out the PRA’s expectations for a firm to produce a ‘solvent exit execution plan’ when solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect for a firm. It also sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should manage and monitor the execution of a solvent exit.
target_text: This Chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should prepare for an orderly solvent exit 17 as part of its BAU activities. These expectations apply regardless of how unlikely or distant a prospect solvent exit may seem to the firm. If and when the execution of a solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the firm should produce a ‘solvent exit execution plan’ as described in Chapter 3 .

question: When the consolidated group SCR is calculated wholly or partly using the standard formula, which currency must be treated as the local currency for that calculation, and how does that choice determine whether another currency is a foreign currency for the purposes of this Chapter?
gold_answer: Where the consolidated group SCR is calculated, wholly or in part, on the basis of the standard formula, the local currency that must be applied for that SCR context is the currency used for the preparation of the consolidated accounts [#SRC:41e05ebdb62ac6a9]. The definition in this Chapter then uses that same concept of “local currency” as the reference point for classifying currencies: a currency is a foreign currency if it is not the currency used for the preparation of the firm’s financial statements (which the definition labels as the local currency) [#TGT:5b64a5c8fc45561c]. Read together, the obligation fixes the relevant “local currency” for the standard-formula consolidated group SCR by tying it to the consolidated accounts, and the definition explains the consequence of that designation—any other currency, i.e., any currency other than the currency used to prepare the relevant financial statements, is treated as foreign currency for the purposes of this Chapter. Accordingly, in the standard-formula consolidated group SCR setting, the currency of the consolidated accounts is the benchmark against which other currencies are assessed as foreign.
source_text: Where the consolidated group SCR is calculated, wholly or in part, on the basis of the standard formula , the local currency referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Standard Formula 3D32.2 shall be the currency used for the preparation of the consolidated accounts.
target_text: For the purposes of this Chapter, foreign currencies are currencies other than the currency used for the preparation of the firm’s financial statements (‘the local currency’).

question: When constructing a relevant portfolio, an insurer must not split an insurance contract’s obligations into parts unless an eligible element exception applies. How does that prohibition interact with the PRA’s position that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be included in a matching adjustment portfolio when they are separately identifiable and managed separately, and what limits does the PRA place on using recovery time risk to justify inclusion?
gold_answer: The general rule is that, when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract must not be split into different parts, except where the split is within an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. The PRA’s matching adjustment material indicates a circumstance in which a component of a broader income protection contract can be treated distinctly: in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with the referenced regulatory requirement [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. Read together, the prohibition means a firm cannot carve up obligations merely for portfolio construction convenience; it needs the eligible-element basis, and the PRA’s eligibility conditions for in-payment elements help define when that basis may be available. The PRA also frames the underwriting risk context: permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio may include recovery time risk for policyholders in receipt of income protection payments, with no restriction on exposure to that risk in MA portfolios, but the PRA does not expect recognition of recovery time risk to expand inclusion beyond income protection claims in payment, and it notes inclusion where claims are not subject to future premiums [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: For SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, define what “non-neutrality” means in terms of the relationship between tranche RWAs and the RWAs of the underlying portfolio absent securitisation, and explain how the framework’s reliance on pre-defined inputs (such as STS status) affects the level of that non-neutrality, including the mechanisms by which it is introduced.
gold_answer: In SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, “non-neutrality” refers to the typical outcome that the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation are higher than the RWAs that would have been calculated for the underlying portfolio if it had not been securitised [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17]. This feature matters because the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their capital requirement calculations and are primarily focused on credit risk, so they may fail to recognise the presence of non-credit risks; the framework reflects some additional non-credit risks arising from securitisation through this non-neutrality [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. The level of non-neutrality is not open-ended; it is driven by pre-defined inputs, such as STS status [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. In practice, the framework introduces non-neutrality primarily through applying a risk weight floor that differs by STS versus non-STS positions and through the supervisory “p” factor, which together push tranche RWAs above the underlying portfolio benchmark [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17].
source_text: The SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their calculation of capital requirements, primarily focused on credit risk. These methods may fail to recognise the presence of non-credit risks. To an extent some additional non-credit risks which can arise from securitisation are reflected in the ‘non-neutrality’ of the securitisation capital framework. 1 However the level of non-neutrality is driven by pre-defined inputs (eg STS status).
target_text: 1. ‘Non-neutrality’ of the framework here means that typically the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation will be higher than the RWAs calculated for the underlying portfolio had it not been securitised. In the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, this non-neutrality is introduced primarily through the application of a risk weight floor (10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions) and the supervisory ‘p’ factor.

question: In the PRA’s process for assessing whether minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceed that entity’s portion of consolidated group requirements for the same risk type, how must the entity’s portion of the consolidated group capital requirement be determined, and which categories of requirements or risks would the PRA generally exclude from that assessment?
gold_answer: The assessment compares, for a given risk type, the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom (on an individual or sub-consolidated basis) against that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317]. To determine the entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement, the consolidated group capital requirement is multiplied by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs attributable to that entity [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. The RWAs attributable to the entity are calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs (calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs) minus the entity’s risk-weighted exposures to other group entities, so intragroup exposures are removed in the attribution step [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. When making the overall assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements attributable to risks that are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, or risks that net off in consolidation (with intragroup risks and offsetting positions given as examples) [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317].
source_text: the extent to which, for any given risk type, the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom, on an individual or sub-consolidated basis, exceed the entity’s share 19 of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk. When making this assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements that are attributable to risks that: (i) are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework 20 or by other means; 21 or (ii) net off in consolidation (for example, intragroup risks and offsetting positions); and
target_text: 19. An entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement can be determined by multiplying that consolidated group capital requirement by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs that are attributable to that entity. The consolidated group’s RWAs that are attributable to an entity is calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs, calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs, minus the risk-weighted exposures of the entity to other group entities.

question: If the credit union is planning its liquidity over time, what minimum level must it always meet, and what else must it consider about the liquid assets it keeps?
gold_answer: When planning and managing liquidity over time, the credit union must ensure it meets a minimum quantitative level and also considers the broader expectations about what it holds. The minimum level is that a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. At the same time, the credit union must focus on both the quantity and the quality of the liquid assets it maintains over time, and it must do so taking into account the applicable minimum liquidity requirements [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. This means the credit union’s liquidity approach should be continuous and forward-looking: it should maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets over time, ensure those assets are of appropriate quality (not just any liquid assets), and keep the overall position aligned with the minimum percentage requirement. In other words, the 10% of total relevant liabilities requirement sets a baseline that must be met, while the ongoing maintenance obligation requires the credit union to manage the amount and suitability of liquid assets over time so that the baseline is consistently satisfied as part of its overall liquidity management [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce] and not treated as a one-off calculation [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf].
source_text: the quantity and quality of liquid assets to be maintained by the credit union over time, taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements in Rule 9.2 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook; and
target_text: A credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities .

question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission, what must it do to (1) find all uncertainties in the timing and amount of cash-flows for highly predictable cash-flow assets in the relevant portfolio, and (2) make sure the SCR calculation reflects how those uncertainties could change the fundamental spread, matching adjustment, and expected cash-flow patterns under stress?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty about the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio where cash-flows are highly predictable, so the firm can understand what could cause cash-flows to differ from expectations [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35]. The firm must then ensure its SCR captures all material and quantifiable risks it is exposed to, and that the SCR calculation allows for changes to the fundamental spread and matching adjustment after a stress event [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. This means the firm should determine the risks affecting the matching adjustment portfolio, consider how those risks could affect the fundamental spread and matching adjustment, and assess how that effect is captured within the SCR calculation [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. In stress conditions, the firm should include changes to additions made to the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions, including additions made through the attestation process, and for assets with highly predictable cash flows the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash-flow pattern and any related fundamental spread additions [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1].
source_text: A firm’s SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks 6 to which it is exposed. The calculation of the SCR should therefore allow for any changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. In doing this, firms should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed, how these risks could affect the FS and MA and assess how this impact is captured within the SCR calculation. Changes to the FS in stress conditions should include any changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including those made as part of the attestation process. For assets with HP cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets as well as any changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment 8 .
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty regarding the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable .

question: If the PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs but is consulted when they are developed, what must a firm do to be ready for resolution in a way that supports the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and keeps disruption to critical services to a minimum?
gold_answer: A firm must prepare for resolution so that, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]. The SOURCE adds important context on how a firm can operationalise that requirement: the PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC, but the PRA is consulted in developing those policies and the Bank’s approach promotes the PRA’s safety and soundness objective [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. Therefore, even without direct supervision “against” the SoPs, the firm should implement the Bank’s SoPs as part of its resolution preparedness work to align its planning and execution capabilities with the approach that is intended to support the PRA’s objective [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. The SOURCE also states that implementing these SoPs will help TWD firms develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring, which is a concrete way to strengthen readiness to act in resolution while maintaining continuity of critical services [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52].
source_text: The PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC. However, the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies. The Bank’s approach acts to promote the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8 in the Fundamental Rules Part of the PRA Rulebook. Implementing these Bank’s SoPs will help TWD firms to develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: If two or more people have a joint account, how do you work out each person’s share for compensation, and how does that link to the £120,000 limit per depositor?
gold_answer: You must treat each depositor’s share of a joint account as its own separate amount when you calculate compensation limits, rather than applying the limit to the joint account as a whole [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae]. That matters because the maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, so each depositor’s separately calculated share is the figure that must be tested against that £120,000 “maximum compensation sum payable” [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]. If there is no contrary provision telling you a different split, you must divide the joint account equally among the depositors, and you must do the equal split to the nearest penny, so each person’s share is a precise amount for the depositor-level calculation [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae]. After you have allocated and rounded each depositor’s share, you apply the £120,000 cap to that depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits. You must also take into account that the rule on the £120,000 maximum compensation sum payable states that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply, so the cap may be supplemented in those cases [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e].
source_text: The share of each depositor of a joint account shall be considered separately in calculating the limits provided for in 4.2 and 4.3 , except where 5.5 applies. In the absence of contrary provision, the joint account shall be divided equally among the depositors to the nearest penny.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: When a person becomes a notified non-executive director, the firm must notify the PRA and provide fitness and propriety information. In the specific case where that person, on becoming a notified non-executive director, ceases to perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function, when is the firm permitted not to provide the information needed to assess fitness and propriety, and what notification duty still applies?
gold_answer: The firm must notify the PRA when a person becomes a notified non-executive director, and the baseline expectation is that the firm provides the PRA with all information needed to assess whether that person is fit and proper [#TGT:f38f6326407a41cb]. However, where the notification concerns a person who, on becoming a notified non-executive director, ceases to perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function, the firm is permitted not to provide the information needed for the fitness and propriety assessment unless there has been a change in the information previously provided about that person’s fitness and propriety to the PRA or the FCA at the time the relevant approval application was made [#SRC:329854445e828dde]. In other words, the notification obligation to the PRA remains, but the accompanying fitness and propriety information can be omitted only to the extent it is unchanged from what was already provided in connection with the earlier approval process, and must be provided if there has been any change [#TGT:f38f6326407a41cb] [#SRC:329854445e828dde].
source_text: If the notification referred to in 4.2 is in respect of a person who, on becoming a notified non-executive director , ceases to perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function , the firm is not required to provide information needed to assess the fitness and propriety of that person unless there has been a change in the information provided in respect of that person regarding fitness and propriety provided to the PRA or the FCA at the time the application for the approval for performance of the PRA senior management function or the FCA-designated senior management function was made.
target_text: A firm must notify the PRA when a person becomes a notified non-executive director and shall provide the PRA with all of the information needed to assess whether that person is fit and proper. The PRA directs that when such information is provided by a designated investment firm , it must be accompanied by the designated additional information .

question: When an institution has stopped calculating exposure values for its derivative positions using the relevant approaches, under what conditions may it resume calculating those exposure values using the Section 5 method, including any required demonstration to the competent authority and any ongoing size-based eligibility limits?
gold_answer: An institution that has ceased calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions using the applicable approaches is not automatically allowed to restart; it is only permitted to resume calculating the exposure value using the relevant approach if it demonstrates to the competent authority that all conditions referenced for resumption have been satisfied continuously for an uninterrupted period of one year [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]. If the institution intends to resume using the method set out in Section 5, it must also meet the separate permission conditions attached to that method: the ability to calculate exposure value under Section 5 is subject to a restriction and is only available where the size of the institution’s on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below both specified thresholds, determined on the basis of a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of each month [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d]. Read together, resumption after a cessation requires both (i) the one-year uninterrupted compliance demonstration to the competent authority and (ii) continued satisfaction of the monthly, threshold-based eligibility (and any stated restriction) for using the Section 5 method.
source_text: Where an institution has ceased to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, it shall only be permitted to resume calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions as set out in Section 4 or 5 where it demonstrates to the competent authority that all the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) or (2) have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year.
target_text: Subject to the restriction set out in Article 273b(2) , an institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions in accordance with the method set out in Section 5 , provided that the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is equal to or less than both of the following thresholds on the basis of an assessment carried out on a monthly basis using the data as of the last day of the month :

question: When working out long-term insurance liabilities that are not already due before the valuation date, what must the determination do to follow actuarial principles and policyholder expectations, while also taking into account the type and length of the assets backing the liabilities and possible future changes in those asset values?
gold_answer: The determination must be carried out using generally accepted actuarial principles and must have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders, while also making proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62]. At the same time, the determination must take into account the nature and term of the assets representing those liabilities and the value placed on those assets, and it must include prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of the assets [#SRC:77cfb62c67129fc6]. In practice, this means you cannot value the liabilities in isolation: the approach and assumptions used to calculate the liabilities must be prudent and include margins, and they must be applied with an understanding of what assets are backing the liabilities, how long those assets run, and how changes in asset values could affect the adequacy of the provisions. The resulting figure should therefore reflect both actuarial prudence and asset-related risk prudence.
source_text: The determination referred to in 6.1 must take into account the nature and term of the assets representing those liabilities and the value placed upon them and must include prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of the assets on:
target_text: In accordance with 6.2 to 6.4 , the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (other than liabilities which have fallen due for payment before the valuation date ) must be made in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles and have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders and make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation.

question: If a firm holds many different assets in its MA portfolio, including less liquid ones, what does it need to do to make sure its FS model works for each asset type, given that the PRA’s expectations generally apply even when the assets are not corporate bonds?
gold_answer: Because the PRA recognises that many firms’ MA portfolios include a relatively wide range of assets that vary in liquidity and complexity (and may not be traded), firms should not treat the SS as relevant only to corporate bonds; instead, many expectations should be considered applicable regardless of the assets held unless the SS says otherwise [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec]. When the firm has material exposure to less liquid assets in the MA portfolio (such as illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects the firm to develop a separate approach to model the FS for those assets [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]. The firm may be able to use an approach similar to the corporate bond method, but it should adapt the core methodology and calibration based on how similar the assets are to corporate bonds, and it may need a more bespoke methodology in some cases [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]. If the firm does not split modelling by asset class, it should clearly justify why the model is appropriate for each asset class, aligning with the PRA’s expectation that the SS be applied more widely across the MA portfolio [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a].
source_text: The PRA recognises that many firms hold a relatively wide range of assets in their MA portfolios. These assets will differ in terms of liquidity and complexity; many of them may not be traded assets. The PRA’s expectations set out in this statement primarily apply to the risks arising in respect of corporate bond assets within firms’ MA portfolios. However, many of the expectations apply irrespective of the assets held and the PRA would therefore expect firms to consider the expectations set out in the SS to be more widely applicable unless specifically stated otherwise. In a number of places (eg paragraphs 4.10 , 4.15 , 4.20 , 4.22 , 5.17 and 5.18 ) the SS sets out specific expectations in relation to less liquid assets. In future, the PRA may issue further, more bespoke, expectations for the SCR treatment of other assets within an MA portfolio, such as illiquid assets.
target_text: In the case of firms that have material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments) within the MA portfolio, the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for these assets. While an approach similar to that used for corporate bonds may be possible, the level of adaptation from the core corporate bond methodology and calibration should depend on the similarity of the assets in question to corporate bonds. In some cases a more bespoke methodology may be necessary. Where firms do not distinguish between asset classes in their modelling, then the appropriateness of the model for each asset class should be clearly justified.

question: How must a firm’s obligation to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures be operationalised so that relevant persons are made aware of, and follow, the procedures required for the proper discharge of their responsibilities?
gold_answer: A firm must translate its duty to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures into practical internal measures that ensure relevant persons are aware of the procedures that must be followed to properly discharge their responsibilities. This requires the firm not only to design governance and decision-making procedures as part of its overall arrangements, but also to implement them in a way that makes them known to the relevant persons who need to apply them in practice, and to maintain them so awareness and adherence are sustained over time. In effect, the governance and decision-making framework must include an embedded communication and awareness component: relevant persons should be informed of the applicable procedures and understand that those procedures must be followed when carrying out their responsibilities. The firm’s governance arrangements and decision-making procedures therefore need to be established and implemented with sufficient clarity and accessibility to support proper discharge of responsibilities, and maintained so that awareness does not lapse as roles or circumstances change. These expectations arise from the requirement to ensure awareness and following of procedures by relevant persons [#SRC:87f186d46471481e] and the obligation on a firm to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures [#TGT:51b5542d9eb513b2].
source_text: (1) ensure that relevant persons are aware of the procedures referred to in 2.1 which must be followed for the proper discharge of their responsibilities;
target_text: A firm must establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures, which include:

question: If you see a short reference to SS28/15 about strengthening individual accountability in banking, how do you confirm it is the same PRA document and find the updated version to use?
gold_answer: You confirm the document by matching the supervisory statement number and the title across both references, then use the more detailed reference to locate the current version. The SOURCE gives the abbreviated identification: “Supervisory Statement SS28/15” and the topic/title “Strengthening individual accountability in banking,” which tells you what document is being pointed to but does not provide publication dates or a location to retrieve it [#SRC:b2172f1564536f99]. The TARGET provides the expanded identification and retrieval details: it names “PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15” with the same title, specifies that it was issued in December 2015 and updated in January 2016, and includes the Bank of England/PRA URL where the updated statement can be accessed [#TGT:b077aee356a13cc2]. Using both together lets you (i) validate you are looking at the correct supervisory statement and (ii) ensure you are using the updated January 2016 version rather than relying only on the abbreviated citation.
source_text: Supervisory Statement SS28/15 : Strengthening individual accountability in banking. 5
target_text: 5. PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’, December 2015 (Updated January 2016): www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/ss/2016/ss2815update.aspx .

question: If competent authorities ask for details on hedging sets, what exactly must institutions make available, and how should that information reflect the requirement to map a derivative transaction to multiple risk categories when it has material risk drivers in different categories?
gold_answer: When competent authorities request it, institutions must make available a structured summary of hedging sets by risk category: the number of hedging sets for each risk category, the identifying risk driver information for each hedging set (the primary or most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers, as relevant), and the number of transactions in each hedging set [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]. That reporting must align with how institutions are required to map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver. Specifically, if a transaction’s material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, the transaction must be mapped once to each such risk category, using the most material risk driver within each risk category as the basis for that mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If all material risk drivers are within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, based on the most material risk driver, which helps ensure the transaction counts institutions provide per hedging set and risk category are consistent and not overstated [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] while still meeting the requested disclosure items [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce].
source_text: Institutions shall make available upon request by the competent authorities the number of hedging sets established in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article for each risk category, with the primary risk driver, or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) , or the pair of risk drivers of each of those hedging sets and with the number of transactions in each of those hedging sets .
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: If the firm needs to depart from the booking model policy, what must happen so the departure is rare and formally approved, and who should independently assess the procedures that support this approach?
gold_answer: Any departure from the booking model policy must be treated as an exception that happens only rarely and only through an explicitly approved exception process that is documented in the same booking model policy, with appropriate involvement of the firm in that process [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a]. Alongside this, the procedures that govern how these matters are handled are expected to be independently assessed by assurance functions, including compliance, operational risk and internal audit [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2]. In practice, the firm should ensure there is a clear, policy-contained route for requesting and approving exceptions, rather than allowing informal workarounds, and it should ensure the assurance functions review and assess the relevant procedures to provide independent challenge and oversight. This pairing helps keep deviations controlled (rare and explicitly approved under the documented process) while also ensuring the procedures behind that control framework are subject to assessment by the firm’s assurance functions [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a] [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2].
source_text: Independent review: The procedures set out in 4.25H - 4.25U are expected to be subject to assessment by assurance functions such as compliance, operational risk and internal audit.
target_text: Exceptions: Any deviations from the booking model policy should occur rarely and only by way of an explicitly approved exception process documented in the same policy with appropriate involvement of the firm.

question: Where a firm is considering how the PRA Fundamental Rules 2, 3, 5 and 6 relate to its conduct toward supervisory authorities, what must the firm do in its dealings with its regulators, and what disclosure duty does it owe specifically to the PRA?
gold_answer: In the context of the PRA Fundamental Rules 2, 3, 5 and 6, the applicable conduct standard is expressly linked to Fundamental Rule 7, which sets out how a firm must behave toward supervisory authorities [#SRC:8f6bca5498448a3f]. Under Fundamental Rule 7, a firm must deal with its regulators in an open and cooperative way, meaning its interactions should be transparent and constructive rather than obstructive or selective [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd]. In addition, Fundamental Rule 7 imposes a specific disclosure obligation to the PRA: the firm must disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd]. Read together, the source’s reference to PRA Fundamental Rules 2, 3, 5 and 6, and 7 indicates that compliance analysis for those rules must also account for the Fundamental Rule 7 requirements on openness, cooperation, and appropriate notification to the PRA [#SRC:8f6bca5498448a3f] [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd].
source_text: PRA Fundamental Rules 2 , 3 , 5 and 6 , and 7 ;
target_text: Fundamental Rule 7: A firm must deal with its regulators in an open and cooperative way and must disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice.

question: If firms are updating TMTP after a transfer event, what must they do to keep Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions complied with, and what must not happen to the total TMTP claimed by the firms involved in the transfer (even if they adjust inputs or have a waiver/modification)?
gold_answer: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification under the relevant permissions statement; the PRA expects this can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]. However, when the firms that are parties to the transfer event apply the relevant updates, those updates must not lead to any increase in the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by those firms [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6]. In practice, this means firms can make the adjustments the PRA expects (or rely on a waiver/modification where applicable) to keep the transitional measure properly applied, but they must do so in a way that does not raise the combined TMTP claimed across all firms involved in the transfer event. The compliance approach therefore needs to balance two constraints: maintaining adherence to the transitional measure framework while ensuring the update process does not create an aggregate uplift in TMTP for the transfer-event parties.
source_text: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification as set out in 3.3 of the SoP ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. The PRA expects this can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’.

question: Where the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that the home resolution authority’s regime will achieve outcomes aligned with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives, may the firm be required to move toward UK structures and supervision that enable the Bank to resolve the UK branch on a standalone basis in certain circumstances?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE explains that the PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, and that without adequate assurance the PRA will likely not be prepared to host a branch from that jurisdiction; for an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125]. The SOURCE further indicates that if there is insufficient assurance over home state resolution arrangements, it may be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with an MPE approach to resolution [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125]. The TARGET complements this by stating that the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]. Read together, the PRA’s willingness to host and its potential requirement for a UK subsidiary and more standalone supervision align with enabling the Bank’s branch resolution powers to be exercised on a standalone basis when the relevant circumstances arise.
source_text: The PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver the appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority. In the absence of adequate levels of assurance, the PRA will likely not be prepared to host such a branch from that jurisdiction. 53 In the case of an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary. If there is insufficient assurance over the home state resolution arrangements, this may in turn mean that it would be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with a MPE approach to resolution.
target_text: 53. The Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances.

question: For institutions that are small CRR firms and are subject to the relevant disclosure framework, what remuneration-related information must they disclose, and how is that obligation framed for the staff categories in scope?
gold_answer: Where an institution is both subject to the applicable disclosure framework and qualifies as a small CRR firm, the scope condition in the source text clarifies that a specific disclosure approach applies notwithstanding other paragraphs, and it ties that approach to the information set associated with the remuneration disclosure framework [#SRC:47c62d3f801c6d13]. Within that scoped population, the institution’s concrete obligation is to make disclosures about its remuneration policy and practices, but only as they relate to those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. Read together, the source establishes when the tailored disclosure treatment is triggered (i.e., for institutions subject to the Article that are small CRR firms and for the information referred to in the remuneration disclosure framework), while the target specifies the substantive content focus of what must be disclosed (remuneration policy and practices) and the personnel boundary that limits the disclosure to material risk-impacting staff categories. Accordingly, a small CRR firm that is in scope must ensure its remuneration disclosures are directed to those staff categories and cover the required policy-and-practices information.

question: When applying the derogation that requires institutions to create separate individual hedging sets by risk category for specified transactions, how must an institution reflect those hedging sets in the index used for a netting set that denotes all credit risk hedging sets established under the relevant framework?
gold_answer: Where institutions apply the derogation that obliges them to establish separate individual hedging sets in each risk category for the relevant transactions, those newly created hedging sets form part of the population of “credit risk hedging sets” that must be captured for the netting set. The index “j” is defined as the index that denotes all the credit risk hedging sets established in accordance with the specified establishment framework for the netting set [#SRC:8837142e47055ac2]. Accordingly, once institutions are required to create separate individual hedging sets by risk category under the derogation [#TGT:a3cc17fc347e6b59], they must ensure that the index “j” denotes (i.e., enumerates or references) all such established credit risk hedging sets for that netting set, including those arising from the derogation. In practice, this means institutions should not treat the derogation-created hedging sets as outside the indexing scheme; instead, they should be incorporated into the complete set of hedging sets that “j” denotes for the netting set, consistent with the definition’s “all … established” scope [#SRC:8837142e47055ac2] and the obligation to establish separate sets by risk category [#TGT:a3cc17fc347e6b59].
