question: For governance documentation on strengthening individual accountability in banking, how should a firm identify the relevant PRA Supervisory Statement and its current version, given that one reference is abbreviated and the other provides the dated, updated publication details and link?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the abbreviated reference to the supervisory statement as pointing to the same PRA document that is fully identified in the cross-reference, and then use the fuller citation to confirm the authoritative title, publisher, and the most current version information. Specifically, the SOURCE indicates the existence of “Supervisory Statement SS28/15” with the subject “Strengthening individual accountability in banking” [#SRC:b2172f1564536f99]. The TARGET clarifies that this is “PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15” with the same title, originally dated December 2015 and subsequently updated in January 2016, and it provides the Bank of England/PRA webpage where the updated statement is hosted [#TGT:b077aee356a13cc2]. Read together, these references support documenting the supervisory statement consistently by name and number while also evidencing that the firm has checked the update status and is relying on the updated publication location when maintaining internal accountability-related governance materials.
source_text: Supervisory Statement SS28/15 : Strengthening individual accountability in banking. 5
target_text: 5. PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’, December 2015 (Updated January 2016): www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/ss/2016/ss2815update.aspx .

question: If the PRA asks a firm to run a test based on EVT in stress, what does the firm have to do to make it part of its regular internal model validation cycle, including showing the PRA the capital requirements are appropriate and checking how sensitive results are to key assumptions?
gold_answer: The firm should build the EVT-in-stress test into its regular internal model validation cycle as one of the tools it uses to validate the model on an ongoing basis, because the PRA says it will ask firms to apply a test based on EVT in stress when assessing internal model applications and continued compliance, to help assure that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4]. To fit the required validation cycle, the firm should connect the test to routine monitoring of internal model performance, periodic review of whether the model specification remains appropriate, and testing of results against experience, so the EVT-in-stress output is evaluated alongside other evidence about model performance [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]. The firm must also ensure the test is supported by an effective statistical validation process that enables it to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate, using the EVT-in-stress results as part of that demonstration [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]. In addition, the firm should use the EVT-in-stress work to inform required stability and sensitivity testing to changes in key underlying assumptions, and ensure the data used for the test is accurate, complete, and appropriate [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb].
source_text: The PRA considers reassessment of the EVT in stress, in particular the comparison of stressed economic value and Effective Value in (iv) above, to be a helpful validation exercise that could contribute to firms meeting the internal model requirements (see Chapter 14 of the Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models Part of the PRA Rulebook). When assessing internal model applications and firms’ continued compliance with the calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 relevant for granting internal model permissions, the PRA will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress, to assist in providing assurance that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated. Firms may wish to consider adding an EVT in stress to their regular suite of validation tools.
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place a regular cycle of internal model validation which includes: (a) monitoring the performance of the internal model , reviewing the ongoing appropriateness of its specification and testing its results against experience; (b) an effective statistical process for validating the internal model which enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) an analysis of the stability of the internal model and, in particular, the testing of the sensitivity of the results of the internal model to changes in key underlying assumptions; and (d) an assessment of the accuracy, completeness and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model .

question: Who does this Chapter apply to, and if a firm is in scope, what must it not include in the matching adjustment because it reflects risks the firm keeps?
gold_answer: This Chapter applies to a firm only if it has been granted a matching adjustment permission, so the Chapter’s requirements are directed at firms that hold that permission and not at firms outside that category [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131]. For a firm that is in scope on that basis, the Chapter also sets a specific prohibition about how the matching adjustment is put together: the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread where that fundamental spread reflects the risks retained by the firm [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]. In practical compliance terms, you first confirm whether the firm has the matching adjustment permission (which determines whether the Chapter applies at all), and then, if it does, you ensure the matching adjustment calculation excludes the fundamental spread component tied to the firm’s retained risks. This links the Chapter’s scope limitation to the substantive “must not include” restriction, as stated in the Chapter’s application provision [#TGT:c1fbf309f3bf1131] and the prohibition on including the fundamental spread reflecting retained risks [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0].
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, which restates the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations, sets out (at Rule 4.6 ) that the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread reflecting the risks retained by the firm.
target_text: This Chapter applies to a firm that has been granted a matching adjustment permission .

question: What has to happen with PRA approval before the transfer notification statement is sent to members, and how will the PRA show the society that the Transfer Statement has been approved?
gold_answer: The transfer notification statement cannot be sent to members unless it has first been approved by the PRA, and the society should seek that approval by submitting an application that generally follows the referenced procedure and includes a final draft of the statement with the relevant supporting documents, adjusted to what the statement is required to contain in the particular case [#SRC:fd3cb3782a25a1b2]. When the PRA grants approval of the Transfer Statement, it will confirm that approval to the society by returning one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement that carries the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA, reflecting the PRA’s statement of approval described in the target [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be]. In addition, once the printed materials are available, the society will be asked to provide the PRA with 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and any Transfer Summary. Although there is no statutory requirement for copies of the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary to be placed on the society’s public file, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and the Transfer Statement (if printed separately) to be placed on the public file because they are public documents.
source_text: The transfer notification statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraphs 4.97 to 4.103 , and the final draft of the statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 4.102 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain.
target_text: The PRA’s statement of approval of the Transfer Statement will be given as is set out in Appendix 1 . The PRA’s approval of the Transfer Statement will be confirmed by returning to the society one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement with the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA. The society will be asked to give 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and Transfer Summary, if any, to the PRA when they are available. There is no statutory requirement for copies of the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary to be placed on the public file of a society but, because they are both public documents, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and Transfer Statement, if printed separately, to be placed on the public file.

question: If workers are in a third country firm’s UK establishment, what must the firm do so those workers can report concerns internally through the firm’s channel?
gold_answer: The firm has to do two connected things: it must have the right kind of internal channel in place, and it must ensure the UK establishment workers can actually use it. On the channel itself, the firm must establish, implement and maintain appropriate and effective arrangements so that reportable concerns can be disclosed internally by a person, including a firm’s employee, through a specific channel that is independent and autonomous; this means the channel must exist, be put into operation, and be kept effective over time [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6]. For the third country firm’s UK establishment, the firm must also provide information to the third country firm in the UK about the channel and must make the channel available to workers in that UK establishment; this ensures the relevant workers know about the channel and can access it in practice [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e]. Read together, the requirements cover both maintaining the internal reporting arrangements and ensuring availability and communication for the UK establishment workforce.
source_text: the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK on the channel in 2A.2 and make the channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment.
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement and maintain appropriate and effective arrangements for the disclosure of reportable concerns by a person , including a firm’s employee , internally through a specific, independent and autonomous channel.

question: If a DGS member says it is unfair for it to pay its levy share (or unfair for the FSCS to keep it), must the FSCS avoid changing the levy calculation for that reason, and where should that kind of claim be dealt with instead?
gold_answer: Yes. The two passages align on a clear rule: the FSCS must not change the calculation of a DGS member’s share of the relevant DGS levy just because someone argues the result is inequitable—either inequitable for the firm to pay that share (or part of it) or inequitable for the FSCS to retain that share (or part of it). The source explains that the broader chapter describes when adjustments may be made, but it then highlights this specific carve-out: “inequity” is not an allowed basis for adjusting the member’s levy share, because those arguments are meant to be handled elsewhere. The target states the same prohibition in operative terms and adds the required handling: any such inequity claim should be dealt with under the separate chapter identified for those claims, rather than being resolved by recalculating the levy share. This means the FSCS must keep the levy calculation process separate from fairness-based disputes and direct those disputes to the alternative route specified. [#SRC:be6e30ab19ad7164] [#TGT:d621f6d5a6a205d5]
source_text: Depositor Protection Chapter 38 sets out when the FSCS may adjust the calculation of a DGS member’s share of any levy. Depositor Protection 38.5 sets out that the FSCS may not adjust the calculation of a DGS member’s levy under Depositor Protection 38.4 on the grounds that it would be inequitable for that firm to pay that share or part of it (or on the grounds that it would be inequitable for the FSCS to retain that share or part of it). The reason for this rule is that any such claim should be dealt with under Depositor Protection Chapter 46 .
target_text: The FSCS must not adjust the calculation of a DGS member’s share of any DGS levy under 38.4 on the grounds that it would be inequitable for that firm to pay that share or part of it or on the grounds that it would be inequitable for the FSCS to retain that share or part of it. Any such claim should be dealt with under Chapter 46 .

question: When a group includes more than one firm using an internal model, what must Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies do each year to meet the PRA’s analysis-of-change reporting requirement, and how does the PRA’s AoC.01 template fit into the required submission process?
gold_answer: Where reporting is being made on a group that includes more than one firm using an internal model, Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies must submit to the PRA an annual analysis-of-change return using template AoC.01, and that submission must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, prepared in line with the relevant instructions for the template [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556]. The PRA supports this obligation by providing an analysis of change template named AoC.01 for firms to complete, designed to capture key information regarding movement in the SCR, and the completed template is then submitted to the PRA as part of the reporting process described in the PRA Rulebook context referenced in the procedure [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]. In practice, this means the firm (or, where applicable, the UK holding company) should use the PRA-provided AoC.01 format to structure the required analysis-of-change content, ensure the template is completed with the key SCR movement information, and submit it annually to the PRA in the manner contemplated by the reporting framework and the template’s instructions [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291].
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies reporting information on a group which includes more than one firm using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: If a firm finds it does not meet the combined buffer, how is the MDA defined for calculation purposes, and what must the firm send to the PRA and by when?
gold_answer: If a firm identifies that it did not meet the combined buffer, it has to connect the definition of MDA with the required actions that follow from that situation. The MDA is defined as the maximum distributable amount calculated in accordance with 4.3(4), which tells you what “MDA” refers to and anchors the calculation approach to that reference point [#SRC:6f6f09b3b818845e]. Once the firm is in the position of not meeting the combined buffer, it must calculate the MDA in line with the applicable calculation requirement and then complete a reporting step to the regulator: it must report the MDA to the PRA in writing [#TGT:44d5e9b0c2dba929]. The deadline is specific and is measured from when the firm itself makes the identification that it did not meet the combined buffer: the written report must be provided no later than 5 working days after that identification [#TGT:44d5e9b0c2dba929]. In practice, this means the firm should ensure the amount it reports is the defined MDA (calculated in accordance with 4.3(4)) and that the PRA receives the written report within the 5 working day timeframe.
source_text: means maximum distributable amount calculated in accordance with 4.3(4) .
target_text: (1) A firm that does not meet the combined buffer must: (a) calculate the MDA in accordance with (4); and (b) report the MDA to the PRA in writing no later than 5 working days after the firm identified that it did not meet the combined buffer .

question: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, a firm must not split an insurance contract’s obligations into parts except for an eligible element. In that context, when may a component of a with-profits annuity contract be treated as eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, and what limits apply to ensure the firm is not using impermissible splitting?
gold_answer: A firm is prohibited from splitting the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio, unless the split is limited to an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. Within that constraint, a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio only where the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. To demonstrate that the permitted treatment is not an impermissible fragmentation of obligations, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment showing that the only elements included in the MA portfolio are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. The PRA also expects the firm to set out a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses are added within the MA portfolio or elsewhere, supporting disciplined boundary-setting around what is included as the eligible element [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: If you are analysing balance sheet items that might be hard to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books are disposed of, what examples should you include, and how should you use sensitivity analysis to show the resources needed?
gold_answer: You should produce an appropriate analysis that does two things: (1) uses sensitivity analyses to test factors that may change the resources needed, and (2) specifically examines any balance sheet items that may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of [#SRC:87da92e5a5f203f5]. To make that second part concrete, include examples such as deposits with untraceable or uncontactable customers and small and niche lending books, since these are identified as illustrative items that can create practical difficulties in transfer or sale [#TGT:16a5bdc394f9858e]. Your sensitivity analysis should then show how different assumptions about these items (for example, how many such deposits remain, or how hard it is to exit a niche lending book) could affect the level of resources required. The end result should link the identified hard-to-move items to resource impacts under different scenarios, demonstrating why these items matter after the main books have been disposed of.
source_text: appropriate analysis, such as sensitivity analyses of factors that may impact the resources needed, and an analysis of any balance sheet items which may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of; 46 and
target_text: 46. Examples include deposits with untraceable/uncontactable customers; and small and niche lending books.

question: When you write up what a model is for and how it is used on a product or portfolio, what does “operating boundaries” mean, and how do you tell if the model is being used outside those boundaries compared with its intended use?
gold_answer: In the model description, you should explain the purpose and use of the model, identify the relevant product or portfolio, and state the intended use with a comparison to the model’s actual use; you must also describe the model operating boundaries under which performance is expected to be acceptable [#SRC:eee778735c44195f]. “Operating boundaries” means the sample data range used to measure model performance, including the empirical variance-covariance relationships if the model is multivariate [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. To tell whether the model is being used outside those boundaries, compare the conditions and data characteristics of the actual use case to the sample data range and relationships that were used for performance measurement. If actual use requires extrapolating beyond that range—such as applying the model when macroeconomic indices reflect shock or stressed economic conditions—then it should be treated as outside the operating boundaries and assumed to involve increased model risk [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. This check ties the “intended vs actual use” comparison to a concrete, data-based boundary definition [#SRC:eee778735c44195f].
source_text: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable;
target_text: 7. Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model. While not a measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk.

question: How must a firm demonstrate to the PRA that the methods and assumptions used in its internal model adhere to the Statistical Quality Standards principles, while also ensuring the internal model’s probability distribution forecast calculation meets the required compliance scope?
gold_answer: A firm must do two linked things: (1) ensure its internal model—specifically including the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it—meets the defined compliance scope, and (2) be able to demonstrate to the PRA that it complies with the relevant Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) principles governing the methods and assumptions used in the internal model. The operational compliance requirement is that the internal model and, in particular, the probability distribution forecast calculation, complies with 11.2 to 11.13, which sets the concrete compliance span the firm must satisfy and be able to point to in its governance and model operation [#TGT:3ed819cc35a6fc9d]. In parallel, the SQS for internal models set out requirements on the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to, and the firm’s compliance with those requirements must be evidenced to the PRA, meaning the firm must maintain and provide appropriate evidence demonstrating adherence rather than relying on unsupported assertions [#SRC:f9ebadff53a4bf82].
source_text: The Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) for internal models in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11 and Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 16.2 set out requirements on the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to. Compliance with those requirements must be evidenced to the PRA.
target_text: A firm must ensure that its internal model and, in particular, the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it, complies with 11.2 to 11.13 .

question: When an institution that acts as a clearing member calculates the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client using the specified method, is it permitted to apply the fixed maturity factor in that calculation and, in parallel, to rely on the reduced exposure at default produced by the relevant calculation steps when determining its own funds requirements for CVA risk?
gold_answer: Yes. Where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, it is permitted to apply a maturity factor of 0.21 within that client-exposure own-funds calculation [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]. Separately, for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk, an institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations set out in the relevant paragraphs, provided it is using that reduced exposure at default specifically for its CVA own-funds requirement determination [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea]. Read together, the permissions operate on two linked but distinct inputs to own-funds computations: the TARGET permits a particular maturity factor when the clearing member is calculating the own-funds requirement for exposures to a client using the stated method, while the SOURCE permits the clearing member to carry forward a reduced exposure at default (as calculated under the referenced steps) into its CVA risk own-funds requirement calculation. Both permissions are framed for the same actor and are conditional on using the specified calculation approaches for the respective purposes.
source_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default resulting from the calculations set out in paragraphs 3 , 4 and 5 for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Title VI.
target_text: By way of derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) , where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client , that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation.

question: When you test your recovery plan governance, what should you check to make sure the board and the business areas can quickly use the plan to make key strategic decisions during a stress, including by getting the right people together fast?
gold_answer: When testing recovery plan governance, you should check that the recovery plan is set up and organised so it can be used quickly by both the board and the specific business areas that would need to use it, and that the board can rapidly find and understand what it needs because it will be taking the key decisions in a stress [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d]. The governance test should not be abstract: it should include assembling the right people at short notice and then assessing whether those people can actually use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions, which directly tests whether the plan works as a practical playbook in the moment [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc]. If the board cannot navigate the plan quickly, or if the relevant business areas cannot use it to support decision-making and action, the test indicates the plan is not readily usable in the way expected. The outcome should be clear evidence that the plan’s structure supports fast understanding and real decision-taking under stress.
source_text: testing the governance arrangements. This might include assembling the right people at short notice and understanding whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions. This would test the usefulness of the ‘playbook’ (see ‘ (vii) Playbooks and structure of recovery plans ’ below);
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: How should a branch evidence that its organisational arrangements are both comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of its business, and where should it look for the PRA’s further expectations that apply specifically to systemic wholesale branches?
gold_answer: A branch should structure and document its organisational arrangements so they are comprehensive in coverage while remaining proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of its business, because the PRA expects this baseline standard to apply across all branches [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. In practice, that means the branch should be able to demonstrate that its arrangements are sufficiently complete for its activities, but not unnecessarily burdensome relative to its business profile, and that it has considered how its own scale and complexity affect what “proportionate” looks like. Where the branch is a systemic wholesale branch, it should also recognise that the PRA has additional expectations beyond the all-branches baseline [#SRC:1a3f38d6bb2c475e]. To identify and apply those additional expectations, the branch should refer to the supervisory statement indicated in the cross-reference, which directs readers to SS4/16 on internal governance of third-country branches [#TGT:88729e1f70d7220c]. The branch should therefore align its governance approach to both the general PRA expectation for all branches and the further, systemic wholesale-specific expectations set out in that referenced material.
source_text: Whereas the PRA expects all branches’ organisational arrangements to be comprehensive yet proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of their business, the PRA has additional expectations for systemic wholesale branches. 59
target_text: 59. See SS4/16: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/internal-governance-of-third-country-branches-ss

question: Where the firm is required to calculate on the basis of specified accounts, what accounting records must a composite firm maintain for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, and how must those records support the firm’s calculation basis?
gold_answer: The firm’s calculation must be performed using the relevant accounts, and this requirement operates alongside (and does not override) the SCR Rules and the Minimum Capital Requirement Part [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678]. For a composite firm, the accounts that underpin that calculation basis must be structured as separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. Those separate accounts must be maintained in a way that shows the sources of the results for each activity separately, so that the firm can evidence that the figures used in its calculations are derived from the appropriate business line and are not blended across activities [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. In practice, this means the firm should ensure that the calculation basis referenced in the source obligation is traceable back to the distinct long-term and general insurance accounts, enabling clear attribution of results by activity while still applying the SCR Rules and Minimum Capital Requirement framework as applicable [#SRC:cb9941f1ee5a4678] [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0].
source_text: Without prejudice to the SCR Rules and the Minimum Capital Requirement Part , the firm must calculate on the basis of the accounts referred to in 3.2 :
target_text: A composite firm must maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business to show the sources of the results for each activity separately.

question: For the PRA’s expectation about branches maintaining a threshold level of FSCS-covered retail and small company deposits, how must a firm determine whether the relevant balances are held in an “instant access account,” and what operational feature of the account is decisive for that classification?
gold_answer: To apply the PRA’s expectation for branches regarding the level of FSCS-covered retail and small company instant access deposit balances, the firm must first classify which account balances qualify as being in an “instant access account,” because the expectation is specifically framed around “FSCS covered instant access deposits” held at branches and kept under the stated threshold [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad]. The decisive feature for that classification is the customer’s withdrawal right: an instant access account is one from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, and they must be able to do so without having to provide notice and without paying penalties [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3]. Accordingly, when assessing whether branch-held retail and small company balances fall within the scope of the PRA’s expectation, the firm should treat balances as “instant access” only where the account terms and actual customer access allow unconditional withdrawals with no notice requirement and no penalty. Balances in accounts that impose notice periods, conditionality, or withdrawal penalties would not meet the definition and therefore should not be counted as instant access for purposes of applying the branch expectation on FSCS-covered balances [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3].
source_text: (a) FSCS covered instant access deposits: the PRA expects branches to have under £130 million of retail and small company 55 instant access 56 account balances covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS);
target_text: 56. An instant access account means accounts from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, without providing notice or paying penalties.

question: When an institution uses the standardised framework, how does the derogation for the requirements concerning descriptions of the economic value of equity affect what the institution must disclose about interest rate risk in its non-trading book activities, including impacts on both economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: Institutions are generally required to disclose specified quantitative and qualitative information about risks from potential changes in interest rates affecting both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#TGT:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. However, where an institution uses the standardised framework, a derogation applies such that the particular requirements that are set out for descriptions relating to the economic value of equity—namely those identified as points (c) and (e)(i) to (e)(iv)—do not apply to that institution [#SRC:f79420213b392d41]. Read together, this means the institution still has a disclosure obligation covering interest rate risk impacts on both economic value of equity and net interest income for its non-trading book activities, but it is not required to comply with the specific subset of requirements that would otherwise mandate certain descriptions relating to the economic value of equity. The practical effect is a scoped adjustment to the content of the economic value of equity-related descriptive elements within the broader interest rate risk disclosure package, limited to institutions that use the standardised framework.
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 1 of this Article, the requirements set out in points (c) and (e)(i) to (e)(iv) of paragraph 1 of this Article for descriptions relating to economic value of equity shall not apply to institutions that use the standardised framework referred to in Rule 9.1B of the ICAA Part of the PRA Rulebook.

question: When Institutions calculate replacement cost for a single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement (and is not within the separate treatment referenced for certain cases), what margin factor must be applied for the transactions that fall within the netting sets cross-referred to in the relevant provision, and how does that requirement integrate into the replacement cost calculation obligation?
gold_answer: Institutions must calculate the replacement cost for single netting sets that are subject to margin agreements, except where the netting set falls under the separate treatment referenced for certain cases, and they must do so using the prescribed formula-based approach for that replacement cost calculation [#TGT:19512cdca8e04e88]. Within that calculation framework, where the replacement cost computation concerns transactions that are included in the specific netting sets that are cross-referred to in the relevant provision, Institutions must apply a margin factor (MF) equal to 0.42 for those transactions [#SRC:465c803c2a417476]. Read together, the obligation is twofold: (1) Institutions are required to perform a replacement cost calculation for each qualifying single netting set subject to a margin agreement using the stated formula approach, and (2) in populating that formula for the subset of transactions that are included in the cross-referred netting sets, Institutions must use MF = 0.42 as the applicable factor. This ensures consistent parameterisation of the replacement cost calculation for those transactions under the margin agreement context.

question: In a TWD scenario, what exactly counts as an “exit cost,” and how should a TWD firm use that definition when it needs to project its exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period?
gold_answer: An “exit cost” in a TWD scenario has a specific meaning that a TWD firm should use when meeting the expectation that it can project its exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. The definition ties exit cost to certain positions and to a particular calculation: it is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. So, when the firm projects “exit costs” over time, it should not treat the term as a general label for all wind-down spending. Instead, it should focus on the relevant positions that its TWD actions and measures would novate, terminate, or liquidate, estimate what those positions are expected to exit for under the TWD scenario, and then compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to determine the gap. That gap is what the firm should project as its exit costs across the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 24. An exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and accounting book value for positions to be novated, terminated or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario.

question: When an institution is required to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions within a six‑month period after a triggering event, can it still apply netting to compute a single exposure value across transactions under a contractual netting agreement, and what calculation approach applies if the netting conditions are not met?
gold_answer: The institution’s starting point is that it has a time‑bound obligation to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions under the specified calculation approach within six months after a relevant trigger occurs [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Separately, the framework permits institutions to calculate one combined exposure value for all transactions covered by a contractual netting agreement, but only where all the stated conditions for that netting treatment are met [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. If those netting conditions are not met, the institution is not permitted to aggregate and instead must calculate an exposure value for each transaction on a standalone basis, with each transaction treated as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Read together, the permission to use a single exposure value under qualifying contractual netting does not remove or extend the separate requirement to cease the specified exposure‑value calculation method within the six‑month window; rather, it governs how exposure values may be determined (single netted value versus separate transaction values) in the circumstances where exposure values are being calculated [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c].
source_text: An institution shall cease to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, within six months of one of the following occurring:
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: How should a firm distinguish between (i) an arrangement with a third party that triggers the PRA Rulebook outsourcing definition and (ii) other third‑party arrangements outside that definition, given the third‑party concept is tied to a contractual or business relationship to provide a product or service?
gold_answer: The distinction begins with the scope of “third party”: the source text frames a third party as an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. Not every such third‑party relationship is “outsourcing.” To determine whether the arrangement is outsourcing, the firm must assess whether it is an arrangement (of any form) under which the service provider performs a process, service, or activity—whether directly or by sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise undertake itself [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. The target further indicates that, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the outsourcing definition, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. If the arrangement does not meet that outsourcing definition, the source text states that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to “outsourcing” as defined and do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside the definition [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].
source_text: Existing requirements on outsourcing, including Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook, only apply to ‘outsourcing’ as defined in paragraph 2.1 . They do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties which fall outside the definition of outsourcing. In line with the definition in the G7 Third Party Elements and EBA ICT GL, this SS defines a ‘third party’ as ‘an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service’.
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: Given that the PRA recognises scenario analysis does not commit the firm to taking any particular actions in a real-life stress, how should firms set out which recovery options may be used across different stresses while still meeting the expectation to map the options to scenarios, sequence them, and justify their appropriateness and expected benefits?
gold_answer: Firms may present scenario-based analysis of recovery options without being treated as committing to those actions in a real-life stress, because the PRA recognises that the nature of each stress is different and the analysis does not bind the firm to any particular actions [#TGT:bffc8c656af6bbfe]. At the same time, firms should still explain which recovery options would be used in each scenario and demonstrate that the options are appropriate for restoring the firm to viability [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5]. The scenarios should map which recovery options would be used and in which order, and the options should be tailored to each stress with justification for why each option was selected and the quantum of benefits that can be realised under each type of stress [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5]. In doing so, firms should also consider dependencies between options, internal resource constraints, and external factors that could affect feasibility, so the analysis remains credible while still being explicitly framed as non-committal planning rather than a promise of execution [#SRC:6788e4f238d4f3f5].
source_text: Firms should explain which recovery options would be used in each of the scenarios and demonstrate that the recovery options are appropriate for restoring the firm to viability. The scenarios should map which recovery options would be used and in which order. 14 The options should be tailored to each stress with justification of the selection of recovery options and the quantum of benefits that can be realised for each selected option under each type of stress. Firms should consider the dependencies between options, internal resource constraints and external factors that might affect the feasibility of options.
target_text: 14. The PRA recognises that the nature of each stress is different and this analysis does not commit the firm to taking any particular actions in a real life stress.

question: Starting at year-end 2025, what does a firm have to send the PRA each year about its annual AoC exercise, and after it finishes its ORSA what report must it send and how quickly?
gold_answer: From year-end 2025, firms must send the PRA the results of their annual AoC exercise and the supporting narrative documentation every year, and the PRA also encourages firms to submit earlier where possible so it can engage sooner [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c]. Separately, once a firm has concluded its ORSA, it has to submit the ORSA report, and it must do that within 10 business days after concluding the ORSA [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e]. These are two different required submissions with different triggers: the AoC package is an annual deliverable (results plus supporting narrative documentation) tied to the year-end cycle, while the ORSA report is a time-bound deliverable tied to the moment the ORSA is completed. Even if a firm submits AoC materials early to support early engagement, it still must meet the ORSA report deadline once the ORSA is concluded. Planning should therefore cover both the annual AoC submission to the PRA and the post-ORSA submission window for the ORSA report [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c] [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e].
source_text: Commencing year-end 2025, firms are required to submit the results of their annual AoC exercise and supporting narrative documentation to the PRA annually, in line with Reporting 2.5B in the PRA Rulebook for groups and solos, as applicable. Where possible, the PRA encourages earlier submission to allow early engagement. When firms seek new internal model permissions or variations to existing permissions, firms may be expected to submit the results of an AoC exercise and supporting narrative documentation to the PRA and are expected to do so on the permission application date.
target_text: (1) A firm must submit the ORSA report referred to in 2.5A (2)(a) within 10 business days after concluding the ORSA .

question: What must a firm do to clearly set out who is allowed to make bookings and, at the same time, classify the different booking types it uses (including remote, split, shared, and branch bookings) so each booking can be tied back to a responsible person?
gold_answer: A firm should do two connected things: define permissions and define categories. On permissions, it should define and record who is permitted to book and what counts as a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should explain any differences in roles between traders, sales, and sales traders. It should also cover people booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and ensure the correctness of any given booking can be traced to at least one (preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]. On categorisation, it should identify and classify the types of booking it employs and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy, clearly defining terms such as remote booking (both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and ensuring branch bookings are included in the classification [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87]. Taken together, the firm’s records of who may book should align with its taxonomy so that each booking type and booking location is consistently described and can be linked back to a clearly accountable individual [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] while using the firm’s own taxonomy approach [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87].
source_text: Booking responsibilities: A firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking including whether the trader is solely responsible. This should articulate the distinction, if any, between traders, sales and sales traders. This should also cover those individuals booking into legal entities and branches including traders based overseas booking into UK branches. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traced to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual, which will usually be the trader. Trade entry is different from the independent checking of the trade and should be performed in line with the firm’s segregation of duties controls. 37
target_text: Booking taxonomy: A firm should identify and classify the types of booking they employ and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy to assist with this. This should clearly define the use of terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, and shared desks. The classification of branch bookings should also be covered. The PRA recognises that firms have already developed their own independent taxonomies to describe booking practices and is not seeking to impose common definitions for booking taxonomies at the current time. However, a set of illustrative examples have been provided in the Annex that the PRA considers to be an approximation of current industry practice and represent how the PRA has used certain terms throughout this statement.

question: If a firm is calculating the fundamental spread using the approach referenced in the matching adjustment rules, must it keep that fundamental spread out of the matching adjustment when it reflects risks the firm keeps?
gold_answer: Yes. The PRA Rulebook description explains that Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part restates the relevant IRPR provisions and includes a clear prohibition: the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread where that spread reflects risks retained by the firm [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]. The matching adjustment requirement itself repeats the same prohibition and makes explicit that the excluded fundamental spread is the one calculated under the referenced calculation approach, while still being the spread that reflects risks retained by the firm [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c]. Taken together, this means the firm cannot treat the fundamental spread as an input to, or component of, the matching adjustment in those circumstances. The fact that the fundamental spread is calculated under the referenced approach does not create an exception; it identifies which fundamental spread is being referred to. So, if the spread reflects risks the firm retains, it must be excluded from the matching adjustment.
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, which restates the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations, sets out (at Rule 4.6 ) that the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread reflecting the risks retained by the firm.
target_text: The matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread (as calculated in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17 ) reflecting the risks retained by the firm .

question: When determining whether the total gross cost of proposed bonus(es) is within the prescribed limit for purposes of where members’ approval must be included in the Merger Resolutions, how must a society calculate the relevant limit by reference to a sum tied to its reserves after deducting fixed assets, including any required pro rata apportionment, and what is the resulting procedural consequence if the cost exceeds that limit?
gold_answer: To apply the procedure for members’ approval of bonus payments through the Merger Resolutions, the society must first determine the prescribed limit by using the defined calculation that refers to “a sum equal to the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets,” with the fixed assets apportioned pro rata for the relevant context, and then taking the lesser amount where the definition requires that comparison [#SRC:fa83aff840ed1f2b]. Once that limit is established, the society compares it to the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (calculated without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) to decide how widely the approval must be embedded in the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, approval need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed; however, if the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].
source_text: (c) a sum equal to the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets (apportioned pro rata in respect of paragraph 3.107(b) above), whichever is the less. The Regulations should be consulted for the full detail of the calculations.
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society.
