question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the participating undertaking reflect its interests in related undertakings, and how must data for related undertakings linked by a common management relationship be included notwithstanding other treatment of that data?
gold_answer: In calculating the solvency of a group, the participating undertaking must ensure that the calculation reflects the proportional share it holds in its related undertakings, so that the group solvency outcome is based on the participating undertaking’s proportionate interest rather than a full consolidation or other non-proportional approach [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc]. Consistently with that requirement, data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship must be included on a proportional-share basis, and this inclusion applies notwithstanding the otherwise applicable treatment referenced for that data [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]. Practically, this means the participating undertaking should identify which undertakings are “related undertakings” and which of those are linked by a common management relationship, then include the relevant data using one of the specified inclusion approaches, but always calibrated to the proportional share. The proportional share basis is the common thread: it governs both the group solvency calculation and the inclusion of data for commonly managed related undertakings, ensuring the same proportionality principle is applied across the calculation and the underlying data inputs [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc].
source_text: Notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship shall be included in accordance with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A on the basis of the proportional share as referred to in Chapter 8 .
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: When a related undertaking is included in the consolidated calculation and its contribution to the consolidated group SCR is being calculated to reflect diversification effects, how must the firm ensure that the allocation percentages across all included related undertakings are set so that the overall total is correct?
gold_answer: When a related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company is included in the consolidated data, its contribution to the consolidated group SCR must be calculated in a way that reflects diversification effects, using the calculation approach specified for that contribution [#TGT:f0367d1134b80463]. In applying that procedure, the firm must also comply with the separate requirement governing the allocation percentages used for related undertakings included in the consolidated calculation: for all related undertakings that are Solvency II undertakings, insurance holding companies or mixed financial holding companies included in the consolidated calculation, the sum of the percentages referred to must equal 100% [#SRC:7ea086354fb4a782]. Practically, this means the firm should (i) identify which related undertakings fall within the categories covered by the percentage-sum requirement and are included in the consolidated calculation, (ii) assign the relevant percentages to each of those undertakings consistently with the contribution calculation being performed, and (iii) validate that the assigned percentages across that set add up to exactly 100% before finalising the consolidated group SCR contribution outputs.
source_text: In each of 9.4D(1) and (2) , the sum of the percentages referred to for all the related undertakings that are Solvency II undertakings , insurance holding companies or mixed financial holding companies included in the consolidated calculation must equal 100%.

question: For a composite firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, what accounts must it maintain so that it can prepare the required statement on the basis of those accounts, and what must that statement identify in relation to the notional MCRs for each business?
gold_answer: A composite firm must first maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, so that the sources of the results for each activity are shown separately [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. Those separate accounts then form the basis on which the firm must prepare a statement [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]. Using that accounts-based foundation, the statement must identify the eligible own funds that cover the notional long-term insurance MCR and, separately, the eligible own funds that cover the notional general insurance MCR [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]. Read together, the obligations require a clear separation of accounting information by business line (long-term versus general) and a corresponding, accounts-supported identification in the statement of which eligible own funds are attributed to covering each notional MCR. This linkage ensures the statement is prepared on an appropriate evidential basis (the separate accounts) and that the identification of coverage is made distinctly for each of the two notional MCRs, rather than on a combined or undifferentiated basis.
source_text: The firm must prepare a statement on the basis of the accounts referred to in 3.2 identifying the eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and the notional general insurance MCR , respectively.
target_text: A composite firm must maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business to show the sources of the results for each activity separately.

question: Where a firm has a material outsourcing arrangement, what must it do to ensure business continuity and exit strategies are in place and operationally validated, consistent with the PRA’s expectations?
gold_answer: Taken together, the SOURCE frames the relevant control objective as “business continuity and exit strategies,” while the TARGET sets out the PRA’s expectation that, for each material outsourcing arrangement, firms take specific lifecycle actions. In practice, a firm should treat business continuity and exit strategies as the required focus area [#SRC:cbf91fe709000f41] and then, for every outsourcing arrangement that is material, develop an appropriate plan or framework addressing that focus, keep it current over time, and validate it through testing, because the PRA expects firms to “develop, maintain, and test” the relevant artefact for each such arrangement [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1]. This means the obligation is not satisfied by a one-off document: the firm should (i) create the continuity and exit approach for the specific material arrangement, (ii) maintain it so it remains fit for purpose as the arrangement evolves, and (iii) test it to demonstrate it can be executed in practice. The scope trigger is materiality of the outsourcing arrangement, and the subject matter is continuity and exit.
source_text: business continuity and exit strategies ( Chapter 10 ).

question: Where a charge is treated as a special project fee as specified in the relevant provision, what deadline must the firm meet to pay an SPF for restructuring once the PRA issues an invoice?
gold_answer: When a fee is treated as a “special project fees” item—i.e., it is the category of fee that is “as specified” in the referenced provision [#SRC:ad40c03e3a8c8ea1]—the firm must apply the payment timing rule that governs an “SPF for restructuring” in the obligation text. Specifically, once the PRA issues an invoice to the firm for an SPF for restructuring, the firm’s payment is due 30 days from the date of that invoice [#TGT:bcf7e19d119fd6d9]. Read together, the source establishes that “special project fees” is a defined category tied to the specified provision [#SRC:ad40c03e3a8c8ea1], and the target sets the concrete due-date requirement for the restructuring variant of that category, keyed to each invoice from the PRA to the firm [#TGT:bcf7e19d119fd6d9]. Accordingly, for each such invoice, the firm should calculate the due date by counting 30 days from the invoice date and ensure payment is made by that date, treating each invoice as a separate trigger for the 30-day period.
source_text: (3) special project fees is as specified in 5.8 .
target_text: The due date for payment of an SPF for restructuring is 30 days from the date of each invoice from the PRA to the firm .

question: When determining FS additions, how must firms address additional risks arising from cash flow variability while also deciding whether to apply an advanced methodology or retain the standard approach across different assets with HP cash flows, and what justification must be available for any mixed approach?
gold_answer: Firms must actively consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability and ensure those risks are sufficiently captured through the required FS additions, rather than assuming the base calculation is complete without that assessment [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. At the same time, firms must apply a practical methodology choice that reflects the PRA’s recognition that not all sources of variability can be modelled using an advanced approach (for example, where data are scarce) [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. Accordingly, firms may pursue advanced calculation methodologies for some assets with HP cash flows while retaining the standard approach for others, but they must be able to justify why an advanced approach is proposed for certain exposures and not for others [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. In practice, this means the firm’s approach to capturing additional variability-driven risks in FS additions should be consistent with its modelling capability and data availability, and the firm should be prepared to explain how the selected mix of advanced and standard approaches still results in those additional risks being sufficiently captured [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6].
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: The PRA recognises that not all sources of variability can be modelled using an advanced approach to calculating the FS additions, for example due to a scarcity of data. The PRA therefore expects that firms may seek to pursue advanced calculation methodologies for some assets with HP cash flows, while retaining the standard approach for others. The PRA expects firms to be able to justify why an advanced approach has been proposed for some exposures but not others.

question: If the Issuer is thinking about publishing a notice, what should it decide first, and what document should it use to understand the PRA’s publication process for supervisory decisions?
gold_answer: The Issuer should first make a specific decision about whether publishing the notice is desirable, rather than treating publication as automatic, and it should make that judgment by using the PRA’s approach to publication of regulatory action as the relevant reference point for deciding on publication [#SRC:425700642a4abb17]. If the Issuer then needs more detail on how publication works in practice—especially where the context is supervisory decisions—it should look to the statement of the PRA’s approach to publication of regulatory action in relation to supervisory decisions, which is explicitly identified as the place to find further information on the publication process [#TGT:80f95b6fab047f59]. Together, these requirements mean the Issuer’s “should we publish?” decision and its understanding of “how publication is handled” are both anchored to the same PRA statement, helping the Issuer align its internal decision-making with the PRA’s described publication approach.
source_text: (c) consider whether it is desirable to publish the notice as provided in the PRA’s approach to publication of regulatory action. 17
target_text: 17. For further information on the publication process, see the statement of the PRA’s approach to publication of regulatory action in relation to supervisory decisions.

question: If the PRA has to publish a volatility adjustment for each relevant currency, how does it work out the risk-corrected currency spread it uses—what does it subtract from the starting spread to remove parts linked to expected losses or other asset risks?
gold_answer: Because the PRA must determine and publish a volatility adjustment for each relevant currency, it needs to follow the stated method for calculating the risk-corrected currency spread that is referenced in that framework [#TGT:765ce35d98758ebb]. The method is a subtraction: the PRA starts with the relevant spread and then takes away the part of that spread that comes from a realistic assessment of expected losses, unexpected credit risk, or other risk of the assets [#SRC:b66636b622164b50]. Put simply, the “risk-corrected” figure is the remainder after removing the portion that is explained by those loss and risk components. This ensures the spread used for the PRA’s volatility adjustment work is not overstated by including amounts that are attributable to expected losses or other identified asset risks. The same actor—the PRA—both performs this calculation and is responsible for determining and publishing the volatility adjustment for each relevant currency, so the calculation step is integral to how the PRA meets the publication obligation.
source_text: The PRA calculates the risk-corrected currency spread referred to in paragraph 2.1C(b) as the difference between the spread referred to in paragraph 2.1C(a) and the portion of that spread that is attributable to a realistic assessment of expected losses or unexpected credit risk or other risk of the assets.

question: For a firm, how must the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) be defined within the PRA’s capital framework, and what is its stated purpose and determination in relation to the TCR, the combined buffer, and the CRD buffers, including how the PRA’s Pillar 2B approach addresses weak governance and risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: The PRA buffer, also referred to as Pillar 2B, is defined as an amount of capital that firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and it forms part of the PRA’s capital framework alongside those elements [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224]. Its purpose is to absorb losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers, and it sits with the combined buffer and the TCR as components of the overall framework [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224]. The accompanying Pillar 2B material provides information on how this buffer is determined and how it relates to the CRD buffers, indicating that its calibration is considered in the context of other buffer requirements rather than in isolation [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]. That same Pillar 2B discussion also sets out the PRA’s approach to tackling weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B and to addressing group risk, including RFB group risk, which frames the supervisory considerations that inform how the PRA buffer is determined and applied in practice [#SRC:1399703aeb306995].
source_text: Section II: Pillar 2B provides information on the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined and how it relates to the CRD buffers. Section II also provides details on the PRA’s approach to tackling weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B and group risk, including RFB group risk.
target_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.

question: When a firm permits deviations from the booking model policy, what must the firm do to ensure those deviations remain tightly controlled through a documented, explicitly approved exception process, and how must the firm’s assurance functions assess the relevant procedures to provide independent oversight?
gold_answer: The firm must treat any deviation from the booking model policy as an exception that is both rare and handled only through an explicitly approved exception process that is documented within the same booking model policy, with appropriate involvement of the firm in that process [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a]. In parallel, the firm must ensure independent oversight of the procedures that govern how such matters are handled by subjecting those procedures to assessment by assurance functions, specifically including compliance, operational risk and internal audit [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2]. Read together, this means the firm should not allow ad hoc departures from the policy: deviations must be channelled through the documented approval pathway, and the underlying procedures supporting that pathway should be independently assessed by the named assurance functions. This combination supports both front-line control (rare, explicitly approved, policy-documented exceptions with firm involvement) and second/third-line challenge (assurance assessment of the procedures) to help ensure deviations are justified, consistently processed, and appropriately governed across the firm [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a] [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2].
source_text: Independent review: The procedures set out in 4.25H - 4.25U are expected to be subject to assessment by assurance functions such as compliance, operational risk and internal audit.
target_text: Exceptions: Any deviations from the booking model policy should occur rarely and only by way of an explicitly approved exception process documented in the same policy with appropriate involvement of the firm.

question: What does a critical third party need to show regulators to prove it can meet the Part, when it has to regularly check whether its incident management playbook works and run a suitable playbook exercise with a representative sample of the firms it supports within 12 months of being designated by the Treasury and at least every two years after that?
gold_answer: A critical third party must be able to demonstrate to the regulators its ability to comply with this Part [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70]. For incident preparedness, that demonstration should cover the specific steps it is required to take: it must regularly assess how effective its incident management playbook is, and it must also carry out an appropriate incident management playbook exercise using a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d]. The timing matters to what it needs to show: the exercise must be completed within 12 months of the critical third party being designated by the Treasury, and then repeated at least biennially thereafter [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d]. So, to satisfy the regulators, the critical third party should be ready to point to evidence that these assessments and exercises are happening on the required schedule and that the exercise involves a representative sample of the relevant firms, because those actions support its claim that it can comply with the Part [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70].
source_text: As part of its obligation under 5.1 , a critical third party must assess the effectiveness of its incident management playbook regularly, including undertaking an appropriate incident management playbook exercise with a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services within 12 months of the critical third party being designated by the Treasury and at least biennially thereafter.
target_text: A critical third party must be able to demonstrate to the regulators its ability to comply with this Part.

question: If a firm created a record under SYSC 2.2.1R (as at 31 December 2015), what does it have to do with each version of the management responsibilities map and that record—how long must it keep them, and what must it do if the PRA asks for them?
gold_answer: If a firm has created any record in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015, the firm must comply with the applicable requirements that govern how it handles that record [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe]. This includes a clear retention and access expectation for versioned documents: each version of both the management responsibilities map and the relevant record must be kept for ten years, and the ten-year period starts on the date that version was replaced by a more up-to-date record [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]. The firm must also provide those versions to the PRA if the PRA requests them, so the firm needs to store them in a way that allows it to locate and produce the correct version when asked [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]. Read together, the obligations mean the firm should manage records created under the specified conditions with proper version control, track when each version is superseded, retain each version for the full ten-year period, and be prepared to supply the records to the PRA on request [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2].
source_text: A firm must comply with 5.8 in relation to any record created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015.
target_text: Each version of both the management responsibilities map and the record in 5.4 must be retained for a period of ten years from the date on which it was superseded by a more up-to-date record, and must be provided to the PRA on request.

question: If a depositor applies for compensation for a temporary high balance, can the FSCS refuse to pay because the application or evidence has a material mistake or missing information, and if not refused, when must the FSCS pay?
gold_answer: Yes, the FSCS can refuse (reject) a claim for compensation if the written application or evidence provided by the depositor contains a material inaccuracy or omission, because the FSCS is permitted to reject in those circumstances [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c]. But that permission is limited: the FSCS may not reject the claim if it considers the material inaccuracy or omission to be wholly unintentional, meaning the claim can still be processed despite the issue [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c]. If the claim is not rejected and the depositor is claiming in respect of a temporary high balance, the FSCS must pay the compensation within three months of the compensation date, unless an exception applies [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f]. In practice, this means the depositor’s accuracy and completeness can determine whether the FSCS pays at all, while the three-month requirement governs how quickly the FSCS must pay once it accepts the claim for the temporary high balance [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c].
source_text: The FSCS must pay compensation in respect of a temporary high balance within three months of the compensation date , unless one or more of 10.9 to 10.11 applies.
target_text: If the written application or evidence provided by the depositor under 10.3 contains any material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may reject the claim for compensation unless this is considered by the FSCS to be wholly unintentional.

question: For purposes of defining a firm’s recovery capacity, how must a firm assess the combined impact of all recovery options that could credibly be realised together across different types of stress, including any dependencies between options, and how does this definition distinguish that assessment from scenario testing?
gold_answer: A firm’s recovery capacity is defined by the need for firms to understand the total financial benefits they could credibly realise if needed across a range of stresses, and this total must be built from an assessment of the combined impact of all options that could currently credibly be realised together under different types of stress, explicitly taking account of dependencies between options [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e]. Consistent with that definition, the total recovery capacity should include the benefits of all options that could be realised together under different types of stress, rather than limiting the analysis to a subset of options [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b]. This combined, dependency-aware assessment is distinct from scenario testing: scenario testing focuses on which options would likely be selected in response to the specific conditions in particular scenarios, whereas recovery capacity focuses on the total credible financial benefits available across stresses when options are considered together [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b]. Accordingly, the definition requires a holistic aggregation of credible, concurrently realisable option benefits under stress, not a scenario-by-scenario choice exercise [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e].
source_text: the assessment of the combined impact of all options that could currently credibly be realised together under different types of stress, considering the dependencies between options (covered in ‘ (ii) Recovery capacity ’ below); and
target_text: It is important that firms understand the total financial benefits they could credibly realise in a range of stresses if they need to do so (ie their ‘recovery capacity’). The total recovery capacity should include the benefits of all options that could be realised together under different types of stress. This is different from scenario testing, where firms consider which options would likely be selected in response to the specific conditions in the different scenarios.

question: Where more than one SMF holds PR Q, the firm must ensure that all such SMFs provide the required attestation; in doing so, must the firm also avoid treating assets as eligible for the matching adjustment where the asset’s cash flows could be altered by early redemption or termination rights that are entirely at the discretion of the issuer or a third party (subject to any stated exception)?
gold_answer: The firm must organise its governance so that the senior manager(s) holding PR Q are responsible for the attestation, and where more than one SMF holds PR Q, the PRA expects all of those SMFs to attest, reflecting their ultimate governance responsibility for the calculation of the FS and MA even where tasks are delegated [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb]. In parallel, when determining whether assets support fixed cash flows for matching adjustment purposes, the firm must not treat as eligible those assets whose cash flows could be changed by early redemption or termination rights that are entirely at the discretion of the issuer or a third party, except where the stated exception applies [#TGT:d5964c3fc12fead2]. Read together, this means the attesting SMF(s) should ensure the attestation process and underlying calculations do not rely on assets with prohibited discretionary redemption/termination features, because such features would undermine the fixed cash flow eligibility condition that the firm’s MA calculation depends on. If governance arrangements suggest a different SMF should attest, the firm should approach its usual supervisory contact in the first instance [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 9.1(3) requires that the senior manager with the prescribed responsibility for the production and integrity of the firm’s financial information and its regulatory reporting (PR Q), as provided for in Rule 3.1(4) of the Insurance – Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook, will be responsible for the attestation. This is because the SMF should have ultimate governance responsibility for the calculation of the FS and MA (regardless of delegations of any of their responsibilities), and can therefore implement an increase to the FS if required. In many cases, this will be SMF 2, the Chief Financial Officer, but this could be another SMF depending on how responsibility is allocated within the firm. A firm should approach its usual supervisory contact, in the first instance, should its governance arrangements mean that an alternative SMF would be more appropriate to undertake the attestation. Where more than one SMF holds PR Q, the PRA would expect all of those SMFs to attest. The PRA considers that the supervisory guidance contained in SS35/15 – Strengthening individual accountability in insurance 25 on sharing prescribed responsibilities (in particular paragraph 2.19A of that SS) would also apply.
target_text: Certain categories of early redemption or termination rights would clearly not meet the eligibility criterion for fixed cash flows in regulation 4(9) of the IRPR regulations, for example rights of redemption or termination that are entirely at the discretion of the issuer or third party (subject to the exception in regulation 4(9)(c) of the IRPR regulations).

question: When a society is determining which shareholders must receive the Statutory Cash Bonus, how must it apply the concept that only one Qualifying Day can be used for these purposes, and how does that single day interact with the requirement to pay the bonus only to those who held shares on that day and were not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution?
gold_answer: In applying the Statutory Cash Bonus requirement, the society must treat the Qualifying Day as the single, decisive reference point for identifying the population of shareholders who are in scope for the payment, and it must not attempt to use multiple qualifying days or substitute other “reference dates” for this purpose. The Source explains that the choice of Qualifying Day is a determining factor in deciding which members must have conferred upon them a right to the Statutory Cash Bonus, and it records the Commission’s view that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these purposes, clearly distinguished from any other dates a society might select for its transfer scheme [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a]. The Target then specifies the operative eligibility test for payment: the bonus is required to be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc]. Read together, the society must (i) fix one Qualifying Day for the bonus determination and (ii) apply the Target’s two conditions (held shares on that day; not eligible to vote) to that single day to decide who must be paid.
source_text: The choice of Qualifying Day 53 is important because it is a determining factor in deciding which members must have conferred upon them a right to the Statutory Cash Bonus 54 provided by Section 100 of the 1986 Act. It may also be relevant in deciding which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or of shares in the successor company. The Commission’s view was that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these purposes, which must be clearly distinguished from any other ‘reference dates’ which may be chosen by a society for the purposes of its transfer scheme.
target_text: 54. The bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) of the 1986 Act to be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution.

question: If we are looking at PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024, what does it mean that Appendix 1 is a past version, and how does that fit with the PRA saying it has described other versions before and that the tests shown below are the latest?
gold_answer: For PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024, the reference to a “Past version of Appendix 1” signals that the Appendix 1 material you are using is an earlier version tied to that pre‑31/12/2024 context [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620]. Separately, the PRA has explained that, in earlier communications with firms, it described other versions of these tests, and that the tests presented “below” are the most recent versions [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472]. Putting those points together, you should treat the pre‑31/12/2024 Appendix 1 content as historical and understand that it may not match the latest version of the tests. You should also be aware that there may have been multiple prior versions communicated over time, not just the one captured in the past Appendix 1 reference. When you write up your compliance evidence for the pre‑31/12/2024 period, make sure you label the version you used as the past Appendix 1 version and distinguish it from the most recent versions the PRA refers to, so there is no confusion about which test set applied to which period [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620] [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472].
source_text: Past version of Appendix 1 : PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024
target_text: In previous communications with firms, the PRA has described other versions of these tests. The tests described below are the most recent versions.

question: How should a firm evidence that it meets the PRA’s expectation to appoint an independent non-executive chair, and what external governance framework should it reference when documenting that expectation and any rationale for alternative arrangements?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s position as an expectation that its chair is a non-executive and is independent at the point of appointment, and it should align its documentation and governance rationale with the external framework the PRA points to, namely the Financial Reporting Council’s UK Corporate Governance Code [#SRC:b3eb99a0f75eb2b9] and [#TGT:c8661f4cac901566]. Where the firm does not have an independent non-executive chair on appointment, it should be prepared to explain, in a clear and auditable way, how its governance arrangements nonetheless satisfy the underlying objective of independent oversight of the executives [#SRC:b3eb99a0f75eb2b9]. In practice, this means the firm’s governance narrative should (i) state whether the chair meets the independence-on-appointment expectation, (ii) identify the relevant governance benchmark it is using (the UK Corporate Governance Code), and (iii) if the expectation is not met, set out the alternative oversight mechanisms the firm relies on and why they deliver independent oversight consistent with that benchmark [#SRC:b3eb99a0f75eb2b9] and [#TGT:c8661f4cac901566].
source_text: The PRA also expects firms to have a non-executive chair who is independent on appointment, in line with the Corporate Governance Code. 6 Where this is not the case, the firm should be able to explain how its governance arrangements will otherwise satisfy the need for independent oversight of the executives.
target_text: 6. See Financial Reporting Council’s ‘UK Corporate Governance Code’; https://www.frc.org.uk/Our-Work/CodesStandards/Corporate-governance/UK-Corporate-Governance-Code.aspx .

question: What does the firm have to do to keep its compliance policies and procedures effective—both when setting them up to spot non-compliance risks and when checking them regularly and fixing gaps?
gold_answer: The firm has two connected duties: building the right controls and then continuously checking that they work. It must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures that are designed to detect any risk that the firm could fail to comply with its obligations under the regulatory system, along with the associated risks [#TGT:99eb8123bfeb79db]. After putting these measures in place, the firm must monitor them on a permanent basis and assess on a regular basis whether the measures, policies and procedures remain adequate and effective [#SRC:ee9f6727d198f98e]. The firm’s regular assessment is not limited to the written policies; it must also cover the actions taken to address any deficiencies in the firm’s compliance with its obligations, so the firm evaluates whether identified issues are being corrected and whether the fixes are working [#SRC:ee9f6727d198f98e]. Read together, the requirements mean the firm should treat its policies and procedures as an active system: designed to detect non-compliance risks, continuously monitored, periodically reviewed for effectiveness, and updated or strengthened when deficiencies are found [#TGT:99eb8123bfeb79db].
source_text: (1) monitoring on a permanent basis, and assessing on a regular basis, the adequacy and effectiveness of the measures, policies and procedures put in place in accordance with 2.1A , and the actions taken to address any deficiencies in the firm's compliance with its obligations;
target_text: (1) establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures designed to detect any risk of failure by the firm to comply with its obligations under the regulatory system , as well as the associated risks; and

question: If a society is planning a transfer, what must the directors check with their external auditors (or other advisers) about the society’s systems, and what must the society do after the Transfer Resolutions are passed so the transfer can actually take effect?
gold_answer: The directors of a society contemplating a transfer must satisfy themselves—after consulting their external auditors or other advisers—that the society’s systems can deliver the required information, because the PRA will require an assurance on that point when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c]. Separately, the transfer cannot take effect until the PRA has confirmed it, and once the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the manner the PRA may direct [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]. Putting these together, the directors’ systems check is an early, required step to support the Transfer Statement process, while the society’s confirmation application is a later, required step triggered by the passing of Transfer Resolutions and is essential because confirmation is a condition for the transfer to take effect. This sequencing also matters because, at the confirmation stage, the PRA considers whether a relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled, so the directors’ assurance and the society’s properly made application both support meeting the PRA’s expectations through to confirmation [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5].
source_text: The directors of a society contemplating a transfer must satisfy themselves, in consultation with their external auditors, or other advisers, that the society’s systems are capable of delivering the information described above. The PRA will require an assurance on this point when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. One of the criteria which the PRA has to consider at the confirmation stage is whether some relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled (see section ‘ Confirmation ’).
target_text: No transfer can take effect until it has been confirmed by the PRA. This section first describes the form of application and public notice required. It then explains the PRA view of how the statutory Confirmation Criteria should be interpreted. Finally, it gives guidance on the procedure customarily followed by the PRA when considering confirmation applications and hearing representations. Sections 97(4)(d) and 98(2) of, together with Part II of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, provide that when the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in such manner as the PRA may direct.

question: If a composite firm needs to prepare a statement based on its accounts, what kind of accounts must it keep for its long-term insurance business and general insurance business, and what must the statement say about eligible own funds for each notional MCR?
gold_answer: A composite firm must keep separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, with those accounts showing the sources of the results for each activity separately [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0]. The firm must then prepare a statement using those accounts as the basis [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]. In that statement, it must identify the eligible own funds that cover the notional long-term insurance MCR and also identify the eligible own funds that cover the notional general insurance MCR, treating them as separate identifications for the two business types [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]. Put simply, the separate-account requirement supports the statement requirement: the accounts are kept separately by business line, and the statement built from those accounts must clearly point to which eligible own funds are covering each of the two notional MCRs. This combined approach avoids mixing the long-term and general insurance positions when presenting results and when identifying coverage for each notional MCR.
source_text: The firm must prepare a statement on the basis of the accounts referred to in 3.2 identifying the eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and the notional general insurance MCR , respectively.
target_text: A composite firm must maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business to show the sources of the results for each activity separately.

question: If an own funds item is issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, what must you do to classify it, and when are you not allowed to say it is free from encumbrances?
gold_answer: Where an own funds item has been issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, you must classify the own funds item using the criteria for classification set out in Own Funds 3A – 3J, but only if the applicable requirements for using those criteria are met [#TGT:e82491299baf128a]. At the same time, you must not treat the item as free from encumbrances unless a specific condition about claim ranking is satisfied: the claims relating to the own funds item must rank after the claims of all policyholders of the Solvency II undertakings belonging to the group [#SRC:bc73a26522603455]. So, when you are doing the classification required for these issuer types, you need to check how the claims on the item rank compared with those policyholder claims. If the item’s claims do not rank after all such policyholder claims, then it is prohibited to consider the item free from encumbrances, and your classification work must proceed without that assumption, aligning the classification obligation [#TGT:e82491299baf128a] with the encumbrance restriction [#SRC:bc73a26522603455].

question: Under what circumstances may an institution calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the Section 5 method, and when is the institution prohibited from using that method because it does not satisfy the relevant conditions?
gold_answer: An institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method in Section 5 only where the permission’s preconditions are met: it must be subject to the stated restriction, and it must ensure—based on a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of the month—that the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is equal to or below both specified thresholds [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d]. However, that permission does not override the separate prohibition that applies when the institution fails to meet the conditions tied to eligibility for the Section 5 method. Specifically, if an institution does not meet the conditions set out for that method, it shall not use the Section 5 method at all [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598]. In practice, the institution must therefore confirm two things before applying Section 5: (i) it remains within the permission’s operational limits (restriction plus monthly threshold-based sizing), and (ii) it meets the underlying conditions that determine whether it is allowed to use Section 5 in the first place; if it fails the latter, use is prohibited even if the monthly sizing assessment would otherwise support use [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598] [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d].
source_text: An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) shall not use the method set out in Section 4 . An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(2) shall not use the method set out in Section 5 .

question: When relying on the past version of the Annex 1 information sheet (Chapter 16) that applied before 01/12/2025, how must the firm describe deposit protection under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS), and what must it indicate about confirming eligibility and any exclusions?
gold_answer: Using the past version of the Annex 1 – Information Sheet (Chapter 16) that applied before 01/12/2025, the firm’s information sheet should communicate that the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (‘FSCS’) provides protection for deposits made by most individuals and businesses, and it should do so in a way that is consistent with that earlier information-sheet context [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a]. It must also explain how a customer can verify whether their deposits with [name of firm] qualify for FSCS protection, namely by referring the customer to their account statement as the confirmation mechanism [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. In addition, the information sheet should alert customers that FSCS protection is not universal and that there are exclusions, and it should direct them to the exclusions list that follows the information sheet for details of those exclusions [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. Taken together, the past-version framing and the FSCS content require a clear statement of the protection, a specific method for checking eligibility, and a signpost to the exclusions list [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a] [#TGT:f949291233620ea1].
source_text: Past version of Annex 1 – Information Sheet (Chapter 16) before 01/12/2025
target_text: The Financial Services Compensation Scheme (‘FSCS’) protects deposits made by most individuals and businesses. Your account statement will confirm whether your deposits with [name of firm] are eligible for FSCS protection. Details of certain exclusions from the FSCS’s protection are set out in the exclusions list after this information sheet.

question: In preparing recovery planning materials, how should a TWD firm evidence that its TWD option includes concrete actions, arrangements and measures to reduce risk and leverage and restructure trading activities, given the requirement to consider the PRA Rulebook Recovery Plans provisions and the specified related references?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should evidence its TWD option by explicitly setting out the actions, arrangements and measures that would allow it to reduce risk and leverage and to restructure its trading activities, making clear that these are integral components of the option rather than ancillary considerations [#SRC:f125cff5511a454b]. That evidence should be positioned within the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook framework, taking account of the specific rule reference and the further materials signposted for interpretation and completeness, namely the referenced paragraphs in SS9/17 and the referenced Article in Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 as it forms part of UK law [#TGT:da63c97283a5093f]. In effect, the firm should ensure its documentation both (i) describes the concrete content of the TWD option (actions/arrangements/measures and their intended effects) and (ii) is structured and supported in a way that is consistent with the Recovery Plans rule context and its linked guidance and legal cross-references.
source_text: have set out actions, arrangements and measures as part of the TWD option that would allow the TWD firm to reduce risk and leverage, and restructure its trading activities; 26
target_text: 26. Rule 2.10 in the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook. See also paragraphs 2.53-2.60 and 2.76-2.78, SS9/17. See also Article 9 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 as it forms part of UK law.

question: When deposits become unavailable deposits, what must a firm deliver to the FSCS, in what format, and within what deadline, taking into account both the requirement to provide single customer view and exclusions view information and the expectation that the firm can produce the relevant SCV and exclusions view files on demand?
gold_answer: When the relevant deposits become unavailable deposits, a firm must provide the FSCS with the required single customer view information and the related exclusions view information within 24 hours. Under the TARGET obligation, this is framed as providing to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within that 24-hour window once the deposits are unavailable deposits [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619]. The SOURCE complements this by specifying the deliverable form as an SCV file and an exclusions view file, and by reinforcing the same 24-hour timing expectation for providing those files to the FSCS (and also to the PRA) when a deposit becomes an unavailable deposit, as well as when the PRA or the FSCS requests them [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c]. Read together, the firm’s compliance outcome is that it must be operationally ready to generate and submit the SCV file and exclusions view file so that the FSCS receives the complete set of single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the triggering event, and the firm should maintain readiness to meet the same file-submission requirement upon request within the applicable time period.
source_text: Depositor Protection 12.1 and 12.2 set out that a firm must provide an SCV file and an exclusions view file to the PRA or the FSCS within 24 hours of a deposit becoming an unavailable deposit or request by the PRA or the FSCS. The PRA considers that the beginning of the 24-hour period can be taken as the end of the business day on which the request was made. The PRA or the FSCS may request the submission of an SCV file and exclusions view file at any time, including as part of the business as usual review programme. As such, firms should be ready and able to submit SCV and exclusions view files to the PRA and FSCS upon request, and within the time period set out in the depositor protection rules.
target_text: A firm must provide to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the relevant deposits becoming unavailable deposits .

question: How must a firm align its interest rate risk governance for non-trading activities so that the systems it implements to identify, evaluate and manage that risk also support the institution-level obligation to disclose quantitative and qualitative information on the resulting impacts on economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: A firm must put in place systems that identify, evaluate and manage the risk from potential changes in interest rates affecting its non-trading activities, including where those changes impact one or both relevant outcomes for those activities [#TGT:70fc9e8a73e07e79]. In parallel, institutions must disclose quantitative and qualitative information about the risks from potential interest rate changes as they affect both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#SRC:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. Read together, the systems requirement should be implemented in a way that produces and maintains the risk identification, evaluation and management outputs needed to underpin the required disclosures, covering both dimensions (economic value of equity and net interest income) for the non-trading book. This means the firm’s systems should be capable of capturing and assessing interest rate change risk across non-trading activities and translating that assessment into information suitable for institution disclosures that are both quantitative (measurable impacts) and qualitative (descriptive risk information), ensuring consistency between internal risk management and external disclosure.

question: For compliance documentation, how should an institution identify the EBA guidance that sets a minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, and where should it direct readers to access the authoritative version online?
gold_answer: An institution should identify the relevant guidance by naming it as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” ensuring the reference clearly ties the document to recovery plan indicators and the minimum qualitative and quantitative set expected under that guidance [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. In the same compliance documentation (e.g., a recovery planning policy, indicator framework, or internal governance memo), it should also provide an access point to the authoritative online location by directing readers to the EBA webpage where the guidelines are made available, using the provided “Available at” link to the EBA site [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Taken together, this approach both (i) specifies the exact EBA guidelines being relied upon for the minimum list of recovery plan indicators and (ii) enables reviewers, auditors, and supervisors to retrieve the current official version from the EBA’s published source. This pairing supports traceability between the named guidelines and the official online publication location, reducing ambiguity about which EBA recovery indicator guidance is being applied.
source_text: the EBA ‘Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators’; 3
target_text: 3. Available at: https://www.eba.europa.eu/activities/single-rulebook/regulatory-activities/recovery-resolution-and-dgs/guidelines-recovery .

question: To satisfy the obligation to mark eligible deposits so they can be identified immediately, what must a firm be able to provide to the PRA or the FSCS, in what form, and within what timeframe after a request?
gold_answer: A firm must implement its marking of eligible deposits so that those deposits can be identified immediately, and this marking obligation is not met in isolation: the firm must also be able to produce supporting account-level information on request. Specifically, in line with the requirement to mark eligible deposits for immediate identification [#TGT:60b306349873ce31], the PRA expects that a firm can make available to the PRA or the FSCS the details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts, with those categories separately identified, and that the information is provided in a format consistent with the relevant rule and the related statement. The firm must be able to do this within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS, demonstrating that the marking approach is operationally capable of rapid extraction and delivery of the relevant account details to the authorities when needed [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc].
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: After receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, what must a firm do within three months to evidence to the PRA that its systems will support the required identification of eligible deposits, and what operational outcome must those systems achieve for deposit marking?
gold_answer: Following receipt of a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, a firm has a time-bound reporting obligation to the PRA and a related operational obligation concerning how deposits are handled. Specifically, the firm must provide the PRA with a report on its systems within three months of receiving that permission, and the report must address the firm’s systems for compliance with the relevant requirements [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558]. In parallel, the firm’s systems and processes must ensure that eligible deposits are marked in a manner that enables immediate identification of those deposits, meaning the marking approach must support prompt recognition without delay in practice [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Read together, the report to the PRA should therefore cover how the firm’s systems are designed and operated to deliver this immediate-identification outcome for eligible deposits, including the mechanisms by which deposits are marked and how that marking is relied upon to distinguish eligible deposits as soon as needed [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558] [#TGT:60b306349873ce31].
source_text: A firm must provide the PRA with a report on its systems to comply with 11.1 and 11.2 within three months of receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: When a firm uses internal credit assessments for Matching Adjustment purposes, what must it do to validate its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria (including identification and allowance for all sources of credit risk), and how must it demonstrate that the resulting internal credit assessment outcomes are comparable to CRA issue ratings in terms of plausibility, consistency, and absence of bias?
gold_answer: A firm must operate an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation, and that validation must cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how the firm has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk on either a qualitative or quantitative basis [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. In addition, the firm’s validation work must ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes meet the relevant points referenced in the source passage, so that the outputs are not only produced but also checked against the required standards [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. Alongside this, the firm must demonstrate that its internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating by ensuring outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA, and by meeting requirements for broad consistency and no bias within that plausible range when comparing internal outcomes to CRA issue ratings at both asset-type and portfolio levels [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]. Using sample assets assessed by a CRA can further support demonstrating broad consistency, but the firm should not rely solely or mechanistically on credit ratings when assessing creditworthiness [#TGT:5fd5739308652721].
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: If the firm is checking whether it has covered all SCR-related risks, what must its risk-management system include, and what must be true about the calibration so that all quantifiable risks (at least the named ones) are counted?
gold_answer: To check that SCR-related risks are fully covered, the firm must ensure its risk-management system is effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, and it must cover the risks to be included in the SCR calculation as well as risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]. At the same time, the firm must ensure the calibration is designed so that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]. In practice, this means the firm’s system must not only focus on the risks already reflected in the SCR calculation but also identify and cover any additional or partially captured risks, while the calibration requirement ensures that every quantifiable exposure—starting with the minimum set of specified risk types—is included in the firm’s quantified risk capture.
source_text: (2) That risk-management system must: (a) be effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions ; (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and (c) cover at least the following areas: (i) underwriting and reserving as set out in 3.1A(1) ; (ii) asset-liability management as set out in 3.1A(2) ; (iii) investment risk management, in particular derivatives , quasi-derivatives and similar commitments, as set out in 3.1A(3) ; (iv) liquidity risk and concentration risk management: as set out in 3.1A(4) and 3.1A(5) ; (v) operational risk management as set out in 3.1A(6) ; and (vi) reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques as set out in 3.1A(7) .
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: What has to happen before the Merger Notification Statement is sent to members, and what does the board have to say about any important financial changes that happened after the financial period covered but before the statement is approved?
gold_answer: The Merger Notification Statement cannot be sent to the members unless it has first been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc]. Separately, because the financial information in the Schedule 16 Statement will cover a period that ends before the date that statement is approved, the board must tell members whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the meantime [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. If the board cannot put a number on the effect of a change, it still has to describe the change so members at least know it has been identified and is relevant to their decision on the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. The target text also warns that not disclosing these interim changes will matter to the PRA when it later considers the society’s application for confirmation of the merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Taken together, the PRA-approval-before-sending requirement and the board’s interim-change disclosure obligation are intended to ensure members receive a PRA-approved communication that also addresses any significant developments since the financial period reported [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1].
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: If the PRA cannot make a society change the merger terms after members approve them, when can the PRA still tell a society to do something else, and what happens if the society fixes (or does not fix) the problem?
gold_answer: The PRA’s involvement in an application to confirm a merger is limited to checking whether, based on the facts, any of the Three Criteria apply. It is not the PRA’s job to decide whether the merger is a good idea or whether the terms are fair; those decisions are for the board of a society and then its members. After members approve the merger and its terms, the PRA has no power to require a society to change those terms, and its discretion remains confined to the limited matters described in the relevant paragraphs [#SRC:aba762e80d02874f]. Even so, if the PRA would be unable to confirm the merger because there are defects that fall within the Three Criteria, it may direct a society to remedy those defects [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee]. That direction can include requiring the society to call a further meeting, such as to vote again after a revised Schedule 16 Statement corrects material information that was previously omitted, or after defects in sending notices and Statements and in validating votes are corrected [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee]. If the PRA is satisfied, based on evidence the society provides, that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm; otherwise it must refuse confirmation [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee].
source_text: The PRA’s powers in connection with applications for confirmation of a merger are confined to considerations of whether, in the light of the facts, any of the Three Criteria apply. It is not for the PRA to consider, or make judgements about, the merits of a proposed merger or the fairness of its terms; these matters are first for the board of a society, and then for its members to decide. Once the members have approved the merger and its terms, the PRA has no powers to require a society to make any changes to those terms. The PRA’s discretionary powers are similarly confined to the matters described in paragraphs 3.157 and 3.158 .
target_text: Where the PRA would be precluded from confirming a merger by reason of any of the defects specified in the Three Criteria, 37 Section 95(6) provides that it may direct a society to remedy the defects. A direction under that subsection may require a society to call a further meeting; for example, to vote again in the light of a revised Schedule 16 Statement containing material information previously omitted, or after correction of defects in the systems for sending notices of meeting and Statements and validation of votes. If the PRA is then satisfied, having considered evidence furnished by the society, that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger. If not, then confirmation must be refused.

question: How should a firm identify FCA materials that provide practical content and examples of good practice on wind-down planning, and what publication timing should it use when referencing the FCA’s concluding report on IFPR implementation observations?
gold_answer: A firm should look to the FCA’s Wind-down Planning Guide (WDPG) and the FCA’s related observations publications as sources of practical content and examples of good practice that firms may find helpful when developing or improving wind-down planning. In particular, the FCA materials described include the FCA’s ‘Observations on wind-down planning: liquidity, triggers & intragroup dependencies’ and the FCA’s ‘Investment Firms Prudential Regime implementation observations: quantifying threshold requirements and managing financial resources – concluding report’, which is noted as containing relevant wind-down planning material (including section 4.3 on Wind-down plans and section 6.6 on the Wind-down planning process). These documents are presented as providing helpful content and examples of good practice for firms to use in their wind-down planning approach, including considerations such as liquidity, triggers, and intragroup dependencies [#SRC:099eb63ae7c9d32e]. When citing or locating the concluding report, the firm should use the publication timing and reference provided in the FCA publication listing, which identifies the concluding report as a multi-firm review publication dated November 2023 [#TGT:9d30654f4dcfe280].
source_text: the FCA’s ‘Wind-down Planning Guide’ (WDPG), 14 TR22/1: ‘Observations on wind-down planning: liquidity, triggers & intragroup dependencies’, 15 and ‘Investment Firms Prudential Regime implementation observations: quantifying threshold requirements and managing financial resources – concluding report’ (such as section 4.3 Wind-down plans and section 6.6 Wind-down planning process) 16 which contain content and examples of good practice which firms may find helpful.

question: When Institutions are required to publish prudential disclosures in electronic format in a single medium or location, under what circumstances may a G-SII instead place the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location, and how should that be reconciled with the standalone-document or distinctive-section requirement?
gold_answer: Institutions have a general obligation to make all information required under Titles II and III available electronically in a single medium or location, structured either as a standalone document providing a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or as a distinctive, easily identifiable section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]. Against that baseline, a specific permission applies by way of derogation: where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1, it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document referenced in the single-medium framework [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76]. Read together, the G-SII’s ability to separate the Article 441 information is conditional (it must be relying on the derogation) and limited in scope (it concerns the information required under Article 441), while the broader single-medium presentation remains the default for the overall set of required prudential disclosures. Accordingly, the compliance approach is to maintain the required single medium or location for Titles II and III disclosures, while using the permitted separation only for the specified Article 441 content when the derogation conditions are met.
source_text: By way of derogation from Article 434(1) , where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1 , it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.

question: If a credit union has more than £50 million in total assets, what must it do each year to test liquidity, and how should those tests cover severe but plausible situations (including combined ones) and be linked to a clearly set RAS about how long and what kind of stress the credit union aims to survive?
gold_answer: A credit union with more than £50 million in total assets is expected by the PRA to carry out periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually, and those tests must consider the impact of stressed outflows as part of ensuring the credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0]. To make those annual tests fit the PRA’s wider expectation for liquidity stress testing, the credit union should design them to consider a range of severe, but plausible scenarios, including combined scenarios, rather than focusing on only one stress [#SRC:505c78059496b268]. The credit union can do this through its own analysis, but it should base that analysis on a clearly articulated RAS that defines the duration and type of stress or stresses the credit union aims to survive, so the testing has a clear survival objective and time horizon [#SRC:505c78059496b268]. The credit union should also expect the PRA to discuss the method and assumptions used, including how it estimates the likely run-off of different parts of the retail book, and should be ready to explain how those assumptions affect the stressed outflows in the periodic tests [#SRC:505c78059496b268].
source_text: The liquidity stress testing expectation referred to in paragraph 12.1 could be met by the credit union’s own analysis, which is based on a clearly articulated RAS (see paragraph 10.1 ) defining the duration and type of stress or stresses that the credit union aims to survive. The PRA expects the stress tests to consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios (including combined scenarios). Credit unions should expect the PRA to engage with them on the method used and assumptions made, eg their assessment of the likely run-off of different elements of the retail book.
target_text: In order to ensure a credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds under Credit Unions 9.4 , the PRA expects credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing whereby the impact of stressed outflows is considered.

question: Where one or more of the specified circumstances arise, is the FSCS permitted to postpone paying compensation beyond the standard time period, and is that permission limited to cases where those circumstances are present?
gold_answer: Yes. The scope trigger is that one or more of the specified circumstances must arise; that condition defines when the relevant framework applies and therefore when any related timing flexibility can be engaged [#SRC:815814104eb16d96]. In that same situation, the permission granted to the FSCS is that it may decide to defer the payment of compensation beyond the otherwise applicable time period, but only where the deferral condition is met—namely, where the relevant circumstances arise [#TGT:e7ff6bd16d34a149]. Read together, the SOURCE establishes the applicability boundary (the occurrence of one or more of the listed circumstances), and the TARGET provides the operational consequence within that boundary (a discretionary decision by the FSCS to defer payment beyond the standard period). Accordingly, absent the arising of at least one of those circumstances, the SOURCE does not indicate that the deferral condition is satisfied, and the TARGET’s permission to defer is not engaged; conversely, once the condition is met, the FSCS has discretion to defer rather than an obligation to do so.

question: If a credit union has more than £10 million in total assets or holds certain investments that trigger extra PRA expectations, what must it do about having a board-approved investment policy, and what else is it expected to follow on investment concentration limits (including any stated exception)?
gold_answer: If a credit union is in the group the PRA treats as needing extra investment safeguards—such as credit unions with more than £10 million in assets and those investing in more complex investments or undertaking additional activities—it is expected to maintain a board-approved investment policy [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c]. Separately, the PRA expects credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets, and any credit unions that hold investments that fall under the specified Rules, to adhere to additional concentration limits, on top of other required limits, while recognising there is an exception for the investments identified in the referenced list [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce]. Putting these together, a credit union that meets the PRA’s scope conditions should treat the board-approved investment policy as the key internal document that sets how it will control and oversee its investment activity so it can meet the PRA’s concentration expectations for the relevant investments. This means the policy should be designed to support adherence to the concentration limits that apply to in-scope credit unions and to account for the stated exception, consistent with the PRA’s expectations [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce].
source_text: Additional expectations relating to investments for credit unions with more than £10 million in assets and credit unions that invest in more complex investments (supranational bonds, corporate bonds, bank bonds, and money market funds) are set out in Chapters 11 and 14 , respectively.
