question: For a third country CRR firm, how should a firm determine whether the responsibilities described as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” are in scope, given that the scope provision states that such prescribed responsibilities do not apply? In your answer, explain what is captured by the definition of a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” and how the stated non-application affects that category.
gold_answer: The definition establishes the category: subject to a stated condition, each responsibility set out in the relevant rule is treated as a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105]. Separately, the scope statement provides an explicit carve-out for a third country CRR firm by stating that the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities do not apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. Read together, this means that even though the rule text may classify responsibilities as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” (i.e., they fall within the defined label when the definition’s condition is met), the scope provision removes their applicability to the third country CRR firm in question. Practically, the firm should (i) identify the responsibilities that would otherwise be captured by the definition as being “set out in this rule” and therefore within the defined category [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105], and then (ii) apply the scope carve-out confirming that those prescribed responsibilities are not applicable to the third country CRR firm [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec].
source_text: (1) the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities in 6.2 do not apply; and
target_text: Subject to 6.3 , each of the responsibilities set out in this rule is a third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility :

question: You must not split a contract’s insurance obligations into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, unless it is an eligible element. If you want to include only the in-payment part of an income protection contract in a matching adjustment portfolio, when is that allowed and what is not allowed, especially around recovery time risk?
gold_answer: The rule for building the relevant portfolio is that you must not split the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract into different parts, unless the split is within an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. The PRA’s matching adjustment guidance describes when an in-payment portion of an income protection contract may fit within that kind of exception: in-payment elements may be eligible for inclusion where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in line with the referenced regulatory requirement, and the PRA expects this to allow in-payment claims under group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios where the claims are not subject to future premiums [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. The PRA also explains the underwriting risk angle: permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio may include recovery time risk (the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover than expected), and unlike mortality risk there is no restriction on exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. However, the PRA does not expect that recognising recovery time risk should be used to bring in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment, so splitting cannot be used to widen the portfolio beyond that scope [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: If a firm is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm, does it still have to state whether the institution benefits from a derogation in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook, even though certain rules do not apply to that kind of firm?
gold_answer: Yes, the institution still needs to provide information on whether it benefits from a derogation laid down in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook, because that item is explicitly framed as information to be provided about the institution’s derogation status [#SRC:8b3d59ee5a01ffc2]. Separately, the scope text says that certain listed provisions do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03]. Putting these together, being within the category of a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm affects whether the specified provisions apply, but it does not remove the need to communicate whether the institution benefits from a derogation where that information is required to be supplied. In practice, the firm should (1) confirm whether it is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm for the purpose of the non-applicability statement, and (2) still include a clear statement on whether the institution benefits from a derogation under the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook.
source_text: (k) information on whether the institution benefits from a derogation laid down in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 5.3 , and/or 12.2 (second subparagraph), and 15.A1 (3) .
target_text: 12.2 , 15.15 to 15.19 , 15.20 (2) and (3A), 15.20A to 15.23 and 15A do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm .

question: When institutions handle derivative transactions that are mapped to the commodity risk category and the transaction has more than one material risk driver, how shall the transaction be mapped across risk categories and, within the commodity risk category, how shall it be assigned to a hedging set based on the relevant risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions must first determine whether a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and, if so, apply the derogation requiring mapping to more than one risk category where relevant. If all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Separately, for the portion of the analysis where the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category, institutions must then assign that transaction to one of the specified hedging sets. That hedging set assignment must be made on the basis of the nature of the transaction’s primary risk driver, or (where applicable) the most material risk driver within the commodity risk category for the relevant transactions [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]. In practice, this means multi-risk-driver transactions may require multiple category mappings, while the commodity hedging set selection is anchored to the primary or most material commodity risk driver.
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK, including where traders have been relocated to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK, what must a UK trading bank or international bank carrying on activities in the UK do to evidence appropriate control and ensure effective UK oversight of the resulting remote books, including any orphan or shared books?
gold_answer: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK—whether arising from relocation of traders to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK or otherwise—the arrangements must be treated as higher-risk and subjected to greater scrutiny, supported by high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]. In parallel, any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings must ensure there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, with particular focus where there is no UK based trader covering the book (orphan books) [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Where the operating model includes shared books or desks with a mix of local and remote traders, the bank must clearly define these in the booking taxonomy and identify the portion of risk remote-booked into the UK so it can be subject to remote booking controls [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Taken together, the heightened evidencing expectation for 100% remote booking should be met through demonstrable UK oversight and clear taxonomy and control of remote-booked risk.
source_text: c) Whether the change may lead to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity with the role of remotely managing risk into the UK; where the firm plans an increase in remote trading, the allocation of the number and relative seniority of traders should normally be broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations. Where the size of business undertaken in the second location is negligible, this is unlikely to be sufficient justification to warrant the splitting of a desk. Any existing arrangements where there is 100% remote booking into the UK, irrespective of whether they result from a relocation or not, should be subjected to greater scrutiny, and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled (and see 4.25P ).
target_text: Any UK trading bank or international bank (whether a subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure that there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, and particularly in cases where there is no UK based trader covering the book (often called ‘orphan books’). ‘Shared’ books or desks, where there is a mix of local and remote traders, should be clearly defined in the booking taxonomy and the portion of the risk remote-booked into the UK is expected to be identified and subject to remote booking controls.

question: If a firm is a UK subsidiary in an international group and may mainly rely on parental support, what does its plan need to cover about UK-specific recovery options and how quickly those options could be put in place?
gold_answer: The firm’s plan needs to cover UK-specific recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary, even if the PRA recognises that a subsidiary may have fewer options and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. This means the firm should not stop at describing parental support; it should consider what additional options are available locally and set out those recovery options in the plan as UK subsidiary actions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. Alongside describing each recovery option, the firm should include the timelines over which the recovery options could be implemented, so the plan shows when each option could realistically be carried out [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. If the firm is an O-SII, the recovery options it includes should also be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still being clearly described for the UK subsidiary and paired with implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Together, these elements help show both what the firm could do in the UK and how quickly it could do it.
source_text: (iii) The plan should include UK specific recovery options: the PRA recognises that as subsidiaries of international groups, firms may have a more limited set of recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option. However, the PRA expects firms to consider what additional options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and set out its recovery options against the expectations set out in Chapter 2 (i) (b) , (c) , (d) , (e) , (f) , (g) and (ii) . For O-SIIs the PRA expects these options to be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan.
target_text: Firms should include the timelines over which recovery options could be implemented.

question: Where a firm and a group are within scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and related PRA Rulebook Articles, what must the firm ensure is additionally included in its SFCR regarding capital management, and how must that content be presented?
gold_answer: When a firm and a group are in scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and the referenced Articles of Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, that disclosure context frames the broader set of information the firm is expected to address [#SRC:2ae4fedd8ca85f88]. In addition to whatever information is disclosed under those Reporting routes, the firm has a distinct SFCR obligation focused on capital management: the SFCR must go beyond the core items and include any other information that is material to the capital management of the firm. This additional material information is not to be embedded informally within other narrative; it must be presented in a dedicated, separate section of the SFCR, ensuring it is clearly identifiable as supplementary capital-management content [#TGT:6d803b1270670d13]. Read together, the scope provision clarifies the disclosure setting (information disclosed by a firm and a group under the listed Reporting provisions), while the SFCR requirement imposes an affirmative duty on the firm to capture any further material capital-management information and to structure it as a standalone section within the SFCR.
source_text: (1) Subject to (3), (4) and 4.2 , the information that a firm and a group discloses pursuant to Reporting 3.3 (5)(d), 3.4 , 3.4A , 3.5A , 3.5B , 3.6B , 3.7A to 3.7C , and Articles 7A(1) (d) and Articles 7A(1) (e) of Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook;
target_text: The SFCR shall include any other material information, in a separate section, regarding the capital management of the firm .

question: For firms within the scope of the PRA’s stated expectations on marking eligible deposits and accounts, what must a firm do to ensure eligible deposits can be identified without delay, and how does that obligation align with the chapter’s intended application?
gold_answer: Where the chapter applies, it frames the PRA’s expectations for how firms will approach the marking of eligible deposits and accounts, setting the scope and context for what firms are expected to implement in practice [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d]. Within that scoped framework, the operative requirement is that a firm must implement a marking approach for eligible deposits that enables those deposits to be identified immediately, i.e., the marking must be designed so that eligible deposits can be recognised without delay when needed [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Read together, the source establishes that the topic is specifically the marking of eligible deposits (and related accounts) and that the PRA is articulating expectations for firms’ processes in this area [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d], while the target provides the concrete compliance outcome that the marking must achieve—immediate identifiability of eligible deposits [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Accordingly, a firm should treat the chapter’s expectations as the contextual guide for designing and operating its marking arrangements, but ensure the implemented method meets the mandatory standard of immediate identification.
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts and is intended to be read together with Chapters 11 and 13 of the Depositor Protection Part .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: When a firm calibrates a residential mortgage rating system by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average and uses an embedded calculation mechanism that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics, how must the firm treat that mechanism for recalibration purposes, and what cyclicality assumption must it apply when grade-level internal observed default rates are unavailable (including how the PRA may vary that expectation)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat any embedded calculation mechanism in its rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics as a recalibration, rather than as an intended feature of rating system design, because the PRA expects such recalibrations to be rare and symptomatic of failures in the rating system’s assumptions [#SRC:5f859b5bac10db27]. In parallel, when calibrating residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, the firm should assume that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in years where grade-level internal observed default rates are not available, as this cap is the PRA’s expectation for imputing missing historical default rates [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The firm should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that, when assigning long-run average default rates to each rating grade, at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate is assumed to reflect grade-level changes in default rate (with the remaining portion attributable to grade migration) [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The PRA indicates this expectation may be adjusted if it judges the risk of under-calibration has changed [#TGT:8705f442785054e1].
source_text: The PRA expects recalibrations of rating systems applying the cyclicality assumptions set out in paragraph 12.4 to be rare and to be symptomatic of failures of the rating system’s assumptions rather than part of rating system design. For these purposes any calculation mechanism embedded in a rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics should be treated as a recalibration. The PRA expects that any recalibration of such a rating system would include:
target_text: In the PRA’s experience, firms often have difficulty in practice in understanding the cyclicality of their residential mortgage rating systems. To mitigate the risk of under-calibration of these rating systems due to inaccurate estimation of their cyclicality, the PRA expects that when firms calibrate their residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, they should do so on the assumption that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in those years where grade level internal observed default rates are not available. This cyclicality cap is the PRA’s expectation of what firms should assume is the maximum level of cyclicality when imputing missing historical default rates. If 30% of the change in portfolio default rates comes from grade migration the remaining 70% would come from change in default rates within grades. Therefore when calibrating the long-run average default rates to assign to each rating grade the PRA expects firms to assume that at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate reflects grade level changes in default rate. This level reflects the PRA’s current view of an appropriately conservative assumption for rating system cyclicality in light of recent experience. This expectation may be adjusted by the PRA if it judges that there has been a change in the risk of under-calibration.

question: If a relevant third-country firm is preparing the whole-firm liquidity information the PRA expects, what LCR materials must it include from what it already reports to its home state supervisor (HSS), and what does it mean that this is based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s 2013 Liquidity Coverage Requirement?
gold_answer: When a relevant third-country firm prepares the whole-firm liquidity information the PRA expects, it should build the submission from the data it reports to its home state supervisor (HSS). The PRA expects the firm to provide the information in a single, consolidated currency and, if the firm provides it to the HSS, also on a significant currency basis. For the LCR part specifically, the firm should include the LCR-related data it reports to the HSS, including the completed LCR template and any other additional liquidity reports it submits to the HSS [#SRC:432f97ed6f63cee5]. The reference point for what “LCR” means in this context is that it is based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s introduction of the Liquidity Coverage Requirement in 2013, so the firm’s LCR materials should reflect how its HSS has implemented that 2013 requirement [#TGT:b05def7c40876dda].
source_text: The PRA expects relevant third-country firms to submit liquidity information at the whole-firm level, based upon data which is reported to the firm’s home state supervisor (‘HSS’). Data should be provided in a single, consolidated currency and where this is provided to the HSS, also on a significant currency basis. In particular, this should include data reported to the firm’s HSS that relates to the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) 2 and in particular the completed LCR template and any other additional liquidity reports submitted to the HSS. 3
target_text: 2. Based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s introduction of Liquidity Coverage Requirement (LCR) in 2013.

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract, must the calculation be prospective, and in what limited circumstances may a retrospective calculation be used instead to determine the liabilities?
gold_answer: For each contract, the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined using a prospective calculation, establishing the default method that applies on a contract-by-contract basis [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. A retrospective calculation is not a free alternative to that requirement; it may only be applied to determine the liabilities in narrowly defined situations tied to the feasibility and prudence of the prospective approach [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. Specifically, a retrospective calculation may be used where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, which functions as an exception to the otherwise mandatory prospective determination for each contract [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] read together with [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. Alternatively, even if a prospective method could be applied, a retrospective calculation may be used where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation, ensuring the retrospective outcome is at least as conservative as the prudent prospective benchmark [#TGT:30f622a929df3844].
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: When Institutions disclose the information required across the relevant disclosure titles, how must they present those disclosures in terms of format and location, and how must the risk management objectives and policies disclosures be structured across separate categories of risk, including the risks referred to in the applicable Title?
gold_answer: Institutions must ensure that the full set of required disclosures is made available in electronic format and consolidated in a single medium or location, rather than dispersed across multiple places. That single medium or location must take the form of either a standalone document that serves as a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or a distinctive, easily identifiable section included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports. Within that same disclosure package, Institutions must also provide disclosures on their risk management objectives and policies, and they must do so for each separate category of risk, explicitly covering the risks referred to in the applicable Title. In practice, this means the electronic, single-location disclosure vehicle must be organized so users can readily find, by risk category, the institution’s stated objectives and policies, while still meeting the overarching requirement to include all information required under the relevant titles in one accessible place [#SRC:8422ed9edcda5caa] and to cover each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in the Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].
source_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.
target_text: Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in this Title. These disclosures shall include:

question: When an institution maps a derivative transaction with more than one material risk driver to multiple risk categories, how must it determine whether it has a long or short position in the most material risk driver within each mapped risk category, based on the condition that the transaction’s market value moves with increases in that risk driver’s value?
gold_answer: Institutions must first apply the mapping requirement for derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver by assigning the transaction to more than one risk category, unless all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver in that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Once the relevant risk category (or categories) is determined, the institution must identify, within each mapped risk category, the primary risk driver or the most material risk driver used as the basis for mapping. The institution then determines position direction by assessing how the transaction’s market value responds to an increase in the value of that risk driver: if the market value increases when the risk driver’s value increases, the position in that risk driver is long; if the market value decreases when the risk driver’s value increases, the position is short [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]. This long/short determination is therefore performed per mapped risk category, aligned to the most material risk driver selected for that category under the mapping approach.
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission, how must the firm determine the permissible range for the transitional deduction it applies, and how is the “maximum amount” defined for that purpose? Where the firm elects to apply less than that maximum, what disclosure and supervisory-sharing steps does the PRA expect, and how must the firm ensure consistency of this approach across its Solvency II reporting and governance materials?
gold_answer: For all firms with a TMTP permission, the firm must ensure the amount of the transitional deduction it applies sits within a defined range: it must be no less than zero and no more than the maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” for this purpose is defined as the maximum number derived either from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach set out in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm decides to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. In addition, the firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the TMTP benefit it is applying, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed consistently across all Solvency II reporting, including Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs), and to be reflected within the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].
source_text: For all firms with a TMTP permission there is a requirement that the amount of the transitional deduction to be applied by a firm is to be between zero and a maximum amount. 6 If a decision is taken by such a firm to apply less than the maximum amount, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures, and to share this information with its supervision team. The firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the amount of TMTP benefit it is applying. The PRA expects this approach to be followed consistently by firms within all Solvency II reporting including for Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs). This approach should also be reflected within a firm’s ORSA and risk management framework.
target_text: 6. The amount is the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or the legacy approach outlined in the relevant firm’s permission.

question: For purposes of the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement setting expectations on banks’ model risk management, which types of firms fall within scope, and which categories are expressly outside scope despite the use of the term “banks” in the title?
gold_answer: The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement is framed as setting out the PRA’s expectations for banks’ model risk management (MRM), and it also makes clear that the PRA considers model risk to be a risk in its own right [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d]. Read together with the scope clarification, the expectations are not limited only to entities commonly described as “banks” in ordinary language: the scope includes banks, building societies, and designated investment firms [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. At the same time, the use of “banks” in the title is specifically intended to signal an exclusion: the expectations do not apply to insurers or reinsurers [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. Accordingly, when applying the PRA’s MRM expectations, firms should determine applicability by reference to the stated scope categories (banks, building societies, and designated investment firms) and should treat insurers and reinsurers as out of scope, even though the statement’s title uses the term “banks” [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d] [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa].
source_text: This Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement (SS) sets out the PRA’s expectations for banks’ 1 model risk management (MRM). The PRA considers model risk as a risk in its own right.
target_text: 1. While the scope of this SS includes banks, building societies, and designated investment firms, the term ‘banks’ is used in the title to make it clear that the expectations do not apply to insurers or reinsurers.

question: When an applicant is required to provide the Merger Document including the Schedule 16 Statement (and the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments), what must the board state about interim financial developments between the period covered by the financial information and the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, and how must any unquantifiable effects be handled for members’ consideration?
gold_answer: Where the Merger Document is to be provided and it includes the Schedule 16 Statement (together with the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments), the board must address the timing gap inherent in the financial information by stating whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim between the period end covered by that information and the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. This is not optional: the board is required to make an explicit statement either way, so members are not left to infer whether the position has changed. If there has been a change and its effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe it in a way that makes clear it has been identified and is relevant to members’ consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. The disclosure expectation operates alongside the obligation to include the Schedule 16 Statement within the Merger Document (unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society) [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1].
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: When you assess a model’s complexity, what risk factors should you look at across the modelling process, and what does “designer or data bias” mean so you can decide whether it needs to be considered as part of that complexity assessment?
gold_answer: When assessing a model’s complexity, you should consider the risk factors that impact the model’s inherent risk within each component of the modelling process. This includes reviewing the nature and quality of the input data, the choice of methodology (including assumptions), the requirements and integrity of implementation, and how frequently and/or extensively the model is used [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253]. If it is necessary—especially where newly advanced approaches or technologies are involved—the complexity assessment may also take into account additional risk factors, including the use of alternative and unstructured data and measures of interpretability, explainability, transparency, and whether designer or data bias could be present [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253]. “Designer or data bias” means that elements of a dataset (or, alternatively, aspects of model design) are more heavily weighted and/or represented than others, and that this can produce results with ethical and/or social implications [#TGT:330cb726532ca174]. Using that definition, you should treat any disproportionate weighting or representation—whether coming from the data or the model design—as a specific risk factor to be considered within the overall complexity assessment, alongside the other modelling-process factors [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] [#TGT:330cb726532ca174].
source_text: c) The assessment of a model's complexity should consider the risk factors that impact a model’s inherent risk 8 within each component of the modelling process, eg the nature and quality of the input data, the choice of methodology (including assumptions), the requirements and integrity of implementation, and the frequency and/or extensiveness of use of the model. Where necessary (in particular with the use of newly advanced approaches or technologies), the complexity assessment may also consider risk factors related to: (i) the use of alternative and unstructured data, 9 and (ii) measures of a model's interpretability, 10 explainability, 11 transparency, and the potential for designer or data bias 12 to be present.
target_text: 12. When elements of a dataset (or as a result of model design) are more heavily weighted and/or represented than others, producing results that could have ethical and/ or social implications.

question: When explaining the basis for an SS that draws on earlier publications from the Bank and the PRA on new bank authorisation and related supervisory material, which specific prior publications on governance and accountability should be identified as part of the referenced set of SSs and guidance materials?
gold_answer: The SS should be described as building on earlier publications from the Bank and the PRA on new bank authorisation, alongside other supervisory statements and statements of policy referenced as supporting material, and the Bank’s approach to resolution [#SRC:1434fc4338d6998c]. Within that referenced body of prior publications, the governance and accountability items that should be identified include SS5/16 on Corporate Governance (Board responsibilities), SS21/15 on Internal governance, the EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance (EBA Governance Guidelines), and SS28/15 on Strengthening individual accountability in banking [#TGT:2c626199be43f728]. Taken together, these items illustrate the specific governance and individual accountability sources that the SS can point to when evidencing that it “draws upon” previous Bank and PRA publications, rather than presenting its expectations in isolation. Framing the cross-reference this way also helps show how the SS’s governance-related expectations align with established supervisory materials while remaining part of a broader set of inputs that also includes authorisation-focused publications and the Bank’s resolution approach [#SRC:1434fc4338d6998c] and the listed governance and accountability publications [#TGT:2c626199be43f728].
source_text: The SS additionally draws upon previous publications from the Bank and the PRA on new bank authorisation, 18 various SSs and SoPs (see Table 1 ), and the Bank's approach to resolution. 19
target_text: SS5/16 ‘Corporate Governance: Board responsibilities’ 25 SS21/15 ‘Internal governance’ 26 EBA Guidelines on Internal Governance (EBA Governance Guidelines) 27 SS28/15 ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’ 28

question: When preparing an appropriate analysis of balance sheet items that may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of, what types of items should be considered, and how should sensitivity analysis be used to assess the resources needed?
gold_answer: The analysis should be framed as an “appropriate analysis” that explicitly tests how key factors could change the resources needed, including by using sensitivity analyses, and it must also include a focused review of any balance sheet items that could be hard to transfer or sell once the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of [#SRC:87da92e5a5f203f5]. In applying that requirement, the analysis should consider concrete examples of potentially difficult items, including deposits with untraceable or uncontactable customers and small and niche lending books, as these illustrate categories that may present transferability or sale challenges and therefore may drive residual resource needs [#TGT:16a5bdc394f9858e]. Practically, the sensitivity analyses should be used to explore how variations in assumptions (for example, the scale or persistence of such hard-to-move items) could increase the time, effort, or other resources required to complete disposal and manage remaining exposures. The output should connect the identified difficult items to resource impacts under different scenarios, so that the assessment is not purely descriptive but demonstrates how these items could affect the resources needed to execute the post-disposal position.
source_text: appropriate analysis, such as sensitivity analyses of factors that may impact the resources needed, and an analysis of any balance sheet items which may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of; 46 and
target_text: 46. Examples include deposits with untraceable/uncontactable customers; and small and niche lending books.

question: If a firm has a 10% overall limit for certain described assets, and there is also a 1% limit for investments valued under a specific method per issuer (with some exceptions), how do these two limits work together for the same holdings?
gold_answer: They work together by limiting exposure in two different ways, so the firm should check both. Under the SOURCE, the firm must look at the total (aggregate) amount of assets that fall within the specified described categories and keep that combined amount within a 10% cap [#SRC:ed238e6c1b77ab93]. Under the TARGET, the firm must also look at a narrower group of investments—those that can be valued using the stated valuation method—and apply a separate concentration limit based on a single issuer: the relevant investments issued by any one issuer, taken together, are limited to 1% [#TGT:9b20c41c2fcfcc52]. The TARGET also makes clear that some items are not counted in that 1% bucket, namely secured debt securities, debt securities issued by a regulated institution, and investments that are listed and readily realisable. So, for holdings that are in scope of both provisions (and not excluded under the TARGET), the firm should ensure the issuer total stays within 1% while also ensuring the broader aggregate pool stays within 10%.
source_text: 10% for the aggregate of assets of any of the descriptions in 28.3 and 28.13 .
target_text: 1% for all investments of a kind which may be valued in accordance with 12 (other than secured debt securities , debt securities issued by a regulated institution or investments which are listed and readily realisable ) issued by any one issuer taken together with:

question: When a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, how must it apply the obligation to maintain a margin of solvency—does it need to maintain separate margins for each kind of business, and how does that interact with the requirement that the margin be at least the required margin of solvency (including any stated carve-out)?
gold_answer: A firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business must treat the general obligation to maintain a margin of solvency as applying separately to each of those two kinds of business, rather than as a single combined margin across the firm. In other words, the requirement is modified so that the firm maintains separate margins in respect of long-term insurance business and general insurance business [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b]. At the same time, the firm remains subject to the baseline obligation that it must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency, subject to the stated condition and excluding a flat rate benefits business friendly society from that obligation [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690]. Read together, this means that where the firm is within scope of the margin requirement, it must ensure compliance with the “equal to or greater than the required margin” standard while applying it in a way that reflects separate margins for the two categories of insurance business, rather than a single aggregated measure.
source_text: Where a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business , 2.1 has effect as if the requirement to maintain a margin of solvency were a requirement to maintain separate margins in respect of the two kinds of business.
target_text: Subject to 2.3 , a firm (other than a flat rate benefits business friendly society ) must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency .

question: If an institution has to work out risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs, can it set the exposure value to zero for some collateral exposures, and when does that apply if a CCP or clearing member becomes insolvent?
gold_answer: The institution must calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by summing the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (calculated under the specified paragraphs) and then multiplying that total by the risk weight determined under the specified paragraph [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]. Separately, the institution may, as a derogation, assign an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for assets it has posted as collateral to a CCP or to a clearing member, but only if those collateral assets are bankruptcy remote when insolvency occurs [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4]. The insolvency trigger is not limited to the CCP itself: the condition is met if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, provided the posted collateral remains bankruptcy remote in that scenario. In effect, the required CCP trade-exposure calculation uses exposure values, and the permission allows certain qualifying collateral-related exposure values to be reduced to zero before they feed into the summed amount.
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 1 , where assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member are bankruptcy remote in the event that the CCP, the clearing member or one or more of the other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, an institution may attribute an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for those assets.

question: When calculating surplus funds and assessing whether an own funds item qualifies as Tier 1 own funds, how must a firm apply the expectation to have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook alongside the requirement to treat specified basic own funds items as having the relevant characteristics and to classify them as Tier 1 where they display all required features?
gold_answer: A firm must approach Tier 1 classification by combining the general expectation to use the PRA Rulebook’s Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts as the framework for its calculations and assessment with the specific classification outcome required for certain basic own funds items. Under the SOURCE, firms should have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts when calculating surplus funds and when considering whether they meet the criteria for classification as Tier 1 own funds, including by using the listed own funds items and the features that determine Tier 1 classification [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e]. Under the TARGET, the firm must then apply the rule that the identified basic own funds items are deemed to substantially possess the relevant characteristics when the stated features are taken into consideration, and the firm must classify those items as Tier 1 own funds where the items display all of the specified features [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]. Read together, the firm’s process is: calculate and assess using the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts as the reference point, and, for the basic own funds items covered by the deeming provision, treat the characteristics as satisfied and complete the mandatory Tier 1 classification when the full set of required features is present.
source_text: Firms should have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and considering whether they meet the criteria for classification as Tier 1 own funds. In particular, Own Funds 3A sets out a list of own funds items and Own Funds 3B the features determining classification as Tier 1 own funds.
target_text: The following basic own funds items shall be deemed to substantially possess the characteristics set out in 3.5 , taking into consideration the features set out in 3.6 , and a firm must classify them as Tier 1 own funds , where the following items display all of the features set out in 3B :

question: Where the PRA has deferred, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy because payment would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, when must the deferred amount be paid, and what limits apply to the duration and renewal of the deferral?
gold_answer: If the PRA defers, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy because the PRA considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, the deferred contribution must be paid once making the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] [#SRC:f026573295165d20]. The deferral is time-limited: it must not be granted for longer than six months at a time, but it may be renewed if the firm requests renewal [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]. Accordingly, the compliance expectation is that the firm monitors whether the original jeopardy condition has ceased and, when it has, ensures payment is made without waiting for the end of any deferral period, while also tracking the six‑month cap and submitting a renewal request if the PRA’s deferral needs to continue because the jeopardy condition persists [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b].
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: When a firm is a UK subsidiary of an international group and parental support may be the most credible recovery option, what must the firm set out in its plan regarding UK-specific recovery options and the implementation timelines for those options, including any consistency expectations for O-SIIs with the group plan?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its plan goes beyond relying solely on parental support by identifying and documenting UK-specific recovery options available at the level of the UK subsidiary, reflecting that subsidiaries of international groups may have a more limited set of options but are still expected to consider additional actions that could be taken locally [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. Where the firm is an O-SII, the recovery options it sets out should be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, so that the UK subsidiary’s actions align with the wider group approach while still being articulated at the UK level [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. In addition to describing the options themselves, the firm should include the timelines over which each recovery option could be implemented, so the plan indicates how quickly the firm could execute the identified UK-specific measures (and any parental support option) in practice [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Taken together, the plan should present a coherent set of UK subsidiary recovery options and a clear view of when each could be deployed, enabling assessment of credibility and practicality in stressed conditions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8].
source_text: (iii) The plan should include UK specific recovery options: the PRA recognises that as subsidiaries of international groups, firms may have a more limited set of recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option. However, the PRA expects firms to consider what additional options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and set out its recovery options against the expectations set out in Chapter 2 (i) (b) , (c) , (d) , (e) , (f) , (g) and (ii) . For O-SIIs the PRA expects these options to be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan.
target_text: Firms should include the timelines over which recovery options could be implemented.

question: When submitting an application to the PRA for confirmation of an amalgamation or a transfer of engagements, may the parties include additional narrative in the scrutineers report beyond the required enclosure, and if so, what extra matters does the PRA indicate it would find helpful to be covered where invalid votes appear significant?
gold_answer: In an application for confirmation submitted to the PRA, the parties must enclose the scrutineers report as part of the application package, alongside the other required supporting documents (including the certified minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved) [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e]. In addition to that required enclosure, the PRA indicates it is permitted and would be helpful for the scrutineers report to go further than simply reporting the voting outcome by also addressing process quality: it should comment on any procedural difficulties encountered during the voting process and provide an analysis of why votes were found to be invalid, but specifically where the number of invalid votes appears to be significant [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]. Read together, this means the scrutineers report is not only a mandatory component of each confirmation application, but it may also be expanded to include diagnostic commentary and root-cause analysis to assist the PRA’s assessment, particularly in cases where invalid voting could be material to the integrity of the member decision-making process.
source_text: The parties in an amalgamation should make a joint application for confirmation to the PRA, while the parties to a transfer of engagements should make separate applications for confirmation of the transfer. These applications should specify the date on which the merger is intended to take effect and should be accompanied by two authenticated copies of the Instrument of Transfer, or the amalgamation agreement, and of the Merger Document or separate Schedule 16 Statement. In addition, in the case of an amalgamation, three signed copies of the Memorandum and Rules of the successor 34 to the amalgamating societies should be sent to the PRA and the FCA. The scrutineers report described in paragraphs 3.146 to 3.148 , and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved, must be enclosed with each application.
target_text: The PRA would find it helpful if the scrutineers report would also comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant (see also paragraph 3.171 ).

question: What must a firm do to keep enough liquid assets to pay liabilities when they are due, and how does this connect to the expectation that an insurer holds a liquidity buffer and monitors liquid assets (including possible haircuts on sale)?
gold_answer: A firm must hold and maintain liquid assets that are sufficient to meet its liabilities as they become due [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855]. The related expectation for an insurer is more specific about how to achieve that outcome: it must maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets (a liquidity buffer) sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and it is expected to be able to do so under both benign and stressed conditions [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0]. To support this, the insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer, and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale, which could reduce the cash actually available when assets are liquidated [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0]. Read together, the requirement is not only to have liquid assets on paper, but to ensure the portfolio and buffer are managed and monitored so that liabilities can be met when due in normal and stressed environments [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0] while still satisfying the baseline obligation to meet liabilities as they become due [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855].
source_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.
target_text: A firm must maintain liquid assets sufficient to meet its liabilities as they become due.

question: Up to 31 December 2024, when you calculate the leverage ratio as if Article 473a of the CRR does not apply for the capital measure, what capital measure must you use in that calculation across those quarterly periods?
gold_answer: Across the quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024, the scope condition is that the leverage ratio is calculated on a basis that assumes Article 473a of the CRR does not apply for the purposes of the capital measure [#SRC:05bd855cd46919eb]. When that condition applies, the definition of the capital measure is clear and fixed: for the relevant purposes, the capital measure must be tier 1 capital (leverage) [#TGT:1d76390248a589f0]. So, for each quarterly period within that timeframe, if you are using the “treat Article 473a as not applying” approach for the capital measure part of the leverage ratio, you must use tier 1 capital (leverage) as the capital measure. The timing element (quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024) limits when this approach is relevant, and the definition element ensures the same capital measure is used whenever it is relevant.
source_text: (g) in relation to the quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024, the leverage ratio calculated as if Article 473a of the CRR did not apply for purposes of the capital measure under Article 429(3) of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part .
target_text: For the purposes of paragraph 2 , the capital measure shall be tier 1 capital (leverage) .

question: Given the PRA’s expectation that boards obtain suitable management information to oversee operational resilience and to challenge senior management effectively, which PRA Rulebook provision is identified as the relevant cross-reference for CRR firms, and how should the board’s collective capability be framed in that context?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation is that, even though individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, boards must ensure they have appropriate management information to oversee operational resilience effectively, and that the board collectively has adequate knowledge, skills, and experience to provide constructive challenge to senior management and inform decisions with operational resilience consequences [#SRC:899315b848004882]. The cross-referenced PRA Rulebook provision identified for CRR firms is Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms) [#TGT:39817b585204e92e]. Read together, this means the board should treat the availability and quality of management information as a core governance input supporting its collective ability to scrutinise and challenge senior management decisions affecting operational resilience, rather than relying on technical expertise of any single director. The linkage to Rule 5.2 provides the specific Rulebook anchor for CRR firms to align organisational requirements with the PRA’s stated expectation about board information and collective capability [#SRC:899315b848004882] [#TGT:39817b585204e92e].
source_text: While individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, the PRA expects boards to ensure that they have the appropriate management information. Boards should also collectively possess adequate knowledge, skills, and experience to provide constructive challenge to senior management and inform decisions that have consequences for operational resilience. 26
target_text: 26. Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms), Rule 2.7 in the Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook (Solvency II firms).

question: Where a credit union proposes to offer shares within an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper and also intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, what must it do to ensure it is referring to the relevant regulations and meeting all statutory mandatory requirements before commencing the fixed-rate activity, and how should it treat any HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) approval in its compliance assessment?
gold_answer: A credit union that wishes to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper is expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), and it must not treat HMRC approval as reducing or displacing its need to comply with statutory requirements [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d]. In parallel, where the same credit union intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, the PRA expects it to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning that activity [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]. Read together, the obligations require the credit union to (i) consult and follow the applicable HMRC regulatory framework for the ISA wrapper, (ii) recognise that obtaining HMRC approval does not provide any exemption from statutory compliance duties, and (iii) ensure that all statutory mandatory preconditions for issuing fixed-rate shares or deposits are met before it starts offering or issuing those products. The compliance approach should therefore treat HMRC approval as separate from, and not a substitute for, satisfying the statutory mandatory requirements expected by the PRA prior to commencement.
source_text: Credit unions that wish to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper are expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Credit unions should be aware that approval from HMRC does not provide any degree of exemption from compliance with the statutory requirements referred to above in paragraph 5.2 .
target_text: The PRA expects that any credit union that intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning such activity. 2

question: When calculating and disclosing changes in the economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods, how must a firm apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios across currencies, and what determines the scope of currencies to which those scenarios must be applied?
gold_answer: A firm’s obligation to calculate and disclose the changes in the economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods must be carried out using the prescribed interest rate scenarios that the firm is required to apply for the relevant evaluation. Specifically, the firm must apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios to all material currencies, with materiality determined as specified for that purpose, so that the economic value of equity changes produced under the six supervisory shock scenarios are generated on a currency-complete basis for all currencies that meet the materiality determination. This links the disclosure of economic value of equity changes under the six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods [#SRC:c83e5203dad7e1bc] to the requirement that, for the purposes of the evaluation, the firm must apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios to all material currencies as determined [#TGT:e1e527ecb87d369a]. In practice, the firm should ensure its calculations and resulting disclosures reflect scenario application consistently across the set of material currencies, rather than limiting scenario application to a subset that would omit required currency exposures.
