question: What procedures must the firm set out for how the firm’s governing body will keep itself satisfied on an ongoing basis that the firm’s systems support immediate identification of accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits, including client accounts and trust accounts?
gold_answer: The firm must document and operate procedures explaining how the firm’s governing body will ensure it remains satisfied, on an ongoing basis, that the firm’s systems comply with the relevant requirements [#SRC:d11985b37b3a54b1]. In practical terms, that governance procedure must be capable of demonstrating that the firm’s systems deliver the specific outcome required: the firm must mark accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries—expressly including client accounts and trust accounts—where those accounts contain or may contain eligible deposits, in a manner that enables immediate identification of those accounts [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. Accordingly, the governing body’s oversight should focus on whether the account-marking approach is implemented across all in-scope account types, whether it covers both accounts that currently contain eligible deposits and those that may contain them, and whether the marking is sufficient to allow immediate identification. The procedure should also describe how the governing body obtains assurance (for example, through review of system operation and evidence of correct marking) and how it maintains that assurance over time, so that continued compliance with the marking requirement is demonstrable.
source_text: (d) how the firm’s governing body will ensure that they remain satisfied that its systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 ;
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: For a firm that is an international bank or a UK trading bank, how must the bank address resolution-related risks created by a global booking model—particularly where a multiple-point-of-entry strategy is relevant—given the PRA’s expectations on booking arrangements and proportional application based on the firm’s investment banking or sales and trading activity?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectations on booking arrangements apply across the population of international banks and UK trading banks, and the PRA applies those expectations proportionately to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity the firm undertakes [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]. Within that scope, a bank using a global booking model should treat the model as a potential source of resolution friction: even if it is not a direct impediment under a single point of entry approach, it can increase complexity in post-resolution group restructuring, and under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the wider group associated with global booking could be an impediment that the bank should address [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d]. In addition, because contingency plans to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion are important to orderly exit, recovery, or resolution, the PRA expects the bank’s chosen booking model to be fully taken into account in those plans [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d].
source_text: The expectations of a firm’s booking arrangements set out in this section are applicable to all international banks and UK trading banks. Paragraphs 4.24A - 4.25Z and 4.25AE are applicable to both types of bank, paragraphs 4.25AA - 4.25AD are applicable only to international banks [see para 1.1 ]. The PRA will apply these expectations in a manner that is proportionate to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity that the firm undertakes.
target_text: While a global booking model may not be considered a direct impediment under a single point of entry resolution strategy, it could add complexity to the restructuring of the group post resolution. Under a multiple-point-of-entry (MPE) strategy, the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the group associated to a global booking could be an impediment to resolution that the bank should address. 40 Similarly, where contingency plans to be able to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion are important to any orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy, the PRA expects that the particular booking model adopted by a bank will have been fully taken into account in those plans.

question: For the model inventory, what does “operating boundaries” mean, and how should it be used when you describe a model’s purpose and intended use versus its actual use?
gold_answer: When you document a model’s purpose and use in the model inventory, you must capture the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries under which model performance is expected to be acceptable [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]. “Operating boundaries” is defined as the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of a statistical model, including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. So, in the inventory, operating boundaries should be written as a specific description of the data range that underpins the model’s parameter estimation, and then used as a reference point when assessing whether the model is being applied in the same conditions it was designed for. If the model is used outside that sample data range—i.e., extrapolated beyond its operating boundaries—this should be treated as involving increased model risk, such as when macroeconomic indices are in shock or stressed economic conditions [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. That risk implication should be reflected in the purpose-and-use comparison between intended and actual use, consistent with the inventory capture requirement [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd].
source_text: c) The types of information the model inventory should capture include: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable; (ii) model assumptions and limitations. For example, risks not captured in model and limitations in the data used to calibrate the model; (iii) findings from validation. For example, indicators of whether models are functioning properly, the dates when those indicators were last updated, any outstanding remediation actions; and (iv) governance details. For example, the names of individuals responsible for validation, the dates when validation was last performed, and the frequency of future validation.
target_text: 7. Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model. While not a measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk.

question: When the PRA assesses a firm’s ICAAP stress testing within the SREP, what elements must that assessment cover regarding the firm’s projected stress outcomes and the basis for those outcomes, and how should the PRA’s review sequence address scenario-driven impacts on the firm’s capital position and any proposed mitigating actions?
gold_answer: In carrying out its assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP, the PRA’s review should first evaluate whether the firm’s projected stress results are credible and reasonable and whether the assumptions used to generate those projections are themselves credible and reasonable [#SRC:7a56cad9ade1c41e] [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]. Building on that foundation, the assessment should then focus on where the stress scenario adversely affects the firm’s capital position, specifically by reducing capital resources and increasing capital requirements, so that the PRA can identify the most material vulnerabilities revealed by the stress [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]. The PRA should also consider the nature and severity of the scenario that underpins the stress results, since the plausibility and intensity of the scenario are integral to judging the reasonableness of the projected outcomes [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]. Finally, the PRA should assess the reasonableness of any mitigating actions the firm proposes to mitigate the impact of the stress, ensuring those actions are evaluated in the context of the scenario’s severity and the quantified capital impacts [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4].
source_text: The PRA carries out an assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP. 40 For the major UK firms this is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). 41
target_text: The assessment considers the credibility and reasonableness of firms’ projected stress results and the underlying assumptions on which the stress projections are build. The assessment focusses on the areas where the stress scenario adversely impacts firms’ capital positions (ie reducing capital resources and increasing capital requirements), the nature and severity of the scenario on which the stress results are based and the reasonableness of mitigating actions firms propose to mitigate the impact of the stress.

question: When setting priorities for investment and agreeing recovery and response arrangements, how must boards and senior management use impact tolerances, and how must the firm’s regular testing be structured in severe but plausible disruption scenarios to evidence it can remain within those tolerances?
gold_answer: Boards and senior management should treat impact tolerances as the standard for prioritising investment and for shaping the firm’s recovery and response arrangements, using them to decide where resources and operational changes are most needed to support resilience and effective incident management [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. Consistent with that governance use, the firm must also test regularly its ability to remain within those impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]. Because impact tolerances assume a disruption has already occurred, the firm’s testing should be designed around operating through disruption and staying within the tolerance, rather than concentrating on controls intended to stop incidents from happening in the first place [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]. The PRA expects the firm to focus its testing on recovery and response arrangements, aligning the test objectives and scenarios with the arrangements that boards and senior management have prioritised and put in place using the impact tolerance standard [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55].
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 22 require firms to test regularly their ability to remain within impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios. Impact tolerances assume a disruption has occurred, and so testing the ability to remain within impact tolerances should not focus on preventing incidents from occurring. The PRA expects firms to focus on recovery and response arrangements.

question: What does a TWD firm need to write into its recovery plan about wind-down costs and the effect on capital and liquidity during the wind-down period, and how should the firm use its TWD capabilities to develop and carry out the recovery plan and BRP in real-life situations?
gold_answer: A TWD firm needs to make its recovery plan usable for actually carrying out the TWD option under stress, and that means combining clear plan content with practical capability. In the recovery plan, the firm should explain the TWD option so it can be implemented easily in a stress, including the playbook where relevant, and it should also set out the quantification of the costs of the wind-down and any impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources throughout the wind-down period (from executing the TWD option until trading activities are wound down). The wind-down period is described as having an active phase (exiting positions where possible without undue costs) and a passive phase (hedging remaining rump exposures where possible until expiry), and the recovery plan’s cost and resource impacts should cover that overall period [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67]. Separately, the firm should have TWD capabilities that allow it to develop and execute the TWD option in a range of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities to help it develop and execute its recovery plan and BRP [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8].
source_text: The TWD option should be explained in the TWD firm’s recovery plan, including the playbook where relevant, such that the TWD option would be easily implemented in a stress. The quantification of the costs of the wind-down, set out in more detail in Chapter 4 , and any impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources throughout the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm’s trading activities have been wound down (hereinafter referred to as the ‘wind-down period’), should also be set out in the TWD firm’s recovery plan. 14 The wind-down period can be split into the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm has exited all the positions it can exit without incurring undue costs (hereinafter referred to as the ‘active wind-down period’); and the rest of the wind-down period, during which the firm hedges the exposures of the remaining ‘rump’ positions (insofar as this is possible) until they expire (hereinafter referred to as the ‘passive wind-down period’).
target_text: TWD firms should have TWD capabilities that will enable them to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances. TWD firms should use their TWD capabilities to help them to develop and execute their recovery plan and BRP.

question: When determining the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance, how must the firm apply the cap and the personal-injury/incapacity exception in light of the PRA’s view that temporary high balance protection is assessed per depositor per event per authorised entity and is intended to apply only to natural persons (including how trusts are treated)?
gold_answer: The maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is capped at £1,400,000, except that no limit applies where the temporary high balance arises from a payment connected with personal injury or incapacity, and this must be applied subject to the stated qualification in the rule [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. In applying that maximum (or the no-limit exception), the PRA’s view is that temporary high balance protection is assessed for each depositor on a per event per authorised entity basis and is intended to apply only to natural persons rather than all eligible depositors such as companies [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. For trusts, the relevant individual is the underlying beneficiary who must be an individual, including a beneficiary absolutely entitled under a bare trust; however, trustees may make a temporary high balance claim on behalf of the trust as a whole where individual beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest, including discretionary trusts [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. Where more than one qualifying life event results in eligible deposits exceeding £85,000, a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both events and the protection limit applies separately to each event, which informs how the cap is applied across events [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef].
source_text: The PRA considers that the THB protection limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 applies to each depositor on a ‘per event per authorised entity’ basis and is intended to apply to natural persons only (ie individuals) and not all eligible depositors (eg not companies). Where the depositor is a trust, the PRA considers that it is the underlying beneficiary that is required to be an individual. This includes a beneficiary who is absolutely entitled to the deposit (under a bare trust). Trustees of a trust where individual beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest may make a THB claim on behalf of the trust as a whole. This includes where the trust involves the exercise of discretion (under a discretionary trust). If an individual or a trustee has eligible deposits in excess of £85,000 as a result of more than one of the life events set out in Depositor Protection 10.2 , a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both of those events and the limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 would apply separately to each event. For example, if an individual had a deposit of £750,000 from an inheritance and a deposit of £750,000 from a house sale, then they would be able to claim up to £750,000 in each case.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: When a large subsidiary of a UK parent institution, a UK parent financial holding company or a UK parent mixed financial holding company is preparing its required disclosures, how must it align the required article-based disclosures (including the leverage-ratio-related disclosure duty) with the requirement to disclose leverage ratio information and excessive leverage risk management, and at what level must those disclosures be made?
gold_answer: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, as well as large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country, have a duty to disclose specified information by reference to a set of Articles, and they must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673]. In parallel, Institutions have a specific obligation to disclose information regarding their leverage ratio and their management of the risk of excessive leverage, with the leverage ratio being calculated in accordance with Article 429 of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part [#TGT:01b09661643bb171]. Read together, the disclosure package for an in-scope large subsidiary must include the leverage-ratio-related information required of Institutions (including the Article 429 calculation basis and the related risk-management information) while also meeting the broader article-specified disclosure set applicable to those large subsidiaries, and the entity must ensure the disclosures are presented at the required level (individual or sub-consolidated) rather than assuming a different reporting perimeter [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:01b09661643bb171].
source_text: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country shall disclose the information specified in Articles 437 , 438 , 440 , 442 , 450 , 451 , 451a and 453 on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis.
target_text: Institutions shall disclose the following information regarding their leverage ratio as calculated in accordance with Article 429 of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part and their management of the risk of excessive leverage:

question: How must Institutions meet their public disclosure duty for information covered by Titles II and III while also ensuring that their disclosures include risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in this Title, and how should any applicable exceptions be handled?
gold_answer: Institutions must treat the disclosure of risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk as part of their broader public disclosure framework. Specifically, they are required to publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in accordance with the provisions laid down in this Title, and they must do so subject to the applicable exceptions referenced in the Source obligation [#SRC:8764079e3800c628]. Within that same disclosure regime, Institutions must also disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, expressly including the risks referred to in this Title, and ensure that these disclosures include the required elements indicated in the Target obligation [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. Practically, this means Institutions should structure their public disclosures so that risk-category-specific objectives and policies are clearly presented as part of the information set being disclosed under Titles II and III, while also applying any relevant exceptions consistently to the extent they affect what is publicly disclosed. The combined effect is a public, Title-compliant disclosure package that covers both the referenced Titles II and III information and the risk-management objectives and policies by risk category.
source_text: Institutions shall publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in accordance with the provisions laid down in this Title, subject to the exceptions referred to in Article 432 .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in this Title. These disclosures shall include:

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and must be mapped to more than one risk category, how does an institution decide whether it is long or short in the most material risk driver for each risk category, using the rule about when the transaction’s market value increases?
gold_answer: An institution must map a derivative transaction that has more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category, unless all of the transaction’s material risk drivers are in the same risk category, in which case it maps the transaction only once to that single category using the most material risk driver [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the institution maps the transaction once to each relevant risk category, and for each category it uses the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. After that, the institution determines whether its position in the primary risk driver or most material risk driver (for the given risk category) is long or short by checking how the transaction’s market value reacts when that risk driver’s value increases: market value increasing implies a long position, while market value decreasing implies a short position [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]. This means the long/short assessment is tied to the specific most material risk driver used for each mapped risk category.
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: If Institutions choose to satisfy the single-medium disclosure requirement by using a section within or appended to their financial statements or financial reports, what must they ensure about user accessibility and identifiability, and how does that choice affect the way they must disclose risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk?
gold_answer: Where Institutions elect to place the required disclosures within or appended to their financial statements or financial reports, they must ensure that the disclosure content is presented as a distinctive section that is easily identifiable to users and functions as a readily accessible source of prudential information. This approach is permitted only if it still achieves the core requirement that all required information is disclosed electronically and in a single medium or location, so users can locate the prudential disclosures without searching across multiple documents or channels. In addition, Institutions must incorporate within that same identifiable section the disclosures on risk management objectives and policies, and they must structure those disclosures by each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in the applicable Title. Accordingly, the financial-statement-based section must be organized in a way that clearly separates risk categories and presents the corresponding objectives and policies, while remaining part of the single, electronic disclosure location required for the complete set of mandated disclosures [#SRC:8422ed9edcda5caa] and meeting the obligation to disclose risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].

question: Is a BRRD undertaking barred from entering into a group financial support agreement unless the deal sets out the terms for the financial support (including consideration) in line with the referenced requirements?
gold_answer: Yes. The rule in the target text is framed as a prohibition: a BRRD undertaking must not enter into a group financial support agreement unless certain conditions are satisfied [#TGT:7bf72e89d4d4b9ff]. The source text describes a key element that must be built into how the financial support is provided—namely, it must be provided on terms, including consideration, and those terms must be in accordance with the referenced requirements [#SRC:2648535839d54757]. Putting these together, the BRRD undertaking cannot treat the agreement as acceptable unless it can point to defined support terms (not just a general intention to provide support), and those terms must cover consideration and follow the referenced framework. If the agreement does not include that kind of terms-and-consideration structure in accordance with the referenced requirements, then the undertaking has not met the conditions needed to get past the “must not enter into” restriction, and entering into the agreement would be prohibited under the target statement.

question: What does a firm have to do to check (validate) its internal credit assessment method and criteria, and what does it have to show about the results so they line up with what a CRA could have rated—without just relying on ratings?
gold_answer: A firm must have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation, and that validation must cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including the way it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether the firm does this qualitatively or quantitatively [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. The validation is also expected to ensure the internal credit assessment outcomes satisfy the relevant points referenced in the source passage, meaning the firm should be able to evidence that its outputs meet the required standards rather than being untested results [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. Separately, to demonstrate the internal assessments are comparable to a credit rating, the firm must ensure its internal credit assessment outcomes fall within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA, and it must show broad consistency and no bias within that plausible range when comparing its outcomes to CRA issue ratings at both the asset type level and the portfolio level [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA can help demonstrate broad consistency, but firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings to assess creditworthiness [#TGT:5fd5739308652721].
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: If the financial conglomerate is a third country financial conglomerate, do the rules still require a firm to keep enough capital resources at all times to make the financial conglomerate’s capital resources adequate, or are those rules switched off for that situation?
gold_answer: The requirement on its face is continuous: a firm must at all times have capital resources of the right amount and type so that the capital resources of the financial conglomerate are adequate [#TGT:bb825e3fc5dd5d17]. But the scope text adds an important boundary: the rules in the listed provisions, including Chapter 7, do not apply with respect to a third country financial conglomerate [#SRC:326d068c15dba31a]. Putting these together, you need to classify the financial conglomerate first. If it is a third country financial conglomerate, then the identified rules are stated not to apply “with respect to” that conglomerate, which means the obligations contained in those rules are not intended to operate for that third country case [#SRC:326d068c15dba31a]. If the financial conglomerate is not a third country financial conglomerate, the scope carve-out does not apply, and the firm remains subject to the ongoing obligation to maintain capital resources that make the financial conglomerate’s capital resources adequate [#TGT:bb825e3fc5dd5d17].
source_text: The rules in 3.2 , 4.2 and Chapter 7 do not apply with respect to a third country financial conglomerate .
target_text: A firm must at all times have capital resources of such an amount and type that results in the capital resources of the financial conglomerate being adequate.

question: When establishing hedging sets, what must be done to ensure they are set up in accordance with the applicable requirements, and how must Institutions structure those hedging sets by risk category within a netting set while allocating transactions to them?
gold_answer: The requirements operate together to impose both a compliance condition and an operational structuring duty. First, all hedging sets must be established in accordance with the specified framework, meaning the act of creating any hedging set is not discretionary as to method and must follow the referenced requirements [#SRC:aad180c11178b9e8]. Second, Institutions must implement that compliant establishment in a way that is granular to the netting set: they shall establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and, in addition, they shall assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a]. Read together, this means Institutions cannot treat hedging sets as a single undifferentiated bucket; they must (i) create hedging sets that meet the “in accordance with” condition, and (ii) ensure the resulting hedging-set architecture is organized per risk category within each netting set, with every transaction mapped into the appropriate hedging set. The combined obligation therefore covers both how hedging sets are established and how transactions are allocated across them.
source_text: (e) all hedging sets shall be established in accordance with Article 277a(1) ;

question: When quantifying wind-down costs for capital and liquidity projections, how must TWD firms incorporate the potential effect of market price movements on trading-position valuations, and how should those resulting RBL estimates be positioned for the PRA’s comparative procedure against Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to evidence the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb?
gold_answer: TWD firms should structure their wind-down modelling around the TWD scenario and the specific actions, arrangements, and measures they would implement in that scenario, rather than attempting to maintain capabilities to fully model a large number of scenarios given the significant uncertainty in projections [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649]. Within that focused approach, they should be able to account for the potential impact of market price movements over the wind-down period on the valuations of trading positions, producing an estimate of risk-based losses (RBLs) that reflects those valuation effects [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649]. In the PRA’s assessment process, the PRA will then compare the firm’s RBL estimates with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to assess the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb [#TGT:31786ae603de3309]. The firm should therefore present its RBL calculation and supporting explanation in a way that enables this comparison, while recognising that the PRA uses Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A only as contextual metric and does not treat that sum as an appropriate measure of RBLs [#TGT:31786ae603de3309].
source_text: These projections may be subject to significant levels of uncertainty, and it would not be proportionate for TWD firms to build and maintain capabilities to fully model a large number of scenarios. TWD firms should focus the modelling of their quantification of wind-down costs, used to determine their capital and liquidity projections, on the TWD scenario, and the actions, arrangements, and measures that the TWD firm would implement under that scenario. TWD firms should be able to account for the potential impact of market price movements throughout the wind-down period on the valuations of trading positions, known as risk-based losses (RBLs, see paragraphs 4.26 and 4.38 - 4.40 ).
target_text: The PRA will compare TWD firms’ estimates of RBLs with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A in order to assess the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb. It should be understood that the PRA does not regard the sum of Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A capital as an appropriate measure of RBLs, but rather as a metric for the purpose of providing context to understand the results of a firm’s RBL calculation as part of the PRA’s assessment.

question: When calculating compensation for a joint account, how must the share attributable to each depositor be determined and applied to the depositor-level compensation cap, and what must be done where there is no contrary provision on the split?
gold_answer: For a joint account, the share of each depositor must be treated as a separate amount for the purpose of applying depositor-level compensation limits, rather than treating the joint balance as a single undivided sum [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae]. That separate-share approach is required when calculating the depositor’s entitlement against the maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor, which is £120,000 (the “maximum compensation sum payable”) [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]. Where there is no contrary provision governing how the joint account is allocated, the joint account must be divided equally among the depositors, and the equal division must be rounded to the nearest penny, so that each depositor’s separately considered share can be compared to the £120,000 cap [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae]. In addition, the depositor-level cap is stated to be subject to the possibility that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply, so the calculation must recognize that the £120,000 maximum compensation sum payable may not be the only amount payable in those specified cases [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e].
source_text: The share of each depositor of a joint account shall be considered separately in calculating the limits provided for in 4.2 and 4.3 , except where 5.5 applies. In the absence of contrary provision, the joint account shall be divided equally among the depositors to the nearest penny.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: If a firm has an establishment in the UK and it outsources important functions or services, does it still have to take responsibility for meeting its internal governance obligations, and what does it have to do about its regulatory obligations?
gold_answer: Yes. When the firm has an establishment in the UK, the scope text indicates that responsibility for the firm’s performance of its obligations under the Internal Governance of Third Country Branches framework sits with the firm [#SRC:f36241be1dd8e22c]. That responsibility is not reduced just because work is done by someone else. Separately, the outsourcing requirement states that if a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or any relevant services and activities, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the regulatory system and must comply with the conditions that apply to outsourcing [#TGT:03c2dace9ff8e0e4]. Putting these together: having a UK establishment brings the internal governance responsibility into play, and outsourcing does not change who is accountable. The firm must therefore ensure it continues to meet its internal governance obligations and, at the same time, treat all regulatory obligations as still resting with it even where outsourced providers carry out the day-to-day activities [#SRC:f36241be1dd8e22c] [#TGT:03c2dace9ff8e0e4].

question: How must a firm ensure it can continue delivering its important business services within impact tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios, and how should boards and senior management use those impact tolerances as a standard to prioritise investment and set recovery and response arrangements for operational disruptions?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure it can deliver its important business services within its impact tolerances even in severe but plausible scenarios, and it should use mapping and testing of those services to determine whether and how it can remain within those tolerances [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950]. In parallel, impact tolerances are intended to provide a standard that boards and senior management should use to prioritise investment and to make recovery and response arrangements, so governance decisions on resilience capabilities should be anchored to the same tolerances the firm is required to meet [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. During an operational disruption, those impact tolerances may also help inform decision-making, but they should be considered alongside other information relevant to managing the incident effectively, ensuring that real-time response choices remain aligned with the firm’s ability to stay within tolerances while addressing the broader incident context [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. Taken together, the obligation to remain within tolerances and the governance use of tolerances as an investment and response standard create a single framework for preparation (mapping/testing) and execution (recovery/response) [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950] [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5].
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 17 require firms to ensure they are able to deliver their important business services within impact tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios. Mapping and testing the delivery of important business services will equip firms to establish whether and how they can remain within impact tolerances.

question: For scope purposes, when assessing whether a deposit qualifies as an eligible deposit, how should a firm align the applicability of Depositor Protection 2.2 with the applicability of this rule, and what is the common determination both sets of provisions are intended to make?
gold_answer: Both the SOURCE and the TARGET define their scope around the same compliance outcome: determining whether a deposit is an eligible deposit. Under the SOURCE, the relevant scope trigger is that the provisions in Depositor Protection 2.2 are the provisions that perform this determination, so the eligibility assessment must be made by applying those provisions when the question is whether a deposit is an eligible deposit [#SRC:c5f1de45f3052c9c]. Under the TARGET, the scope is framed in parallel terms: the provisions in this rule are likewise the provisions that determine whether a deposit is an eligible deposit, meaning the eligibility assessment must be made by applying the provisions of this rule for that same determination [#TGT:02fb0fbf6939a082]. Read together, the applicability boundary is not tied to a particular product subset or party description in either passage; instead, it is tied to the act of making the eligibility determination itself. Accordingly, a firm should treat both texts as directing that, whenever the eligibility status of a deposit is being assessed, the determination is to be made by applying the identified provisions in each instrument to reach the eligible-deposit conclusion.
source_text: The provisions in Depositor Protection 2.2 determine whether a deposit is an eligible deposit.
target_text: The provisions in this rule determine whether a deposit is an eligible deposit :

question: In addition to PRA rules, what other supervisory materials does the PRA issue, and where is the PRA’s page for its approach documents made available online?
gold_answer: The SOURCE establishes that, alongside PRA rules, the PRA also issues supervisory approach documents and identifies these as including SoPs and SSs, indicating that these materials sit in addition to the PRA’s rules-based framework [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841]. The TARGET complements this by specifying where the PRA’s approach documents are made available online, providing a direct Bank of England web address for the PRA approach documents page [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb]. Read together, the passages support a compliance conclusion that firms should look beyond PRA rules to the PRA’s supervisory approach documents (including SoPs and SSs) and that the PRA maintains an accessible online location for these approach documents via the referenced Bank of England URL. This pairing is useful for governance and regulatory change management because it links the existence and types of supervisory approach documents the PRA issues with a concrete source location where those documents can be accessed and monitored for updates [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841] [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb].
source_text: Alongside PRA rules, the PRA also issues supervisory approach documents, 1 SoPs, 2 and SSs. 3
target_text: 1. Available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2018/pra-approach-documents-2018 .

question: Where the requirements apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV on the basis that references to a key function holder are read as references to a PRA senior management function holder, who must sign the required record and any updates, and what additional firm signatory is required?
gold_answer: For a firm that is a UK ISPV, the relevant requirements apply on a modified basis: any reference to a “key function holder” is to be treated as a reference to a “PRA senior management function holder” [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c]. Applying that scope adjustment to the signing obligation means the record and each updated version must be signed by the PRA senior management function holder (standing in for the key function holder) and also by an appropriate representative of the firm [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. In practice, this creates a dual-signature requirement for UK ISPV firms: one signature from the individual occupying the PRA senior management function holder role that corresponds to the key function holder reference, and a second signature from a firm representative who is appropriate to sign on the firm’s behalf. The obligation covers both the initial record and every subsequent updated version, so the same two-party sign-off must be obtained whenever the record is revised, with the role-substitution applied consistently for UK ISPV firms [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The requirements in 5.4 and 5.6 apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV as if any reference to a key function holder were a reference to a PRA senior management function holder .
target_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .

question: If a firm is planning a material change to its booking arrangements that could change how its risk management works, what should it do about telling the PRA, and how does this connect to the requirement that the firm must be ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption of critical services?
gold_answer: If a firm plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements and those changes could impact how its risk management operates, the PRA expects the firm to inform the PRA about what it is planning [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680]. This expectation should be understood alongside the firm’s obligation to prepare for resolution so that, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]. In practical terms, the firm should treat planned booking-arrangement changes as potentially relevant not only to risk management but also to resolvability: how the firm books business can influence how risks are managed and how the firm could be resolved while maintaining critical services. So, when planning material booking changes that could affect risk management, the firm should notify the PRA and ensure its organisation of booking arrangements continues to support both effective risk management and readiness for orderly resolution with minimal disruption.
source_text: The PRA has a number of expectations concerning how international banks and UK trading banks should organise their booking arrangements in order to meet the threshold condition on the prudent conduct of business, their obligations under Fundamental Rules 3 , 5 , 6 and 8 , and under the General Organisational Requirements (GOR) relating to risk management and resolvability. The PRA also has an expectation under Fundamental Rule 7 and General Notification Requirement 2.3(1) that a firm should inform the PRA when it plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: If board members do not have to be technical experts on operational resilience, what does the PRA still expect the board to have so it can challenge senior management, and which named PRA Rulebook rule is pointed to for CRR firms?
gold_answer: Even where individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, the PRA still expects boards to make sure they have the appropriate management information, and that the board as a whole has enough knowledge, skills, and experience to challenge senior management constructively and to make informed decisions that affect operational resilience [#SRC:899315b848004882]. For CRR firms, the specific PRA Rulebook cross-reference identified is Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms) [#TGT:39817b585204e92e]. Putting these together, the practical message is that the board’s effectiveness on operational resilience should be evidenced through the management information it receives and uses, and through the board’s collective capability to question and test senior management’s approach, rather than through each director being a technical specialist. The Rule 5.2 reference provides the concrete rule label that is linked to this expectation for CRR firms [#SRC:899315b848004882] [#TGT:39817b585204e92e].
source_text: While individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, the PRA expects boards to ensure that they have the appropriate management information. Boards should also collectively possess adequate knowledge, skills, and experience to provide constructive challenge to senior management and inform decisions that have consequences for operational resilience. 26
target_text: 26. Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms), Rule 2.7 in the Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook (Solvency II firms).

question: Where the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and Threshold Conditions policy to MREL set by the Bank for interim and end-state requirements, what is a firm prohibited from doing with CET1 when demonstrating compliance with both MREL and its risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers?
gold_answer: When the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy in respect of MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, firms are expected to manage compliance on a basis that keeps the MREL requirement and the firm’s risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers conceptually distinct [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. In that context, the PRA’s prohibition is that firms should not double count CET1 to satisfy both (i) MREL and (ii) the amount of CET1 that reflects the firm’s risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1]. The PRA expects firms to meet both obligations, but the same CET1 resources should not be used to meet each simultaneously. At the same time, the PRA recognises that firms can meet MREL with CET1, but they are not required to meet MREL with CET1; this flexibility does not remove the expectation that any CET1 held to reflect buffers remains separately maintained and not counted again toward MREL [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1].
source_text: The PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy ( Chapter 2 ) and Threshold Conditions policy ( Chapter 3 ) in respect of MREL set by the Bank with respect to both interim and end-state MREL requirements.
target_text: The PRA expects firms to meet both MREL and maintain an amount of CET1 that reflects their risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. The PRA expects firms not to double count CET1 towards both MREL and the amount reflecting the risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. While firms can meet MREL with CET1, they do not have to meet it with CET1. See ‘The Bank of England’s approach to setting MREL’ 5 for details.

question: When applying updates following a transfer event, how must firms ensure ongoing adherence to Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions, and what outcome is prohibited regarding the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by the firms that are parties to the transfer event (including any relevance of a waiver or modification)?
gold_answer: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification under the relevant permissions statement; the PRA indicates this expectation can be met by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]. At the same time, when firms that are parties to a transfer event apply the specified updates, those updates must not produce an increase in the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by those firms [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6]. Read together, this means a firm cannot treat the act of “ensuring adherence” (including any recalibration via ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’) as a basis to raise the combined TMTP claimed across the transferring parties; compliance steps must be implemented in a way that preserves adherence while avoiding any aggregate uplift attributable to the updates. If a waiver or modification has been granted, the firm’s adherence obligation is qualified accordingly, but the prohibition still constrains the effect of the updates on the aggregate TMTP claimed by the transfer-event parties.
source_text: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification as set out in 3.3 of the SoP ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. The PRA expects this can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’.
